editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE Sir Robert Clayton, Lord Mayor of London.
div.p:
I Be≈øeech You Pardon my Boldne≈øs, that (Poor) I do take upon me to Interrupt your Lord≈øhip in your ≈øo Great Affairs and ≈øo Emergent Occa≈øions, as the Saving of a Sinking City and Nation, mo≈øt ju≈øtly Challengeth: Were I as Worthy as Jonathan, 'tis no le≈øs a Law writ in my Heart to do for your Lord≈øhip what he did for David, [In going to him into the Wood, to Strengthen His Hands in God,] I do here Pre≈øent to your Noble Hands as Noble and Nece≈ø≈øary a Pro≈øpect as this lower World can Afford, to wit, GOD wageing War again≈øt the DEVIL, from the Beginning of the World to the End thereof, and God all along (as is mo≈øt meet) Obtaining the VICTORY: 'Tis a plea≈øant Spectacle to behold Chri≈øt and Antichri≈øt contending for Ma≈øtery: To be an Univer≈øal HISTORIAN, (as I pre≈øume your Lord≈øhip to be) is the mo≈øt Effectual Means to make Wi≈øe for both Worlds: Hence Plato Derives Hi≈øtoria, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,] from Stopping the Flux of Humane Extravagancy, Hi≈øtory being the Witne≈øs of Time, the Light of Truth, the Life of Memory, and the Doctre≈øs of the Life of Man: As it is a continued Kalendar of mo≈øt Remarkable Actions in former Ages, ≈øo it holds forth Caution, Coun≈øel, and Comfort, to following
Generations; Quid Divinius, N√¥≈ø≈øe omnia? To be a good Hi≈øtorian, is a good way to be both Wi≈øe and Good, as Contracting a Ble≈øt Compo≈øition of all tho≈øe Perfections peru≈øed in every Age, and leaving a Transforming Influence behind them: Hi≈øtory makes Wi≈øe (1) to Secular Affairs, as it is a Knowledge of Things pa≈øt, whereby we may Judge of Things pre≈øent, and make Probable Conjectures at Things to come, ≈øeeing there is no New thing under the Sun. The ≈øelf-≈øame Scenes are Acted over and over again upon the Stage of the World, 'Tis onely the Per≈øons (that Act them) which are changed; therefore the Repre≈øenting in an Hi≈øtorical-Gla≈øs, what hath been before, is a plain Praemonition of what ≈øhall be Hereafter. 2. Wi≈øe to Salvation: The Great God hath been making a Large Comment (even in Capital Characters) upon his own Text, Gen. 4. 7. If thou do≈øt Well, ≈øhalt thou not be Accepted? and If Ill, Sin lies at thy Door: and upon that Text, I≈øa. 3.10, 11. Say to the Righteous, It is well, &c. and Woe to the wicked, and tell them ≈øo from me, ≈øaith the Lord. As the mo≈øt Wi≈øe God made Two Great Luminaries (the Sun and Moon) to give Light to the World, ≈øo hath he Ordained Two Great Lights (the Word of His Promi≈øe, and the Work of his Providence) to Enlighten his Church: as the Moon borrows Light from the Sun, wherewith ≈øhe looks upon the World with greater Splendour: ≈øo the Work of Providence (as to us) Receives Light from the Word of Promi≈øe, whereby the Church is more Illuminated. What is the Work of Providence, (upon all Ages, Places, Families, Per≈øons, &c.) but the Accompli≈øhment of the Words of Prophecy and Promi≈øe: All the Actings and Emanations of Providence, are a ≈øtanding Comment and a clear Interpretation of Ab≈øtru≈øe Prophecies, and of ∆≤nfulfill'd Promi≈øes: All Occurrences (whether Great or Small) in the World, are but the Accompli≈øhment of what God hath Prophecy'd and Promis'd in His Word: Solomon Saith, The thing that hath been, it is that which ≈øhall be, Eccle≈ø. 1. 9, 10, 'Tis True, there hath been ≈øome Extraordinary Actings of God in the World, (≈øuch as Noah's
Deluge, the promulgation of the Law, the Suns ≈øtanding ≈øtill and going back, a Virgin bearing a Son, &c.) ≈øhall never be again: Yet all Ordinary Occurencies are alike in all Ages, from a Two-fold Ground. 1. All Natural Cau≈øes and Effects continue as they were at the Beginning, Natura nihil Molitur Novi, Nature Produces no New Species of Creatures, though there may be ≈øome Accidental Defect or Superfluity in the Matter. (2.) All Humane and Voluntary Actions, Coun≈øels, and Contrivances, (having the ≈øame Principles to Produce them, and the ≈øame Objects to Draw them forth,) are the ≈øame in Sub≈øtance, as Heretofore, and therefore mu≈øt have the ≈øame Tendency: As Face An≈øwers to Face in a Gla≈øs, ≈øo doth the Heart of Man to Man, Prov. 27. 19. that is, The Coun≈øels of the Hearts, and Cour≈øes of the Lives of Men in one Age, do exactly An≈øwer unto tho≈øe of another, As it was in the Days of Noah, even ≈øo ≈øhall it be, &c. Matth. 24. 31, 39. A Man may as in a Mirror take a Shrewd Pro≈øpect of Future Events by former In≈øtances. It mu≈øt therefore be acknowledg'd a mighty Lo≈øs to Mankind to Bury the Knowledge of former things in the Grave of Unmindful Heads, or Unthankful Hearts.

My Lord, You are WISE (I would ≈øay) as an Angel of God, to Di≈øcern Dexterou≈øly, and Improve Practically, what is here (Quale, quale e≈øt,) Pre≈øented to your Lord-≈øhip, 'tis a CHURCH-HISTORY, being an Orderly Commemoration of Things pa≈øt, with the Circum≈øtances of Time and Place in Di≈øtinct De≈øcents and Di≈øtances for the better Help of Remembrance, Affection and Application: wherein your HONOUR may turn a≈øide with Mo≈øes to Behold the Bu≈øh ever Burning ‚ñ™ in the Flames of Her Adver≈øaries Fury‚ñ™ yet never Con≈øumed, Exod. 3. 3. becau≈øe the Good will of him that dwelt in the Bu≈øh, did pre≈øerve it, Deut. 33. 16. That Excellent Emblem of the Church had a Complication of Wonders, as 1. There was a Flame of Fire, el≈øe how could the Bu≈øh be Burning? 2. There was Light, el≈øe how could Mo≈øes behold it? 3. Yet no Heat, el≈øe the Bu≈øh had been Con≈øumed: It was the Angel of the Covenant, that either Qualify'd the Fire to have Light without
Heat, or Con≈øolidated the Bu≈øh, ≈øo, as not to become Combu≈øtible: 'Twas the pre≈øence of Chri≈øt that made the Fiery Furnace a Gallery of Plea≈øure to the Three Nobles of Babylon. The Church is the onely Salamander that can Live in the Fire by Vertue of that Promi≈øe, I≈øa. 43. 2. No Flame can Con≈øume her. And to Behold a Lilly in the mid≈øt of Thorns, Cant. 2. 3. Though one Churli≈øh Thorn can Scratch in pieces 10000 Tender Lillys, yet is ≈øo Marvelou≈øly Pre≈øerv'd in the mid≈øt of many and mighty Enemies, It could never be Cut up by the Sword of Per≈øecution, or Burnt down by the Fire of Martyrdom: And to Behold all along a mo≈øt Harmonious Con≈øort, and a mo≈øt Con onant Coincident Corre≈øpondency betwixt the Words of Gods Mouth, and the Works of Gods Hand. La≈øtly, Your Honour may behold how the Church hath been (and will be) Secured by a Divine Power, Promi≈øe, Prophecy, and Providence, again≈øt the Fraud and Force, Craft and Cruelty, Power and Policy of all her Foes, that notwith≈øtanding all their Stratagems and Strength, the I≈ø≈øue hath ever been the De≈øtruction of All the De≈øigners, leaving a Fatal Monument of them≈øelves to Po≈øterity behind them; yet the Church is ≈øtill pre≈øerved: That your Lord≈øhip may be

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
TIS a mo≈øt Sacred and undenyable Truth, that The Wicked Plotteth again≈øt the Righteous. [Zomem Ra≈øhang let≈øadik.] The Mouth of the Lord (the God of Truth) hath Spoken it, P≈øal. 37. 12. This is the Churches Malady in all the Ages of the World; it hath been ≈øo in times pa≈øt, (both before the Flood, and after it, under the Law, and under the Go≈øpel.) It is ≈øo in time pre≈øent, and it will be ≈øo for time to come, until time ≈øhall be no more. And 'tis as Sacred and certain a Truth, That the Lord laughs all tho≈øe Plots to nothing, ver. 13. This is the Churches Remedy. Deus Videt Ridet,
God looks and laughs, he laughs them to ≈øcorn; when he looks, that their Day is comming, even their di≈ømal Day, wherein they ≈øhall be Slain with their own Sword, v. 14, 15, 17. and Fall by their own Coun≈øel (though no Hand be upon them.) P≈øal. 5. 9, 10. Now while God laughs at the Plots of the Wicked, (both to di≈øgrace the Plotters, and to degrade their Plots,) God's People have little cau≈øe to cry; e≈øpecially con≈øidering, that their God is loath to laugh alone, and therefore he tells them of a time, wherein they ≈øhall laugh (with him) at their over-witted, and over-power'd Adver≈øaries, P≈øal. 52. 6. The Cau≈øe of the Wickeds Plotting again≈øt the Righteous in all Ages, is Twofold; The 1≈øt. is [Cau≈øa
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or) The Inward Cau≈øe; to wit, The Old Enmity which the Fall of Man brought (Judicially) betwixt the Two Seeds: Gen. 3. 15. Ever ≈øince, there hath been a boi≈øterous and bloody Di≈øpo≈øition (running all along in the Black Line of a carnal Generation,) in all the Seed of the Serpent again≈øt the Seed of the Woman: This Enmity had there its beginning; but it ≈øhall never have an ending until
the World endeth; Yea, it may be call'd an Eternal Enmity: [a parte po≈øt] though not [a parte ante,] for as the Angels and the Souls of Men had a beginning, but ≈øhall never have an end: So this Cur≈øed Enmity (which had its beginning at the Fall) will continue beyond this World, even in the World to come. As long as evil Angels and damned Souls continue in Hell, (which ≈øhall be for ever,) ≈øo long will this Enmity continue in them again≈øt the Glorious Angels and Glorify'd Saints; Thus 'tis a Bottomle≈øs, boundle≈øs, and endle≈øs Enmity. The 2d. Cau≈øe is [Cau≈øa
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] or, The Outward Cau≈øe why the Wicked Plot, &c. is, the Malignant Adver≈øary of Mankind, the Devil, ≈øo called Qua≈øi, [Do Evil.] 1≈øt. He is their Father, and they are his Children, and the Lu≈øts of their Father they will (and mu≈øt) do, Joh. 8. 44. 2dly. He is their Lord, and they are his Va≈ø≈øals, and they will (and mu≈øt) run his Errands. Yea, 3dly. He is their God, 2 Cor. 4. 4. and they are his Creatures. And as God (at the Creation of the World) did but Speak the Word, and it was done: So if the Devil (in the Conver≈øation of the
wicked) do but ≈øpeak the word, hold up his ≈øinger, his will is done; He leads them Captive at his will, 2 Tim. 2. 26. He leads them like a Dog in a ≈øtring, whether he plea≈øes, yet hangs them up at la≈øt (like Dogs) upon everla≈øting Gibbits in Hell, where they hang and howl as Dogs, yet never dye; to which if Tertullian's Character [Se≈ø≈øorem habent Diabolum.] be added, Then (4ly.) He is the Rider, and they are his A≈ø≈øes, which he Rides upon, whipping and ≈øpurring them (as Balaam did his A≈øs,) as if Riding Po≈øt to meet their own De≈øtruction: And (as ≈øaith the Proverb) They mu≈øt needs go (yea, gallop,) whom the Devil drives; e≈øpecially ≈øuch as (with the Man in the Go≈øpel) have a whole legion of Devils in them; ≈øuch wicked ones (with the Gadaren's Hoggs) do Run Violently down mo≈øt ≈øteep places, and mo≈øt de≈øperate praecipices, until (at la≈øt) They be choaked in the deep Pit of Hell, Matth. 8. 32. Now as long as there be the ≈øame Original Corruption in wicked Men (while this pre≈øent evil World la≈øts) to be drawn forth; and the ≈øame Devil (who, who≈øoever become Converts, can never become one) to
draw forth that depraved Di≈øpo≈øition, ≈øo long, there will be a wicked Plotting and practi≈øing again≈øt the Church of God in the World. Solomon ≈øaith, There is no new thing under the Sun, the thing that hath been, it is that which ≈øhall be, Eccle≈ø. 1. 9, 10. And the Apo≈øtle telleth us, As it was then, he that was Born after the Fle≈øh, per≈øecuted him that was Born after the Spirit, (as I≈øhmael did I≈øaac) even ≈øo it is now, Gal. 4. 29. Paul ≈øaith, It is ≈øo, now in my days; And we may ≈øay, It is even ≈øo now in our days: It was ≈øo then, it is ≈øo now, and it will be ≈øo for ever; ≈øo long as there be any wicked in the World, and the old Man-≈ølayer to ≈øet them on, who is that Evil Spirit which worketh (as the Artificer doth in his Shop) in the Children of Di≈øobedience, Ephe. 2. 3. We Read of the Dragons War (but as a ≈øad Cordolium) with the Woman (the Church) and her Seed; Rev. 12. And if this War were in Heaven, v. 7. how much more on Earth? v. 17. This War is manag'd and maintain'd with great Wrath, v. 12. having the A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of an Inveterate, Implacable, and Everla≈øting Enmity in all
incarnate Devils (his Auxiliaries) all acted and agitated by the Devil, who lends them his Seven Heads to Plot with, and his Ten Horns to pu≈øh with again≈øt the Church. And we Read of the Lambs War with this Dragon, (as a ≈øweet and Soveraign Cordial) even our Ble≈ø≈øed Michael and his Angels in the behalf of the Woman and her Seed, Rev. 12. 7, 8. And though the Bea≈øt (to whom the Dragon gave his power, Rev. 13. 2.) make War with the Saints, and overcome them, (during his Lea≈øe of 1260 y. allotted him) Rev. 13. 7. yet the Lamb ≈øhall overcome the Dragon and all his Auxiliaries, Rev. 17. 14. and 19. 19, 20. and 20. 10. div.head: CHAP. II.
div.p:
WHen Satan ≈øaw his fir≈øt Plot Defeated, (in as much as Man did not dye immediately, nor was made as mi≈øerable as him≈øelf) and that (in de≈øpight of the Devil) God would have his Church in the World, to make up that Breach withal in the City of God, which Lucifer and his Apo≈øtate Angels had made therein; he takes other Mea≈øures, and projects a New Plot by his Serpentine ≈øubtilty, to wit, ≈øeeing he could not Hinder the Being of the Church, he (next) Endeavours to Divide it into a True and Fal≈øe Church, that (at lea≈øt) he might thereby hinder the Well-being of it; if he could not make the Fal≈øe Church De≈øtroy the True One. This is held forth in Cain and Abel, both whom our fir≈øt Parents had Religiou≈øly Trained up in the Wor≈øhip of God by Sacrifice: they were (both) Wor≈øhippers of the True God, Cain as well as Abel, Cain did not offer his Oblation

Dei. lib. 15. cap. 1.) expre≈ø≈øeth it, Cain was the Author of the City of the World, both as he was Born fir≈øt of faln Man, and was called Cain, which ≈øignifies Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; ≈øo he made the World his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that fir≈øt City which he Built therein: yea, and as he Plots again≈øt his Brother Abel, who was cho≈øen out of the World; Born ≈øecond, and call'd Abel, i. e. Menachem ≈øaith) was conceived of the Filth and Seed that the Serpent had conveyed into Eve: However Gods Word ≈øpeaks Infallibly, That Eve was much mi≈øtaken at Cain's Birth, ≈øaying; She had got a Man from the Lord, Gen. 4. 7. or, that Famous Man, The Lord; as if ≈øhe had brought forth that promi≈øed Seed of the Woman, Gen. 3. 15. the Holy Child Je≈øus: The≈øe were Verba Spei, non Rei, her Hoping was better than her Having, for Cain was a Wicked One, and of the Wikced One, 1 Joh. 3. 10, 12. Joh. 8. 44. ≈øo was the Root of all the Reprobates in the World: but Abel was the Root of the Righteous, as Chri≈øt him≈øelf reckons him, Matth. 23. 35. This Head of the Black-Line, Cain, Clubbing wits with the Head of the Serpent, Satan, (who≈øe Head was already Broken or Brui≈øed by the Promi≈øe of Chri≈øt) E≈ø≈øays the 2d. The preparation to this 2d. Plot was, This Lucifer (that was come down from Heaven in great Rage, Rev. 12. 12.) enrages Cain, touching him with a live Coal from Hell, (as the Angel did the Prophets with one from Heaven, I≈øai. 6. 5.) and ≈øets his Heart on Fire of Hell, Jam. 3. 6. Yea, and ≈øuch was his Rage again≈øt God, that when he, not only told him, [If thou do≈øt well, ≈øhall thou not be accepted, v. 7.] but
al≈øo asks him, Where is Abel thy Brother, v. 9. Cain Angerly An≈øwers, and bids God Go look, as if God had ask'd him an Impertinent Que≈øtion, and as if he had put an Office upon him which belong'd not to him; yet he that di≈ødain'd to be his Brothers Keeper, di≈ødain'd not to be his Brothers Executioner, and the Wrath of Man, that never ≈øpeaks the Righteou≈øne≈øs of God, much le≈øs works it, Jam. 1. 20. tran≈øported Cain ≈øo far, as to tell the God of Truth a loud Lye, in his ≈øaying, [I know not where he is.] Thinking, by this frivolous Eva≈øion to blind the Eyes of the All-knowing God, as the God of this World had blinded his Eyes, and hardned his Heart too: and hereby he declared him≈øelf to be immediately de≈øcended from the Devil, who was both a Lyar and a Murderer from the beginning, Joh. 8. 44. 2dly. His Rage again≈øt Abel, for though his Rage was great again≈øt God, in≈øomuch that he could have found in his heart to have pull'd God out of Heaven, (Omne peccatum e≈øt Deicidium, all ≈øin is a kind of God-Murther) for his partiality, but God was out of his Reach, yea, and of the Devil's too that ≈øet him on work; The Borrowing power can never match the Lending power: The Creature can never be too ≈øtrong for the Creator; Howbeit Abel was within his Reach, and he will Wound the Ma≈øter in his Servant: The Rabbins ≈øay, The Devil was mad at Abel, becau≈øe Abel had ≈ølain
the ≈øame Serpent, which he had lately po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed to ≈øeduce his Mother, yet not without a wound in his Heel, before he could break its Head.

This Satan takes as an high Affront, and therefore Plots to break Abels Head with a Club, as if not enough, his Heel was brui≈øed by the Serpent: however this is certain, and beyond the Credit of a Jewi≈øh-Fable, That Cain was mad again≈øt Abel, becau≈øe his own Works were wicked, and his Brothers Righteous, 1 Joh. 3. 12. Now when he ≈øaw Abels Wor≈øhip Received and his own Rejected, and thereby lo≈øing the Ble≈ø≈øing of the Primogeniture, and the Con≈øecration of the Fir≈øt-Born; this Ripen'd him for the Devils po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, who thereupon Enters and Fills his Heart (as Act. 5. 3.) from corner to corner, then falls Cain's Countenance from a cheerful to a churli≈øh one, Index animi Vultus: The Malignity of his Mind was bewrayed by his ≈øurly and lowring Look, Heu qu√†m Di≈ø≈øicile e≈øt Animum non prodere Vultu: And being thus prepared, yea and Acted by the Devil's both craft and cruelty he falls upon plotting Abel's Death and De≈øtruction.

The 1≈øt. part of his Plot, was his Deep Di≈ø≈øimulation, Talking with Abel after a Friendly and Brother-like manner, V. 8. In the Hebrew there is an Extraordinary pau≈øe, Intimating ≈øome Amicable Di≈øcour≈øe, and in the Word [Amar] an In≈øinuating Invitation, as [Let
us go into the Field.] This the Greek, Ver≈øion & Thargum Jerus: addeth: his Rage by a Diabolical Fire lay now ≈ømothered, and he puts on as fair a Look as his Fe≈øter'd Heart would admit, not unlike that of Ab≈øolom to Amnon, who hated him with an Habit of Hatred, wherein the Venom of all Vice is ≈øteeped, yet ≈øpake he to his Brother neither Good nor Bad for Two full Years together, 2 Sam. 13. 22, 23. Yet all this time he Nouri≈øh'd a Re≈øolution for Revenge, and onely waited for a fair opportunity to his foul Fratricide; ≈øo long did Inveterate Rancour lye lurking in Ab≈øoloms Malicious Heart, and then could Invite his Brother to a Fea≈øt, V. 26, 27. which had ≈øowr Sauce in the end. Thus Cain covers with Di≈ø≈øembled Courte≈øie his De≈øign of Cruelty, and draws a fair Glove upon his foul Hand, Enticing Abel to walk hand in hand (as a Brother) with him into the Field, a convenient place for his bloody contrivance.

The 2d: part of the Plot, was, When Cain had got Abel thither, he picks a Quarrel with him, upon the occa≈øion of Abel's contradicting his Di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øaying, (as the Chaldee Paraphra≈øe adds,) That there was no Judge, nor Day of Judgement, nor World to come, nor Reward for Righteou≈øne≈øs, nor Puni≈øhment for Wickedne≈øs, &c. Thus he (as it were) Impri≈øoned tho≈øe [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] common principles of Nature in ∆≤nrighteou≈øne≈øs, Rom. 1. 18. and
Muzzl'd the Mouth of his own Con≈øcience, that he might gratifie his revengeful Spirit without controul. Hereupon he turns all his former Flattery into downright Railery and Chiding of Abel, for who≈øe ≈øake he had been newly chidden of God, v. 6. 17. This done, he falls on

The 3d. part of the Plot, by Adding to his Craft in the Two former, his Cruelty in this later; who having Decoy'd his Brother far enough from his Fathers Hou≈øe, from all ≈øight, noi≈øe, and relief, (none being nigh to Re≈øcue his Innocent Brother out of his nocent Hands) he Addre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf to knock him down on the Head with his Clubb, or Plough-≈øtaff, wherewith (as 'tis ≈øuppo≈øed) he, being an Hu≈øbandman, u≈øually walked, Inter Amplexus Interfecit: or (as the Greek-Word
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ≈øignifies, which we Read Slew,) He cut his Throat, 1 Joh. 3. 12. Now when Cain (the Devils fir≈øt Patriarch) had Killed Abel God's fir≈øt Martyr, and the Onely Hope of a Succeeding Church, Satan had ≈øeeming ≈øucce≈øs; yet this 2d. Plot is ≈øoon Bla≈øted, the Lord Laugh'd it to nothing, (though the Devil and his lmps had been Laughing together for laying Abel (their Tormenter, along on the Ground, as Revel. 11. 10.) and that by the≈øe Means: 1≈øt. Though there was no Man an Eye-Witne≈øs of the Murder, and though Cain, (to keep it the more ≈øecret, (as Jo≈øephus ≈øaith) did Bury
the Murdered Body privately, yet God (who is „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
All-Eye ≈øaw it, and heard the Cry of Abel's Blood, (which had as many Tongues, as Drops, and every Drop crying for Vengeance,) v. 10. Heb. 11. 4, and 12. 24. Murder ever Bleeds fre≈øh in the Eye of God: Surely (≈øaith he) I have ≈øeen Ye≈øterday the Blood of Naboth, &c. 2 Kin. 9. 26. And crys as fre≈øh in the Ear of God, whereby Abel, though Dead, yet ≈øpeaketh, Hebr. 11. 4. Hereupon God comes to make Inqui≈øition for this Fre≈øh-bleeding and Fre≈øh-≈øpeaking, or crying Sin, (who is not ≈øaid to make Inqui≈øition after any other ≈øin, as after Murder,) P≈øa. 9. 12. And God in his Inqui≈øition is more ≈øtrict and critical, than the Spani≈øh-Inqui≈øition, Though that be done with utmo≈øt ≈øecre≈øie and ≈øeverity: The Lord looked upon it, and Required it, 2 Chron. 24. 22. Yea, and Requited it too, Mat. 23. 35. and 22. 6, 7. Revel. 16. 6. Even upon the Heads of every [I≈øh-Damm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ,] or Man of Bloods, P≈øa. 5. 6. ≈øuch as the Damming Hectors of this Day mo≈øtly be. 2dly. God (after his ≈øevere Inque≈øt) pa≈ø≈øes a ≈øad Doom upon the Murderer, ver. 11. a more ≈øevere Sentence is not found in Sacred Scripture, Woe be to Cain, and to all that walk in his way, Jude. v. 11. The Judge of all the Earth will do right, Gen. 18. 25. Cain ≈øhall not e≈øcape Scot-free, (as he hoped,) God will appear (him≈øelf) when Man either doth not, will not, or cannot: The
Judge of Quick and Dead (him≈øelf) Arraigns Cain at the Barr, denounces Iudgement (notwith≈øtanding all his Je≈øuitical Eva≈øions as before) again≈øt him, which con≈øi≈øts of 3 Particulars. 1≈øt. He is cur≈øed in his Per≈øon, v. 11. and they whom God cur≈øeth, ≈øhall be cur≈øed, as they whom God ble≈ø≈øeth, ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed, Gen. 27. 33. Numb. 23. 20. Even the Grand Balaam of Rome (who Canonizeth Cains for Murdering Righteous Abels) cannot take off that Cur≈øe which the great God lays on: better all the Witches in the World, and all the Devils in Hell or their Elde≈øt Son the Pope, ≈øhould cur≈øe us with Bell, Book, and Candle, than this one God who≈øe Cur≈øe is Irrevocable, and can never be Rever≈øed. This Cain was the fir≈øt cur≈øed Man upon Earth, cur≈øed in his per≈øon: 2dly. He was cur≈øed in his Patrimony, v. 12. his Land he Tilled, was cur≈øed to him. The former cur≈øe, laid upon the Earth for Adam's ≈øin, in general, Gen. 3. 17. was now Increa≈øed by Cain's Murder unto him in particular: This was a particular cur≈øe upon Cain's Portion wherever he came, when he Tilled it as an Husbandman, it might Upbraid him as a Murderer in its barrenne≈øs: The Earth had been Kinder than Cain to Abel, for it had opened its Mouth to Receive his Blood from Cain's cruel hands, and ≈øo to give it an honorable Interrment, and now opens its Mouth again (in not yielding him its ≈øtrength) in a clamorous
petition for Vengeance again≈øt him: As the cur≈øed Fig-Tree lo≈øt its Vigour, and Withered, Mark 11. 21. So a Fruitful Land is made barren for the Wickedne≈øs of its owners, and Occupiers, P≈øal. 107. 34.

The 3d. Means God u≈øes to Defeat the Devils De≈øign, is, He Excommunicates Cain (Satans prime Patriark) out of the Church, who would have Excommunicated the Church out of the World, (in God's proto Martyr Abel) and that with the greater Excommunication, v. 12. [A Vagrant, and a Vagabond ≈øhalt thou be. Thus his Doom Ri≈øes higher, and falls heavier upon him, P≈øa. 59. 12. and 109. 10. Cain (the fir≈øt Apo≈øtate) went out from the Pre≈øence of the Lord, and dwelt in the Land of Nod, (which ≈øignifies Wandring, v. 14. 16. So that he was a Vagrant from the Church (from his Fathers Family and Fellow≈øhip) as well as a Vagabond upon Earth: God would come and Talk with him no more, nor Vouch≈øafe one Gracious Glance towards him, nor Accept any one Oblation from him at any time.

4thly. God ≈øets a Brand upon him, v. 15. and thereby (as it were) Burns him in the Hand, and Stigmatizes him for a Rogue. This mark was not an Horn in his Forehead, (as the Jews feign) but 'twas an Hornet in his Con≈øcience, (as Exod. 23. 28.) ≈øtinging him with horrible Conviction and Compunction for his Murder: The words of the Septuagint [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ]
≈øignifies Sighing and Trembling; as if God's Mark upon him had been (probably) a Trembling, not onely of his Hands and Head, but al≈øo of his Heart and whole Body, which made all People pitty him: Some Rabbins ≈øay, Cain was continually Dogged with Abel's Dog, but A≈ø≈øuredly he was Haunted with his own Evil Gho≈øt, which made him look with a mo≈øt gha≈øtly Countenance, having Horror in his Heart, and a very Hell in his Con≈øcience. This might make him Tremble every where, and fear every Bu≈øh (he ≈øaw) was a Bayliff to Arre≈øt him, and every Man (he met) a Devil to Torment him; So that a longer Lea≈øe of his Life was no better than a lingring Death: nay, ≈øuch a Life (under the Guilt of ≈øuch a ≈øin, and under the ≈øen≈øe of ≈øuch a Cur≈øe) was far wor≈øe then a Temporal Death: Therefore God Dooms him to Live, and not immediately to Dye, that he might be a Land-Mark of Shame, and a Living-Monument again≈øt Murder and Murderers.

5thly. His Death after a Woful Life, was Woful al≈øo, as humane Te≈øtimony Reports, for though he us'd ≈øome Carnal Anodynes to Allay the unbearable pangs of his wounded Spirit, and to drown the horrible noi≈øe of his ≈øelf-condemning Con≈øcience, he falls upon Building a City, and call'd it Enoch, that his Son might be call'd Lord Enoch of Enoch, v. 17. Yet Vengeance would not ≈øuffer him to live,
Act. 28. 4. Nor to Live out half his Days, P≈øal. 55. 23. Nor to go down to the Grave in peace, 2 Kin. 2. 5. That he Dyed an Untimely death (all Hi≈øtorians concurr) about the Year 131. the manner how is Variou≈øly Reported; ≈øome ≈øay It was by the Fall of an Hou≈øe which he was Building in his New City: Others ≈øay, He was ≈ølain by his Grand-child Lamech, who being a Blind Archer, was led to ≈øhoot him by a wicked Boy: Take it either way, and his Sin is Writ upon his Puni≈øhment, for either, as he that De≈øigned to pull down Gods Hou≈øe (the Church) ≈øo his own Hou≈øe which he was rearing up, falls down upon him and knocks him down dead on the place, as he had done his Brother Abel: or, As he Di≈ødain'd to be his Brothers Keeper, but not to be his Executioner, Lives to beget a Son, who≈øe Son became his Grand-Fathers Executioner: Thus when God makes Inqui≈øition for Blood, P≈øal. 9. 12. ≈øhall not he Search it out? P≈øal. 44. 21. Yea, he will, and wound the Hairy Scalp of ≈øuch as go on in their Iniquity, P≈øal. 68. 21.

6thly. Neither doth Divine Vengeance upon him End here in his Untimely and Violent Death, but his la≈øt Doom is the mo≈øt Woful of all Dooms; Cain mu≈øt not onely be doom'd out of the Church, and out of the World, but al≈øo he mu≈øt be Doom'd to Hell, whither all wicked Men are turned, and all the People
(though there be whole Nations of them) that forget God, (as Cain did) P≈øa. 9. 17. E≈øpecially Murderers, who are abhorred of the Lord, P≈øal. 5. 6. He that ≈øat upon the Throne hath (him≈øelf) ≈øaid it, Rev. 21. 8. Murderers ≈øhall have their Lot in the Lake that Burneth with Fire and Brim≈øtone; more e≈øpecially ≈øuch as Murder Gods Image in his Servants, who have his Image upon them in a double manner, both by Generation, Gen. 9. 6. And al≈øo by Regeneration, Eph. 4. 24. God will (of all others) avenge their Blood, Rev 6. 10. and that ≈øpeedily, Luk 18. 7. Thus Cain was a wicked One, was of the wicked One, and went to the wicked One in Hell at la≈øt.

But the la≈øt Means whereby God Defeated the Devil's 2d. Plot, was, In rai≈øing up a Seth to Stand up in Abel's Stead, according to the Signification of his Name Seth, Hebr. Po≈øuit placed in his Brothers place for Upholding the Church; Sic ∆≤no avul≈øo non Deficit Alter Aureus: Though one Branch (Abel) was lop'd off from the Tree of Mankind, (Adam) yet another Springs up (and that a Golden One) in his Stead; And out of the A≈øhes of the Dying Phoenix another Phoenix Ari≈øeth to Continue its Kind in the World. Thus Seth or Sheth ≈øignifies, not onely Po≈øuit, but Repo≈øuit, layd up, as his Godly Mother believingly Acknowledged, That the Church was layd up in him, and that he was the Foundation of it, a
Type of Chri≈øt, I≈øa. 28. 16. 1 Cor. 3. 11. out of whom Chri≈øt Sprung, Luk. 3. la≈øt. Gen. 4. 25. and, though Adam had many other Sons, Gen. 5. 4. yet none are Named, ≈øavely onely Seth, as being the only Profe≈ø≈øor of the True Religion, and Foundation of the Church.

Now when the Devil and his Agents had got Abel out of the Way and World, and ≈øaw Adam for an 130 Y. without an other in his ≈øtead, Gen. 5. 3. Oh what Rejoycing was there, and ≈øending of Gifts among≈øt them, as Rev. 11. 10. But God Cut their Coxcombs, and Confuted their Confidences in Rai≈øing up Seth; by who≈øe Means, with God's Ble≈ø≈øing, the Devil lo≈øt and the Church won Ground, for then ('tis ≈øaid) Men began to call upon the Name of the Lord, Gen. 4. 26. That is, Publickly and in Solemn A≈ø≈øemblies, making an Open Profe≈ø≈øion, which hitherto had been but Privately done.

argument.p: The Third Plot again≈øt the Church, in SETH, Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. III.
div.p: WHen Satan ≈øaw his 2d. Plot Defeated, and Laugh'd to Nothing by the Lord, that Seth mu≈øt Live and have many Children, (though Abel was Dead, and that Childle≈øs) Gen. 5. 7. Numb. 24. 17. And the Church not onely Maintained but Advanced by them. This Re≈øtle≈øs Adver≈øary Projects a 3d. Plot: that is, To Corrupt the White Line, (the Po≈øterity of Seth,) and to make them as Black as tho≈øe of the black Line, the Cur≈øed brood of Cain.

That the latter Line was very Obnoxious and Injurious to the former all along, may ea≈øily be believed, though the Scripture doth not expre≈øs it: even until they were all ≈øwept away with the Flood, Job 22. 16, 17. However this is Expre≈øt, That the Devils de≈øign was now to Debauch tho≈øe bold Profe≈ø≈øors; (who
had ≈øo openly oppo≈øed his Kingdom) and this he promotes and pur≈øues by ≈øetting the Fair Faces of the Daughters of Men (Cain's Brood) before the Eyes of the Sons of God, the off-≈øpring of Seth, Gen. 6. 2. This, by the Tempters In≈øtigation drawing out Mans Corruption, Corrupted the very Church it ≈øelf: The Sons of God, (Deut. 14. 1.) or Members of the Church, looks, loves, and Lu≈øts after the Daughters of Men, that were out of the Church, Their Eyes became Burning-Gla≈ø≈øes to ≈øe ‚Ä¢ their Hearts on Fire, even Loop-holes of Lu≈øt, and Windows of all Wickedne≈øs, the Lu≈øt of the Eyes u≈øher'd in the Lu≈øt of the Fle≈øh and the Pride of Life, 1 Joh. 2. 16. Profe≈ø≈øors then began to be pro≈øligate with the Prophane, and made Prophane Marriages with them, as prophane E≈øau did, Gen. 26. 34, 35. and 28. 8, 9. contrary to God's Law, Deut. 7. 3, 4. They took them Wives, of all which they cho≈øe: that is, Such as their wanton Eyes and Wild Affections liked and loved, without either Gods Licen≈øe, or their Godly Parents leave: [C√π ‚Ä¢ mult√πm Caepi≈ø≈øent Generare, Mult√πm Caepi≈ø≈øen ‚Ä¢ Degenerare.] When the Two Seeds mingled multiply'd, and began to Generate much, they began to Degenerate much: Their Marrying by the Eye, more than by the Ear, (thinking a fair Face enough, though covering never ≈øo foul a Soul, without either Holy Grace, or an Hone≈øt-Race) made them as Carnal as the
Off-≈øpring of Cain: Hence ≈øprang the Gyants call'd Nephilims, that is, Faln Ones, (as the Hebrew Word ≈øignifies) for they were faln from God, as they had faln on Men, and made Men (by force and fear) to fall before them: They fall into Lamechs ≈øin of Poligamy, and mu≈øt have more Wives than one; [Item pollices Quot & Quas Volebant,] and as many Whores as they plea≈øed: Hence all the World was over≈øpread with Cruelty and Corruption, even a World of ungodly Men, 2 Pet. 2. 5. Hereupon God ≈øaith, Gen. 6. 3. I'le Con≈øult no more with my Mercy for ≈øparing them, I am Re≈øolved with my Ju≈øtice to Ruine them: Satan had Con≈øulted to De≈øtroy, (and his Con≈øult had an Happy (or rather Unhappy) Hit here.) 'Tis ≈øad when God will not (at ≈øuch a time) Con≈øult to Deliver:

The World was now become ≈øo Fowl with Sin, that there was no Remedy but to Wa≈øh it clean with a Flood, the whole Earth (plainly) ≈øtank before God, v. 11, 12. and he Sweetens it with a dow≈øing Deluge: This Re≈øolve to Ruine the World, (to wit) both the Seeds, of Seth, as well as of Cain) mu≈øt needs make the Devil Laugh to ≈øee his De≈øign ≈øo ≈øeemingly ≈øucce≈øsful; notwith≈øtanding all this, The Lord laughs this Project to nothing: God ≈øtill con≈øults to Save, as well as to De≈øtroy; Though the World ≈øhall be Drown'd, yet the Church
≈øhall not be ≈øo, according to the Devils De≈øign: for unto Noah God graciou≈øly gives a Promi≈øe of Pre≈øervation, and the Platform of an Ark, wherein he and his ≈øhould be Pre≈øerved, Gen. 6. 8, 14. Yea, and for the Churches future Su≈øtenance and Accomodation, Two of every ≈øort of Creatures ≈øhall be pre≈øerved al≈øo, Gen. 6. 20. And ah how Sequacious were they all to God their Centurion, they All come at his Call; and even Bea≈øts of Prey were ≈øo cicurated and Tamed for this Time, that they all Liv'd together and Dyeted together, (the Lyon with the Lamb, I≈øa. 11. 6.) without any di≈ø≈øention: Yea, the Antipathy and Enmity 'twixt the Serpent and the Woman, was here Re≈øtrained: By Faith Noah prepares the Ark, Heb. 11. 7. and every ≈øtroke upon it was a Real Sermon to Fore-warn the Old World, that they flee from the Wrath to come: And ≈øo this Preacher of Righteou≈øne≈øs Preached without Preaching; In the mid≈øt of Wrath, (re≈øolv'd on) God remembred Mercy, Habb. 3. 2. Tho≈øe Corrupters of the Earth, and of their Ways had 120 Y. given them, wherein to be Reclaim'd by this Preacher of Right: but they had the Space (not the Grace) of Repentance, and they Jeered where they ≈øhould have Feared; looking upon Noah's Work (of Preparing an Ark) onely as a Work of Dotage: as if he had Dreamed, not ≈øo much of a Dry Summer, as of a Wet Winter. This long-Suffering of God
is Admir'd and Ador'd, 1 Pet. 3. 18, 19, 20. All the Devils Va≈ø≈øals were Drown'd, (Yea, and Burn'd too,) (So Deep is the Stain of Sin, it Requires Fire as well as Water to fetch it out.) For they are call'd, The Spirits, once in Plea≈øure, now in Pri≈øon, and in pain of Everla≈øting Burnings; but Noah, Gods Servant, was Saved, who in the Spirit of Chri≈øt ≈øtrove long with them for their Salvation, to whom he was but a little Beholden for his own, in this Re≈øpect e≈øpecially. The Door into his Ark mu≈øt be in the ≈øide of the lowe≈øt Story, and ≈øo it was under Water a whole Year, all the time of the Flood; and it mu≈øt be a prodigiou≈øly great Door for ≈øo va≈øt and Bulky a Body as an Elephant to enter; Noah within cannot ≈øhut it, 'tis too heavy for him: This Jeering Generation without would not; they ought him no ≈øuch Service. Now rather than the Church ≈øhould be drown'd, either by an Open, or a not well-≈øhut Door, the mo≈øt High God ≈øtoops to that low Office of Shutting the Door after Noah: That which God does, is well done, therefore it Leaked not for ≈øo long a time; and he that Vouch≈øaf'd to be Noah's Turnkey, conde≈øcends to be his Pilot too for a long and dangerous Voyage, whereby the Ship (or Church) Swam ≈øafe to ≈øhore: the Ark arrives at Arrarat its place of Re≈øt, Gen. 7. 16. and 8. 4.

argument.p: The Fourth Plot again≈øt the Church, in AEGYPT: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. IIII.
div.p: NO ≈øooner was the Church (in Noah) ≈øafely Landed, and God had Smelt a ≈øweet Savour (in≈øtead of the ≈øtench of the Old World) from Noah's Sacrifice, Gen. 8. 11. but Satan hath a 4th. Plot to Promote and Pur≈øue: God will not War with a Weaponle≈øs Devil, but out of his Un≈øearchable Wi≈ødom ever allows him Suitable In≈øtruments to work withal in the World for the Glory of his own Grace: The Enmity betwixt the Two Seeds never dyes (as before) ≈øo long as the World Lives, and Cain will be Murdering Abel (by Propagation) to the end of the World: Yea, and the Older he grows, the more Savage and Bloody will he be; The la≈øt Bite of the Bea≈øt will be the mo≈øt deadly Bite.

As the Serpent had crept into Paradi≈øe to Plot again≈øt our fir≈øt Parents, the Fir≈øt Foundation of the Church, ≈øo Satan creeps into the Ark to Plot again≈øt the Super≈øtructure thereof:
He wants not his (Cham) even in the Ark, (a Type of the Church) a fit In≈øtrument for him to Work with. 'Tis thought this Cham had concealed his wickedne≈øs from Men, (which he could not from God,) and ≈øoon after Degenerated: However this bad Son had a Temporal Favour for the ≈øake of his good Father, which he badly Requited afterwards: This Cur≈øed Cham or Ham the Devil makes U≈øe of. 1≈øt. In his Per≈øon. 2dly. In his Po≈øterity again≈øt the Church of God. 1≈øt. In his Per≈øon: The Occa≈øion was this. As Satan had made Adam Tran≈øgre≈øs in Eating; ≈øo he made Noah to Tran≈øgre≈øs in Drinking, Gen. 9. 21. He that had E≈øcaped the Drowning of the World by Water, (becau≈øe Ju≈øt and ∆≤pright) was now (perhaps not knowing the ≈øtrength of the Grape) him≈øelf Drown'd in Wine, and was Shamefully ∆≤ncovered. Though this Act was but once, (he was Ebrius, not Ebrio≈øus, Drunk, not a Drunkard, Denominatio non ≈øit a particulari,) yet this wicked Cham ≈øaw it both with Delight to him≈øelf, and with Deri≈øion to his Father: and therefore Noah (for who≈øe ≈øake he had been Saved in the Ark) did Doom him accur≈øed, and his other Two Sons he Ble≈ø≈øed. 2dly. In his Po≈øterity. The Aegyptians (from whom the Church ≈øuffered hard things in their Hou≈øe of Bondage) are frequently call'd the Children of Ham, and Aegypt the Land of Ham, P≈øal. 78. 51.
and 105. 23, 27. and 106. 22. 'Tis True, there be ≈øome Hundreds of Years betwixt tho≈øe Two Actions (of Hams Per≈øon, and of his Po≈øterity) again≈øt the Church, which ≈øome may judge over-large a Leap, as if the Devil had been Idle all that Inter≈øpace of Time: No doubt but it may be ≈øafely ≈øaid, There is ≈øome time wherein God Chains up the Devil, as Rev. 20. 2. And wherein the Church hath her lucid Intervals, as Act. 9. 31. Yea, and this may be ≈øaid al≈øo, That all tho≈øe Games the Devil play'd, and all the Plots he Plotted betwixt the≈øe Two, were the lower Games, the le≈ø≈øer Plots of a Daring Devil: compared with this of the Church, and (of I≈øraels) being in Aegypts Bondage. No doubt, but the Devil was gratifi'd in the Building of the Tower of Babel, whereby the Holy Tongue was lo≈øt to all the World, (≈øave to One Family) and ≈øo the Doctrine of Salvation, which was Preached in that Tongue onely. This began Satans Kingdom in Heatheni≈øm through the Confu≈øion of Tongues at Babel, which was Ble≈ø≈øedly Recover'd by the Gift of Tongues at Sion, Act. 2. 4. 13. The Devil was al≈øo well-plea≈øed to have Lots Righteous Soul vexed with the Wicked Sodomites, To have I≈øaac (that Heir of the Promi≈øe) Scoffed at by I≈øhmael, Yea, Per≈øecuted al≈øo by him, Gal. 4. 29. To have likewi≈øe Prophane E≈øau ≈øo Bloodily bent again≈øt plain Jacob; To have Godly Jo≈øeph Abu≈øed both by

Oh how would Satan have Rejoyced to ≈øee Lot and his Family Burn'd in Sodom, I≈øaac Sacrific'd by his own Father Abraham, Jacob Murdered by his own Brother E≈øau, (as Abel had been by Cain at his In≈øtigation,) Yea, and Jo≈øeph Peri≈øhed in the Pit (his) Brethren ca≈øt him into: or in the Pri≈øon where his wicked Mi≈øtris Lodged him. Yet God baffled the Devil (who will Play at ≈ømall Games rather than ≈øit Idle) in all the≈øe Plots. But now when the 70 Souls (that went down into Aegypt, that Land of Ham) were Increa≈øed to a great People, ≈øo as to fill the Countrey of Go≈øhen, Exod. 1. 7. this Enraged him, ≈øo that he puts out his utmo≈øt Power and Policy to Suppre≈øs them. In the fir≈øt Age before the Flood, the Church of God was Shut up ≈øome time in One Per≈øon, as in Adam, Abel, Seth, Enoch, &c. And though Adam Falls, Abel is Slain, Seth Dyes, and Enoch is Tran≈ølated, &c. Yea, and the Devil doth his wor≈øt to Extirpate it out of the World, (as above;) yet the Great God hath ≈øo Secur'd his Church, (both by) Promi≈øe and Providence, that his Mount Sion can never be Removed: In≈øomuch that in the 2d. Age after the Flood, the Devil Lo≈øes, and the Church Wins Ground, and Spreads her ≈øelf from the Narrow Compa≈øs of Per≈øons, to Families, as in Noahs, Abrahams, Lots, and the Patriarchs Families: and yet more, when the Time of the
Promi≈øe drew nigh, Act. 7. 17. Through the Special Ble≈ø≈øing of God, the Church Spreads forth her Tents, (as ≈øhe is bidden) I≈øa. 54. 2, 3.) from the Narrow Compa≈øs of Families, and became a Nation Great Mighty and Populous, Deut. 26. 5. and all this, out of One, as Good as Dead, Hebr. 11. 12. Satan meddles not with his Match, when he Meddles with God, who of very Stones can Rai≈øe up Children unto Abraham, Matth. 3. 9. To behold the Church Increa≈øe as Stars in the Heaven, and as Sands on the Sea-≈øhore, This makes the Devil more mad then ever; So he falls upon his 4th. grand Plot, to Cutt her ≈øhort by the Children of Ham the Father of Mitzraim, (which is the Hebrew Word for Aegypt) Gen. 10. 6.

The 1≈øt. part of his Plot, was to make God their Enemy by their Sinning fowly again≈øt him. In Order hereunto, he Tempts them to Commit Idolatry, (a God-provoking Sin,) Jo≈øh. 24. 14. Ezek. 20. 8. and 23. 3, 8.
(2.) To forego Circumci≈øion, (the Covenant of their God) which was the Reproach of Aegypt. Jo≈øh. 5. 9.

3. To joyn in Marriage with the Egyptians, Levit. 24. 20. and Exod. 12. 38. Hereby the Sun (of Religion) goes down upon them, as God told Abraham, Gen. 15. 12. Then God was Angry, and he Turn'd the Hearts of the Children of Ham to hate his own (God-provoking) People, P≈øal. 105. 25. as after the Death of
Methu≈øalem. (which in Hebrew ≈øignifies, He Dyeth, and the Dart commeth.) The Deluge came; ≈øo after the death of the Godly Patriarks their Bondage began; They were ca≈øt into a Furnace of Iron, Deut. 4. 20. to ≈øee them there mu≈øt needs be the Devils Delight, who≈øe De≈øign Undoubtedly was to Burn up the Church as Dro≈øs therein; but Gods De≈øign (which is always to countermine his Mines, and to counterplot his Plots) was, when he had Tryed them, to bring them out as Gold, Job 23. 10. as he did his Servant Job from Satans Furnace of Affliction. The 2d. part of his Plot, was, To ≈øtir up a new King that knew not Jo≈øeph, Exod. 1. 8. Well knowing, that ≈øuch Kings as know not Jo≈øeph or Je≈øus (our Brother) are his ≈øitte≈øt Tools for Oppre≈ø≈øing the Church: This King (the 8th. from Ham, and Suppo≈øed to be Bu≈øiris, a Savage Tyrant in Heathen Hi≈øtory) was the fir≈øt that Oppre≈ø≈øed I≈ørael, whom his Predece≈ø≈øors had Entertained as Gue≈øts, and Enjoyed as Friends and Benefactors: He (I ≈øay) deals both Craftily and Cruelly with them, and (both) to Prevent their further Increa≈øe, (which he ≈øaw, v. 7.) Exod. 1. 10, 11. Ach. 7. 19. P≈øa. 105. 25. and all this was to prove God a Lyar in his Promi≈øe to Jacob, Gen. 46. 3. 4. Yet his „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
Sept. & „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Gre. Dealing Subtilly, his Setting Severe Task-Ma≈øters over them, as making them to make Brick, Yea, ≈øuch a Tale and no Straw given:
All this would not do, for God Catches this Fox in his own Net of Craft and Cruelty, 1 Cor. 3, 19. and the more the Church was Mole≈øted, the more they Multiplyed. 'Tis true, This Rigour and Fiercene≈øs (from Pherec the Hebr. Word) in Impo≈øing Intollerable hard Labour upon them, was a probable Plot (in the Ordinary Cour≈øe of Nature) to Prohibit Procreation of Children; yet this King was, as every Oppre≈ø≈øor is, a Fool, Prov. 28. 16. For, be≈øides 'tis u≈øually ≈øeen, That Labouring Men have the mo≈øt and the Lu≈øtie≈øt Children. Here was an Extraordinary Path of Providence to over-rule this Project: which David Celebrates, [God Increa≈øed his People greatly, and made them ≈øtronger than their Enemies,] P≈øa. 105.24. This Camomile, the more it is troden, the fa≈øter it groweth: This Walnut-Tree, the more it is beaten, the more it bears. This Grieved their Grievers, Exod. 1. 12. So the Egyptians grieving at I≈øraels Growth, it became both their Crime and their Cur≈øe: When this De≈øign was Defeated, this Dragon (lying in the mid≈øt of the Waters, Ezek. 29. 3.) falls upon his 2d. Plot, to De≈øtroy all the Males of I≈ørael as ≈øoon as Born, not unlike the great Red Dragon who ≈øtood ready to Devour the Man-Child as ≈øoon as the Woman (the Church) had brought it forth, Rev. 12. 3. 4. This Pharaoh Treads in that Fiends ≈øteps, and Commands the Mid-Wives to Strangle (with a privy-Pinch) All the Born
Males: Hoping that the Lyons (or Dragons) Skin might Patch up the Fox that had fail'd in worrying up I≈øruel: But God Baffll'd this Plot too, for Shiphrah and Puah (the 2 Principal Mid-Wives) Feared God, and dur≈øt not Obey the Kings Inhumane and Unnatural Command, v. 17. That which is Inferior and Subordinate, may not Controul and Contradict that which is Superior. Thus Peter Explains his two Sociable Duties, [Fear God, Honour the King, 1 Pet. 2. 17. Compar'd with Act. 5. 29. and 4. 19. Here the Mid-Wives ≈øtick, (they cannot do the Devils Drudgery,) and here the Plot ≈øticks. Pharaoh Frowns upon them for this, but God Smiles on them, and Ble≈ø≈øes them, v. 18. 19, 20, 21. They would not pull down Gods Hou≈øe, (his Church) and God Builds up theirs. Pharaoh (thus di≈øappointed) falls on
‚Ä¢ is 4th. Plot, in Publi≈øhing a Bloody Edict to all his People (among whom ≈øome Savage Slaughter-Men he might probably not mi≈øs, and po≈ø≈øibly not without a Penalty to Neglecters,) To Drown tho≈øe Males openly which the Mid-Wives would not Strangle Privately, v. 22. Notwith≈øtanding this Edict, and the ≈øtrict Execution of it, Exod. 2. 3. Mo≈øes is Pre≈øerved by Pharaohs Daughter, who becomes the Ruine of Pharaohs Kingdom: Thus no Coun≈øel, nor Might, nor Wi≈ødom [neither Craft nor Cruelty] can prevail again≈øt the Lord, Prov. 21.30. This (Miraculou≈øly Pre≈øerved) Mo≈øes brings
10 Plagues on Egypt; The 1st. whereof was, The Waters wherein the Childrens Blood had been ≈øhed, were turned into Blood. And in the la≈øt were Slain all Egypts fir≈øt-Born, for their ≈ølaying I≈ørael, Gods fir≈øt-Born, Exod. 4, 22. Then did I≈ørael go out of the Furnace, being loaded with Spoils, and Egypt was glad that they were gone, though gone with their Jewels, P≈øal. 105. 36, 37, 38. Exod. 12. 33, 35, 36. Hath the Devil now done, and his In≈øtrument Pharaoh? Oh no! he hath yet another (his 5th. and la≈øt Plot,) which endeth (as all other Plots again≈øt the Church do) in his own De≈øtruction.

I≈ørael Marches 3 Days directly to Horeb, (as they had Reque≈øted, Exod. 3. 18. and 5.3.) then turning towards the Red-Sea, Pharaoh's Spys gave Intelligence, That they were Run away, and would not Return, and that they were Intangl'd in the Mountains, Exod. 14. 3. This hardens his Heart, (at which Gods Mighty Hammer had given 10 Mighty Stroaks in the 10 Plagues, yet could find no Entrance) and Re≈øolves to pur≈øue them; Yea, and his People al≈øo, (who Repented of their Well-doing, but not of their Ill) ≈øaying, Why have we let them go, v. 5. all pur≈øues, and overtakes to Recover their Jewels, and to bring them back to Bondage, thinking they had caught them in a Pound, they had no way to e≈øcape, unle≈øs they could Climb up to Heaven, which becau≈øe they could not do, Heaven comes down to them,

The Aegyptians follow them into the Sea, the Angel of Gods Pre≈øence (who had led them thither) remov'd from the Van to the Rear, to be betwixt them and their Enemies, they who had drowned I≈øraels fir≈øt-Born were all drown'd; but I≈ørael (the Church) pa≈ø≈øes over dry-≈øhod, and when ≈øafely Landed, Sang that Song of Prai≈øe to the God of I≈ørael, Exod. 15. P≈øal. 77. 18. and 18. 11.) for this great Deliverance.

argument.p: The Fifth Plot again≈øt the Church, in the Wilderne≈øs: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. V.
div.p:
NO ≈øooner was I≈ørael got ≈øafe out of the Red-Sea, and into the Barren Wilderne≈øs, but pre≈øently the Devil Projects a 5th. Plot, and plays a New-Game again≈øt the Church in the Wilderne≈øs, (≈øo called) Act. 7. 38.) In not onely making the Multitude
to murmur again≈øt Mo≈øes no le≈øs than four times about their Meat, (in the Cau≈øe and Quarrel of the Belly, as the Wilderne≈øs wanted provi≈øion, ≈øo they wanted patience to keep peace with their governors) But al≈øo in ≈øtirring up Amalek (E≈øau's Grand-Child, Gen. 36. 15, 16. and the Heir of his Hatred again≈øt I≈ørael, for beguiling him of his Ble≈ø≈øing as well as Birth-right) to War again≈øt him, Exod. 17.8. The≈øe Amalekites being a Warlike People, and now fearing that the Ble≈ø≈øing (conferr'd upon Jacob by I≈øaac) would be confirm'd, and [not having the fear of God before their Eyes, Deut. 25. 18.] This Seed of the Serpent Way-lays the Seed of the Woman in their pa≈ø≈øage to the Land of Promi≈øe, which was the Ble≈ø≈øing promi≈øed: Amalek meets them by the way, not with Broad and Water, as he ≈øhould have done to his afflicted Kindred, Obad. v. 10. 11, 12, 13. but with Fire and Sword, and cuts off the hindmo≈øt of them, Deut. 25. 18. Yea, and he exercis'd the Devils Craft as well as his Cruelty, in ≈ømiting all that were faint and feeble, that came behind the Ho≈øt, not unlike the Serpent (that Acted him) in his brui≈øing the Heel of I≈ørael. This (Jo≈øephus ≈øaith) was done by common con≈øent and Council of all the Nations adjacent in their Emba≈ø≈øadours, pitching Unanimou≈øly upon this People of Amalek, (as being of the mo≈øt Martial and Military Spirit and Courage) to cut off I≈ørael,
who≈øe Renown now had ≈øo exceedingly Alarum'd them. I≈ørael (or the Church in the Wilderne≈øs) was at this time under great Di≈øadvantages, (neither expecting any Acts of Ho≈øtility, nor being provided of due Arms and Ammunition) was much di≈ømayed at the danger of being A≈ø≈øaulted by a pui≈ø≈øant and well-armed Adver≈øary. Now the grand Plotter (Satan) had a fair Pro≈øpect of his 5th. Plot as to its ≈øucce≈øs, but ≈øtill the mi≈øchief of it was, he Reckon'd without his Ho≈øt, even the Lord of Ho≈øts, (that Man of War, Exod. 15. 3.) who giveth Victory (not as the Devil, but) as him≈øelf plea≈øeth: For though the Lord permitteth Amalek to oppo≈øe I≈ørael, for the Cha≈øtizement of their Murmurings, yet had he other De≈øigns then onely to Cha≈øtize his Church whom he had allur'd into the Wilderne≈øs; He mu≈øt al≈øo Speak Comfortably to her Heart, Ho≈ø. 2. 14. Amalek mu≈øt Fall (and therein the Devils Project) before the People of his Promi≈øe, and they mu≈øt not onely be Encouraged by their Victory over the Amalekites, (as they had been with that over the Aegyptians) but al≈øo Enriched with their Spoils, and Furni≈øhed with their Arms and Ammunition. God hath (in his De≈øign) not onely the want of Innocency in his People to Cha≈øtize with Rods, but al≈øo the Guilt of In≈øolency in his Enemies to Scourge with Scorpions.

Amalek (indeed) comes forth to meet I≈ørael, but
it was to meet his own ruine, and to fetch in his own de≈øtruction, which Mo≈øes [Precando] by Praying, and Jo≈øhua [Praeliando] by Fighting brought upon him: Mo≈øes in the Mount lifts up the Rod to God, as a Standard again≈øt Amalek; and Jo≈øhua in the Valley Engages them: and Mo≈øes Prayers gave mo≈øt-effectual Pu≈øhes as well as Jo≈øhua's Pikes again≈øt the Enemy. Mo≈øes Orat & Vincit, Ce≈ø≈øat & Vincitur, v. 12. While Mo≈øes Devotion goes down, Amaleks Courage gets up and prevaileth; but when it goes up and keeps up, being ≈øu≈øtained upon Chri≈øt, the Stone of I≈ørael, then Amalek is di≈øcomfitted, v. 13. And being the fir≈øt Nation that Warr'd again≈øt the Church after her deliverance from Aegypt, Gods Hand is upon his Throne, Swearing, That he will have a perpetual War with Amalek, and wipe out the Remembrance of them from under Heaven, v. 14, 16. Amaleks Hand had been lifted up again≈øt Gods Throne, (his Church, ≈øo call'd, Jerem. 14. 21. Now Gods Hand is lifted up upon his own Throne, in taking this Solemn Oath, That he would wage War again≈øt Amalek for ever: This pre≈øent Di≈øcom≈øiture was but a [praelibamen] or Pledge of this perpetual War. As a la≈øting Monument of Gods great Mercy to I≈ørael in this fir≈øt Victory. Mo≈øes Builds an Altar, and calls it [Jehovah Ni≈ø≈øi,] that is, The Lord is my Banner, under who≈øe Standard he had got the Victory: And as a la≈øting Memorial
of Gods great Wrath again≈øt Amalek in this fir≈øt Oppo≈øition, Mo≈øes mu≈øt Record this of them, (either in the Book of the Wars of the Lord, Numb. 21. 14. which is latent, or in the Pentatuch which he was then Writing, and now Extant,) That they ≈øhould utterly be de≈øtroyed. This Saul ≈øhould have done, 1 Sam. 15.7. &c. de≈øtroying onely ≈øome, David de≈øtroyed more, 2 Sam. 8. 12. Such as e≈øcaped tho≈øe De≈øtructions, were de≈øtroyed by the Simeonites in Hezekiah's time, 1 Chron. 4. 41, 42, 43. La≈øtly, Haman and his Ten Sons were ≈ølips of this cur≈øed Stock, and Hanging was their end, and the end of that Race of Rebels (being the la≈øt that we read of) to be Rooted out. Oh how dangerous it is to Anger the Antient of Days his Forbearance (for many Hundred Years) is no Forgivene≈øs: 'Twas 400 Y. after when God gave Command to de≈øtroy them utterly, 1 Sam. 15. 2. and long after that, God made a War again≈øt them, and at la≈øt did Root them out, [Root and Branch] thus Amalek, Hebrew ≈øignifying [Populus Ling ‚Ä¢ us] a Licking People, that had licked up the Hindmo≈øt of I≈ørael, the Wrath of God licked them all up as Fire doth Stubble, who can ≈øtand before Everla≈øting burnings, I≈øa. 33. 14. The Church's Prote≈øta ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
is Con≈øuming fire to them, Hebr. 12. la≈øt, who not onely Laughs but Burns, not onely their Plots but their Per≈øons, to nothing. A Man had better Anger all the Witches in the World,
Yea, all the Devils in Hell; as Anger this One Jealous God, the Heat of who≈øe Wrath la≈øts longer, and Burns deeper than the Coals of Juniper, P≈øal. 120. 4. His Judgements are ≈øevere and durable, never Rots in the Sky: 'Twas this Divine Wrath that waged War again≈øt Amalek from one Generation to another, until it came at la≈øt to an utter Extirpation; Haman (the Agagite) of the Blood-Royal of Amalek, de≈øcending from Agag their King whom Saul ≈øpared) is Hanged, no more of that Rebellious Race (that Warr'd again≈øt I≈ørael without Cau≈øe or Provocation) do we Read of, the Wicked are forgotten, Eccle≈ø. 8. 10. Yea, the Devil (that ≈øet them on work) is Chain'd and Defeated: The Church (by her Champions help) abides for ever.

argument.p: The Sixth Plot again≈øt the Church, in the Wilderne≈øs: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. VI.
div.p:
'TIs ≈øaid, Luk. 4. 13. That Satan Departed from Chri≈øt onely for a Sea≈øon; no more doth he depart from his Church, he will have his Returns to do her all
the ill turns he can: Thus doth he here to the Church in the Wilderne≈øs, that almo≈øt as clo≈øe did he Dogg her behind, as the Pillar of Glory did Conduct her before, and though Christ (whom ≈øhe Tempted there, 1 Cor. 10. 9.) ≈øuffered her thus to be Proved and Tryed, yet it was always to do her Good at the latter end, Deut. 8. 16.

The 6th. Plot again≈øt the Church, (which was the 2d. in her Wilderne≈øs-State) was the Tempter tempting I≈ørael to Set up the Golden-Calf, Exod. 32. 1. which, the Devil knew well, would make God di≈øown Di≈øcard, and Di≈øcovenant his People. This is one of Satans Grand Wiles, that when he cannot play his Game upon the open Stage of the World by an Extrin≈øick Adver≈øary, as by Amalek, then he trys his Skill by an Imrin≈øick-Engine, Screwing him≈øelf into the Minds of I≈ørael, (this piece of Ingenuity he taught the Je≈øuits,) and being „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a Lover of Idol-Wor≈øhip, (as being Devil-Wor≈øhip, 1 Cor. 10. 20, 21.) he puts them upon making an Idol, to make God ca≈øt them off and de≈øtroy them for ≈øuch a God-provoking Sin, v. 22. as provoked God to Jealou≈øie: The Advantage Satan took for promoting this his Project, was Mo≈øes Ab≈øence, (Non-Re≈øidents do little con≈øider this,) though Mo≈øes had Warrant for his Ab≈øence both from God and his People, for 1≈øt. God call'd him up into the Mount, Exod. 24. 12. and
2d. The People con≈øented that he ≈øhould be as an Amba≈ø≈øadour and Mediator 'twixt them and God, Exod. 20. 19. Mo≈øes (the 40 Days fa≈øter) ≈øtaid longer with God in the Mount than the People expected, though all the while he was Negotiating their Weal in bringing the Two Tables of the Decalogue, (both of Gods Writing and Workman-≈øhip, Exod. 31. 18. and 32. 16.) The Heavenly Pattern of the Tabernacle with all the Ordinances concerning Legal Wor≈øhip, to them: They grew Impatient of Mo≈øes delay: The Devil (no doubt) did ≈øugge≈øt to the Wor≈øer ≈øort, That he was torn of Wild Bea≈øts, and to the Better ≈øort, That (as Enoch was) he was Tran≈ølated into Heaven, as Jo≈øephus ≈øaith: Or, That he had de≈øerted his Charge and mocked them, as ≈øome, Or that he was A≈øhamed to Return, becau≈øe he could not make good his Promi≈øe of Conducting them into the Land of Promi≈øe, as others ≈øay: Hereupon this Stiff-necked People (≈øo call'd, Exod. 32.9.) will ≈øtay no longer; Jo≈øhuah could wait for Mo≈øes (all alone all the time) on the out-≈øide of the Cloud, Exod. 24. 13. and 33. 17. yet the People could not (with Company) in their Tents. Thus Deluded by the Devil, would have a Wor≈øhip of their own, ≈øuch as they had Retail'd in their trading with the Merchants of Aegypt, Act. 7. 39. 40. Though they wanted Mo≈øes, yet they wanted not the Pillar, Deut. 9. 15. But becau≈øe this Pillar of Glory
≈øtood ≈øtill during Mo≈øes Ab≈øence, they would have a ≈øtirring God to lead them at their will when and whither they plea≈øed: Hence they ≈øay, [∆≤p, make us Gods, to go before us:] Oh! How had the Devil Deluded them (even to a Stupefaction) to make them prefer a Stirring Calf (that could not ≈øtir, but as they ≈øtirr'd it, having Feet, but walked not, &c. P≈øal. 115. 4. 5, 6, 7, 8.) before a Standing-Pillar, that did Support their Union and Communion with God, Yea, a Pillar of Glory, which had Divided the Red-Sea, and De≈øtroyed both Aegypt and Amalek for them; And Oh how had Satan Intoxicated I≈ørael ≈øo, as to make them See double for though they had but one Calf, yet they cry, [The≈øe be thy Gods which brought thee out of Aegypt, v. 4.] even to this ≈øingle as well as ≈øencele≈øs Idol. No doubt but the Grand Plotter had now a fair Pro≈øpect of his pre≈øent project, and could not but think, he might win the Game. And ≈øo indeed he bid fair for it, having gain'd this Notable Point, ina≈ømuch as I≈ørael had twice promi≈øed To do all that God had Commanded, Exod. 19. 8. and 24. 7. Yet here he makes them to break the very 1≈øt of the Ten, [in having other Gods,] and the 2d al≈øo, [in Making and Wor≈øhipping a Calf-Idol,] as if he had de≈øign'd to drive them thorough gradually in the Breach of all the Ten, one after another: However he had already drawn them ≈øo far out of Gods Favour, as to make
them Naked, Exod. 32. 25. to wit, De≈øtitute of Divine Protection, (which had hitherto been their Armor of Proof) and Expos'd to be devoured of their Adver≈øaries, Gen. 3. 10. Rev. 3. 18. and 16. 15. God bids Mo≈øes Get thee down, (before the 40 Days were Expir'd) for thy People have Corrupted them≈øelves, v. 7. God will own them no longer, they are thine, rather than mine, ≈øeeing they have turned a≈øide ≈øo quickly (when thy back was but newly turn'd of them) let me alone that I may de≈øtroy them, v. 10. Now the Devils Game was at the Faire≈øt, yet he wins not, but lo≈ø ‚Ä¢ th it: God ≈øaith to Mo≈øes, Go down quickly, Deut. 9. 12. but he return'd not till he had fir≈øt Prayed, and al≈øo had Prevailed, Ezek. 32. 11, 12, 13, 14. God (as it were) be≈øpeaks his own Freedom, v. 10. Mo≈øes by the great power of his Prayer doth (after a ≈øort) tye Gods Hands from Puni≈øhing this Rebellious People; as if Mo≈øes's Devotion had been ≈øtronger than Gods Indignation, not by the prevailing of Humane Power above Divine Omnipotence, but by Conde≈øcending of Divine Grace to Humane Prayer; e≈øpecially this of Mo≈øes, who preferr'd Gods Glory before his own Preferment, which God offer'd him, v. 10. God grants a pre≈øent Reprieve from Utter De≈øtruction, yet not a Liberate from future Plagues, v. 35. Upon New Provocation God Reckons for the New and the Old: There is (≈øaith the Rabbys) an Ounce
of this Calf in all the Plagues upon them to this day: Though Satan had got by this Calf, the Breaking of the Two Tables, (hewn out of the Saphir of the Throne of God, Exod. 24. 10. as the Thargum ≈øaith) by his Tran≈øporting Mo≈øes to do unadvi≈øedly with his hands, v. 19. (as well as to Speak ∆≤nadvi≈øedly with his Lips, P≈øa. 106. 33.) Judging I≈ørael unworthy of ≈øuch a Jewel now Forfeited: They had broke the Two fir≈øt of the Ten, and for this, he breaks them all at once, becau≈øe Gods Bride had plaid the Whore at the Thre≈øhold of the Marriage-Bed-Chamber, ≈øo had lo≈øt her Title to her Dowry and Jewels, neither the Tables to be Re≈øtored, nor Tabernacle to be Erected, nor the Creating Angel (Chri≈øt) Exod. 23. 20, 21. to go along with them, but they ≈øhall be turn'd over to a Created Angel, Exod. 33. 23. This Degraded their Dignity. Notwith≈øtanding all this, the Cra≈øty Devil carries it not, but his Plot is Laugh'd to nothing, for Mo≈øes broke the Golden Calf, as well as the Two Rich Jewel-Tables, Executed Divine Ju≈øtice upon the Chief in the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, (about 3000 of the Ring-Leaders) Exod. 32. 20, 27, 28. Then Return'd he up again unto God (as Angry as he was) to Intercede for tho≈øe Calvi≈øh-Idolaters the 2d. time, v. 30. and (though Return'd back the ≈øame day with a ≈øad An≈øwer, whereupon I≈ørael is Humbled, Exod. 33. 3, 4.) The Mourners (as good cau≈øe
they had to mourn for the lo≈øs of Gods pre≈øence, Ho≈ø. 9. 12.) looked after Mo≈øes, Exod. 33.7, 8. to ≈øee what acce≈øs to God, and what Succe≈øs from God he could Obtain; by this Addre≈øs he gains ≈øome Hope of Reconciliation, then the 3d. time he goes up again, v. 14, 17. and Fa≈øts other 40 Days, and by hard tugging in Prayer and Fa≈øting, he at la≈øt prevails in the whole: (This kind of Devils (the Devil of Idolatry) would not be Ca≈øt out but by Fa≈øting and Prayer;) Then comes he down with Glad Tydings, That all is well betwixt God and I≈ørael: The Cloudy Pillar Returns, the Two Tables are Re≈øtor'd, and a Commi≈ø≈øion given to Build a Tabernacle; I≈ørael ≈øets about it, and not onely does, but over-does in their Offerings, Exod. 36. 7. (like a Stumbling Hor≈øe, gains Ground by his Stumbling,) The Tabernacle is Fini≈øhed, and Fill'd with Gods Glory, Exod. 40. Thus the Devil is Di≈øappointed, and his De≈øign is Defeated, and the Church in the Wilderne≈øs [al De≈øpito de grand Diabolo,] Marches forward towards the Land of Promi≈øe.

argument.p: The Seventh Plot again≈øt the Church, in the Wilderne≈øs: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. VII.
div.p:
THe Devil hath not yet done with the Church, but makes one Proof more of another Plot from Intrin≈øick Engines, to wit, in the Con≈øpiracy of Korah, Numb. 16. Satan had given the Church many Di≈øturbances betwixt this Plot or Con≈øpiracy, and that about the Golden Calf: The People were often making Tumults again≈øt Mo≈øes, and as often did Mo≈øes (in the Wi≈ødom and Power of God,) quiet the≈øe Tumults. One of the wor≈øt of them was that, wherein Aaron and Miriam did murmur again≈øt Mo≈øes upon the account of Zipporah, either becau≈øe ≈øhe, being not of the Stock of I≈ørael, hinder'd him from Circumci≈øing his Son, Exod. 4. 24. or becau≈øe he was too much with God, and too little with his Wife, as the Rabbins ≈øay: Or rather, becau≈øe Miriam (according to the ≈øignification of her Name) would be Exalted, (as ≈øhe was a Prophete≈øs,
Micah 6. 5. Exod. 15. 20.) and could not brook that Zipporah ≈øhould take too much Honour upon her ≈øelf, (becau≈øe of her Honourable Husband) and give too little to her: As Satan prevailed fir≈øt with Eve, then by her with Adam; So here fir≈øt with Miriam, then by her with Aaron; ≈øo ≈øets a Si≈øter and a Brother again≈øt Mo≈øes, he loves to Fi≈øh in Troubled Waters, no Relation or Qualification (either of Honour or Meekne≈øs) can ≈øecure a Man from Offen≈øive exceptions. Their Murmuring again≈øt meek Mo≈øes, cau≈øes the Cloud of Glory to depart, as the ≈øin of the golden Calf had done before, wherein Aaron had a Hand in the Sin al≈øo: Mo≈øes is Vindicated by God him≈øelf, Numb. 12. 4. He that had been a Lyon in Gods Cau≈øe, (in breaking the Calf to Powder) was a Lamb in his own: and the le≈øs he ≈øpeaks for him≈øelf, the more God ≈øpeaks for him. God Hears and Stirs, Yea, and Strikes Miriam with Lepro≈øie, becau≈øe Chief in the crime, and (po≈ø≈øibly) more pa≈ø≈øionate and peremptory in her Reports and Reproaches: Not Aaron, becau≈øe he was the Judge of Lepro≈øie, and ≈øo could not be tainted with it, as ≈øome ≈øay; but rather, becau≈øe he met God by Repentance, v. 10. So di≈øarm'd Gods Indignation, and Redeem'd his own ≈øorrow, Yea, and Miriam was humbled too, Deut. 24. 9. The People ≈øtaying and Mourning for her, (to go before them, Micha 6. 5.) till ≈øhe was Recover'd.
And another Di≈øturbance (after this Halt) was, They Journeyed to Kade≈øh-barnea, Numb. 13. 3, 26. not far from the South-point of the Land of Promi≈øe, Deut. 1. 2, 19. 20. From hence they ≈øent the Spys, which (no doubt, but) the Devil of Unbelief put them upon, ≈øeeing God had before Spyed out the Land for them, Ezek. 20. 6. and Search'd it out, Deut. 1. 33. But this Satisfied them not, Seeing (with them) mu≈øt be Believing: Tho≈øe Spys came to Hebron, Deut. 1. 22. and Returning with the Fruit of the Land, Ten (again≈øt Two, great odds) prove the Devils In≈øtruments, (who had prompted them to this Practice) and Rais'd an hard Report upon the Glory of all Lands, Ezek. 20.6. Numb. 13. 32. Hereupon I≈ørael falls upon Mi≈øtakes: As 1≈øt. That the Lord Hated them, Deut. 1.27. whereas never was Child more Charily carried by a Tender Father, (as his own Bowels,) and never was Prince ≈øerved in more State, than they had been all along, yet they thus De≈øperately Belyed the Lord. 2dly. They make them≈øelves a Captain to Return to Aegypt, Neh. 9. 16, 17. as if that were better for them, (which could no way be.) Thus they ca≈øt the Helve (according to the Proverb) after the Hatchet, and like Children becau≈øe they might not have what they would, grew Sullain, and would have nothing: This highly plea≈øed the Devil, and the rather, becau≈øe it mightily Di≈øplea≈øed
the Lord, in≈øomuch as he Swore, They ≈øhould wander in a Circle until they were worn out, and ≈øpend about 38 y. in Journeying from that place (of their Sin) Kadi≈øh-Barnea, to the ≈øelf-≈øame place Kadi≈øh-Barnea again, Numb. 33. 18. and 37. which is call'd Richmah here, but before, Paran, and Kade≈øh, Numb. 13. 3, 26. and Deut. 1. 19. Kadi≈øh-Barnea, as the Lord was there Sanctify'd (Hebr. Kade≈øh,) upon the People, and made them Wandring Sons, as [Barnea] ≈øignifies, Numb. 14. 32. Yea, and there Mans Life was ≈øhortned, from Hundreds of Years they had Lived, to 70 or 80 Y. (as Mo≈øes (then making the 90 P≈øalm) ≈øheweth) to wear them out the ≈øooner. And thus God was a Moth to them (to wear them [Sen≈øim ≈øine Sen≈øu] in≈øen≈øibly away, though he would not be as a Lyon to them to Devour them at once, and to Extirpate them utterly, Ho≈ø. 5. 12, 14. becau≈øe he had Pardon'd them at Mo≈øes Prayer, Numb. 14.20. And therefore doth he Pre≈øerve their Children both to Propagate the Church, and to Po≈ø≈øe≈øs the Land: However, this ≈øad Doom, (both in cutting their Lives ≈øhorter, and in cau≈øing them to Wander ≈øo as to make that way, which in it ≈øelf was but 11 days Journey, Deut. 1. 2. to be above Three times 11 years Journey long) Expos'd them for the Devil of Di≈øcontent to po≈ø≈øe≈øs: Hence aro≈øe this grand Plot, Korah's Con≈øpiracy, as well as all their other
Murmuring afterwards. Korah was the Devils Chief In≈øtrument in this 3d. and Grand Di≈øturbance, or Internal Impediment, in the Church's Motion towards Canaan, he was the Principal Rebel: Hence this Plot is call'd Korah's con≈øpiracy, and 'tis Korah's Congregation or Company, Numb. 16. 5, 16, 22. and 26. 9. and 27. 3. And the Gain-≈øaying of Korah, Jude v. 11. And to make his Con≈øpiracy the ≈øtronger, draws in Dathan and Abiram to be his Complices, Yea, and 250 Princes of the A≈ø≈øembly, Numb. 16. 2. and not onely ≈øo, but even all the Congregation, v. 19. Who were all too ready to promote this Plot, he having per≈øwaded them that God al≈øo would promote and Pro≈øper it, v. 41. Thus one Scabb'd Sheep infected the whole Flock; and as Juvenal ≈øaith, Vua
que Corrupt√¢ livorem ducitabab Vu√¢: Hence the P≈øalmi≈øt Imputeth this Con≈øpiracy to all I≈ørael, [They Envyed Mo≈øes al≈øo, and Aaron the Saint of the Lord, P≈øa. 106. 16.] Ina≈ømuch as the People did neither De≈øire to Puni≈øh tho≈øe Con≈øpirators, nor Enter'd their prote≈øt again≈øt them, they are all look'd on as a Rabble of Rebels again≈øt God and his Servants, and accu≈øed as Guilty of the Sin: (Thus Satans ≈øowr Leaven almo≈øt Leaven'd the whole Lump:) And though Aaron was not Innocent in the Two former Internal Impediments, being an Acce≈ø≈øory in them both, yet in this he keeps Clean, and is call'd a Saint of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Lord, being
one of the main Marks tho≈øe Rebels Shot at, for Korah (his Cou≈øin-German, Exod. 6. 18.) of the Tribe of Levi, A≈øpired to have the Prie≈øt-Hood from Aaron, v. 11. and being enraged that Elizaphan Son of the 4th. Family, ≈øhould be preferred before him≈øelf of the 2d. Family, Numb. 3. 30, and he Incen≈øes Dathan and Abiram (who were his next Neighbours in the Camp, ≈øo ≈øoone≈øt ≈øeduced) to claim the Principality from Mo≈øes, as being of Reuben the Fir≈øt-Born: 'Tis again≈øt Mo≈øes, and again≈øt Aaron, Numb. 16. 3, 11. again≈øt Magi≈øtracy, and again≈øt Mini≈øtry, a De≈øperate and Dangerous Con≈øpiracy, 1≈øt. In Slaunderlng the Governours, that they took too much State, too much Power, too much Honour, and too much Holine≈øs upon them, whereas they took none of the≈øe upon them, but what the Lord God had given them, Hebr. 3. 3. and 5. 4. Thus the≈øe Ring-leaders of the Rebellion mo≈øt Pre≈øumptuou≈øly pre≈øcribe an Amendment of Gods Word and Work, and would have his Divine In≈øtitutions to truckle unto their Humane Humours, and fond Inventions. 2dly. In Flattering the Governed, As if the People were Holy, and might make their immediate approaches to God both with their Incen≈øe and Offerings. All this is as fal≈øe as the former, Mo≈øes was Ambitious, (≈øay they,) 'Tis as true as I≈ørael was Holy, much alike: had Mo≈øes been ≈øo, while God lifted him up over I≈ørael, he had
never faln at their Feet, as v. 1. And had I≈ørael been Holy, (who had now ≈øcarcely wiped their Mouths of the late Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion) a≈ø≈øuredly there had never been ≈øo much Idolatry, Infidelity, and Mutiny among≈øt them: What could make them Wicked, if all the≈øe would Denominate them Holy?

No doubt but the Devil had a fair pro≈øpect of his Plot and De≈øign, when he had rai≈øed up a Grand Ring-leader of Rebellion, and not onely ≈øo, but when this One Man, v. 22. the Great Wheel (the Primus Motor, or Primum Mobile,) thereof, had (by his In≈øtigation) Twi≈øted to him≈øelf ≈øuch Two con≈øiderable Intere≈øts of 250 Princes, and of ≈øo many People, yet the Great God (who is higher then the Highe≈øt, Eccle≈ø. 5. 8.) Laughs all this to Nothing; for Mo≈øes well tells them, v. 11. That this their Ri≈øing was again≈øt the Lord, as the Lord told Saul after, Saul, Saul, why Per≈øecute≈øt thou me? Act. 9. 4. Who ever hardened him≈øelf aegain≈øt God, and pro≈øpered? Job 9. 4. Nor they then, for (1≈øt.) Mo≈øes Retorts upon tho≈øe Rebels the ≈øame they had fal≈øly reflected upon him and Aaron, v. 7. Ye take too much upon you, ye Sons of Levi: (as doth Elias upon Ahab, 1 Kin. 18. 17, 18.) and (to Hide pride from them, Job 33. 17.) he minds them, not to look up at tho≈øe few Prie≈øts that were above them, ≈øo much as look down at the many Myriads of People that were below them.
Their Thankful-Contentedne≈øs with their Advancement (as Levites) above all the People, ≈øhould have kept them from all Repining Di≈øcontentedne≈øs at the few Prie≈øts that were above them: But tho≈øe ≈øturdy Rebels were Uncoun≈øellable, Incorrigible, and their Envy and Ambition are re≈øtle≈øs and Un≈øatisfiable: Hence they ≈øay, We will not come up, v. 12. Preferring the Land of Aegypt (their Hou≈øe of Bondage, and their Iron Furnace, Deut. 4.20.) mo≈øt Ungratefully and Maliciou≈øly, before that of Gods mo≈øt Gracious Promi≈øe, v. 13.14. Hereupon (2d.) Mo≈øes referrs this Controver≈øie betwixt the Church Malignant and the True Church Militant to a Divine Deci≈øion, 1≈øt in Praying, that God would not re≈øpect their Offering, v. 15. and thereby maintain his Hone≈øt Cau≈øe and Holy Calling again≈øt tho≈øe Invaders thereof; they had forgot Gods Judgements upon Nadab and Abihu, Levit. 10. 1. which ≈øhould have made their Hands Tremble, in≈øomuch as Handling ≈øtrange Incen≈øe and Cen≈øors, which they had ready provided when fir≈øt they Combined to U≈øurp the Prie≈øts Office, and now ≈øtood ≈øtouting it out in the very Face of God; but he had no Re≈øpect to their Offering, when he came to make known who were his, as v. 5. Though he An≈øwer'd by Fire from Heaven, it was to Burn them≈øelves, but not their Sacrifice. 2dly. In Predicting Gods Miraculous Judgement upon tho≈øe Rebels,
v. 28. 29, 30. wherein Mo≈øes Engageth the Truth and Honour of his Cau≈øe upon a Miracle Immediately comming to pa≈øs: At la≈øt (3dly.) both the Plot and all the Plotters Peri≈øhed, Jude v. 11. Some one way, and ≈øome another, (as the Word [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] ≈øignifies) none of them dying a common Death, God Created Two New De≈øtructions for them: Some were Swallowed up of the Earth, ≈øo Buryed Quick, (the wor≈øt of Deaths) becau≈øe their Mouths had been open Sepulchres to ≈øwallow up Gods Servants, and Others were Burnt to Death with Fire from Heaven, having ≈øinned by Fire in their Cen≈øors and Incen≈øe. As for Korah (the Captain of the Con≈øpiracy, and the Ring-leader of the Rebellion, the main Wheel of this Malicious Mutiny) the Scripture ≈øeems to doom him to a double Death, (as his Sin was [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] a Twice-dip'd Scarlet Sin, and of a double dye: As if he were not onely Buryed Quick, (in that Di≈ømal and Univer≈øal Grave) but al≈øo Burned with tho≈øe that Offer'd ≈øtrange Incen≈øe, as if the Mouth of the Earth below him, and Fire from Heaven above him had both Con≈øpir'd together to Stigmatize and Brand that Arch-Rebel who had been the Original of all.

For 1≈øt. That he was Swallowed up of the Earth, Appears, (1.) Ina≈ømuch as the People were bidden to Seperate from the Tents of Korah,
as well as of Dathan and Abiram, Numb. 16. 24. and accordingly they did ≈øo, v. 27. (2.) The Words, [v. 30. If the Lord Create a New Thing, and the Earth open her mouth and Swallow Them up] ≈øeems to referr unto all the Three: (3.) The Earth did Swallow up all the Men that appertaineth unto Korah, v. 32. And (4.) 'tis Expre≈øly ≈øaid, That the Earth did Devour Korah him≈øelf, Numb. 26. 10.
