2dly, That he was burned by Fire from Heaven, Ina≈ømuch as Korah being a Levite. 1. was one of tho≈øe that offered ≈øuch Incen≈øe as God Re≈øpected not. 2. Korah joyning with them in the ≈øame Sin, was al≈øo joyn'd with them in the ≈øame Puni≈øhment: They all ≈øinn'd together by Fire, and they were all Puni≈øh'd together by Fire, and that Immediately after their burning Incen≈øe. 3. Tho≈øe that were thus burnt are call'd Korah and his Company, ver. 40. 4. Korah's Cen≈øer was among tho≈øe Cen≈øers which were to be Plates for the Altar as a Caveat to ≈øucceeding Ages, That none ≈øhould Invade the Prie≈øt-hood as Korah and his Company had done, Numb. 16. 6, 17, 38, 39, 40. However he was Burned in Hell, both he and his whole Tribe of Traitors; Thus the Sheol, v. 30. (taken either ≈øtrictly or largely, for Hell or Grave) Swallow'd up both this Plot and all the Plotters; Yea, and the Wi≈øe God here beats Satan, and batters his Kingdom with his own Weapon, and ≈øtrikes him
thorough with Arrows out of his own Quiver; in his Re≈øerving Korah's Children alive: [The Sons of Korah Dyed not, Numb. 26. 11.] who (≈øome ≈øay) were born up (Pendulous) in the Air by Divine Power, (while the Earth had Swallowed up their Wicked Father) being either Innocent of their Fathers Sin, or Penitent at Mo≈øes Admonition, Numb. 16.5. And tho≈øe became as eminently Serviceable, as their Father had been notoriou≈øly De≈øtructive to the Church. Of them de≈øcended Samuel, 1 Chro. 6. 33, 34. (with 1 Sam. 1. 20.) They were ≈øingers in the Hou≈øe of the Lord, v. 31. and many P≈øalms have them in their Titles, as P≈øal 42, 44, 45, &c. Thus God can gather Grapes from Thorns, and Figgs from Thi≈øtles: And (as one ≈øaith) can make White Paper even of Dung-Hill Raggs: An Holy Off-Spring Extracted out of an ∆≤nholy Root: Thus Satan lo≈øes Ground by this Plot, and the Church winns; Aaron's Prie≈øt-Hood (≈øo oppo≈øed) is Confirm'd by a Miracle, Aaron's Rod (alone) Budded, Numb. 17. And the Church marches on towards Canaan.

argument.p: The Eighth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.
div.p: THe 8th. Plot is as a Rope of the Devils making, wherewith he De≈øigns to draw back the Church not onely from Canaan, (when they were come to the very South-point of it, Numb. 21. 1.) but al≈øo farther off into the Wilderne≈øs, yea (if po≈ø≈øible) into Aegypt again: And in Order hereunto, [whereas the Scripture ≈øaith, A 3-fold Cord is not ea≈øily broken, Eccl. 4. 12.] To make it ≈øtronger, Satan Twi≈øts his Rope (here) of 4 Cords to make it a 4-fold one, that it might make a ≈øtronger Hale without breaking: to wit, 2 Internal Cords, or 2 Murmurings within the Camp: and 2 External Cords, or 2 A≈ø≈øaults and On≈øetts upon the Camp by King Arad and by King Sihon: yet God broke this 4-fold Cord more ea≈øily than Sam≈øon did his, when Phili≈øtims were upon him, Judg. 15. 14. and 16.12.

As 1≈øt. Internally: And 1≈øt. A Murmuring within the Camp for Water at Meribah,
Numb. 20. 2. They wanted Water the fir≈øt Year of their comming into the Wilderne≈øs, and now the like want befalls them in this 40th. Year of their Wilderne≈øs-Wandring: In the 1≈øt. Year-want, God Tryed the Fathers, Exod. 17. 1, 2. &c. and God gave them Water out of the Rock Horeb, v. 6. which followed them all along, till they came near Canaan, 1 Cor. 10. 4. In this la≈øt Year-want God tryed the Children, and they Murmur like their Fathers, and [Patrizando] do want Patience as well as Water: The former at Rephidim, Exod. 17. and this at Kade≈øh do Harmonize in many Particulars; ≈øave that Satan was more ≈øucce≈øsful in this Plot than in that, for here he Tran≈øports meek Mo≈øes (1.) to an Immoderate Anger, to Speak unadvi≈øedly with his Lips, P≈øal. 106. 32. (2.) To a Speaking (pa≈ø≈øionately) to the People, when he ≈øhould have ≈øpoken (believingly) to the Rock, v. 8. (3.) To his Smiting it, and that Twice as in a pang of Pa≈ø≈øion, when he ≈øhould have onely Spoken to it with the Rod in his Hand ≈øtretched towards it, v. 10. 'Tis true, while Mo≈øes Spoke to tho≈øe Rebels, he ≈øpoke to a Rock, even to their rocky hearts. Here Mo≈øes is at a ≈øtand, and his Faith ≈øtaggers, (as knowing a Flinty rock was more likely to have Fire fetch'd out of it than Water, by ≈øtriking: He is not bidden Here to ≈ømite the Rock, as El≈øewhere, Exod. 17. 6. And becau≈øe he did it Unbidden, (not
believing in the Lord, nor Sanctifying him before the People, v. 12.) both he and Aaron his Brother (for the ≈øame fault) were Excluded Canaan; but Satan could not get either of them Excluded Heaven. However, God pardons their Murmurings, (the Belly hath no Ears) and ≈øatisfies their Thir≈øt by a Miracle: Waters came out abundantly by a Work of Omnipotency, v. 11. and ≈øo the Church is Pre≈øerved.

2dly. A Murmuring within the Camp at the Tediou≈øne≈øs of the way in compa≈ø≈øing the Land of Edom, when that Unkind Cou≈øin would not ≈øuffer I≈ørael to pa≈øs thorough his Land, Numb. 20. 14, 17, 18. and 21. 4. which had been the far neare≈øt way: This turning about Mount-Seir, turns them again into their Old (Paroxy≈øms, or) Fits of Murmuring again≈øt God, (that forbad them the way thorough Seir or Edom, Deut. 2. 5.) and of Loathing Manna, as their Fathers had done, Numb. 11. 5, 6. as if it were not ≈øo Solid and Sub≈øtantial as that Food they had in Aegypt; Though it maintain'd the Body in an equal Temperature of Strength and Vigorous Health (without offending the Organs, or oppre≈ø≈øing with Fullne≈øs) for many Years, as it did Mo≈øes, Deut. 34. 7. and Caleb, Jo≈øh. 14. 11. For this Contempt God ≈øent [Seraphim Neha≈øhim] Fiery Serpents to Sting them, that tho≈øe Ungrateful ones (who had cau≈øele≈øly Cryed) might now
have ≈øome Cau≈øe to cry. 'Tis a Wonder, that ≈øeeing the Wilderne≈øs (through which they went) did Abound with tho≈øe and other Serpents, Deut. 8. 15. That the Old Serpent the Devil) had not (before this) Mole≈øted the Church with the≈øe Biteing and killing-Serpents, but the Great God (who was their Conduct and Covering) over-rul'd the Devil or Serpent, and kept all tho≈øe Serpents from hurting his People, till now (by their Sin) he gave them a Commi≈ø≈øion, as Amos 9. 3. I will command the Serpent, and he ≈øhall bite thee: 'Tis the Church's Mercy that the Serpent cannot Hurt nor De≈øtroy upon Gods Holy Mountain, but when God permits, I≈øa. 65. 25. And though God (here for their Sin) doth permit this grievous Malady, yet Provides he a mo≈øt gracious Remedy at the Pray'rs of his people, v. 7, 8. to wit, The Brazen-Serpent upon a Pole (a Figure of Chri≈øt, Joh. 3. 14, 15.) to which whoever looks (tho' with a weak Eye) are healed, I≈øa. 17. 7. and 45. 23. and Joh. 12. 32.

So 2dly. Externally. (1.) Satan ≈øtirred up the Canaanites to Oppo≈øe this Wilderne≈øs-Church in her Pa≈ø≈øage to Canaan: now when they were come ≈øo nigh to it, even to the South-point of the Land, Numb. 21. 1. and 33. 40. The≈øe under King Arad fought again≈øt I≈ørael, and took ≈øome of them Pri≈øoners. Undoubtedly tho≈øe Canaanites had heard of the over-throw which was given to I≈ørael 38 Y. before this,
when they pre≈øumptiou≈øly went up again≈øt an Expre≈øs Prohibition, Numb. 14.41, 44, 45. and of the Hand of God again≈øt them in Detaining them ≈øo long in the Wilderne≈øs: Hereby the Devil hardned and encouraged them to Encounter I≈ørael, comming ≈øo neer them again, which was done accordingly with ≈øome Succe≈øs, yet from differing Thoughts of God and the Devil; for 1≈øt the Devil did this to di≈øcourage I≈ørael, that as their Fathers through Unbelief entred not into the Promi≈øed Land, but their Carca≈ø≈øes fell in the Wilderne≈øs, Deut. 1. 27, 32, 35. Hebr. 3. 11, 18. So their Children al≈øo might be deprived: (2.) but God Suffer'd this Succe≈øs for a Cha≈øtizement of their Sins, and for a Tryal of their Faith, and that his People might know, that they ≈øhould not Conquer the Land by their own Strength, or for their own Merit, P≈øal. 44. 3. Deut. 9.4. This Succe≈øs of the Canaanites prevailing and taking ≈øome Pri≈øoners, gave Satan a fair Pro≈øpect of his Plot and Project; yet behold how the Lord baffles him, and Laughs it to Nothing, for it was onely ≈øome Pri≈øoners, not all: the Church (as the Old Romans) may lo≈øe a Battel, but never a War: This Lo≈øs was ≈øo Sanctify'd, as made them take the right way to prevail with God, (as Jacob the Father of Vows had found it, Gen. 28. 20.) Upon this Occa≈øion I≈ørael (Jacob's Off-≈øpring) Vowed a Vow, Numb. 21. 2. Invocating Gods A≈ø≈øi≈øtance,
and promi≈øing a Devotement of their Conque≈øt to God: The Lord accepts of this Religious Vow or Promi≈øe, performs his Part of Helping them to a Victory, v. 3. King Arad (Satans In≈øtrument) being Drunk with his former Succe≈øs, comes again into the Field like Thunder and Lightning, but goes out like Smoak, and a Snuff; as 'tis ≈øaid of the French, [Prior Impetus est plus qu√†m Virorum po≈øterior min√πs qu√°m Foeminarum,] More than a Man at fir≈øt, le≈øs than a Woman at la≈øt. God Delivered him into I≈øraels hands, and his Cities they De≈øtroyed, which they Devoted to God, as the fir≈øt Fruits of the Land of Promi≈øe; And that they might keep their Vow the better to the end of their Conque≈øts, the place of this fir≈øt Victory was call'd Hormah, to wit, Devotement, for a Standing Memorial both of Gods Mercy, and I≈øraels Duty, in after Ages, v. 3. And when the Devil ≈øaw that he had lo≈øt this Game, and that I≈øraels Sighing for their fir≈øt Defeat, was Turned into Singing for their la≈øt Victory, (as well as for their Deliverance from the fiery Serpents, and for their Sanedrims (or 70 Elders) cau≈øing Wells to ≈øpring up in the Dry Wilderne≈øs by the ≈øtroke of their Staves, as Mo≈øes had done with the ≈øtroke of his Rod, v. 8. 9, 17.) This Enraged him again (2.) to Stir up Sihon King of the Amorites again≈øt I≈ørael, v. 21.23. Deut. 2. 30. Judg. 11. 20. But behold the I≈ø≈øue,
Sihon comes forth at the Devils In≈øtigation, and it was to fetch his own De≈øtruction, (as King Arad and others had done) Gods Judgments need not go to find Wicked Men, they do come out to meet it the better half way: Jehovah (the God of I≈ørael) Smote him and his Complices, Numb. 21.24. Deut. 2.33. Though their Height was like the height of Cedars, and they as ≈øtrong as Oaks, Amos 2. 9. P≈øal. 135. 10, 11. with 136. 17, 18, 19. The Glory of this Victory in Defeating the Devil and his Imps, is Attributed to the God of I≈ørael: And mark a Marvellous good Providence towards I≈ørael; who was forbidden of God to meddle with Moabs Land, Deut. 2. 9. Yet Sihon had taken this part from Moab, Numb. 21.26. God takes it from him, (making him a Proverb, or By-word, v. 27. Deut. 28. 17.) and Gives it to I≈ørael: Thus they Lo≈øt not, but Gain'd by it herein.

argument.p: The Ninth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. IX.
div.p:
BUt the Sore≈øt Thru≈øt, and mo≈øt Fiery Dart of the Devil again≈øt this Wilderne≈øs-Church, was that of the Moabites, (with their A≈ø≈øi≈øtants the Midianites,) which was [∆≤ltimus Diaboli Crepitus] the la≈øt Gun-Shot of the Wicked one again≈øt I≈ørael, (as to External or Outward Engines,) before they Entred Canaan, yet proved it (by the Over-ruling Providence of God) but the Shot of a Pot-Gun, a Dintle≈øs Dart; and an Un≈øucce≈øsful Thru≈øt in the I≈ø≈øue: No Weapon that is formed again≈øt the Church ≈øhall pro≈øper, I≈øai. 54. 17. This Divine Promi≈øe did blunt the Point, and Spoil'd the Purpo≈øe of all both Humane or Diabolical Projects; Yea, of this la≈øt, which was the wor≈øt of all, [Mor≈øus Morientum ≈øunt Maxim√® Mortiferi.] The la≈øt Bite of Dying Bea≈øts are mo≈øt Deadly, no le≈øs was this la≈øt of the Serpent to Interrupt
the Church in her Pa≈ø≈øage out of the Wilderne≈øs to Canaan.

Take a Particular View of Two Things, 1≈øt. of the Church's Danger, and 2dly. Of the Church's Deliverance. God Requires a Due Commemoration hereof, Micah 6. 5. where he ≈øaith, Oh my People, Remember now what Balak King of Moab Con≈øulted, and what Balaam the Son of Beor An≈øwered from Shittim unto Gilgal, that ye may know the Righteou≈øne≈øs of the Lord: The Compellation [Oh my People,] doth plainly Demon≈øtrate, That the ≈øinfulne≈øs of Gods People doth not De≈øtroy Gods Claim to, and his Intere≈øt in them. They are his by Creation, by Redemption, and by the Covenant of Grace: 'Tis True, by the Old Covenant God might Write Lo-Ammi, and Lo-Ruhamah upon his Sinful Church, but the Free-Grace of this New-Covenant Rides Triumphingly over all the Incapacities and Unworthine≈ø≈øes of his People; and when they are not (in them≈øelves) Worthy, yet their Gracious God will Account them Worthy, Luk. 21.36. when he cannot own them (as his Jewels,) Mal. 3. 17. for their ≈øakes, yet then will he own them for his own ≈øake, Ezek. 36. 22, 32. No Love like Gods love, that Loves thus Freely, Ho≈ø. 14. 4. Though all the World di≈øclaim them, yet mu≈øt God lay his Claim to them, Oh my People; How can he Di≈øclaim them: So he tells us in his 4. ≈øuch Hows as are not to be
parallel'd in the whole Book of God, Ho≈ø. 11.8. How ≈øhall I give thee up Ephraim, &c. I cannot find in my heart to do it, What will the Aegyptians ≈øay, Exod. 32. 12. And, what will become of my Great Name? Jo≈øh. 7. 9. The very Banks of Bla≈øphemy will be broken down, when God cannot behold Innocency in his people, (as before) yet will he prevent the In≈øolency of their Enemies, Deut. 32. 27. P≈øal. 140. 8.

The Commemoration Holds forth Three Things; 1≈øt. The Plot or Danger, as the Church in the Wilderne≈øs had a Balak and a Balaam again≈øt her: So the Church evermore in her Wilderne≈øs-State hath Force and Fraud, Power and Policy again≈øt her. 2. The I≈ø≈øue and Deliverance, God Deliver'd the Church out of their Hands, Jo≈øh. 24. 10. and brought her from Shittim (the place of their Sin of Baal-Peor) to Gilgal, where he Renew'd his Covenant. 3. The End, to Proclaim Gods Prai≈øe.

The other Plots before this was a Complication of le≈ø≈øer Plots, but this la≈øt External, is a Plot of Plots: the Devil Employing his Grande≈øt Engines at this On≈øett again≈øt the Church. As 1≈øt. Balak Hires Balaam to come and ≈øecretly Cur≈øe them, Numb. 22. 4. 2. He Draws out all his Armies in Battel-Array again≈øt them to Suppre≈øs them by Open Power, Numb. 22. 5. Jo≈øh. 24. 9. as ≈øoon as Balaam had Cur≈øed them. 3. When this would not
do, than by Wiles and Private Policy, according to the Coun≈øel of Balaam, he Seduces them to Fornication and Idolatry, Numb. 25. 1, 2, 3. In the Management of this la≈øt and wor≈øt Plot, Ob≈øerve Three things, 1. The Ground or Occa≈øion. 2. The Manner. 3. The Matter thereof. 1. The Ground, it was indeed a groundle≈øs quarrel, for Mo≈øes fretted again≈øt I≈ørael, to ≈øee them upon their Plains, ju≈øt ready to ≈øet foot upon the Land of Promi≈øe, Numb. 22. 3. though Moab was (Allyed to I≈ørael) ea≈øed by them of a Trouble≈øome Incroaching Neighbour, (Sihon King of the Amorites, that had taken ≈øome part of their Land from them, Numb. 21. 26.) and (3) A≈ø≈øur'd by I≈ørael that they would not meddle with them, or mole≈øt them, becau≈øe they were of the Po≈øterity of Lot, Deut. 2. 9. So it was a Cau≈øele≈øs Quarrel, as Satan moved God again≈øt Job without Cau≈øe, Job 2. 3. So they were Acted and Agitated by the Devil without cau≈øe on I≈øraels part: they being of a Differing Religion, were carried on with Satanical malice, and ≈øought their Ruine. Thus Rome (at this Day) ≈øeeks the ruine of tho≈øe of the Reform'd Religion, and Devi≈øes Deceitful matters again≈øt them that are Quiet in the Land, P≈øal. 35. 20. Their Quarrel is Cau≈øele≈øs. 2ly. The Manner, Threefold. (1.) Secret and Undermining, Moab ≈øent no open De≈øiance by ≈øound of Drum or Trumpet, it was clo≈øe as the Plot of Rome again≈øt us at
this Day. (2.) It was Earne≈øt, Importunate and Irreconcileable, for Balak was a re≈øtle≈øs Adver≈øary, and would not give over, till ≈øome Mi≈øchief were done, as Rome doth at this Day. (3.) Sumptuous or Co≈øtly, Balak ≈øpares no Co≈øt, either in proffering Honours, or in Building of Altars and offering Sacrifices: Paul Per≈øecuted out of Ignorance, 1 Tim. 1. 13. ≈øo was ea≈øily Check'd, Act. 9. 4. but Balak out of Malice, as Rome does, and ≈øpares no co≈øt in her Malice. 3ly. The Matter of the Plot. (1) Balak Hires Balaam to Cur≈øe I≈ørael, Numb. 22. 6. Balak was a politick and potent Prince, not more Valiant than Vigilant, Ingenio≈øe Nequam, Wittily Wicked; he calls for Balaam (the Devils Spelman) to Cur≈øe I≈ørael. This Balaam (his In≈øtrument) is call'd a Prophet, 2 Pet. 2. 16. there is frequent mention of his Receiving Me≈ø≈øages and An≈øwers from the Lord, Numb. 22. 8, 13, 18. and 24. 17. 'tis ≈øaid, God put a Word into Balaam's Mouth, Numb. 23. 5. a Phra≈øe never u≈øed concerning the In≈øpiring of any of the Holy Prophets, which Word did but pa≈øs through him as a Trunk through which a Man ≈øpeaks, his Heart was not Holily Affected with what his Tongue uttered; He did not Eat his Words as Jeremy did, Jer. 15. 16. Nor did he Believe what he had ≈øpoken, as David did, P≈øal. 106. 10. And after him Paul, 2 Cor. 4. 13. And as he was call'd Prophet, ≈øo a
Sooth-≈øayer, Jo≈øh. 13. 22. As all his Altars, Sacrifices and Con≈øultations with the Lord were by the Wicked Art of Enchantments, or Ob≈øerving of Fortunes, ≈øuch as the Diviners and Prophets of the Heathen u≈øed, Deut. 18. 10, 14. Numb. 24. 1. He went not as at other times to ≈øeek for Enchantments, as being Re≈øolved to cur≈øe I≈ørael however and without Gods leave, he was fully bent to do it, and nothing ≈øhall Hinder him. Thus Satan makes U≈øe of the meete≈øt Means to Accompli≈øh his own Develi≈øh Ends, and makes Balaam to do more Mi≈øchief to the Church by his Coun≈øel, than Balak could do by his Courage: He lay'd a Stumbling-Block before I≈ørael, Rev. 2. 14. No doubt but this Wicked Per≈øon had excellent Gifts; yet as he was Famous for Prophe≈øie, ≈øo he was Infamous for Prophane≈øs. And oh what pernicious Coun≈øel was this of Balak's Con≈øulting with Balaam to have I≈ørael Cur≈øed, and that, from Heaven too, to wit, by the Mouth of a Prophet, this was more Dangerous than to Fight again≈øt them with all his Forces: And Balaam was as willing to Cur≈øe them, as Balak would have had him, for the word [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] Jude 11. Imports it. He powr'd out his Malice (like Water in a Spout) after an Impetuous and Violent manner, he Ran greedily from Altar to Altar, gaping after the Gain Promi≈øed, If but his Cur≈øing-Cur≈øed-Work were per≈øorm'd, he was like a ≈øwift ≈øwelling Torrent
that breaks down all its Banks and Bounds which are made to keep it in. Thus Balaam's March to Marr the Church was as furious as Jehu's, ≈øo that, neither Gods Prohibition before his Journey, nor the cru≈øhing of his Foot, the Speaking of his A≈øs, the drawn Sword of the Angel in his Journey, nor the Di≈øappointment of all his Endeavours by his Enchantments afterwards, could Hinder him from pur≈øuing his Cur≈øed-Cur≈øing Project: yet God made all Fruitle≈øs and fru≈øtrate, neither had Balak his Will, nor Balaam his Wages: God over-rules the Devil and his Spelman, Turns the De≈øired Cur≈øe into a Devout Ble≈ø≈øing: gladly would Balaam have Cur≈øed I≈ørael, but he cannot wagg his wicked Tongue without Gods leave, nor Balak with his Men of might could find their Hands without Divine Permi≈ø≈øion, P≈øal. 76. 5. Yea, Balaams Heart Cur≈øes again≈øt his Tongue, and his Tongue Ble≈ø≈øes again≈øt his Heart.

Let us turn A≈øide a little here (with Mo≈øes, Exod. 3. 2.) and Wonder a while that this Bu≈øh ≈øhould be ever Burning, yet never Con≈øum'd. Oh let us Admire the Power, Wi≈ødom and Goodne≈øs of God towards his Church, both in that Antient and in this pre≈øent Wilderne≈øs-State, as to tho≈øe Pregnant Parallels following.

The 1≈øt. Parallel is, As the Church then had a Balaam to Cur≈øe her, and a Balak to hire
him thereunto; Even ≈øo it is now, Gal. 4. 29. There is no new thing under the Sun, &c. Eccl. 1. 9. The pre≈øent Church of the Reformed Religion, hath the Great Balaam of Rome to Cur≈øe her with Bel, Book and Candle (as the Phra≈øe is) he is The Devils Spellman, [Primo genitus Diaboli] The Gull and Cheat of the World, to whom the Balaks or Kings (that have given their Power to that Bea≈øt, Revel. 17. 13.) ≈øays, Whom thou ble≈ø≈øeth ≈øhall be ble≈ø≈øed, and whom thou cur≈øeth ≈øhall be cur≈øed, Num. 22. 6. Whereas the Power given to Man, for Ble≈ø≈øing or Cur≈øing others, is not De≈øpotical or Magi≈øterial, but onely Mini≈øterial.

The 2d. Paralel, As Balaam is call'd a Prophet, 2 Pet. 2. 16. yet a Mad One, yea, a Sooth-≈øayer, Jo≈øh. 13. 22. So the Great Man of Rome is ≈øaid to ≈øit in the Temple of God, as a Prophet, 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 4. Yet a Sooth-≈øayer, a Sorcerer, a Necromancer, a Conjurer: See my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, Pag. 48. and 59. So he is the Devils Prophet: and 'tis very remarkable the Devil hath done more Mi≈øchief to the Church of God in his Transforming him≈øelf into an Angel of Light, than ever he could do while he appeared in his own proper Colours, as the Prince of Darkne≈øs, Gog [Tectus] or the Secret Adver≈øary is a greater Plague to the Church, than Magog [Detectus] or, the open Enemy. The Pope, that Fal≈øe Prophet, and Chri≈øts pretended Vice-Gerent, hath given
more bloody blows to the Reform'd Religion, (in its Power and Purity) than ever the Turk hath done.

The 3d Parallel. As Gain is the great Wheel (or at lea≈øt the Yellow ∆≤nction) that made Balaam run ≈øo greedily after his De≈øign of Cur≈øing I≈ørael, Jude v. 11. So the Balaam of Rome Hews out the Principal Pillars of his Romi≈øh-Religion out of the Quarry of filthy lucre. Gain is not onely got from the Living, in his Pardons, Indulgences, Di≈øpen≈øations, Oblations, Pilgrimages, &c. (He making a Money-matter of the mo≈øt Execrable Abominations, as Witchcraft, Parricide, King-Killing, Ince≈øt, Sodomy, Bea≈øtiality, &c.) but al≈øo from the Dead, (in his Ma≈ø≈øes, Diriges, &c.) who leave large Legacies to be Pray'd out of Purgatory, a Toy which he crys not up ≈øo much for Truth as for Traffick; as Mr. Jenkins Excellently ≈øhows, upon Jude la≈øt part. p. 212. ≈øaying, Silver is in the Sacks Mouth of every Popi≈øh-Errour: 'Tis a Religion wholly Compacted and Compounded for Gain: 'Tis altogether a Contrivance to make the Pope's Kitchin Smoak, and their Thir≈øt after Gain makes them Thir≈øt after Blood.

The 4th. Parallel, As Balaam Broke through all Difficulties to break Gods De≈øign of Ble≈ø≈øing I≈ørael, (whom he was Brib'd to Cur≈øe) though (1) a good Angel ≈øtood in his way to ≈øtop him, (who was Acted and Agitated
by the Devil that wicked Angel) (2) though his own A≈øs (that had been long his faithful Servant) did reproove his Madne≈øs, 2 Pet. 2. 16. (3) Though he ≈øaw a Sword drawn before his Eyes, and that in the Hands of an Angel, who was able to Kill 185000 Souldiers (notwith≈øtanding their Armour of Defence) in one Night, I≈øa. 37. 36‚ñ™ and therefore able to Kill him (a Naked Man) at one blow: Yea, and (4) though God ≈øtood over him with a Cudgel, (as the Angel had done with a Sword) or Whip all the time he ran from Altar to Altar with his Enchantments and Diabolical Arts, and would as gladly have Cur≈øed I≈ørael, as ever the Dogg would be at his Carrion, which he yet forbears, not becau≈øe he Hates it but becau≈øe he fears the Whip or Cudgel. So the Grand Impo≈øtour of Rome hath met with many Rebukes in his bloody De≈øigns, the Kingdoms that hath Couch'd under him as his A≈ø≈øes, Gen. 49. 14, 15. and have been over-faithful Servants to him, 1 Chron. 4. 23. have (at lea≈øt ≈øome of them) (through Grace) thrown their Mad Rider. And what Signal and Singular Appearances of Divine Providence hath been Evident again≈øt him, Yea and Ble≈ø≈øed be the Lord who holds his Whip and Cudgel over that Balaam at this Day, ≈øo that the Dog cannot come at his Carrion, (no better than Carrion he accounts the Church) whom he would Eat up as Bread, P≈øal. 14. 4. Yea, as
Fle≈øh, P≈øal. 27. 2. Yet when he comes to do ≈øo, Oh ≈øtand and wonder, God gives him a knock with his Cudgel, and then he Stumbles and Falls.

The 5th. Parallel, As Balaam (who had been brib'd by Balak) goes about to Bribe even God him≈øelf, to keep off the Blows of his Whip and Cudgel, and to purcha≈øe a permi≈ø≈øion for Cur≈øing I≈ørael. Hence was it, that he crys ≈øo oft, Build me here Seven Altars, and Burn on them Seven Bullocks and Seven Rams. The fir≈øt whereof was done upon the High places of Baal, Numb. 22. 41. with 23. 1. a ≈øit place to bribe God in, and to bring him into this Wickedne≈øs, who had forbid him to Cur≈øe his People, Numb. 22. 12. Hereupon Balaam (who in≈øtead of di≈øuading Balak from his Wicked purpo≈øe, and in≈øtead of Con≈øulting with God about the Building of his Altars) he fir≈øt builds his Altars to Con≈øult with God, and then boa≈øts of his Devotion, ≈øaying, I have prepared Seven Altars, &c, Numb. 23.4. as if he would bribe God with his Sacrifices, and now did merit this Favour to turn his Ble≈ø≈øing into a Cur≈øe; but 'tis expre≈øly ≈øaid, God would not hear him, notwith≈øtanding all his Flatteries, Deut. 23. 4, 5. Jo≈øh. 24. 10. God was not ≈øo ≈øoon taken with the Multitude of Balaam's Sacrifices, as he had been with a Multitude of Balaam's Trea≈øures and Honours. So the Balaam of Rome with his many Altars and
Sacrifices (though unbloody) thinks to Merit Gods Favour, Yea, to over-Merit it in his Works of Supererogation; exceeding the Phari≈øee, ≈øaying, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] Wherein am I behind hand with God? Matth. 19. 26. What lack I yet? he can keep the Law, and be before-hand with God, ≈øaying, Coelum Gratis non Accipiam. I ≈øcorn to take Heaven as a Free-Gift, I will either Earn it, or I will never have it: And another Romi≈øh-Phari≈øee ≈øaid, Non habeo Domine, quod mihi Igno≈øcas, I have no Sin, Lord, for which I need to Beg thy pardon. Thus (with Balaam here) they make them≈øelves Ve≈ø≈øels of Merit, rather than Ve≈ø≈øels of Mercy, but they (as Ve≈ø≈øels) ≈øhall be filled with their own Merit, or rather Demerit at la≈øt, even with endle≈øs wrath as ve≈ø≈øels of wrath.

The 6th. Parallel, As Balaam had his Con≈øults, Micah 6. 5. and his Confidence that by his many Altars and Sacrifices he had merited this Favour to Bla≈øt I≈ørael, whom God had Ble≈ø≈øed, yet both were Bla≈øted and Baffled by the God of I≈ørael, who over-rules the Matter ≈øo, that Balaam's An≈øwer unto Balak, was 1. a plain Prohibition, Numb. 23. 8. as God had ≈øaid to Laban concerning Jacob, [I Charge thee not to hurt him,] Gen. 31. 34. It mu≈øt therefore follow, that Laban's Words were fal≈øe, when he ≈øaid, It is in the power of my Hands to hurt thee, v. 29. For that Power mu≈øt be given of God, as Chri≈øt told Pilate, Joh. 19.
10. 11. Even ≈øo had God Charged Balaam not to Cur≈øe or Hurt I≈ørael, Numb. 22. 12. and 23. 12. God Speaks for his People in the Hearts and Mouths of their Enemies, 2dly. Balaam's An≈øwer was an Ab≈øolute Inver≈øion, God doth not onely put a Spoak into his Wheel to ≈øtemm, and to ≈øtop him from Cur≈øing his Church, but he makes him to powr out Ble≈ø≈øings, when he was Hired to Cur≈øe; and thus the Wrath of Man turns to the Prai≈øe of God, P≈øal. 76. 10. 3ly. His An≈øwer is an ∆≤nexpected Retortion, all his Intended Cur≈øes are Retorted and Returned (1.) upon Moab that Hired him, (2.) upon him≈øelf that was Hired, Numb. 24. 9. Cur≈øed be every one that Cur≈øeth thee. They both De≈øigned and De≈øired to Cur≈øe I≈ørael, and therefore on Gods Account they did it, Jo≈øh. 24. 9. Qui, quia non licuit, non facit, ille facit. Even ≈øo the Balaam of Rome hath his Con≈øults de propag and a Fide both at Home and Abroad, and his Confidence in his Multitude of Ma≈ø≈øes and Money: but oh! how Wonderfully hath God hitherto bound their Hands to the Peace, and their Tongues to Good Behaviour. Their cau≈øele≈øs Cur≈øes ≈øhall not come, Prov. 26. 2. but are retorned on their own Heads: And 'tis very Remarkable here (3ly.) that though Balaam cannot Cur≈øe I≈ørael, yet he Cur≈øeth Amalek their fir≈øt, and Rome their la≈øt Enemy, Numb. 24. 20. and 24. As ≈øure as that of Amalek is come to pa≈øs, ≈øo
≈øure ≈øhall that of Rome be [Gods Hand is upon his Throne] to Accompli≈øh both in Chri≈øt, 2 Cor. 1.20. and by him, 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 8. Thus [Me Jad Kittim] from the Coa≈øts of Kittim is meant Italy, as Dan. 11. 33. for there is an Harmony and Congruity betwixt the Two Names, Latium of Latendo, and Kittim of Katham ab≈øcondere, to Hide or Lurk: The Italians, Latines, (call'd Ketims or Ketij, as Suidas ≈øaith,) or Romani≈øts are Gog (ut Supr√†) as the Turks are Magog) to wit, Hidden and Lurking Enemies again≈øt the Church, and do (as Balaam had foretold they ≈øhould) Afflict Heber, Numb. 24. 24. to wit, the Hebrews, or I≈ørael, (Hebers Po≈øterity) or the Church of God. Now Chri≈øt was the Chiefe≈øt of Hebers Race, Luk. 3. 23, 35. and was Kill'd by Pilate the Roman-Deputy, and ≈øince that time, Rome (by Antichri≈øt Raigning there) hath been Killing Chri≈øt in his Members ever ≈øince: But ≈øhall he Kill for ever? Oh no, for God makes Balaam (him≈øelf) to Denounce his Doom and Downfall: [He al≈øo ≈øhall Peri≈øh for ever, Numb. 24. 24.] Or ≈øhall go into Perdition, 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 7, 8, 9. Thus Balaam (the Devils Spelman, and Hired by Balak to Cur≈øe I≈ørael) was over-ruled by the Great God to begin with the Ble≈ø≈øing of them, and to End with the Cur≈øing of their fir≈øt Enemy Amalek, and their la≈øt Enemy Antichri≈øt. The Lord (even by the Mouth of this Sooth-≈øayer) Confirming his Promi≈øes made to Abraham
and to his ≈øeed for ever, which are all Propounded, ratified and Performed in Chri≈øt, 2 Cor. 1. 20, 21. Notwith≈øtanding all this, the Devil hath not yet done, nor his Diveli≈øh Diviner Balaam, although he fore≈øaw ≈øuch Felicity lay'd up for, and to be lay'd out on I≈ørael, as made him Wi≈øh that his own latter End might be like theirs, Numb. 23. 10‚ñ™ Yet Re≈øts he not Here, but Acts ≈øtill in giving cur≈øed Coun≈øel, and never gave over Acting Devili≈øhly until the Sword, which he had ≈øeen Drawn in his way, at la≈øt was Sheath'd in his own Bowels, Numb. 31. 8. 'Tis ≈øaid (indeed) He return'd to his place, Numb. 24. 25. That is, ≈øaith Baal Turim, He went to Hell, as Judas did, Act. 1. 25. had he gone then to his own place in Hell, his Doings of Mi≈øchief would then have Cea≈øed, and been Turned into Suffering of Mi≈øery, which Undoubtedly was done at la≈øt; but either he was (in his Returning Homeward,) Detained by the Midianites, where he gave that Pe≈øtilent Advice to Entice them (with their Daughters) both to Adultery and Idolatry. I≈ørael was joyn'd hereby to Baal-Peor, that Shameful God of Opening, Numb. 25. 3. Ho≈ø. 9. 10. This became [Peccatum Flagrans] a Foul Flaming Sin in God's Eye, that Stank in his No≈øtrils, without which (he had Subtilly ≈øaid) none of his Enchantments could prevail again≈øt I≈ørael, Numb. 23. 21, 23.
Until this ≈øin put them, (at his Advice) under Gods Di≈øplea≈øure, 2 Pet. 2. 15. Jude 11. Rev. 2.14. or if he went Home, he return'd again to Midian to Demand his Wages (≈øaith Chaskuny,) as ≈øoon as he heard Gods Plague was upon I≈ørael through his means, Numb. 25.9. 1 Cor. 10. 8. but as Shemei ≈øought his Servants, and lo≈øt his Life, 1 Kin. 2. 40, 46. ≈øo did Balaam, Numb. 31. 8. Neither Balak had his Will, nor Balaam his Wages: How could he Dye the Death of, that Liv'd not the Life of, but Plots again≈øt the Lives of the Righteous.

argument.p: The Tenth Plot again≈øt the Church, in the Wilderne≈øs: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. X.
div.p:
THus have I ≈øhown what a Marvellous Conduct the Church had by the Pillar of Providence (Defeating all the Devils De≈øigns again≈øt her) from Adam to Noah, from Noah to Mo≈øes, and from Mo≈øes to Jo≈øhuah; Winning (not lo≈øing) Ground all the time, for above 2493 Y. according to
Helvicus, Paro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ; Calvi≈øius; or 2553 according to Dr. Lightfoot. When Satan had got quit of Mo≈øes, (by his Tempting him to ∆≤nbelief, Numb. 20. 12.) who Dyed in the very Borders of Canaan, (whither he had brought I≈ørael) and was Buryed by God him≈øelf, Deut. 34. 5, 6. Next he propo≈øes and pur≈øues his 10th. Plot and Project (which was the la≈øt Internal Engine) again≈øt this Body of the Church, which had now lo≈øt her Head, Mo≈øes; and that, in his Contending with Michael or Chri≈øt about the buryed Body of Mo≈øes, Jude 9. Michael or Chri≈øt (who onely could bury Mo≈øes Law, Rom. 8. 3. Gal. 3. 13, 14. Col. 2. 14, 16, 17. Hebr. 9. 9, 10, 11, &c.) becomes (him≈øelf) a Sexton, and burys Mo≈øes Body; the like is not done by God to any Mortal Man, a Peculiar Priviledge and Honour, te≈øtifying how God Loved him both Alive and Dead; which Body was Rais'd at Chri≈øt's Transfiguration, Matth. 17. 4. with a Glory upon it, and yet ≈øhould Ri≈øe with a greater Glory at the last Day, Phil. 3. 21. The Devil Di≈øputed with Michael about the place of Mo≈øes Sepulchre, that he might take up the Reliques of Dead Mo≈øes (as the Romani≈øts do of their ≈øuppo≈øed, and Suppo≈øititious Saints) and ≈øet them up as Idols in the Hearts of the Living I≈øraelites, who were ≈øo Notoriou≈øly Inclined to any ≈øort of Idolatry, P≈øal. 106.28. I≈øa. 8.19. & 65.4. thus Satan (being ambidexter)
lays about him on both Hands, while Mo≈øes was Living, he Tempts I≈ørael to De≈øpi≈øe him, (in their Murmurings afore≈øaid,) but when he is Dead, he would Tempt them to Idolize him, and to Tran≈ølate his Body out of its Grave into a Temple of their own Hearts: yet all this was but as a Stirrop and Stalking-Hor≈øe to Advance and Advantage the Devils De≈øign of ≈øetting up a Divine Adoration of Him≈øelf among the People of God: This Game did Satan play with Saul in making him Di≈øregard Samuel, while Living, and then puts him upon Conjuring him up (as his God) when Dead. Whereby Satan got Divine wor≈øhip from Saul in that Mock Samuel: Here, Satan had no Re≈øpect to the Body of Mo≈øes, any further than thereby to Hurt the Souls of I≈ørael; 'tis probable, he might Argue to the Arch-Angel in the Di≈øpute: 'Tis a ≈øhame that ≈øuch an Honourable Magi≈øtrate and Holy Man ≈øhould have ≈øuch a private, and not a publick Burial, Attended by all I≈ørael; whereas indeed it was mo≈øt Honourable, for God onely Attended and Acted all the Solemnity, the onely fault or quarrel was, that God would not Invite the Devil to be pre≈øent at the Funeral, for the Rea≈øons afore≈øaid.

Thus the Plot was lay'd, to make Mo≈øes an Idol, and an Occa≈øion of Idolatry when Dead, who had been the greate≈øt Oppo≈øer of it whil≈øt Living; But what Succe≈øs had this Plot? 'twas
Laugh'd into Nothing, for Michael Over-matches the Devil, rebukes him; Satan may be rebuk'd, but never reform'd, he may be Curb'd, but never Cured, he may be Chain'd, but never Changed: And as the Lord's rebuke was upon him for his Contending about the Body of Mo≈øes, ≈øo Undoubtedly it is, about the Body of the Me≈ø≈øias, to wit, the Church, which is his Body, and he is the Head: Never did Michael make War with this Dragon, but he hath always the Victory, as Rev. 12. 8. Dan. 10. la≈øt, &c. And if he do not now lay his rebuke upon Satan, 'tis not from the ≈øcantne≈øs of his Power, but from the greatne≈øs of his Patience, yea, and of his Wi≈ødom. Behold here! God did not leave the Church (his Body) without an Head, but rai≈øes up a Living Head (a Jo≈øhua, or Je≈øus, (≈øo call'd, Act. 7.45.) a Type of Je≈øus, our Lord) in≈øtead of a Dead Mo≈øes: Mo≈øes (or the Law) cannot bring to Canaan, no, it is Dead, and all the Ceremonies of it; and 'tis the Devil that puts Men to digg them out of the Grave: but to bring us into the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Heavenly Canaan, is the work of Je≈øus by the Gospel, as Jo≈øhua (not Mo≈øes) brought I≈ørael into the Earthly Canaan: This Je≈øus is the Head of the Church, a Living Head at the Right Hand of God; Hence the Church can never be Drowned, ≈øo long as her Head (Chri≈øt) is lifted above the Waters: neither doth God ever ≈øtarve his work for want
of In≈øtruments; Mo≈øes Dyes, Jo≈øhua (who had been train'd up with him from a Child) is his Sub≈øtitute, God will not leave his Church De≈øtitute, as one is broke off, another Ri≈øes up in his Room, and that with Commi≈ø≈øion and Qualifications ≈øuitable for his Work, ≈øo that I≈ørael might follow him with Confidence, as they mu≈øt with Obedience, Deut. 31. 1, 8. and 34. 9. and Jo≈øh. 1. 1, 2, 16. who after his Inauguration Renews the Two Sacraments of Circumci≈øion, and the Pa≈ø≈øcover, Conquers all Canaan, ≈øettles I≈ørael in it, and all this after Mo≈øes Death; a Figure of Chri≈øt, who brings into Eternal Re≈øt after the ending of Mo≈øes Law. Thus the Church at la≈øt Landed in the Land of Promi≈øe, maugre the Malice of angry Men, and of Enraged Devils.

argument.p: The Eleventh Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
div.p:
NOw though the Church had lo≈øt Mo≈øes, and at his Death the Cloudy Pillar too which then Departed, yet The Righteou≈øne≈øs of the Lord brought
Her from Shittim to Gilgal, Micah 6. 5. that is, The Faithfulne≈øs and Goodne≈øs of God in keeping Promi≈øe with his People, notwith≈øtanding all their provocations, and in De≈øpite of the Devil that (all the way in the Wilderne≈øs) made many De≈øperate Di≈øturbances: Still the Church had a Jo≈øhua to ≈øtand for her in Mo≈øes ≈øtead, and though the lo≈øs of the Cloudy Pillar was Undoubtedly a very great and mo≈øt Di≈øcouraging lo≈øs, e≈øpecially ≈øhe having Jordan (yea, and at that time, over-flowing all his banks, Jo≈øh. 3. 15.) betwixt her and Canaan, for the Devil had block'd up all other ways to it, having ≈øtirr'd up Moab, Midian, Ammon, Amalek, and the Amorites to ob≈øtruct her pa≈ø≈øage thither.

Yet God comes to Comfort her at that time, Ho≈ø. 2. 14. ≈øaying as it were, Be not De≈øcouraged, I have taken from you my Cloudy Pillar, to Teach you that the Umbrages or Cloudy Shaddows of the Law of Mo≈øes cannot Conduct you into Canaan, (though it hath through the Wilderne≈øs:) yet now ≈øhall you have The Ark of the Covenant (which typi≈øies the Angel of the Covenant Je≈øus Christ) to go before you, Jo≈øh. 3. 3, 11. and that ≈øhall Divide Jordan for you, as the Cloudy Pillar had Divided the Red-Sea for your Fathers. Hereupon the Order and Cour≈øe of carrying the Ark of God's Pre≈øence was changed, for while the Pillar went before the Camp, the Ark abode
in the mid≈øt of it, Numb. 2. 17. (to betoken, Gods pre≈øence in the mid≈øt of his people, P≈øa. 46. 5.) Now the Ark mu≈øt go before (when the Pillar was gone) and I≈ørael mu≈øt follow it to Shew, that as there was no other way of Entrance into the Earthly Canaan but by following the Ark, ≈øo there is no other way of Entrance into the Heavenly Canaan, than onely by following Chri≈øt, (whereof the Ark was the Type) Joh. 14. 6. then did the Lord Magnifie Jo≈øhua, Jo≈øh. 14. 14. by making him Equal with Mo≈øes, (who had divided the Red-Sea for them at their coming out of Aegypt under the Conduct of the Pillar;) now Jo≈øhua divides Jordan under the Conduct of the Ark, and gives them pa≈ø≈øage to and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Canaan in de≈øpight of the Devil and all his In≈øtruments (the Nations aforenamed) that Ob≈øtructed them.

Jo≈øhua (through the Righteou≈øne≈øs and Goodne≈øs of the Lord) brings them from Shittim to Gilgal, Micah 6. 5. He removes them from Shittim, Jo≈øh. 3. 1. This Shittim was the la≈øt Stage of all the 42 Stations or Man≈øions I≈ørael had in the Wilderne≈øs, Numb. 33. 49. and it was that Unhappy place where Balaam (Satans Spelman) made the Midianites out-wit I≈ørael by ≈øetting fair Faces (his ≈øtumbling-block, Rev. 2. 14.) before them, who ≈øoon Drew them into tho≈øe Two Si≈øter-Sins. Adultery and Idolatry, for it was upon tho≈øe Terms, That
if they would Wor≈øhip their Idols, they ≈øhould have the Free u≈øe of their Bodies: ≈øome Derive Shittim from Sethim, Spinae, as it was a place of Thorns, ≈øure I am, here Gods Flock of Sheep, P≈øa. 77. 20. were ≈øo caught among Thorns, (to wit, with that Smoaking and Flaming Sin) as they were not cleans'd from it until after the Conque≈øt of the Land, Jo≈øh. 22. 17. it left (as the Plague of Frogs Exod. 8. 14.) a long la≈øting Stench behind it, by that Sin of Baal-peor. I≈ørael brought them≈øelves under the Wrath and Cur≈øe of God, which Balaam (with all his Spells) could not otherwi≈øe bring them under, and this place is call'd Abel-Shittim, Numb. 13. 49. becau≈øe of the ≈øad Lamentation (as Abel ≈øignifies) which was made for the Death of the 1000 that Dyed (as Ring-leaders) by the Hand of Ju≈øtice, and the 23000 (that followed tho≈øe Ring-leaders) by the Hand of God in the Plague, Numb. 25. 4, 9. 1 Cor. 10. 8. yet the Lord's Goodne≈øs over-comes all I≈øraels Badne≈øs, and not onely ≈øtirs up Phinehas to ≈øtand in the Gap to ≈øtop the Plague, P≈øal. 106. 29, 30. but al≈øo Jo≈øhua, to bring them off from Shittim, where they might all have peri≈øhed, been cut off and ca≈øt away from being a People before him; yea, and to bring them through Jordan even to Gilgal, where he fir≈øt pitched his Tent, and ≈øo did take Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Land of Promi≈øe, wherein Gilgal ≈øtood, Jo≈øh. 4. 19, 20. Nonne hic Reful≈øit Admirabilis
Dei Gratia, ≈øaith Calvin, Behold here a Miracle of Divine Mercy, e≈øpecially in Six Re≈øpects. (1.) The Devil was Infatuated by God in not ≈øtirring up the Canaanites to Guard their Coa≈øts, (as is u≈øual for people to Man their Frontiers in Danger of Inva≈øion) All the Ho≈øt of I≈ørael pa≈ø≈øed over and quietly Landed without any A≈ø≈øault or Oppo≈øition, Jo≈øh. 3. 17. and (2ly.) That the Lord ≈øhould Magnifie his Mercy to his Church (notwith≈øtanding all her Demerit by Sin) in bringing I≈ørael into Canaan (the Land of their Enemies, yet the Land of his Promi≈øe to them) in the very time of Harve≈øt, when it was be≈øt furni≈øhed with all manner of Provi≈øions both for that pre≈øent time and for the following Year, Jo≈øh. 3. 15. 3ly. Another manife≈øtation of God's Mercy to his Church was this, That God Roul'd away (as the Word Gilgal ≈øignifies, and therefore the place is ≈øo call'd) the Reproach of Aegypt, to wit, the Uncircumci≈øion of their Fle≈øh, Jo≈øh. 5.9. Re≈øtoring to them that Seal of the Covenant, to wit, Circumci≈øion, (to Teach, none but the Circumciz'd in Heart mu≈øt Enter the Heavenly Canaan, as none but the Circumci≈øed in the Fle≈øh mu≈øt enter the Earthly one:) Yea, (4ly.) behold a marvellous Mercy of God to I≈ørael in this, that the Devil did not ≈øtir up the Cur≈øed Canaanites to Fall upon I≈ørael when they were (all) ≈øore in their Circumci≈øion, (as Sinicon and Levi did upon the Sichemites, Gen.
34. 25, 26. and ≈ølew them,) then I≈ørael abode in the Camp till they were whole, Jo≈øh. 5.8. Con≈øiding in God's Promi≈øe, Providence and Protection for Securing them from their Enemies; Undoubtedly the Terror of the Lord was upon their Adver≈øaries all the time, (as in Jacob (their Fathers) Ca≈øe, Gen. 35. 5. with 34.30.) that they A≈ø≈øaulted them not upon this Advantage: Yet further, (5ly.) God manife≈øted his mercy to his Church in giving them the other Seal of his Covenant, to wit, the Pa≈ø≈øeover, and that within Three Days of their Circumci≈øion, Jo≈øh. 5. 8, 10. which ≈øhews, not onely their ≈øpeedy and miraculous Healing, otherwi≈øe they could not have (Four Days after) kept the Pa≈ø≈øeover with joy; but al≈øo God's Speedy applying both the Seals to his Bond of Promi≈øe, to A≈ø≈øure them, that though they had wanted them both in their Wilderne≈øs-Wandrings, yet now their former Sins were all pardoned, and their per≈øons now received as a peculiar People into the Bonds of the Covenant, he would be a God to them, and they ≈øhould be a People to him: Moreover (6ly.) Chri≈øt (him≈øelf) comes to be their Generali≈ø≈øimo with a Sword drawn in his Hand, v. 13, 14. which Sword he will never put up, or lay down, till the Wars of the Lord be ended, the Cur≈øed Canaanites were all Conquered by this Captain as the 1≈øt. Fruits, ≈øo ≈øhall all the Cur≈øed Foes of the Church be by his Wi≈ødom
and Power, Hebr. 2. 10. Rom. 8. 31. All that the Devil could do (in this 11th. Plot) further again≈øt the Church under the Conduct of her Captain-General (who was pre≈øent with her, Jo≈øh. 5. 13. and 6. 2. not wrapped up in a Cloud as in the Wilderne≈øs, but as a Man of War, Exo. 15. 3. Mighty in Battel, P≈øal. 24. 8. in Canaan, as a praelude to his Incarnation) ≈øave onely Two poor Spirts, or ≈ømall Skirmages, the one in the beginning, and the other in the end of the Conque≈øt: The 1≈øt. petty-Plot, was that of Achan, who Interrupted their Progre≈øs, and Troubled their Ho≈øt for a time, Jo≈øh. 7. 25. The Occa≈øion was this; The Man Chri≈øt Je≈øus (who appeared to Jo≈øhua) Ordains and Orders the means of the Downfall of Jericho, even ≈øuch as the World would judge De≈øpicable and Ridiculous, not the Silver Trumpets of the Sanctuary, (which might have both Graced the Enterprize, and given Confidence of Succe≈øs) but Contemptible Rams-Horns fitter to be Laugh'd at by a Carnal Eye. God loves to go a way by him≈øelf, Jo≈øh. 6. 3, 4. Jo≈øhua pa≈ø≈øes on before the Lord, v. 8. U≈øes the means Appointed. The Ark of Chri≈øt's Pre≈øence compa≈ø≈øes Jericho and Down it falls, (≈øo ≈øure ≈øhall My≈øtical Jericho or Babylon Fall by the powerful pre≈øence of Chri≈øt, though the means be De≈øpi≈øed.) The whole City (as the 1≈øt. Fruits) is Devoted to De≈øtruction, v. 17. and the People are Commanded
to Keep from the Accur≈øed thing, v. 18. This was fair Warning to that foul Sinner Achan, who Sacrilegiou≈øly ≈øeiz'd on a Wedg of Gold, and a Babyloni≈øh-Garment, Jo≈øh. 7.21. The Devil knew his covetous Temper by feeling his Pul≈øe, ≈øo fitted him with an Object, a fit Penny-worth, or Prize, he ≈øets before him, Achan Covets them, (as he confe≈ø≈øes) Robs God of his Right, God is Di≈øplea≈øed with all the Body for the Contagion of this One Sinner, [Who De≈øtroy'd much Good. Jo≈øh. 7. 1. Eccle≈ø. 9. 18. This one Sin (of one Member of their Body) betrays them into the Hands of Divine Ju≈øtice, (for looking no better, not onely to the Ob≈øerving, but to the Pre≈øerving of God's Law, on which Account every Man ≈øhould be His Brothers Keeper;) I≈ørael Fled before the Men of Ai, Jo≈øh. 7.4. Jo≈øhua Fa≈øts and Prays to find out the Sin and Sinner; God Directs to both, both are Remov'd, and God's Favour Recovered, than the Church goes on (with Chri≈øt) Conquering and to Conquer for Seven Years, till the Land (Lett to her by God's Sealed Lea≈øe) was Subdued before Her. The Devil being ≈øoon Baffled of this 1≈øt. Plot in Canaan, was Chained up to the End of its Conque≈øt: 'Tis True, he put a Cheat upon the Church by the Gibeonites, pleading Antiquity to Her, (as the Romani≈øts would do with Us
now with their Old Sacks and Moulded Bread. See my Antidote again≈øt Popery, in the Chapter of Novelty; But he had like to have made them Sheath their Conquering Swords in one anothers ≈øides, (which was his 2d. Plot) when Reuben, Gad, and the half Tribe of Mana≈ø≈øeth were Di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and Built an Altar of Remembrance on the other ≈øide of Jordan, Jo≈øh. 22. 11, 12, 16, 18. No Doubt but the Devil made the Smoak, while an Holy Fire ≈øo Ble≈ø≈øedly Blows up I≈ørael into ≈øo Incon≈øiderate Zeal and Uncharitable Cen≈øures: but Phinehas (their Amba≈ø≈øadour) being rightly Informed by the Reubenites, takes up the Controver≈øie, v. 22. 30, 31. So Satan lo≈øt this De≈øign al≈øo, and this might rebuke the Reubenites that choo≈øe to Live ≈øo far from the Tabernacle (as they were on the other ≈øide Jordan) ≈øo far off from the place of God's Wor≈øhip.

argument.p: The Twelfth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XII.
div.p:
IN the Devils 12th. De≈øign and Plot again≈øt the Church, (which continued 450 Y. in its ∆≤ps and Downs, Act. 13. 20) Take a Di≈øtinct View, 1. of the Churches Danger, 2ly of the Churches Deliverance: 1st. of her Danger. 'Twas Twofold. 1≈øt. by her Sin the Devil ≈øeduced her into, and 2ly. By her Puni≈øhment the Devil procured upon her for her Sin: 1≈øt. Her Sin was Twofold; 1≈øt. She ≈øinned again≈øt the 1≈øt Table of the Law in her Wor≈øhip. 2ly. again≈øt the 2d. Table thereof in her Manners: Thus the Devil Debauch'd the Church both in her Holine≈øs to God, and in her Righteou≈øne≈øs to Man, and he made her Degenerate into a mo≈øt dangerous Apo≈øtacy, ∆≤ntil this be done, the Devil well knows, none of his Plots can ever be pro≈øperous, Numb. 23. 21, 23. The Churches 1≈øt. Sin again≈øt God in her Wor≈øhip, was Idolatry,
that God-provoking, and Land-de≈øtroying Sin: Idolatry (after the Death of Jo≈øhua, and of the Elders, who had ≈øeen the Wonderous Works of God, and Upheld the purity of Divine Wor≈øhip in her, Judg. 2. 7.) was begun in I≈ørael by a Woman, to wit, Micah's Mother, Judg. 17. 1, 2, 3. &c. (which Story mu≈øt Undonbtedly follow after, Judg. 2. 10. in order of time and place) and that in Ephraim al≈øo, where afterwards Jeroboam E≈øtabli≈øh'd it by a Law: The Devil began his Kingdom of Sin in the World by a Woman, to wit, Eve, 1 Tim. 2. 16. And he carries it on here by a Woman, to wit, Micah's Mother, of the weaker Sex, yea, an Old Woman (who had not onely a Son in a Marryed E≈øtate, but al≈øo a Grand-Son grown up and Con≈øecrated to the Prie≈øts Office, Judg. 17. 5.) The Tempter knew well, that weak and old Wood was mo≈øt Apt to take Fire, even the Fire of Hell: yea, ≈øhe was not onely a Woman, an Old Woman, but al≈øo a very Super≈øtitious Woman, po≈ø≈øibly ≈øhe might (though then very young) Learn her Super≈øtition from the mix'd Multitude, Exod. 12. 38. Numb. 11. 4. And though God had been Ayring I≈ørael full 40 Y. in the Wilderne≈øs, (where many ≈øweet Gales of Grace did blow upon them) yet Micah's Mother did Smell of Aegypt, in her Devoting Eleven Hundred Shekels of Silver to the making of an Idol, for the lo≈øs of which ≈øhe mo≈øt
grievou≈øly Cur≈øed, Cur≈øing Per≈øons are mo≈øtly Cur≈øed Per≈øons; a wicked Heart wants not a wicked Mouth, that is full of Cur≈øing and Bitterne≈øs, Rom. 3. 14. Yea, and out of the ≈øame Mouth proceedeth Ble≈ø≈øing (of the Thief, her Son, without reprooving him for his Sin) as well as Cur≈øing, Jam. 3. 10. Judg. 17. 2. And partus Sequitur Ventrem, The Birth follows the Belly, Morrally as well as Civilly, ≈øo did Micah his Mother, „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ of an Evil Bird comes an Evil Egg, like Mother, like Son; they Two con≈øent together to lay out Nine Hundred of the Shekels for Materials, and the other two Hundred for Workman-≈øhip of the Idol. Micah ≈øets it up in his own Hou≈øe, for his own u≈øe, and the u≈øe of the Neighbourhood round about him. Now he who had been hitherto called (in the Hebrew Text) Micaiahu (with a part of Johovah affixed to his Name) is from v. 5. Cut ≈øhorter in his Name, and ever after is called Micah, as having lo≈øt his part in the Name Jehovah by his Idol he ≈øets up and Wor≈øhips for Jehovah, and Con≈øecrates one of his Sons for his Prie≈øt, though neither of Levi's Tribe, nor of Aaron's Lineage.

Yet afterwards, he bethought him≈øelf to Amend that Fault by Chu≈øing a Novice, one Jonathan, Mo≈øes Grand-Child, a Degenerate Plant, the 1≈øt. Idolatrous Prie≈øt, who would Murder Souls for a mor≈øel of bread, Ezek. 13. 19.
which was the wor≈øe in him, becau≈øe he (De≈øcending from Mo≈øes the Man of God) ≈øhould have been Better. This young Levite Micah Hires for a ≈ølender Sallary to Officiate before his Idol: He, who had Eleven Hundred Shekels to be≈øtow upon his Image, thinks Ten Shekels Wages enough for Prie≈øtly Work, onely he will make up that Defect by a parcel of cheap Complements, (calling the Young-Man a Father) and if that were not enough, he would give him a Summer and a Winter Suit: This Jonathan being forced by the Iniquity of tho≈øe times, (while yet there was no Judge or Supream Magi≈øtrate to Suppre≈øs it, v. 6.) to ≈øhift and ≈øeek Sub≈øi≈øtence any where, (as tho≈øe did after Neh. 13. 10, 11.) and being Hunger-bit, he ≈ønaps at any thing, even at this ≈øordid Work and Wages, not having Grace to Re≈øtrain him, v. 7. 8, 9, 10. Micah Con≈øecrates him as he had done his own Son, (which none might Lawfully do, but the High-Prie≈øt, Exod. 29. 22, 23, 24.) and as Jeroboam did (after) the ba≈øe≈øt of the People, 1 Kin. 13. 33. All this Micah did as a Gro≈øs Idolater, expre≈øly contrary to the Law of God, yet doth he Ble≈øs him≈øelf in all this his Blind Devotion, (Entertaining this Levite as a Son, in re≈øpect of his Youth, yet as a Prie≈øt and a Father in re≈øpect of his Office) v. 11, 12, 13. he promi≈øes him≈øelf much Pro≈øperity (as the Papi≈øts do in their Popes Pardons, and Prie≈øts
Ab≈øolution) in his Idolatrous way of Wor≈øhip: but his gro≈øs Idolatry brought a gro≈øs Di≈øappointment, the contrary came to pa≈øs, it indeed Expos'd him to God's Wrath and Vengeance, as appeareth, Judg. 18. 18, 19, 22, 24. When he had like to have lo≈øt his life for pur≈øuing the Plunderers of his Gods, Goodly Gods they were that could not ≈øecure them≈øelves from Plundring-Men: yet he Accounts them his All, (though of his own making, ≈øo could have made more) Reckoning the re≈øt of his Goods as nothing without his Gods, and therefore Arms him≈øelf and his Neighbourhood (who had Haunted his Hou≈øe of Gods) for a Re≈øcue, but all in vain, v. 26. he returns without his Gods, yet took no Notice that God Puni≈øh'd his Idolatry by this (to him ≈øuch a Lamentable) Injury. However, the Devil (whom Syne≈øius calls „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a Great Promoter of Idolatry) Notably promoted his Notorious De≈øign of ≈øpreading this Sin of Idolatry from an Hou≈øe to a Tribe, even to the Tribe of Dan. (1≈øt.) The Devil gives the Danites his Equivocating Oracle and Doubtful An≈øwer to their Que≈øtion by the Teraphim, (as Ezek. 21. 21. Zach. 10. 2. Ho≈ø. 2. 4.) in bidding them, [Go in Peace, before the Lord is your way] Judg. 18. 5, 6. wherein the wary Devil is [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] Ambiguous, that however the matter prov'd, he might ≈øtill ≈øave his Credit (as in all his Oracles both in Sacred
and Civil Hi≈øtory, 1 Kin. 22. 12, &c) for his An≈øwer Imports, either, God ≈øeeth what you are going about, or, he will al≈øo See to your Safety and Succe≈øs: and yet his An≈øwer might be the more peremptory, ina≈ømuch as he well knew the Men of Lai≈øh (whom they were going to Invade) were throughly Ripe (at that time) for their own Ruine: However, it was ≈øo Accomodated to the Danites Humour, that the Devil (having given them this Sweet Bit for a Foreta≈øt in Micah's Hou≈øe) makes them (2ly.) long to take the Idol along with them, (as mo≈øt U≈øeful in their Un≈øettled-E≈øtate) and to ≈øet it up publickly in their own Tribe after; for which cau≈øe ('tis ≈øuppo≈øed) the Tribe of Dan is not Named among the Sealed of the Lord, Rev. 7. becau≈øe, The fir≈øt publick Idolatry began among them; The fore-≈øight of which (and the Mi≈øery attending it) made the Dying Patriark ≈øigh, Gen. 49. 10:

This Idolatry the Church or I≈ørael doth tolerate, never Entering their Prote≈øts either again≈øt that in Private, (which was in Micah's Temple of Idols, Judg. 17. 5. or again≈øt that in Publick, which was ≈øet up in the Tribe of Dan, Judg. 18. 30. This over-≈øoft Toleration became the Nur≈øe and Mother of all Sorts of Impiety, in≈øomuch as Gibeah, a City of I≈ørael, becommeth as Abominable as Sodom, Judg. 19. 22. tho≈øe Men of Belial, or (as the Word ≈øignifies) Yokele≈øs-Ones, Differing
onely from Bea≈øts, [Non Ratione, ≈øed Oratione] Not in Rea≈øon, but in Speech, had taken their Lu≈øt by Turns upon the Levites Concubine, until they had turn'd her out of the World, and turn'd her Soul out of her Body, which they had ≈øo Villaniou≈øly Abu≈øed, v. 25. Thus a Whori≈øh Woman, Judg. 19. 2. is kill'd with Whoredom, and ≈øo fill'd with the Evil of her own ways, Prov. 14. 14. The Levite Appeals to All the Tribes for Ju≈øtice again≈øt Gibeah, four Hundred Thou≈øand Marches again≈øt it, and that by Command and Commi≈ø≈øion from God: forty Thou≈øand of them are Slain by that Wicked and Wretched Town, and by that Tribe who patroniz'd it in this wicked Lewdne≈øs. Whereby God Avenged his own Cau≈øe again≈øt I≈ørael, becau≈øe I≈ørael would not Avenge God's Cau≈øe again≈øt Idolatry: They were enough Sen≈øible of the Injury done to the Lord's Levite in Gibeah, but were not at all Sen≈øible of the Injury done to the Lord Him≈øelf in Micah's and Dan's Idolatry. Yet the Rod after this Cha≈øtizement is Burnt at la≈øt. When God hath thus u≈øed Benjamin to Correct I≈ørael for their not Puni≈øhing Idolatry, He then u≈øeth I≈ørael to Scourge Benjamin for Protecting Gibeah from Ju≈øtice: No doubt but it greatly gratified the Devil to ≈øee the Tribes of I≈ørael De≈øtroy one another, and to have one Tribe (well nigh) Cut off, which God Ordered as a Ju≈øt Judgement upon them
for their Iniquity in one Tribe, and their Idolatry in another; yet hath not the Devil done here, but he after all this, cau≈øeth this Cur≈øed Leaven of Idolatry (which had hitherto ≈øpread onely over one Tribe, the Tribe of Dan, ju≈øt at their Settling in the Promi≈øed Land,) to Spread over All the Tribes, and ≈øo to Leaven the whole Lump of I≈ørael, Judg. 2. 11. (before which All tho≈øe Stories in Chap. 17. 18, 19, 20, 21. ought to be Under≈øtood, as all Tran≈øacted ≈øoon after Jo≈øhuah's Death, and before they had any Judges.) 'Tis not now ≈øaid the Children of Dan onely, or the Children of Benjamin onely, But, The Children of (All) I≈ørael did Evil in the ≈øight of the Lord, and Served Baalim and Ahtaroth, v. 11, 12. Judg. 10. 6. That is, He-Gods and She-Gods. Idols of all ≈øorts, as the Papi≈øts do Adore their He-Saints, and She-Saints, at this Day: This Corruption of Wor≈øhip brought in (2ly.) Corruption of Manners. (1.) In Neglecting God's Command of Driving out the Canaanites, who became Thorns in their ≈øides, Judg. 2. 2, 3. in their Conver≈øing and Commercing with them, they did draw I≈ørael to Participate both of their Sins and of their Plagues. (2.) In Contracting Marriages with tho≈øe Canaanites, (they thus ≈øpared again≈øt God's Command, Jo≈øh. 23. 13.) Judg. 3. 4, 6. expre≈øly contrary to God's Law, Exod. 34. 16. Deut. 7. 3. Tho≈øe Interchangeable Matches marr'd their
Manners, and produced many Enormities, as (3.) that Prodigious Sodomy and Villany in Gibeah afore≈øaid. Yea (4.) Ob≈øtinacy in their Impieties, Judg. 2. 19. They would Per≈øi≈øt and Per≈øevere in their Stubborn way, and would not Repent either (1) at the Rebuke of the Angel, Chri≈øt, who had offer'd Him≈øelf to be Captain of the Lord's Ho≈øt, Jo≈øh. 5. 13, 14. and had led the Field in all the Wars of Jo≈øhua, yea, and of Judah too, till he ≈øpared the Canaanites, Judg. 1. 18. 19. for this (and other Sins) the Angel of the Covenant did Reproove them, Judg. 2. 1, 2 and for this, Departs from them. Hereupon the People fall a Weeping (as they had good cau≈øe) for the lo≈øs of ≈øuch a Captain-General as Chri≈øt, and call'd the place Bochim, that is Weeping, v. 4, 5. yet this ble≈ø≈øed and Hart-bleeding Frame was ≈øoon lo≈øt, for they For≈øook the Lord, v. 12. and Corrupted them≈øelves, v. 19. and Stubbornly Walked in their own Wicked Ways. Neither would they Repent (2) at the Reproof of the Prophet, whom Chri≈øt (though Him≈øelf was gone) ≈øent with a Me≈ø≈øage, Judg. 10. 11, 12, 13, 14. Thus I≈ørael having broke both the Tables of the Law. The 2d. thing, to wit, Puni≈øhment mu≈øt follow, as the Thread follows the Needle; God is Angry (though Satan is pleas'd) and God's Anger brings Revenge, God ≈øold his People into the Hands of their Enemies, Judg. 2. 14. and 3. 8. and 4. 2, &c. that is, he Renounc'd
his Right in them, writing Lo-Ammi on them, he gave them over as the Seller doth the Matter Sold into the Hands of the Buyer, (yet, without that Complement, I wi≈øh you good of it,) or as the Turk ≈øells his Slaves, and the Conquerour his Captives; And this is Aggravated in Two Circum≈øtances. 1. God made not his Be≈øt of them, but took his fir≈øt Chap-man, (as the Pope gave England, upon the Aboli≈øhing of Abbies, primo occupaturo, to the fir≈øt that could Conquer it, which, he thought, might ea≈øily be done, and won, when he withdrew his Protecting Papal Benediction from it, and put his charming Cur≈øe upon it,) God Sold his People for nought, and did not encrea≈øe his Wealth by their Price, P≈øal. 44. 12, 13. he plainly gave them away gratis, for whom he was wont to give great Nations, I≈øa. 43. 3. They had ≈øold them≈øelves as Ahab did, 1 Kin. 21, 20. to work Wickedne≈øs, I≈øa. 50. 1. and now they are ≈øold by the Lord al≈øo: And as they had ≈øold them≈øelves for nought, I≈øa. 52.3. ≈øo they are ≈øold by God for nought, he had not ≈øo much as Thanks from the Enemy, and as little from the Devil that ≈øet them on: 2ly. They were ≈øold, as to the fir≈øt, ≈øo to the wor≈øt Chapmen, not to their Brethren, who would have ≈øhown ≈øome pitty, as the I≈øraelites did to Benjamin, Judg. 21. 2, 3, 6, 7, 15, 16, 17, 22. nor to Strangers comming in as Conquerors, for then common Humanity would have
taught them ≈øome Mercy: but unto ≈øuch Neighbouring Enemies, as they had highly Incen≈øed in their former Wars, and therefore breath'd forth nothing but the wor≈øt of Rage and Revenge again≈øt them, Judg. 7. 3.

Here the Devils De≈øign again≈øt the Church was promi≈øing and pro≈øperous, and no doubt, he had a fair Pro≈øpect of this Plot; yet the Lord (notwith≈øtanding all) Laughs all to Nothing, and Works (which is the 2d. thing) the Church's Deliverance from this Danger; for (1.) though they were ≈øold as Slaves to their Adver≈øary, yet even then were they precious as Sons to their God, I≈øa. 50. 1, 10. Though the Mother had Divorc'd her ≈øelf, yet God owns him≈øelf the Husband, and he owns them to be his Children, yea, Children of light, even then, when they Walked in Darkne≈øs: And though they had ≈øold them≈øelves for nought, he would (accordingly) Redeem them without Money, I≈øa. 52. 3. and love them freely, Ho≈ø. 14.4. (2) Though the Church was then under great Di≈øtre≈øs, Judg, 2. 15. and 4. 3. (God Strengthening their Enemies, Iudg. 3. 12. as Ezek. 30. 24. and weakening their Arms and Armies, and God Pro≈øpering that Wickedne≈øs in their Adver≈øaries, which he Puni≈øhed in them, being Profe≈ø≈øors) yet had ≈øhe (as oft) great Deliverances, as many Salves as Sores upon their Repentance; God had one Hand to Help them, as well as another to hurt them,
pittying his People for his own ≈øake, he Rais'd them up Iudges, Iudg. 2. 15. 16. as Othniel, Ehud, Shamgar, Deborah, Gedion, Tola, Jair, Jephtah, Ibzan, Elon, Abdon, and Samp≈øon, all Twelve to ≈øave his Church, one by an Oxe Goad, as Shamgar, another by the Jaw-Bone of an A≈øs, as Sam≈øon; and Gideon was but a Barley-Cake, Judg. 7. 13. God never ≈øtarves his Church for want either of In≈øtruments or of Agents. (3) Though the Church was oft Sighing, yet as oft Singing: God goes in a Circle with her, as oft as ≈øhe Repented of her Sins, ≈øo oft God Repented of his Judgements, Judg. 2. 18. and quite through the Book of Iudges. The whole Hi≈øtory of the Book of Judges for 450 Y. the Church lived all that time (as may be ≈øaid) at the Sign of the Chequer. God Chequered his Providences towards her with the Black of Mi≈øery, and with the White of Mercy, and all Chequer'd Work is accounted Beautiful Work: God Speckled his Di≈øpen≈øations to his Church, as is ≈øet forth by tho≈øe ≈øpeckl'd Hor≈øes among the Myrtle Trees in the bottom, Zech. 1. 8. Cro≈ø≈øes and Comforts are Interwooven while ≈øhe is in her Militant-≈øtate in this Vale of Mi≈øery, and Valley of Tears, P≈øal. 84. 6. God hath ≈øet the one over-again≈øt the other, Eccle≈ø. 7. 14. As there is a Vici≈ø≈øitude of Night and Day, ≈øo of Adver≈øity and Pro≈øperity. God turns the Church's Night into Day, and the ∆≤pright hath Dominion
in the Morning, P≈øal. 49. 14. No ≈øooner doth the Church alter her cour≈øe from Sin, and Return to God by Repentance, but pre≈øently God alters his cour≈øe from Wrath, and returns to Her with his Mercy, Zech. 1. 16. Oh that it were the pre≈øent practice (as it was then the Continual Cour≈øe of God with his Church, and his Church with him) in this our Day; God would ≈øoon turn our Mourning into Mirth, Heavine≈øs might endure for the Night, but Joy would come in the Morning, P≈øal. 30. 5: No Doubt, but God Wi≈øhes his Church's Welfare, (as the Loving Bridegroom doth his Beloved Bride's,) otherwi≈øe He had never Sighed out tho≈øe ≈øad Words, [Oh! that my People had Hearkened unto me, &c. I ≈øhould ≈øoon have Subdued their Enemies, &c.] P≈øal. 81. 13, 14, 15, 16. God, with a bare turn of his Hand can overturn both the Many and the Mighty of them, and Re≈øcue his Little Ones out of all their Hands, Zech. 13. 7. I≈øa. 25. 11. none ≈øhall Pluck them out of Chri≈øts and His Fathers Hands, Joh. 10. 28. 29.

argument.p: The Thirteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.
div.p:
THe Church's Re≈øtle≈øs Wretched Adver≈øary, Satan, ≈øeeing he cannot ≈øtill Hinder the Being of God's Church, Trys again his 13th. Experiment again≈øt the Well-Being of it, and that once more before I≈øraels Ari≈øtocracy was chang'd into Monarchy, to wit, in the time of Eli and Samuel the Two la≈øt Judges of I≈ørael; yet ≈øuch was the Over-ruling Providence of God above the Devil, that whatever Ground he Won upon the Church in Old Eli's Male-Admini≈øtration, he Lo≈øt it All again in Young Samuel's Godly Reformation. So that here again Divine Di≈øpen≈øations towards the Church (concerning Sorrows and Joys) were mo≈øt beautifully Chequered with Interchangeable Colours: Magi≈øtracy is, what the Pole is to the Hop, or the Tree to the Ivy, or the Wall to the Vine; the former gives Support to the latter, which cannot
≈øtand alone without ≈øomething to Su≈øtain them: The Church's Word to the State, is, [Te Stante Virebo,] While thou Stands, I Flouri≈øh. This Ble≈ø≈øed Nail (as Eliakim, that Godly Magi≈øtrate) Keeps all the Ve≈ø≈øels of the Lord ≈øtedfa≈øtly, and Holds them from falling to the Ground, I≈øa. 22. 24. This the Devil knew well, and therefore play'd his Pranks again≈øt the Church in that Interval of Magi≈øtracy betwixt Jo≈øhuah and the Judges, in which Inter≈øpace Satan wrought and brought down I≈ørael to that gro≈øs Idolatry, Impiety and Apo≈øtacy, mentioned in the Five la≈øt Chapters of the Book of Judges. The Stories whereof there Related (that the Hi≈øtory of the following Judges might be continued without any Interruption, as before) did all Befall I≈ørael ≈øoon after Jo≈øhuah, and ≈øome 100's of Y. before Samp≈øon, whom this Eli immediately ≈øucceeded, unle≈øs we make Phinehas (mentioned in Iudg. 20. 28.) to live far beyond Mo≈øes term, P≈øal. 90. 10. even above 300 Y. who was at Mans e≈øtate at his Killing Zimri and Cozbi in the Wilderne≈øs, and therefore could not out-live Sam≈øon.

Although Eli was a Godly Man, and both Judge over Civil, and High-Prie≈øt over Eccle≈øia≈øtick Affairs, and ≈øo had a mo≈øt Precious Price put into his Hands for promoting the
Church's Weal, yet the Devil made a Fool of him, ≈øo that he hath no Heart to it, Prov. 17. 10. and this Satan did Accompli≈øh, (1.) by Prompting him to too much Indulgency towards his Di≈ø≈øolute Sons. 2ly. by Tempting him to a too much Neglect of his own Duty towards them, and that in his Threefold Capacity. 1. As a Father. 2. As the High-Prie≈øt. 3. As the Chief Magi≈øtrate or Judge. 1≈øt. As a Father. So the Devil made u≈øe of his Candid Con≈øtitution, and his ≈øweet Natural Di≈øpo≈øition, even to a Cockering of his Sons, and to a too much Tenderne≈øs towards them (as he did David's afterwards towards His, 1 Kin. 1. 6. &c.) both in their Younger and Elder years: over-much Mercy marrs many a Child, Pro. 13. 24. and 23. 13, 14. 'Tis likely, Eli had always been a Fond Father to his Sons, and brought them up in his Doting Indulgency, till he brings down his Hou≈øe by their Diabolical Impiety‚ñ™ 2ly. As High-Prie≈øt, which added more Authority to him over his Wicked Sons, yet doth he ≈øo gently Reproove them for their Sins, (≈øo exceeding ≈øinful, even to Black Sins under a White Ephod,) as if he had been Afraid to Hurt them, 1 Sam. 2. 22, 23. A Gentle Reproof can never be a Salve broad and ≈øharp, enough for ≈øuch a Sore as is Notorious and Abominable Wickedous; He did it (as Hierom ≈øaith) [Lenitate patris, non Authoritate ponti≈øicis,] by the Gentle Lenity of a Father, not by
the grave and Severe Authority of an High-Prie≈øt, who ≈øhould have expell'd them out of their Sacred Function, for their ≈øinful Practices, and Excommunicated them out of the Church of God. 3. As the Judge or Chief Magi≈øtrate, which gave him power (mo≈øt of all) to puni≈øh tho≈øe pro≈øligate Varlets, yet he onely Shaves the Head, which De≈øerved Cutting off; he ≈øhould have puni≈øh'd them for their Adultery, (they having Wives of their own, 1 Sam. 4. 19.) according to the Law, yet comes off onely with [Why do ye ≈øuch things, and Nay my Sons, &c.] whereas he ≈øhould have In≈øtanc'd and Aggravated their evil Doings, for their Shame and Horror, and Executed Ju≈øtice upon them as Degenerate Sons of Belial‚ñ™ rather than of Eli, 1 Sam. 2.23. 24. 25, &c. Hereupon he is blamed for Gratifying his Sons more then Glorifying God, v. 29 chu≈øing rather to plea≈øe them than him, and not puni≈øhing tho≈øe prophane Prie≈øts, either by Eccle≈øia≈øtick Cen≈øures, or by Civil Penalties, Fearing (po≈ø≈øibly) lea≈øt by this means the High-Prie≈øthood ≈øhould go from his Family of Ithamar, as it had from Eleazar's for the like Mi≈ødemeanour) which al≈øo did befall him afterwards, 1 Kin. 1. 26. 1 Chron. 29. 22. Thus Eli by ≈øeeking to prevent that Evil, (in an evil manner and by evil means) did the ≈øooner procure it. For God became highly Di≈øplea≈øed, and the Devil took this Advantage,
and powr'd in three Grand Mi≈øchiefs and Maladies upon the Church of God, (all which had mo≈øt Ble≈ø≈øed Remedies in Samuel, Succe≈ø≈øor to Eli,) to wit, (1.) The Abhorring of the Lord's Sacrifice. (2.) The Failure of all Prophetick Vi≈øions. (3.) The Captivity of the Ark by the Phili≈øtines. 1≈øt. Of the 1≈øt. Tho≈øe Pro≈øligate Prie≈øts made the People to abhorr the Offerings of the Lord, 1 Sam. 2. 17. and to Tran≈øgre≈øs, v. 24. where the Prophane Clergy (≈øo called) laid a Stumbling-Block before the Sober Laity, not onely in their ≈øinning ≈øo pre≈øumptuou≈øly (and ≈øcaping Scot-free in ≈øo Doing,) again≈øt God him≈øelf, and Di≈øhonouring the Lord in prophaning his Wor≈øhip and Abu≈øing his Ordinances: but al≈øo in giving ≈øuch an evil Example to God's People by their wicked Practices, (whom they ≈øhould have In≈øtructed in the good ways of God according to their Office) ≈øo as to make them withdraw from God's Wor≈øhip, when they ≈øaw it ≈øo much prophaned by their Impieties. This God Complains of (as a Spiritual lo≈øs to his Peoples Souls) more than of the Honour of his own Name di≈øhonoured thereby: Hence 'tis ≈øaid the People Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed in Neglecting to come to God's Wor≈øhip in Shilo; The Men would not come, while tho≈øe prophane Prie≈øts Theevi≈øhly and Sacrilegiou≈øly Abu≈øed God's Sacrifice, 1 Sam. 2. 13, to 16. And the Women durst not come for Fear of a Rape, v. 22. for tho≈øe lewd lo≈øels
(though they had Wives of their own) were ≈øick of a Pluri≈øie for knowing more Women. And like the Devil their Ma≈øter, lov'd to Sow their Seed upon other Mens Ground, Matth. 13. 25. The 2d. Malady was The Failure of Prophecy in tho≈øe licentious times of Eli, 1 Sam. 3. 2. The Word of the Lord was Precious in tho≈øe Days, though there was ≈øome ≈øecret Vi≈øion as to Manoah and his Wife, Judg. 13. yet there was no open Vi≈øion, the Spirit of Prophecy was Rare and Scarce, and therefore Pretious, [Rara, Praeclara] in tho≈øe Days of Dete≈øtable Debauchery, and both Neglect and Contempt of God's Wor≈øhip, for which God Inflicted this fore Judgement upon them, that they ≈øhould have a Famine of the Word, Amos 8. 12. and that there ≈øhould not be a Prophet among them, nor any that could tell them how long, P≈øal. 74. 9. 'Tis very ≈øad with the Church, when there is a Sealing up of Prophecy, Dan. 12. 4. and ≈øhe is plainly benighted in this way-le≈øs Wilderne≈øs: This Darkne≈øs upon I≈ørael, (who were Children of light and of the Day, 1 The≈ø≈ø. 5. 5. could not but plea≈øe the Prince of Darkne≈øs, and give him both light and fight of the Succe≈øs of his Plot, to make them both ≈øtumble and fall, Joh. 3. 20. 1 Joh. 2. 11. The 3d. Malady is, the Captivity of the Ark, which was fir≈øt Touched, (for which ∆≤zzah peri≈øhed, 2 Sam. 6, 6. 7.) and al≈øo taken by the Hands of the Uncircumci≈øed,
1 Sam. 4. 11. which made the Wife of Phinehas to cry out, [Ichabod] that Glory was departed from I≈ørael; the greatne≈øs of her Grief made her Repeat it Twice, v. 21, 22. ≈øeeing the Sign of God's pre≈øence and Protection, (which was therefore call'd their Glory, P≈øal. 78. 61. the Face of God, P≈øal. 105. 4. Yea, God him≈øelf, P≈øal 122. 5.) was carried Captive, as if the Devil had been too ≈øtrong for God, and as if God could keep the Ark no longer, but was Con≈øtrained to let it go out of Canaan into the Countrey of the Phili≈øtines, who verily Thought they had taken the God of I≈ørael Pri≈øoner, v. 8. Indeed I≈ørael a≈øcrib'd that Honour to the Ark of God, which was Due onely to God him≈øelf; for upon their Defeat, (knowing no other Cau≈øe, though there was enough, P≈øa. 78. 58, 61, 62, 63. but the want of the Ark.) They ≈øend for it to Shilo, that it might ≈øave them, v. 3, 4. (1) without Con≈øulting with God, (2) they brought it into the Camp without due Reverence, (3) and that by the Hands of Two pro≈ø≈øligate Prie≈øts; All which was more likely to bring a Cur≈øe upon them, and not a Ble≈ø≈øing: When this Ark of Wood was made an Idol by the I≈øraelites, they fare wor≈øe and not better, v. 2, 10. Notwith≈øtanding its pre≈øence (external priviledges re≈øted and Tru≈øted in, are more De≈øtructive than Saving, Rom. 2. 9.) and God ju≈øtly ≈øuffers it to be taken from them by the Phili≈øtines.

Now the Devil having got the Ark of God into his own Temple, to wit, the Temple of Dagon, (which they had Rebuilt, ≈øince Sam≈øon pull'd it Down, Judg. 16. 23, 25.) and the Two Cherubims now Spreading their Wings under the Roof of an Ugly Image (Half a Fi≈øh and Half a Man,) no doubt, but he had a further and fairer Pro≈øpect of pro≈øpering in his Project; yet even Then God Awakes, (who had been A≈øleep, as it were, all this time, P≈øal. 78. 65, 60.) puts forth his Power, Beats Dagon upon his own Dunghill, yea, Beats him down to the Ground, as if he had met his Wor≈øhippers to Wor≈øhip them, and falls down to them, that came the next Morning to fall down to him, 1 Sam. 5. 3. and when their Super≈øtition had made them more Sen≈øele≈øs than their Sen≈øele≈øs Idol, P≈øal. 115. 8. they become Patrons to their God, and (as if it had been onely a Chance) Helps him up into his place. He is a mi≈øerable God that cannot Ri≈øe alone, but ≈øtands in need of Helping up by his own Wor≈øhippers, and craves more Help from them than ever he could give to them: Dagon is again rais'd up into His Rood-loft to Affront the Ark, and hath tho≈øe very hands lifted up to him, which had helped to lift him up. Will a Jealous God (who Winks and ≈øits ≈øtill on purpo≈øe to behold their mad Folly and ≈øtupid Confidence, and to Fetch about his own Glory) put up this Injury? ≈øhall this Lifele≈øs
Stone continue as a ≈øit Companion with the Living God, and ≈øcape Scot-free with an Harmle≈øs Fall? No, God cannot Brook Corrivals, Dagon Falls again and Breaks his Neck, His Head (the Seat of Wi≈ødom,) and His Hands (the Seat of Power) were both Cutt off, v. 4. to ≈øhew them their God could neither Con≈øult nor Act for them; yea, God had chopp'd them off upon the Thre≈øhold of his own Temple, (as a Cook ≈øometimes doth the Head and Leggs of a great Fowl for his Ma≈øters Dinner) and now tho≈øe that came to Wor≈øhip him, might Tread tho≈øe parts (they mo≈øt Tru≈øted in) under foot, as un≈øavoury Salt, and Dagon was now no better than a Dunghill-Deity: They might now ≈øet their Foot upon the be≈øt parts of their Idol; whereon they had ≈øet their Heart, and now tho≈øe chiefe≈øt pieces met them at the Thre≈øhold to tell them how much they were mi≈øtaken in their Headle≈øs, Handle≈øs, and ever Footle≈øs God, Nothing but the Stump remained, to wit, the Fi≈øhy part that had no Feet, and that al≈øo ≈øadly Brui≈øed and Battered by the Fall. And becau≈øe tho≈øe ob≈øtinate Idolaters, in≈øtead of giving Glory to God who had De≈øtroy'd their Idol, gave Honour to the Thre≈øhold which their Dagon had Touched, v. 5. (whereby, however, God perpetuated the Memory of the Miracle in the minds of Po≈øterity) as if the Broken Head and Hands of the Idol had Hallowed it, They had it in
great Veneration. Thus the Pagans of Old Ki≈ø≈øed the Thre≈øhold of their Temples, and the Papagans at this Day do Ki≈øs the Thre≈øhold of Peters-Church in Rome, when they enter into it. Suppo≈øe it were done (as ≈øome ≈øay) by way of Dete≈øtation, and not by way of Veneration, as Dear Relations will Dete≈øt to touch that Sword wherewith their neer Friend hath been Murthered: yet even ≈øo the Romani≈øts do Symbolize with tho≈øe Uncircumci≈øed, ina≈ømuch as the Pope in his Solemn Proce≈ø≈øion declineth to Walk that Street in Rome, wherein Pope Joan was Delivered, as a Street unhappy to the Credit of their Church: Thus the Prie≈øts of the Devil might forbear to Tread upon the Thre≈øhold that was ≈øo Unhappy as to break the Head and Hands of their Suppo≈øed Deity: However, the Lord was Angry, for no better Improoving the Fall of their Idol, (neither the fir≈øt nor ≈øecond) therefore Falls he foul upon them≈øelves, pays their Po≈øteriours like ≈øo many Puniboys, and Plagues them with Emrods, yea, and (as ≈øome think) with the Foul Di≈øea≈øe, and likewi≈øe with Mice, that Marr'd their Land, (as the Blind Piles Marr'd them≈øelves.) Their Dagon could not drive ≈øo much as a poor Mou≈øe from them; in≈øomuch that their own Mouths Confe≈ø≈øed, [The Lord's Hand is ≈øore upon us, and upon Dagon our God.] v. 7. The Ark is too Hot for them to Hold; They carry the Ark of God,
(and with it the Plague of God) up and down to their Neighbours, any whither they would bear it, rather than Home to I≈ørael; until God forced them to yield, ≈øaying, Let the Ark Return to its own place, v. 11. Yea, and that City which fir≈øt ≈øaid ≈øo, fared the be≈øt, for the Men there Dyed not as they did in other Cities. Thus God's Revenge Works out [Nolens, Volens,] the Ark's Return, and not without a Tre≈øpa≈øs-Offering, though Ridiculous, ≈øuch as Satan (in Contempt of God) had ≈øugge≈øted to their Diviners, 1 Sam. 6. 2, 4. The Ark is carryed Home by two Untamed and Untrained Kine, that had Calves at Home, (which, Naturally, they break through All to come at) and that without a Driver; All this made the Miracle greater: God (Him≈øelf) drove the Cart, and made the Kine know their Owner, I≈øa. 1. 3. which Hophni and Phinehas (Two Prie≈øts had not done, 1 Sam. 2. 12. This was (no doubt) The Fruit of Samuel's Pray'r, (in whom the Lord Re≈øtored the lo≈øt Spirit of Prophecy; hence is he called the fir≈øt of the Prophets after that Failure, Act. 3. 24. Hebr. 11. 32.) and of I≈ørael that Lamented after the Ark, not being Contented with an Empty Tabernacle, but thought them≈øelves forlorn without the Ark in it. Thus Gracious was God to his poor People to make the pre≈øence of the Pri≈øoner (the Ark) Grievous to the Phili≈øtines, and being ≈øet at Liberty, Joyful to I≈ørael: Even ≈øo
