will the Lord do with all tho≈øe that Deal thu with the Go≈øpel, as they did with the Ark, he will make them Smart for it, and Laugh all their Plots to Nothing, E≈øpecially, if God give his Samuels to his Church, that cea≈øe not to Cry to the Lord for her, at her Reque≈øt, 1 Sam. 7. 8, 9. And the Spirit of Repentance be powr'd out upon his People, ≈øo that All (Univer≈øally) Lament after the Lord, even with Storms of Sighs, and Shours of Tears (though after 20 Y. Bondage and Back≈ølidings, v. 2, to 6. Weeping before the Lord abundantly, that their Sorrowing might be proportionable to their Sinning. Samuel's Sermons to I≈ørael, in his Itinerary Circuits, wrought ≈øo powerfully upon them, as to fetch Groans out of their Hearts, Tears out of their Eyes, Vows out of their Mouths, and Idols out of their Hands. Oh! for ≈øuch a Divine Di≈øpen≈øation in our Day; then though the Five Lords of the Phili≈øtines, 1 Sam. 6. 16. tho≈øe Five Lords in the Tower do Plot again≈øt us, and A≈ø≈øault us in our Fa≈øting and Praying; If our Samuels do but Cry, (as he was Excellent at that Work, P≈øal. 99. 6. Jer. 15. 1.) and Offer up the Lamb of God with their Prayers, (as he did, v. 7, 9.) God will Hear, and Thunder upon them with a great Thunder, as v. 10. and Ch. 2. 10. and Jo≈øh. 10. 10. Judg. 4. 15. and ≈ømite them ≈øo (at Beth-car, the Hou≈øe of the Lamb) as to make them come no more, v. 10, 11, 12, 13. the ≈øame God is our Eben-Ezor, or Stone of Help, v. 12.

argument.p: The Fourteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.
div.p:
WHen God had Graciou≈øly given a Suitable Remedy to that great Malady (by Eli's Sons) in Holy Samuel, and ≈øo had E≈øtabli≈øh'd his Church, Ark, and Wor≈øhip again; Satan play'd his Pranks, and plys his Plots again, in the Days of Saul, David, and Solomon. 1≈øt. of Saul. The Wicked One (never Idle) Debauches Samuel's Sons, (as he had done Eli's) notwith≈øtanding their ≈øtricter Education, (Samuel could not well be guilty of that Sin of fond Indulgency, which he, from God, had Reprooved in Eli.) This gave the Occa≈øion to I≈ørael for changing their Ari≈øtocracy (or rather, Theocracy, 1 Sam. 8. 7.) into a Monarchy, and Saul (of Wicked Gibeah, Judg. 19.) was ≈øet over them, for his Stature, (as David was after, for his Heart.) Saul at fir≈øt Reigned (as a King) well and Orderly, but being Rejected of God for Di≈øobedience,
he turn'd a Tyrant, and Rul'd with Rigour, 1 Sam. 13. 1. with 14. 47. Then the Spirit of the Lord departed from Saul, and an evil Spirit from the Devil (by the Lord's leave) po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed him, Ch. 16. 14. which ca≈øt him into Fits of Phrenzy and Fury. Here began the 1≈øt. Branch of this 14th. Plot in Saul's Reign, as the other Two did in David's and Solomon's, which all Three (in Conjunction) makes up this 14th. Diabolical de≈øign again≈øt the Church of God. By I≈øraels 1≈øt. King, Satan labours to Hinder the Church; By the 2d. God Advances her; By the 3d. God brought her to her greate≈øt Glory. 1st. In Saul; who at his fir≈øt Entry quitted him≈øelf nobly, in the overthrow of I≈øraels Enemies; but when ≈øcarce well warm in his Kingdom, he Hears of lo≈øing it, 1. For his Incroaching into the Prie≈øts Office of Sacrifi≈øing, 1 Sam. 13. 8, 9, 13, 14. where his di≈øtru≈øt made him praecipitant, he ≈øhould have ≈øtay'd for Samuel one Hour or two longer; had he done ≈øo, his Kingdom had been E≈øtabli≈øh'd upon him, but his Rotten Heart was Di≈øcover'd by this Delay, and his Doing fooli≈øhly in Thru≈øting him≈øelf among the Prie≈øts as he had done among the Prophets, procures him tydings of its Tran≈ølation to Another who≈øe Heart was ∆≤pright, P≈øal. 57. 7. and who would do all Gods wills, Act. 13. 22. 2ly. For his ≈øparing Agag with his Amalekites and Cattel, contrary to God's expre≈øs Command, 1 Sam. 15. 2,
3, 8, 9, 26, 28. out of fooli≈øh pitty to his fellow-King he ≈øpared the one, and becau≈øe he Feared the People, he ≈øpared the other; therefore Samuel ≈øaid to him, The Lord hath Rejected thee, &c. And this Doubly Declared Rejection, brings him into a ≈øad Melancholick Dejection. Di≈øcontent is called the Devil's Bath, wherein he Delights to Wade. The old Man-≈ølayer takes this Advantage, and turns his Melancholly-dumps into a mad Phrenzy, ina≈ømuch as in his frantick Fits he Tran≈øports him outragiou≈øly to Slay all in his way, Friends as well as Foes, even his own dear Jonathan once, Ch. 20. 33. as well as his De≈øerving David often, ≈øometimes covertly, as Ch. 18. 17, 25. and ≈øometimes overtly, as v. 11. and Ch. 19. 10. The Devil (that Evil Spirit po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing him,) had filled Saul's Heart from Corner to Corner with his own Di≈øea≈øe, to wit, Envy (which is call'd Morbus Satanicus & Vitium Diabolicum,) again≈øt David, whom he knew God had Rai≈øed up to Rai≈øe up the low E≈øtate of His Church, 1 Sam. 24. 20. Yet (by the over-ruling Hand of God.) The Spirit of the Lord that re≈øted upon David from his fir≈øt Anointing, ch. 10. 13. (by the power of which he Kill'd a Bear and a Lyon, Chap. 17. 34.) was all along too hard for Sauls Devil, not only when Davids Mu≈øick drove away Sauls Melancholly, Chap. 16. 23. but al≈øo in all Sauls both Secret Craft and open Cruelty: 1≈øt. In
his Craft; How many Plots did the Devil (in Saul) contrive to cut off David from advancing the Church, yet God Laughs them all to nothing; and 'tis very Remarkable‚ñ™ God Extracts Happy Remedies out of the very Loins of Wretched Saul again≈øt all Davids ∆≤nhappy Maladies; once Michal, and often Jonathan, Sauls own Son and Daughter. God makes u≈øe of his own Children to di≈øappoint him of his Wicked De≈øign, and to deliver Innocent David, whom he fooli≈øhly followed as his Adver≈øary, Chap. 19. 2, 4, 12, 13, &c. and 20. 27, 29, 30. 34, to 42. Jonathan ≈øhot over David that Saul might ≈øhoot ≈øhort of him. And 2dly. in his Cruelty, When he threw his Javelin three times to Kill David, yet the Lord Interpo≈øes as oft, and he who Guided the Stone (which David did ≈øling) unto Goliah's Forehead for his De≈øtruction, Diverts Sauls Javelin from Davids Body, (though a fairer Mark and nearer hand) for his Deliverance: This was Sauls Cordolium or Heart-ake, when he could not come at and compa≈øs Davids Heart to de≈øtroy it, (who≈øe onely Fault was Faithfulne≈øs, and who mu≈øt dye, onely becau≈øe he made I≈ørael Live.) Saul (as is the Nature of Envy) feeds upon his own heart, Ch. 18. 12, 15. Invidia Siculi non Inven√™re Tyranni majus Tormentum. Envy exceeds all the Torments the Tyrants of Sicily ever Invented; it de≈øtroys its own Habitation, as the Worm doth the Nut wherein it is bred.
Thus God made Saul his own Inward Executioner (by ≈øending this Fire into his Bo≈øom to burn him, and this Worm to be continually gnawing upon his Intrals) long before he was his own Outward Executioner, at la≈øt. And Sauls Frantick Devil did not hurry him into Outragious Cruelty again≈øt David onely, but again≈øt the Prie≈øts of the Lord, for ≈øhewing kindne≈øs to David, Chap. 22. 12, 13, 16, &c. Oh what a Mad Phren≈øy was manife≈øt in his cruel Commi≈ø≈øion! [Turn and ≈ølay the Prie≈øts of the Lord, Ver. 17. His malice was bent again≈øt the Lord him≈øelf, for taking away his Kingdom and giving it to another, and becau≈øe he could not come at the Lord (who was out of his reach) he ≈øpends his Spleen and vents his mad Fury upon his Prie≈øts: 'Tis a wonder, that the very Word [the Prie≈øts of the Lord] in his Mouth, did not make his Hands tremble to Murther them, and that without two or three Witne≈ø≈øes according to the Law, but only upon the bare ≈øingle Te≈øtimony of a falie and flattering Sycophant; hence ≈øome ≈øay, that this Damnable Hypocrite (Saul) did commit herein, the Sin again≈øt the Holy Gho≈øt, Ma≈ø≈øacreing ≈øuch a multitude of Innocents, as 8, Prie≈øts, as the Scripture, and 300 per≈øons more, as Jo≈øephus tells us, Chap. 18. ver. 18, 19. and though his own Servants dur≈øt not do ≈øuch a Villany, ver≈ø. 17. obeying God rather then the King, yet Doeg (that bloody Edomite of
E≈øau) that had been as far in Gods Sanctuary as David, Chap. 21. 7. ≈øticks not at this De≈øperate Villany; yet in this Horrid Act of Cruelty, God baffles the Devil that acted Saul and (his Swine-herd) Doeg in two re≈øpects. 1≈øt. While this ba≈øe and bloody Wretch and his Ma≈øter thought of nothing but Revenge, and ≈øatiating both their barbarous and bruti≈øh, yea, Devili≈øh Blood-thir≈øtine≈øs, they are Unwittingly made the Executioners of Gods Determined Coun≈øel, and ju≈øtly declared ≈øentence of God again≈øt Eli's Family, Chap. 3. 31, to 37. 2dly. As they ≈øerved Gods Glory, ≈øo they ≈øent David Comfort: Abiathar God marvelou≈øly hid from their bloody hands, he e≈øcapes them according to Gods promi≈øe of pre≈øerving ≈øome of Eli's Hou≈øe, Chap. 2. 33. and comes to David with the Ephod in his hand, Chap. 22. 20. and 23. 6. This Ephod had the Brea≈øt plate with the Urim and Thummim in it, Exod 28. 30. The comming of this mu≈øt needs be very comfortable to Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed David; Now he hath an High-Prie≈øt, Abiathar, with him (as well as the Prophet Gad, Chap. 22. 5.) in his Army, by whom he might con≈øult with God in all his Dangers and difficulties, Chap. 23. 2, 4. and often. Saul ≈øtrengthened David more by ≈øending this Ephod, than if he had ≈øent him (as one ≈øaith) many thou≈øand men: And as he ≈øtrengthened David, ≈øo he weakened him≈øelf, as he complains, God an≈øwered him not by ∆≤rim
and Thummim, 1 Sam. 28. 6. He had bereaved him≈øelf of it, by putting Abiathar to the Run, who brings it to David, which was a plain Evidence of Sauls Falling and Davids Ri≈øing: Saul had neither Prie≈øt nor Prophet to con≈øult with (when David had both) Hereupon he con≈øults with a Witch, Flectere Cum Nequeat Superos Acheronta Movebit. If God will not an≈øwer him, the Devil ≈øhall: Satan comes up in Samuels Re≈øemblance, Preaches Sauls Funeral-Sermon, he flies in Battel, falls upon his own Sword, ≈øo like the Candle in the Socket, goes out in a Stink, and (notwith≈øtanding all his Plots he leaves him≈øelf to the Uncircumci≈øed; yea, his Body to a cold Grave, and his Soul to an hot Hell, as an Hypocrite, Matt. 24. 51. and leaves his Kingdom to David.

The 2d. Branch of this 14th. That in the Church Triumphant in Heaven there ≈øhall be no ≈øorrows nor ≈øufferings, all noi≈øe of fears and tears ≈øhall be done away, the State then ≈øhall be peaceable and joyful, for which the Saints are fitted by the Hammer of Gods Word, and the Hand of his Spirit upon the Mountains of this lower World, there to enjoy re≈øt and glory: The Sanctum Sanctorum of the Temple or Oracle (≈øo called, becau≈øe there God u≈øed to deliver Divine An≈øwers or Oracles, Exod. 30. 5. and Levit. 16. 2.) was the place prepared for the Ark of the Covenant to re≈øt in, after its many removes and wandrings, 1. From the De≈øart to Gilgal. 2. From Gilgal to Shilo. 3. From Shilo to the Phili≈øtims. 4. From thence to Beth≈øheme≈øh. 5. From thence to Kiriath Jearim. 6. From thence to the Hou≈øe of Obed-Edom; And 7. From thence to Sion, the City of David: Now Solomon provides a re≈øting place, to
wit, the be≈øt part of the Temple (the Holy of Holies) for this be≈øt and mo≈øt precious piece (which had the Law within it, and the Mercy-Seat upon it) far more precious than the Palladium at Troy, the Pe≈ø≈øinuntium at Rome, or the Image at Athens (made by Canetias the Artificer, yet ≈øaid by the covetous Prie≈øts to be dropt down from Jupiter, Act. 19. 35.) as it was the principal Evidence of Gods gracious pre≈øence, and the lively Type of Chri≈øt, in whom are hid (as in an Ark or Coffer) all the Trea≈øures of Gods goodne≈øs, Col. 2. 3. So that when Solomon dedicates his glorious Fabrick (which, as Jo≈øephus ≈øaith, dazled the eyes of all its beholders) by Sacrifice and Supplication he concludes his Prayer, ≈øaying, Ari≈øe now therefore, O Lord God, into thy re≈øting place, thou and the Ark of thy ≈øtrength, 2 Chron. 6. 41. whereby he invites the Lord to take po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Temple, where his Ark ≈øhould be no more tran≈øportative, but ≈øetled for a long ≈øea≈øon, P≈øal. 1 ‚Ä¢ 2. 8, 9, 10. And the Lord te≈øtifies his acceptation of all, both by Fire from Heaven, (which was kept alive till the Captivity of Babylon) and by filling the Hou≈øe with his Glory. 2 Chro. 7. 1. Now was the Church of God (by his good hand upon her) brought up to ≈øuch a beauty of Holine≈øs, and to ≈øuch a perfection of dazling ≈øplendour (like that of the Temple) that Religion was had in
great Veneration, both by Dome≈øticks and Forreigners. 1. His own I≈ørael went home ≈øo refre≈øhed with the Prayer, and the Ble≈ø≈øing, that they adored the Lord for his goodne≈øs to them, 1 Kin. 8. 66. and both Hiram King of Yyre prai≈øed God for the Ble≈ø≈øing that the Church had in Solomon, 1 Kin. 5. 7. ≈øaying, Becau≈øe the Lord hath loved his people, he hath ≈øet a Solomon over them, 2 Chro. 2. 11. Hence ≈øome verily think this Hiram was a Pro≈øelited Prince; and (2.) Mackeda, Queen of Sheba, coming from a far Country, Mat. 12. 42. falls into an Exta≈øie of admiration, 1 Kin. 10. 5. and coming to her ≈øelf, ≈øhe ble≈ø≈øes the Lord God that had loved I≈ørael ≈øo, as to ≈øet Solomon on the Throne; ≈øaying, the reality of I≈øraels glory (in him) far exceeded all the Reports ≈øhe had received, v. 7. 9. yea, and not only tho≈øe two Forreigners, but even all the Earth ≈øought to Solomon, &c. v. 24. both Princes and People, Ch. 4. 31. 34. The Devil put I≈ørael upon ca≈øting off God, and de≈øiring a King, 1 Sam. 8. 7. Now God u≈øes a King to rai≈øe his Church to her highe≈øt glory. Thus God over-≈øhoots Satan in his own Bow.

argument.p: The Fifteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XV.
div.p:
HAving ≈øhown how the Pillar of Providence hath u≈øher'd and over-≈øhadow'd the Church of this lower World, from Adam to Solomon, in who≈øe Reign ≈øhe arrived at her greate≈øt Splendour and Beauty, notwith≈øtanding all the Devils Fore-games he plaid to prevent it. Now come we to ≈øpeak of his After-games, whereby he brought an abatement of her glory, and a declen≈øion of her lu≈øtre in this her Militant ≈øtate upon Earth: As it is the cour≈øe of Nature, in Coele≈øtial and Terre≈øtrial things, there is a time of their ri≈øing and growth to their perfection, gradually carried on (for Nature makes no leaps) and there is a time of ≈øetting and gradual declining al≈øo: Thus 'tis in Coele≈øtial Bodies, the Sun ri≈øeth and runs its cour≈øe, till it come to its Zenith at High-noon, or Mid-Summer;
and then it de≈øcends and goes lower to the Earth, ob≈øerving its Apogaeum and Perigaeum.

The Moon hath not only her Ortum & occa≈øum, Ri≈øing and Setting, but al≈øo her Plenilunium & Novi lunium, Increa≈øe and Decrea≈øe: and therefore is the Embleme of the Church in ≈øacred Writ, as having her filling and weaning times; and Terre≈øtrial things, both Animate and Inanimate, have their ≈øea≈øons of attaining their perfection both of parts and degrees, and then follows their declining time; yea, the Kingdoms of the World have their times, and their turns, their points and their periods, beyond which they cannot pa≈øs: Even ≈øo it is with the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, his Church: there is nothing here below that can always ≈øay [I am] but the unchangeable God [Go tell Pharaoh that I am hath ≈øent me unto thee, Exod. 3. 14.] The Creator only can ≈øay, I am that I am; but the Creature is to day, and is not to morrow, being a changeable thing: and ≈øo the Church here upon Earth is changeable as the Moon, which hath her Eclip≈øes, her Obumbrations under a black Cloud, and (when ≈øilled round with light borrowed from the Sun) hath her time of a gradual lo≈øing that lu≈øtre again. Thus the Old Te≈øtament Church came to her Full-Moon of light and glory (borrowed from the Sun of Righteou≈øne≈øs, Mal. 4.2.)
∆≤xor fulget Radiis Mariti, the Spou≈øe ≈øhines with the Beams and Bracelets (≈øuch as I≈øaac ≈øent Rebekah, Gen. 24.) of her Bridegroom, Ezek. 16. 14.) in the days of Solomon for about thirty years together. In his la≈øt ten years, the Devil begins his fir≈øt after-game to bring a decrea≈øe of her glory upon her: It is ob≈øervable, that Gods promi≈øe of e≈øtabli≈øhing the Throne of I≈ørael for ever, 2 Sam. 7. 13, 16. as it was Typical (and ≈øo temporary) relating to Chri≈øt, the Son of David, who ≈øhould build a My≈øtical Temple, the Church, called the Hou≈øe of God, 1 Tim. 3. 15. (who≈øe e≈ø≈øential and natural Kingdom ≈øhall never have an end, though his Mediatory hath, 1 Cor. 15. 24. yet not till he hath put down all contrary Powers, and made all his Foes his foot≈øtool) ≈øo it was (2.) Conditional, relating to Solomon, who built the Material Temple which ≈øhould flouri≈øh for ever, upon condition of his per≈øeverance in Piety: [If he commit iniquity, v. 14.] which Solomon did (but Chri≈øt could not) in the latter end of his Reign, by falling into Idolatry, 1 Kin. 11. 9, 14, 23, 26. therefore the Lord corrected him with the Rod of men, by ≈øtirring up Adver≈øaries again≈øt him, which would not have been, had he been con≈øtant, as at that day (when another promi≈øe was propounded upon that condition) in the good ways of God, 1 Chron. 28. 7. Solomon had
been well educated, both by his Father, Prov. 4. 4. and by his Mother, Prov. 31. 1. and at that day (while young) kept the Commandments of the Lord, and brought both Church and State to the highe≈øt point of ≈øublunary happine≈øs: So that as Davids Reign repre≈øented the Church Militant upon Earth, ≈øo Solomons Reign re≈øembled the Church Triumphant in Heaven: yet as man that is in honour abideth not, P≈øal. 49. 12. ≈øo Solomon (according to the manner of all temporal things, and by the means of mans corruption) abode not in this Honourable and happy e≈øtate, but when he was old, 1 Kin. 11. 4. and then ≈øhould he have been be≈øt, Job 32. 7. Having had ≈øo long Communion with God, and ≈øo much experience of his goodne≈øs in his appearing to him twice after an extraordinary manner, which was a great Evidence of Divine favour, and laid a great ingagement upon him to cleave clo≈øe to God, who twice appeared, 1 Kin. 3. 5. and 9. 2. and 11. 9. Some make Solomon's old age the extenuation of his ≈øin, ina≈ømuch as it brings along with it many weakne≈ø≈øes, which expo≈øed him to be over-witted by Outlandi≈øh Women, upon which he ≈øo fondly doted: But ≈øurely his Age was an aggravation of his ≈øin, his la≈øt days ≈øhould have been his be≈øt days, and his Graces (like good liquor) ≈øhould have run fre≈øh to the bottom: Some do give
the Flower of their Youth to the Devil, and re≈øerve the Dregs of their Old Age for God. This is bad enough; but Solomon did far wor≈øe, in doing quite contrary, as if he expected to find the Devil a better Ma≈øter to ≈øerve in his old age, than he had ≈øound God to be in his youth: ‚òû Oh what need we have to ≈øtand upon our watch, little do we know what the Devil may tempt us to before we die; if God leave us, Satan may ≈øift us wor≈øe (in his Sieve of Temptation) when we are old, than ever he could do while we were young: The Innocente≈øt man Adam, the Stronge≈øt man Samp≈øon, and the Wi≈øe≈øt man Solomon, were all undone by Satan, and all by Women, e≈øpecially Solomon, who had hitherto the character of a None-≈øuch, from 1 Kin. 3. 1. to the end of Ch. 10. then Ch. 11. begins with a But, like that of Naaman, 2 Kin. 5. 1. he was Captain of the Syrian Ho≈øt, a great man with his Ma≈øter, and Honourable; he was al≈øo a mighty man of Valour, But he was a Leper. So here, after all Solomons glory is graphically de≈øcribed in the foregoing Chapters, it follows, Ch. 11. 1. But King Solomon loved many ≈øtrange Women; hereby he (who ≈øhould have been the man for e≈øtabli≈øhing the Church in its perfection of beauty, and for perpetuating the power and purity of Religion to his Po≈øterity) becomes him≈øelf Effeminate, and Ema≈øculates him≈øelf ≈øo far,
as to be intangled by them into great evils: 1. In tolerating (at lea≈øt) their Idolatrous practices. 2. In allowing places for their Idols. 3. In his complying with them, and conforming to them in their wor≈øhipping of Venus, Bacchus, Saturn, &c. and all this (as it were) under Gods very eye, ≈øo nigh the Temple, the place of Gods re≈øidence; for this the Lord was angry, and ≈øays, he will rend the Kingdome, v. 9, 10, 11. and does it (as well as ≈øays it) afterwards. The Devil is as much plea≈øed as God is angry, hopes to win the Game, and to damn Solomon; yet that wicked one could not touch him, to wit, with his deadly touch of final Apo≈øtacy, for the Seed of God was in him, 1 Joh. 3. 9. and 5. 18. the Root of Grace remain'd, wrought in him, and brought him to repentance; his Book of Eccle≈øia≈øtes is his Penitential Palinody, ≈øo ought he not to be pictur'd by Papi≈øts half in Heaven, and half in Hell: 'Tis remarkable, that David and Solomon are conjoyn'd in one Commendatory Sentence, 2 Chron. 11. 17. to ≈øhew that Holy David is as much in Hell as Solomon, and Solomon as much in Heaven as Holy David: And 'tis not po≈ø≈øible that the beginning of Rehoboams Reign could be like Davids (as that Clau≈øe affirms) if Solomon had left his Kingdome in ≈øo corrupt a condition as his Apo≈øtacy cau≈øed, and not have reform'd it after his return
to the Lord. The Devil having lo≈øt this fir≈øt after-game (for eclip≈øing the glory of the Church, which gain'd that ble≈ø≈øed Book of Eccle≈øia≈øtes by Solomons fall) upon Solomons ≈øelf, he trys conclu≈øions upon Solomons Son, as his ≈øecond after-game; and no better Tool could he have to work withal, than Childi≈øh Rehoboam: 'Tis a wonder that ≈øo wi≈øe a Father as Solomon, ≈øhould have (only) ≈øuch a fooli≈øh Son as Rehoboam, and that of ≈øeven hundred Wives, and three hundred Concubines: Many a Fool hath had a wi≈øer Son than this wi≈øe≈øt Father; a≈ø≈øuredly Solomon did progno≈øticate his Sons future folly, in his ≈øaying [Who knows whether he that comes after me will be a wi≈øe man, or a fool, &c. Eccle≈ø. 2. 18. yea, the holy Scripture calls him a Child at forty years old, 2 Chron. 13. 7. All this he did prove him≈øelf in the Parliament held at Shechem, 1 Kin. 12. 1. where an humble Addre≈øs is made to him, that he would lighten their grievous Yoaks, and le≈ø≈øen their great Taxes which his Father had laid on them for the maintenance of his va≈øt Retinue, of ≈øtrange Women e≈øpecially, and (≈øay they) we will be thy ≈øervants for ever; which promi≈øe (annexed) anticipates a tacit Objection, for it might be ≈øaid, if the King had once ≈øubmitted him≈øelf to the reque≈øt of his Subjects, they would prove Lords over him: but here they ≈øhew the contrary, and promi≈øe to accept
of him, and to be ≈øubject to him: he (being le≈øs wi≈øe than his Father who advi≈øed him [by a ≈øoft An≈øwer to pacifie wrath, Prov. 15. 1.] but more wilful) rejects the advice of his Fathers old experienc'd Coun≈øellors (with whom was wi≈ødom, Job 12. 12. and whom he con≈øulted only for fa≈øhion ≈øake) and follow'd the device of his own green-headed Companions and Courtiers, who para≈øitically per≈øwade him to ≈øtand upon his Pantoffles, and not at all to ≈øtoop to his people, for that would make him a King without a Kingdome, and a Subject to his Subjects. Thus they humour him into a conceit of Ab≈øolutene≈øs: Hereupon he threatens Tyranny to the people, who hear of nothing from him, but Scourges and Scorpions, v. 13. Oh fooli≈øh and childi≈øh King, who≈øe very words have Stings! was this the way to gain a di≈øcontented people? No, but rather to di≈øoblige, even a willing people, who could not but think how cruel will this mans hands be, who thus draws blood with his Tongue. Thus he fondly lo≈øes ten Tribes from his Crown with his churli≈øh words, and rough an≈øwers, which he would (and might not) have recover'd with the blood of a great Army, v. 21, 22, 23. Then ≈øaw he (when too late) that ≈øtrife is ea≈øier ≈øtirred than ≈øtinted, and that the people is a mo≈øt Heady Water, when once out of their Banks, which now were
broken down by his indefinite profe≈ø≈øion of rigour and ≈øeverity upon their pur≈øes and per≈øons: ‚òû Sad con≈øequences ever accompany tho≈øe Princes that would be Ab≈øolute in Power, will be Re≈øolute in Will, and dare be Di≈ø≈øolute in Life. The wicked one had a double advantage for promoting this Plot, not only Rehoboam to work on, who was green-headed at forty (though the Son of Solomon, who was grey-headed at twenty) year old, 2 Chro. 13. 7. and 1 Kin. 3. 3. 7. with 2. 6. and 1 Chro. 14. 21. but al≈øo Jeroboam to work by, who was as wily as wicked, plotting a revolt from former affronts, forming a Religion accommodated to his Rebellion, and de≈øignedly marring the I≈ørael of God, for the better making them his own Subjects: By both tho≈øe two helps (of childi≈øhne≈øs in the one, and craftine≈øs in the other) Satan, that Schi≈ømatical Spirit (who made the fir≈øt Schi≈øme or Rent in the City of God, at the fir≈øt being of the World) now made (1.) The large≈øt Schi≈øme or Rent, (2.) The longe≈øt that ever had been made in the Church of God under any Government: (1.) It was the large≈øt, for here the Devil got more than nine parts (even the ten Tribes) leaving God only his tythe, his tenth, his one Tribe, to wit, the Tribe of Judah only; ≈øo 'tis expre≈ø≈øed, 1 Kin. 11. 13. with 12. 20. and it (2.) was the longe≈øt al≈øo, for it was a Rent
that could never be ≈øtitch'd together again, neither by force of arms, nor by the mo≈øt forward Reformers, but la≈øted till the Captivity. However 'tis a work of wonder, a Miracle of Mercy, and a matter of great admiration, that the Devil made not the ten Tribes to ≈øwallow up the one Tribe (ten to one is great odds) the Kingdome of I≈ørael to devour the Kingdome of Judah, ≈øo called, though Benjamin was included in Judah: No, God had promis'd, that his mercy ≈øhould not depart away from Solomon, as he took it from Saul, 2 Sam. 7. 15. that is, I will not quite ca≈øt him out of my favour, or wholly deprive him of his Kingdome, as I did Saul. This ≈øpoil'd the Devils de≈øign of de≈øtroying the Church, for Solomons Seed was not rejected of God, as Sauls was, to give way to Davids ≈øucce≈ø≈øion; yea, and that which ≈øpoil'd Satans project yet more was, when God was angry with Solomon, his Jedidiah, his Darling for his ≈øin, and threatned to rend the Kingdome (which is as a glorious Mantle upon the Kings ≈øhoulder, 1 Sam. 15. 28. 1 Kin.
‚Ä¢ 1. 29, 30.) from him, yet the ≈øeverity of that Sentence God was plea≈øed to ≈øweeten with ≈øome mitigation and mixture of mercy; as, 1. I will not do it in thy days, &c. 2. I will not rend away all, 1 Kin. 11. 11, 12, 13. (1.) For Davids ≈øake (which is five times repeated there for his honour)
and (2.) For Jeru≈øalems ≈øake, both which had peculiar promi≈øes; as, 1. David, 2 Sam. 7. 9, 10, 11, 12, 16. all performed by the promi≈øer, either in the Types' or Antitypes. 2. Jeru≈øalem, that holy City, Neh. 11. 1. 18. I≈øa. 52. 1. wherein Zion and the Temple ≈øtood, and was the ≈øpecial Type of the Church, P≈øal. 51. 18. I≈øa. 62. 1, 7. and 66. 20. Revel. 21. 2. and therein God promis'd to David his ≈øervant, that he ≈øhould have a light or Lamp always, 1 Kin. 11. v. 36. to wit, a Royal Succe≈ø≈øor, that ≈øhould ≈øhine before his people, which was mo≈øt properly accompli≈øh'd in Chri≈øt, Luke 2. 32. The Scepter could not be taken (either by men or Devils) from Judah, until Shilo came, Gen. 49. 10. and then was he a light to the Gentiles, as he had been, (and ≈øtill was) a glory to I≈ørael. Now though the Devil (that Grand Make-bate of the World) had a great hand in this Rent or Divi≈øion, together with his Impious In≈øtrument Jeroboam, yet the Lord had a greater hand in it to ordain, order, and over-rule all: For thus ≈øaith the Lord, This thing is from me; and the cau≈øe was from the Lord (as well as from the Devil) 1 Kin. 12. 15.24. As it was a ≈øin (call'd Rebellion, Ch. 12. 19.) ≈øo it was from the Devil; but as it was a puni≈øhment of ≈øin (both of Solomons Idolatry, Ch. 11. v. 11. and of Rehoboams in≈øolency) ≈øo it was from God, as an Act of Ju≈øtice from
the Supreme Judge, Am. 3. 6. God here withdraws the Spirit of Wi≈ødom from Rehoboam, and leaves him to his own egregious folly, as Chap. 22. 23. 2 Chron. 25. 20. and 32. 31. God knows how to order the di≈øorders of the World to his own glory, as having an over-ruling Providence beyond mans purpo≈øe, and an over-pouring power ≈øtill to pre≈øerve his poor Church, though Solomon had been ≈øharing him≈øelf betwixt God and Idols, and therefore his ≈øervant (Jeroboam) ≈øhall ≈øhare the Kingdome with his Son (Rehoboam) yea, and bear away the better half from him; yet Judah ≈øtill rules with God (and God with them) and is faithful with the Saints: When Ephraim (the ten Tribes) compa≈ø≈øed God about with lyes, Ho≈ø. 11. v. 12. that is, while back-≈øliding I≈ørael went after their Leaden Prie≈øts (made by Jeroboam of the ba≈øe≈øt of the people) and their Golden Calves, Judah kept tite to the Temple-wor≈øhip, and firm in the true Religion. Thus the mo≈øt gracious God, even in the mid≈øt of wrath, remembers mercy, and leaves this ble≈ø≈øing (≈øoon repenting of the evil) behind him, that a Lamp ≈øhould be lighted in Jeru≈øalem, which the mo≈øt boi≈øtrous bla≈øts of the Devil, and his In≈øtruments, ≈øhould not blow out.

argument.p: The Sixteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Canaan: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.
div.p:
NOw when the Devil had divided ≈øo great a ≈øhare of Davids Kingdome to him≈øelf by Divine Permi≈ø≈øion, (the Lord of the Soyl, Ho≈ø. 9. 3. I≈øa. 8. 8. giving way for his own glory to ≈øuch ≈øad Incroachments) he falls upon ≈øowing the cur≈øed ≈øeed of his Tares upon the Lords Land, among tho≈øe Tribes who di≈ødain'd to live any longer by the Lords Law. Oh wonderful! there was no vi≈øible Church upon Earth at this time, but in the Land of Promi≈øe; and yet the only wi≈øe God gives up to Satan (when all the World lay in wickedne≈øs, 1 Joh. 5. 19. and ≈øo in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of that wicked one) even the large≈øt ≈øhare of his own Land al≈øo, though it was but a little ≈øpot of Land (no bigger than our Wales) in all. Thus the Lords Land, Levit. 25. 23. became the Devils Land too (in the greate≈øt part) with all the re≈øt of the
Habitable World: Oh how un≈øearchable are the ways of the Lord, and his works pa≈øt find-out, Rom. 11. 33, 34, 35. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Oh the bottomle≈øs depth of Divine Wi≈ødome! the Devil, having got this leave again≈øt I≈ørael (as once again≈øt Job) when Gods Hedge was gone, begins to lay wa≈øte Gods Vineyard, I≈øa. 5. 5, 6. He now falls to work for debauching I≈ørael; he fir≈øt makes them ca≈øt off their true Soveraign, and chu≈øe a fal≈øe one; Jeroboam the Son of Nebat mu≈øt be the man, one that wanted neither Craft nor Courage to back this Hor≈øe which had ca≈øt his Rider: Next to Achitophel, the Devil had not a craftier Head to plot again≈øt the Church, than this Leader of the Faction and Fraction. As the ≈øubtil Serpent infu≈øed into him his ≈øubtilty for ≈øtealing a Scepter, ≈øo for ≈øecuring it to him when he had ≈øtoln it: His Plotting Head had this con≈øidering Cap upon it, ['twas but a pang of di≈øcontent that made me King, violent things are not permanent, ≈øudden Paroxy≈ømes, or Fits of pa≈ø≈øion, have as ≈øudden Relaxations and recoveries; the Revolters cannot return thrice a year to the Temple in Jeru≈øalem (as God commands them, Exod. 34. 23.) but 'twill make them revolt from me, and return to Rehoboam; I mu≈øt either keep them off from God, or I ≈øhall never keep them off from Loyalty and Piety] Therefore to give them a plea≈øant
Diver≈øion (when he dur≈øt not offer a direct Re≈øtraint and Prohibition) he changes and adulterates that Religion, which he dare neither inhibit nor aboli≈øh: Hereupon this new King plots to make I≈ørael a new God, and (for their ea≈øe) nearer home too, that they might not be toiled with going ≈øo far as the Temple, pretending to be more merciful to the people than the mo≈øt merciful God, yea and more prudent than he in his more compendious and plau≈øible way of wor≈øhip, altogether accommodated to the ea≈øe and humour of the people: Aaron had humour'd I≈ørael with one Golden Calf (≈øuch as they had ≈øeen long in Egypt) Exod. 32. 4. Now Jeroboam (who had lately lived there, 1 Kin. 11. 40.) judges it proper (after Aarons example) to humour them with two, which he ≈øets up at Dan‚ñ™ and Bethel, at both the ends of the Land, North and South, 1 Kin. 12. 27, 28, 29. Thus took he crafty coun≈øel of his cur≈øed Courtiers, and, ≈øo he might ≈øecure his Realm and Region, he matter'd not though Religion were run down to ruine. All along afterwards, he had both Witne≈ø≈øes and people too, that had a ble≈ø≈øed tenderne≈øs towards their two hundred thou≈øand Captives, at the powerful preaching of the Prophet Oded (whom God had as a Witne≈øs in the wor≈øt of times) 2 Chron. 28. 9, to 16. ≈øo mightily did the Word of God work upon this armed Army, that they ≈øhewed a great work of mercy to their di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Brethren, &c. though they had but one Prophet to pre≈øs them to it in ≈øo great an Ho≈øt. And as God had his ≈øeven thou≈øand of people in Ahabs time, 1 Kin. 19. 18. ≈øo he had great multitudes in Ho≈øea's time (their la≈øt King) out of Ephraim, Mana≈ø≈øeh, I≈ø≈øachar, Zebulon, and A≈øher, who humbled them≈øelves under the ≈øight and ≈øen≈øe of their ≈øins, and came to Jeru≈øalem at Hezekiahs Proclamation to keep the Pa≈ø≈øover, according to the Word of the Lord, 2 Chron. 30. 1, 6, 11, 13, 18. though ≈øome jeered (≈øhowing them≈øelves ready ripe for ruine in their la≈øt Kings time) yet many others feared, v. 10, 11. And though tho≈øe which came out of the ten Tribes (out of the fear of God) were ignorant of due preparation, (having been long without God, Law, and Teaching Prie≈øt, 2 Chro. 19. 3.) came rudely and irreverently to the Pa≈ø≈øover (and probably
≈ømarted for it, as 1 Cor. 11. 30. Matth. 22. 12, 13.) yet at Hezekiahs godly Prayer for them, God Healed them and accepted their Service, v. 18, 19, 20. Yea, and Gods Pitty was ≈øuch to his Covenanted people, that the Old Stile and Title [The Lord God of I≈ørael] is kept up even by Abijam, 2 Chron. 13. 5. and ≈øuch was Gods Re≈øpect to I≈ørael under the Revolt, that he ≈øent ≈øometimes Saviours to them, as 2 Kin. 13. 5. Obad. 21. Neh. 9. 27. All which doth plainly Demon≈øtrate Gods Care of his Church even in the wor≈øt of times, let the Devil and his Imps do all they can: And though there hath been ≈øuch a Revolt from the Ture Chri≈øtian-Religion by the Papacy, as this of the Ten Tribes from the Temple-Wor≈øhip, (the Foundation whereof was laid in Blood, to wit, the Blood of Adoram, 1 Kin. 12. 18. as that of the Romi≈øh-Revolt much more.) Yet the Lord ≈øecureth his own Intere≈øt, Rev. 12. 6, 14. Maugre the Malice of Men and Devils, both in Witne≈ø≈øes and People, as I have ≈øhown at large in my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt. Moreover (3ly.) at the End of this Revolting Kingdom, when God had ca≈øt the Ten Tribes out of Canaan, becau≈øe they had ca≈øt him off and his good Laws; yet God had re≈øpect (1) to the very Land out of which they were ca≈øt; for when the King of A≈ø≈øyria had Conquered Samaria and the Cities of the Ten Tribes, which he carried Captive into
his own Countrey, and had Planted his Colonies of mixt People in their place, The Lord ≈øent Lyons among them, which Slew ≈øome of them, 2 Kin. 17. 25. becau≈øe tho≈øe New-Planters (as them≈øelves ≈øay) knew not the manner of the God of the Land, v. 26. fooli≈øhly thinking, that each Land had its proper God: Indeed the Land of I≈ørael had another God than the Gods (or Idols) of tho≈øe Lands from whence they came; it was a Land which Jehovah had Cho≈øen as an Habitation for him≈øelf, and ≈øaith, The Land is mine, Levit. 25. 25. Hence it is called the Lords Land, Ho≈ø. 9. 3. and Immanuels Land, I≈øa. 8. 8. and by their Seventh-Year Sabbath, they Acknowledged that their Land belonged to God, and that they were onely Gods Tenants and Tythe-men: now ≈øeeing tho≈øe A≈ø≈øyrians that came into Canaan in I≈øraels Room, made no ≈øuch Acknowledgment, nor Own'd him in a Land which the True God was plea≈øed to Own, therefore he ≈øent this Judgement of the Lyons upon them, to let them know that the God of this Land had all Creatures (even the mo≈øt Ravenous) at His Command wherewith to be Avenged for their not-Fearing him. Thus, it appears, God did not Hate the Ground (as ≈øome ≈øay) that I≈ørael trode upon, though they were Revolters. 2ly. God had Re≈øpect to them≈øelves much more, (if ≈øo much to their Land,) ≈øo that they were (in a ≈øort) Ammi, while they were Lo-Ammi; and
Ruhamah, while they were Lo-Ruhamah, Ho≈ø. 1. 6. Yea, when the name I≈ørael was too good and too Honourable a name for them, but they mu≈øt be called Jezreel, that is, a People devoted to Di≈øper≈øion, v. 4. and ≈øuch as God would ≈øcatter into the four Winds of Heaven, [Zerang,] as the Seeds-man ≈øcatters his Seed, ≈øo that the Ten Tribes never return'd out of Captivity; yet (≈øure I am) neither the Devil got all, nor God lo≈øt all, for God did not lo≈øe I≈ørael, but onely laid them up in an Unknown Sepulchre with his own Hands, (as he had done their Mediator Mo≈øes,) in ≈øure and certain Hope of a Re≈øurrection: God did not ca≈øt off his People for ever, 1 Kin. 11. 39. Though the dry Bones of I≈ørael lye in Babylon, &c. as in a Sepulchre, and were (as it were) Buryed Alive at their final Abdication, yet the Lord Promi≈øes, The≈øe Graves ≈øhall be opened. This is ≈øpoken over and over again, Ezek. 37. 11, 12, 13, 14. to the whole Hou≈øe of I≈ørael, the Lord ≈øaith, Behold, Oh my People. God owneth them ≈øtill, though they little de≈øerv'd it. This is Alledged as an Allay to tho≈øe Dreadful De≈øolations; ≈øo loath is the Sun of Righteou≈øne≈øs to ≈øett under a Cloud, that in the mid≈øt of Judgement he remembers Mercy, Hab. 3. 2. Thus while the Lord wrote Jezreel, Lo-Ruhamah, and Lo-Ammi upon I≈ørael: In the Inva≈øion made by Tiglath-Pilne≈øer upon the Tribes beyond Jordan, 2 Kin. 15. 29. 1 Chro.
5. 6. and by Salmane≈øer upon the re≈øt of the Ten Tribes on this ≈øide Jordan: Yet behold how graciou≈øly God comes off in that Direful Sentence; Yet the Number of the Children of I≈ørael ≈øhall be as the Sand of the Sea that cannot be Numbred; and where it was ≈øaid, Ye are not my People, there it ≈øhall be ≈øaid, Ye are the Sons of the Living God, Ho≈ø. 1. 4, 6, 9, 10. to ≈øhew Gods great care of his Church, and of his Promi≈øe to Abraham, even when he ≈øeems to have Utterly Abandon'd them: The ≈øame Graciou≈øne≈øs that had ≈øent Prophets to them all along their Revolt, and a Promi≈øe of the Me≈ø≈øiah at the ≈øame time their Rejection was foretold, I≈øa. 7. 8. (within 65 Y. of its comming to pa≈øs,) That the Lord would not quite ca≈øt off the Hou≈øe of David, till a Virgin have born a Son, and he to be God in our Nature, v. 14. and this Son to be Born in Bethelem, One that ≈øhould tread down all the Churches Enemies, and be her Peace, &c. Micah 5. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. yet would be War to the A≈ø≈øyrians in ≈øending Lyons among them, (as before,) all which doth ≈øhow, That this Antient People (of the Ten Tribes) are not altogether Abandon'd and Aboli≈øh'd, but God re≈øerves this Honour for them, to Vouch≈øafe them a Call to the Participation of Chri≈øt, (but more of that in New-Te≈øtament-times.) Ezek. 37. 16, 19. Jer. 3. 12, 13. &c. I≈øa. 11. 12, 13. Obad. 20. Rom. 11. 15, 26.

argument.p: The Seventeenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Judah: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.
div.p: WHen the Devil ≈øaw how ≈øucce≈øsful he had been in Debauching and De≈øtroying the Ten Tribes of I≈ørael, He falls upon his 17th. Plot again≈øt the Kingdom of Judah, which yet Ruled with God, and was Faithful with the Saints, Ho≈ø. 11. 12. God was ≈øincerely ≈øerved among≈øt them, and they Held fa≈øt their fir≈øt integrity, the True Religion was Publickly Profe≈ø≈øed, and the True Wor≈øhip of God was Purely Pre≈øerved in the Temple at Jeru≈øalem: This made Abijah (the next to Rehoboam, though none of the be≈øt) to boa≈øt ≈øo boldly, and therefore prevailed, 2 Chro. 13. 10, 17. I≈øraels Apo≈øtacy was not onely Aggravated, but al≈øo Vanqui≈øhed by Judahs Integrity: yea, and Judah was Kind, Courteous and Communicative to tho≈øe good Souls that left the Ten Tribes and came thither to Injoy the Pure and Publick Wor≈øhip of God.

This the Envious One e≈øpying and Envying, Endeavours to Corrupt Jeru≈øalem as he had done Samaria, that ≈øo Aholah and Aholibah might be both Alike, nay, the latter to be wor≈øe than the former, (as afterwards,) Ezek. 16. 2, 45, 48. and 23. 4, 11. Yea, that Prince of the Ayr (the Devil) never gave over his ≈øtormy Bla≈øts (with his ≈øtinking Breath) until he had Blown out that Lamp which God had promis'd to give David in Jeru≈øalem, 1 Kin. 15. 4. at the la≈øt, which did fall out about the 3420 Y. of the World, in the 11th. Y. of Zedekiah, when Ezekiels 390 Y. (mentioned Ezek. 4. 5.) were exactly accompli≈øh'd,) in that fatal Fall of Jeru≈øalem, for which Jeremy Writt his Book of Lamentations to Condole the ≈øad Condition of the Church, becau≈øe the Crown was faln from her Head, Lam. 5. 15, 16. and her Light, or Lamp, was Extinct by the Devils Extingui≈øher; then was ≈øhe brought into darkne≈øs, and not into light, Lam. 3. 2. and removed into dark places, as they that be dead, v. 6. ≈øo put into the Dark Graves of Babylon, until the Time of their Opening came, Ezek. 37. 12. &c.

Now to Reduce the Church to this faln and Extinct E≈øtate: The Devil De≈øigns again≈øt her many Maladies, and 'tis remarkable, God ≈øent her as many Remedies, in Rai≈øing up a good King for a bad, a good King for a bad, almo≈øt, all-along, (whereas tho≈øe of I≈ørael were all bad
Univer≈øally) until they had ≈øinned them≈øelves beyond the Reach of all Remedies, Prov. 22. 1. 2 Chro. 36. 16. Oh Dreadful and Direful Divine Sentence!

Satans (fir≈øt) Bla≈øt again≈øt the Lamp of the Church in this 17th. Plot, was, in Rehoboam, who at 41 Y. old was Childi≈øh and Simple, 2 Chro. 12. 13. with 13. 7. but of an Haughty and Hard-oppre≈ø≈øing Spirit, ≈øo prooved him≈øelf a very Fool, Eccle≈ø. 2. 19. though he were the Son of ≈øo Wi≈øe a Father, a very fit Tool for the Devil; and though for 3 Y. he did Well, 2 Chron. 11. 17. yet after he did Evil, and Judah with him, which brought up Shi≈øhak K. of Aegypt, to Plunder Jeru≈øalem, 1 Kin. 14. 22, 23, 24. Upon this; the Devil got the Golden Shields of Solomon changed into Brazen ones, v. 27. as he had made the faithful City now to become an Harlot: No Wonder therefore, that her Silver was become Dro≈øs, and her Gold turned into Bra≈øs, I≈øa. 1. 21, 22. Shi≈øhak (prompted to this Enterprize by Jeroboam who had lived in the Court of Aegypt, and (as ≈øome ≈øay) Married a Wife of the Blood-Royal) ea≈øily prevaileth through the Pu≈øillanimity and Effeminacy of Rehoboam, but e≈øpecially becau≈øe Judah had Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øed again≈øt the Lord, 2 Chron. 12. 2. His Prevalency could not have happened without the Church's Prevarication: Notwith≈øtanding at the Preaching of the Prophet Shemaiah,
(which was a great Divine favour) both Princes and People Humbled them≈øelves, v. 5, 6. (which was a greater Divine favour,) but the greate≈øt of all was, that God did not then pour out his whole Wrath, but granted them ≈øome Deliverance, v. 7, 8. So that things went well in Judah, v. 12.

The Devils 2d. Bla≈øt again≈øt Davids promi≈øed Lamp, was in the Reign of Rehoboams Son, call'd Abijah, 2 Chron. 12. 16. ≈øo his Father named him, (≈øignifying, [The Lord is my Father,] with Re≈øpect to that Promi≈øe made to David, 2 Sam. 7. 14. but becau≈øe he Walked not in the ways of David, therefore is Abijah called Abijam, 1 Kin. 15. 1. which ≈øignifies, [My Father is a Sea,] Indeed his Father was as Incon≈øtant in good as the Fluctuating Sea, becau≈øe he Prepared not his Heart to ≈øeek the Lord, 2 Chro. 12. 24. he had only ≈øome ≈øla≈øhy and fleeting Re≈øolutions (in his afore≈øaid Humblings,) but he did not draw them out into Execution, becau≈øe they Sprang not from his Heart, (that right Spring of all True goodne≈øs:) ≈øo they were ≈øoon off again, and he wavering like a wave of the Sea, Jam. 1.6. was driven by the Wind of Temptation to do Evil, and ≈øo Dyes, leaving a Dimini≈øh'd and Impoveri≈øh'd Kingdom to his Son Abijah or Abijam, who did Evil like his Father. Though the Book of Chronicles layeth no Wickedne≈øs to his Charge, (≈øo joyns Jah [the Name of
God] to his name Abijah, yet the Book of Kings Chargeth him with the Wickedne≈øs of his Fathers ways, and therefore calls him Abijam, as above, 1 Kin. 15. 3. Though at fir≈øt, when he went out to War again≈øt Jeroboams va≈øt Army, he ≈øeemed to be good, pretending to, and pleading hard for Religion, 2 Chron. 13. 5, 10, 12. and praying to God in his Di≈øtre≈øs, v. 14. and believing in God, v. 18. but being puffed up with this great Victory, he falls away, and ≈øhew'd him≈øelf in his Colours, treading in the ≈øame Dirty ≈øteps of his Idolatrous Father, who, when he Recover'd Bethel from Jeroboam, 2 Chron. 13. 19. did not De≈øtroy the Calf and Idolatry there, for which cau≈øe ('tis probable) God ≈øhorten'd both his Reign and his Life; Oh what a ≈øad A≈øpect had the Church in that Day, when not onely I≈ørael Wor≈øhip'd Jeroboams Calves, but al≈øo Judah Built them high places, and Images, and Groves on every High Hill, and under every Green-Tree, 1 Kin. 14. 22, 23. Yea, and Tolerated Sodomy in the Land, v. 24. This ≈øad Face of the Church (and that continuing two Kings Reigns) mu≈øt needs ≈øadden the Hearts of tho≈øe Faithful Ones, who (among the 12 Tribes) were Gods Remnant, and In≈øtantly ≈øerved him Day and Night, Act. 26. 7. There was no Vi≈øible Church in the whole World, but in this little part of it, And how was the Church here mo≈øt Deplorably Depraved? God ≈øometimes
≈øuffers his Church (as he doth the Moon) to Wane out of ≈øight and to be Ecclip≈øed; yet ≈øuch Gloomy times ≈øhall not la≈øt always, God cau≈øeth Light to Spring up by A≈øa (the 3d. King after the Revolt,) who Revives the Church, and Refre≈øhes the Children of God by a Right Reformation of Religion, 1 Kin. 15. 11. both in the Privative and in the Po≈øitive part. 1. The Privative. He, finding Sodom in Jeru≈øalem, Roots out the Sodomites, v. 12. Demoli≈øhes the Idols, tho≈øe Dirty Dung-hill Deities, (call'd [Deos ≈øtercoreos] becau≈øe of the Stench wherewith they offend Almighty God; yea, removes Maachah from being Queen-Regent for ≈øetting up a mo≈øt filthy Idol in honour of Venus, ≈øuppo≈øed the Picture of Pan or Priapus, v. 13. (2ly.) The Po≈øitive part; He doth not onely put down Idolatry, &c. but he ≈øets up and Re≈øtores the Splendour of Temple-Wor≈øhip: 'Twas his Grand-Father Rehoboam that turn'd Solomons Gold into Bra≈øs; now A≈øa turns Rehoboams Bra≈øs into Gold, 1 Kin. 15. 15. 'Tis ≈øaid of Augu≈øtus Coe≈øar, [Romam Invenit lateritiam, Reliquit Marmoream,] He ≈øound Rome all of Brick, he left it all of Marble: So it may be ≈øaid, as Rehoboam had turn'd Jeru≈øalems Marble into Brick, ≈øo A≈øa turns it back from Brick to Marble as Solomon had left it. 'Tis a Wonder, that both Sodomy and the Wor≈øt ≈øort of Idolatry (to wit, Priapi≈øm) ≈øhould be found among≈øt Mankind, (being
≈øo contrary to the Light of Nature, Rom. 1. 19, to 28.) but much more among≈øt the onely profe≈ø≈øors of Religion that were then upon Earth. Here the Devils De≈øign had notable Succe≈øs; yet behold as great a Wonder in the Churches Remedy, (as was in her Malady) the Lord rai≈øes up a good Son (A≈øa) from the Seed of an evil Father (Abijam;) and from the Soil of an Idolatrous Mother (Maachah;) and makes him to be ≈øuch an Impartial Reformer, as he would not grant a Di≈øpen≈øation to his own Mother or Grand-Mother, 1 Kin. 15. 13. and 2 Chron. 15. 16. He finds her Unreclaimable from her Idols in her ≈øelf, and very Influential upon the People; Hereupon, the Law of God (in Command: 1. 2.) Preponderates the Law of Nature, (Command. 5th.) Down goes her Idols from their Station, and her ≈øelf from her Regency, becau≈øe his Heart was perfect with the Lord, 1 Kin. 15. 14. And as a Reward of his Covenant-Reformation, God gave him a glorious Victory over the greate≈øt Army that ever we read of in any Hi≈øtory, to wit, a Thou≈øand Thou≈øand Aethiopians, who (likely) were call'd in by the Ten Tribes (at the Devils In≈øtigation) in Revenge of their Five Hundred Thou≈øand which Abijam had overthrown, 2 Chron. 14. 9, to 12. God at good A≈øa's Prayer Smote his Enemies, and (as the Word ≈øignifies) Tumbl'd them down Headlong: A≈øa Reign'd long to do
great and good things for the Church. Therefore the Devil (who did owe him an ill turn, and had been hitherto under a Divine Re≈øtriction, which to him is a grievous Vexation) at la≈øt gets leave to Touch him with his Churli≈øh Touches, (as Job 1. 11, 12.) to wit, in cau≈øing him (1) to Connive at the Will-Wor≈øhip in the High-places, mi≈ø-devoted for the Wor≈øhip of God, (who had Confined it to the Temple;) though he Demoli≈øhed tho≈øe ≈øet up in honour of Idols, 1 Kin. 15. 13, 14. this God graciou≈øly overlooks, beholding Truth in his Heart: God tenderly covers A≈øa's Frailty with the Mantle of Sincerity, which he would not do for Unfound Jehu, though Excellent things were done by him, 2 Kin. 10.31. and ina≈ømuch as the Indulgency of A≈øa's God did draw a Cro≈øs-line over all A≈øa's Weakne≈ø≈øes; Satan lo≈øt his De≈øign in Tempting him to this Sin, and to the following al≈øo. (2) To a Relyance on the King of Syria more than upon the Lord, 2 Chron. 16. 7, 8, 9. Con≈øidence on Man (an Arm of Fle≈øh) draws off his Confidence on God, (who gave him Victory over the Million of Aethiopians) I≈øa. 31. 1, 2. He tru≈øteth. not God at all, who tru≈øteth not God above and over all: A≈øa Hires Benhadad with Sacrilegious Trea≈øure, unfaithfully to break his League with Baa≈øha, and brings a Wicked Enemy into Gods Inheritance: (3) To that which was wor≈øe, even to the Impri≈øoning of
Hanani the Prophet, for reprooving him for his ≈øin, v. 10. A≈øa, in≈øtead of comming to Repentance and calling for Mercy, in a great rage again≈øt his Faithful reproover, commands Revenge. (4) To be as Har≈øh to the People as he was to the Prophet, Tyrannically trampling upon tho≈øe that prote≈øted again≈øt his Tyranny to the Lords Prophet; for this, God did not onely ≈øend upon his Kingdom continual War, v. 11. but upon him≈øelf the ≈øharp Dolorous Gout, v. 12. whereby God clapp'd him up a clo≈øer Pri≈øoner by the Heels in his Bed, and with more Torturing Fetters, than he had done Gods Prophet in Pri≈øon: Then (5) to ≈øeek to the Phy≈øitians for Cure of his Gout, and not to God, v. 12. Thus falls he into his former ≈øin of Creature-Confidence; He that in his outward ≈øtraits ≈øought to Benhadad, and not to God, now in his Inward Sore ≈øeeks not to God, but to Phy≈øitians, not depending upon the Lord for his Ble≈ø≈øing upon Men and Means. No Wonder therefore that his Di≈øea≈øe ≈øtruck upward to his Head and Heart, and that his Hot Feet carried him to his Cold Grave, v. 13. Notwith≈øtanding all tho≈øe Failings the Devil lo≈øt his De≈øign, for 'tis more than probable, that A≈øa repented before he Dyed; Seeing (1) God gave him this commendable Character, That his Heart was Perfect with the Lord all his Days, 1 Kin. 15. 14. 2 Chron. 15. 17. and 20. 32. and (2) his People gave him a mo≈øt Honourable
Funeral, 2 Chron. 16. 14. which was Denyed to Wicked Jehoram, Ch. 21. 19. and which they would not have done (in that co≈øtly Solemnity) for A≈øa, had he not Repented and Reformed, to be thus Honoured at his Burial; Yea, and God ble≈øt him with a long Reign (of 41 Y. v. 13.) wherein he ≈øaw many Succe≈ø≈øions and Changes upon the Throne of the Ten Tribes, who were all ≈øpeedily rooted out by their Idolatry, whereas good A≈øa was long E≈øtabli≈øh'd upon his Throne by his True Piety, in De≈øpight of the Devil; leaving his godly Son Jeho≈øophat (the 4th. King) to ≈øucceed him, who prooved one of the be≈øt of the Princes of Judah, whom God Stirred up for a Farther Reformation of Religion, and for a fuller Pre≈øervation of his Church, &c. 2 Chro. 17, &c. The Father was good, but the Son was better, ina≈ømuch as he Repented, when he was Reprooved, (which his Father did not, but Raged,) Ch. 19. 2, 4. where the Son (Jehu) ≈øucceeded better than his Father (Hanani,) Ch. 16. 7. Now for this his great Goodne≈øs the Devil envyed him, ≈øinding him more forward and forth-putting in religion and reformation than his Father. Hereupon Satan ≈øets upon his over-good Nature, and over-facile Di≈øpo≈øition, ≈øeduces him into an A≈ø≈øinity with Wicked Ahah, 1 Kin. 22. 44. to a Match 'twixt Jehoram his Son, and Athaliah Ahab's wicked Daughter, 2 Kin. 8. 18. and to a Courtly Complyance
in Ahabs Warring again≈øt Syria, which had like to have co≈øt him his life, 1 Kin. 22. 2, 4; 31. Here the Devil had Entangled good Jeho≈øaphat into mo≈øt de≈øperate Danger; but God Di≈øappoints the Devils De≈øign: Jeho≈øaphat Cryed out, that is, to the Lord, 1 Kin. 22. 32. and the Lord Helped him, 2 Chron. 18. 31. So he returned to his Hou≈øe in Peace, Ch. 19. 1. which his Ally Ahab did not, as Micaiah fore-told him, 1 Kin. 22. 28. finding it True (but too late) that a whole Council (of fal≈øe Prophets e≈øpecially) may Err, in telling him the contrary: Jeho≈øaphat now is a Brand pluck'd out of the Fire, ≈øo dare not do as he had done, 2 Chron. 19. 4. and 1 Kin. 22. 49. he now ≈øtays at Jeru≈øalem, making no more any courtly goings on Progre≈øs to Samaria, 2 Chron. 19. 4. This good Man made Peace with bad Ahab the Father, 2 Chron. 19. 3. and with bad Ahaziah the Son, Ch. 20. 35. but better he had not done ≈øo, for God was deeply Di≈øplea≈øed with it, therefore was Wrath upon him, 2 Chron. 10. 2.
