However his Pre≈øervation from the ≈øtroke of Gods Angel, was but a re≈øervation for the ≈øtroke of his own Sons, for he returning with ≈øhame of Face to his own land, 2 Chron. 32. 21. as he was Wor≈øhipping Ni≈øroch his Tutelar God, (to whom he A≈øcribed his pre≈øervation) his Two Elde≈øt Sons (that came forth out of his own Bowels, and yet neither of them having Bowels for their own Father, nor awe to his Idol) Con≈øpire together, and ≈ømote him with the Sword even in the very Act of Wor≈øhipping a God that could not pre≈øerve him, 2 Kin. 19. 37. ‚òû As this Fatal End of Senacherib ≈øounds a loud Alarum to all proud and Bla≈øphemous Princes and Per≈øons; ≈øo it Di≈øcovers their Va≈ø≈øalage and Slavery (far wor≈øe than that of the Turks) to a Cur≈øed and Cruel Ma≈øter, who loves Trea≈øons, but hates Traitors: As it is mo≈øt ≈øure that Satan ≈øtirr'd up Senacherib to war again≈øt the Church of God, ≈øo 'tis no le≈øs ≈øure that he al≈øo ≈øtirr'd
up tho≈øe his Two Sons to Murder their own Father, for he is a Murderer from the beginning, Joh. 8. 44. Such as dare be his Drudges and do his Devili≈øh Work, can expect to have at la≈øt no better than ≈øuch Devili≈øh Wages; Oh who would wear his Cur≈øed Livery? (2ly.) When Satan ≈øaw him≈øelf Ba≈ø≈øled in Senacharib (his Extrin≈øick Engine) again≈øt Hezekiah, he makes an Experiment of an Intrin≈øick, in Tempting him to Pride and ≈øelf Admiration: This he ≈øucce≈øsfully effects in the Matter of the Emba≈ø≈øadors of Babylon, wherein God left him to him≈øelf to let him ≈øee what was in his Heart, 2 Chron. 32. 25, 31. the Occa≈øion and Opportunity of the Temptation was this, Hezekiah had been mortally ≈øick of the Plague, (that had ≈øeized upon his Vitals,) and he had (likely) the Tokens al≈øo, ≈øo that in humane apprehen≈øion a [Mi≈øerere mei] was Writ upon him, he was as a Dead Man; yet at his Prayers and Tears God gives him a new Lea≈øe of his Life, (even a Lea≈øe of Two Lives) Two Seven Years, and one more, to wit, Fifteen Years; ≈øo that 1≈øt. his Recovery [in Three Days] was miraculous by a Catapla≈øme or Plai≈øter of Figs applyed to his Carbuncle; 2ly. to him alone (and to none el≈øe in Scripture) God makes known the Term and Period of his Life. 3ly. As a Sign of his ≈øudden and ≈øupernatural Cure, and of his ≈øuper-added Term of Life. The Sun in the Firmament mu≈øt not
know the time of his going down, that Hezekiah might know his: 4ly. The Caldeans Ob≈øerving how the Sun (their God) had honoured him in its retrograde motion, come 680 miles to Honour him in their Court≈øhip and kind Congratulation: All the≈øe Four peculiar Priviledges Tickled his Depraved Nature, God (for this once) withdrawing, and Satan improoving, blows up this Bladder of Pride, and makes him Act like a petty-God within him≈øelf, without Dependency upon his God; he ≈øhews the Emba≈ø≈øadors all his Trea≈øures, 2 Kin. 20, 12. 13. Hereby Gold-thir≈øty Babylon knew where to have a full Draught, where to have a fit and fat Booty, Oh ≈øublime Folly! yet the Devil is Di≈øappointed of his De≈øign, God for≈øakes not Hezekiah utterly, P≈øal. 119. 8. but ≈øends I≈øaiah to prick this Bladder, lets Pride out of his Heart, (which had been lifted up net as Jeho≈øaphats in the ways of God, 2 Chron. 17. 6. but in ≈øelf-Admiration and Ambition, which is the Work of the Devil, Ch. 32. 25.) hereat Hezekiah is Humbled, Hearing how his o≈øtentation Contributes to the Babyloni≈øh-Captivity, 2 Kin. 20, 16, 19. Satans Snare is broken, and his Soul is Delivered, P≈øa. 1 ‚Ä¢ 4.7. For the very la≈øt thing we hear of Hezekiah, is of his goodne≈øs, 2 Chron. 32. 32. But the Devil plaid a better Game upon his Son Mana≈ø≈øeh (the 14th. King,) whom he wrought and brought up to
become a Sinner of the large≈øt ≈øize, 1. in his Defying of God, 2. in his De≈øtroying of Men, 3. in his Deifying of Devils; yet lo≈øt he his Game at la≈øt, though it la≈øted longe≈øt, Mana≈ø≈øeh having the longe≈øt Reign we read of in the Holy Hi≈øtory, even 55 Years, 2 Kin. 21. 1, to 12, 16. 2 Chron. 33. 1, to 10. This Degenerate Plant of a noble Vine, this Mana≈ø≈øeh was a Matchle≈øs Man in Sin, and quickly made mad Work, turning all up≈øide down; he Deformed all his good Father had Reformed, yet (as Romani≈øts do) under the notion of the Old Religion, and therefore by all means mu≈øt be done: Notwith≈øtanding Affliction tamed this Wild A≈øs, this Mon≈øter of Men, ≈øtop'd him in his Career, yea, brought him Home to God, v. 11, 12. &c. and he that had out-faced Heaven in his Sin, comes to hide him≈øelf among the Thorns, as 1 Sam. 13. 6. in this lurking Hole his Sin finds him out, (and God for his Sin) Numb. 32. 23. becau≈øe he would not find his own ≈øin out; there he was taken, and put into Fetters, and brought to Babylon; now beholding his Golden Chain of a King Changed into an Iron-Chain of a Captive, he bethinks him≈øelf and be≈øought the Lord, v. 12. tho≈øe Sanctify'd Fetters broke the Devils ≈øinful Fetters; when the Rod spake, he heard it, Mic. 6. 9. who would not hear the Word, v. 10. though powerfully Preach'd to him by I≈øaiah, Micah, Joel, Habbakuk,
&c. the Darkne≈øs of his Dungeon helps him to the Light of Gods Love, though he had ca≈øt off his God, yet his God had not ca≈øt him off; Satan would have Coached him to Hell in Pro≈øperity, but his God La≈øhes him to Heaven by Adver≈øity: As he had ≈øinned greatly, ≈øo he Humbled greatly, that there might be a proportion 'twixt his Sinning and his Sorrowing, as he is Humbled for Sin, ≈øo is he Quicken'd to Pray'r, wherein he comes with Fetters on his Feet to his God, as di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Benhadad did with a Rope about his Neck to the merciful King of I≈ørael, 1 Kin. 20. 31, 32. no ≈øooner did he find (through Grace) a Praying Heart, but his God finds al≈øo a Pittying Heart, v. 13. his God heard both his Pray'r for him≈øelf, and Solomons Pray'r for him, 1 Kin. 8.46, to 51. Now is this De≈øign of the Devil Di≈øappointed, Mana≈ø≈øeh is Returned and Re≈øtored to his Realm, and his Reformation (the Ble≈ø≈øed Evidence of his True Repentance) was as large as his Deformation had been, and he mo≈øt Remarkably Reduced his Subjects, (whom he had formally Seduced out of the Right Religion) into it again, v. 15, 16. as Luk. 22. 32. When he had Reform'd effectually, he dyes Religiou≈øly, and leaves Amon (an Irreligious Son) to ≈øucceed him (the 15th. King of Judah) at 22 Y. of Age: he was old enough to take warning by his Fathers Example, yet would not be Warned, but was rather
Hardened in his Wickedne≈øs thereby, as thinking to take a long ≈øwing in ≈øin (as Manna≈ø≈øeh had done,) and to Repent afterward as his Father did; but Gods Thoughts were otherwi≈øe, who neither gave him the space nor the Grace of Repentance: This Man (that Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øed more and more after ≈øuch loud Praemonitions; 2 Chro. 33. 23.) was a ≈øit Engine for the Devil to re≈øtore the Wor≈øhip of tho≈øe Images his Father had onely laid a≈øide and not Burned, as he ≈øhould have done, Deut. 7. 5. In≈øtead of which (the Rabbins ≈øay) this Amon Burned the Law of God, adding Rebellion to his Sin; He Imitates his Father in his Race and Rage of Sin, but not in his Repentance for Sin. God therefore ≈øoon cut him off (as judging it high time after a Year or Two Tryal) by the hands of his own Servants, 2 Kin. 21. 19, 23. which was a wicked Act in them, yet a ju≈øt Judgement from God, as he had Con≈øpir'd with Satan to De≈øtroy the Church; ≈øo God ≈øuffers his Servants to Con≈øpire his De≈øtruction. This Spoil'd the Devils Plot, and yet it was wor≈øe ≈øpoil'd by Jo≈øiah his Son, whom God Rais'd up (the 16th. King) to be his Salvation, (as his Name, which was given him about 340 Y. before he was Born, 1 Kin. 13. 2. doth ≈øignifie) and to be as a fre≈øh Spring after a ≈øharp Winter (as Hezekiah after Ahaz) to the Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Church: God had much Work for him to do in a little time, therefore God
≈øoon removes his Wicked Father out of the way, and ≈øets this godly Son upon the Throne betime, at Eight Y. old God Advances him thither, and there ≈øhows him (as on a Stage) to the World, as the Wonder of the World. Jo≈øiah zealou≈øly lays out his Life until he was 39 Y. old in Reforming Religion, removing all he knew to be Evil, and re≈øtoring all he under≈øtood to be good, even all he could po≈ø≈øibly do to Divert the De≈øolation of the Kingdom foretold by the Prophets, but then the Decree was even ready to bring forth, Zeph. 2. 2. God turned not away from his. Wrath, 2 Kin. 23. 26, 27. he is Unchangeably re≈øolv'd on their Utter Ruine, becau≈øe the Peoples Reformation was but ≈øeigned, Jer. 3. 10. and 4. 3. God is Ab≈øolute in Threatning, becau≈øe Re≈øolute in Puni≈øhing: Now the Devil, being notoriou≈øly Enraged at Jo≈øiahs Glorious reformation, Tempts him to a Fool-Hardy Ra≈øhne≈øs in Affronting Pharaoh-Necho without any provocation, and without Con≈øulting the Lord by Jeremiah, Zephaniah, &c. So he ru≈øhes upon his own ruine, v. 29. and 2 Chron. 35. 20, 22, 23. No doubt, but the Devil had an Hand in the Death of this peerle≈øs Prince, wherein Dyed al≈øo the Felicity of that Kingdom, for whom all Judah and Jeru≈øalem (as they had good cau≈øe) made great lamentation, v. 24, 25. yea, and 'tis no le≈øs to be doubted, that God had an Holy Hand (as the Devil had a wicked)
in Jo≈øiah's Death, for now he who ≈øtood in the way of Gods Judgements, was removed, and now the way lay open for the Divine Decree to bring forth, and all Gods Direful Threatnings to ru≈øh in upon that ≈øinful Nation: Yea, and God made good Jo≈øiah to Dye in Peace (according to his Word, 2 Kin. 2 ‚Ä¢ . 20.) though (through the Devils Temptation) he Dyed in War; for 1. he Dyed before that General Deluge of De≈øolation came on the Land, (as the next Word explains it:) 2. He Dyed in Gods favour, though by the Hand of an Enemy: 3. The Tenderne≈øs of his Soul had made War to become Peace to him, his Humiliation had Altered the very Nature of Trouble. 4. He went then to Everla≈øting peace: The Four la≈øt Kings were all Wicked as Jehoahaz (the 17th. King) Jo≈øiahs younger Son, and be≈øt beloved of his Subjects, who therefore ≈øettl'd him on the Throne, 2 Kin. 23. 30. but for his ill-Reigning, at Eight Months end Pharaoh-Necho Depo≈øes him, and Di≈øpo≈øes of his Crown to his Elder Brother Eliakim, whom he named Jehoiakim, v. 34. who was a great Exacter, and got from his Subjects a greater ≈øumm of Cur≈øes than of Coin, v. 35. he was the 18 King, a Degenerate Plant from Jo≈øiah, who Trembled at the Reading of the Law, Ch. 19. 34. but this Son cut it in pieces, Jer. 36. 23. and Burnt it: he flew ∆≤rijah the Prophet, Jer. 26. 23. and
would have ≈ølain Jeremy and Barach, but that the Lord hid them, Jer. 36. 26. For his Wickedne≈øs he was taken Captive by Nebuchadnezzar, again≈øt whom he had rebelled, and was ≈ølain in the way, where he had the Burial of an A≈øs, Jer. 22. 18, 19. His Son Coniah, or Jehoiakin (the 19th. King) is Wicked al≈øo, Jer. 22. 24, &c. and within Three Months ≈øurrenders the City, got Quarter for his Life, and U≈øed kindly after for his yielding, Ch. 24. 11. and 25. 27. Zedekiah (the 20th.) who≈øe Pride again≈øt God, 2 Chron. 36. 12. and Perjury to Nebuchadnezzar, prepared him for De≈øtruction, v. 13. And there was then a general Defection both of Prie≈øts and People; now Gods wrath comes on them without Remedy, v. 14, 16. the Devil is well-plea≈øed (as God was di≈øplea≈øed) to ≈øee the Temple burnt, and Judah carried Captive to Babylon.

argument.p: The Eighteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Babylon: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.
div.p:
NOW when the Devil had got the Church laid wa≈øt in Judah, and (as it is expre≈ø≈øed in Scripture) Buryed
in the Graves of Babylon, he made as ≈øure Work as he could to keep them down there; In order thereunto he made them Servants to Nebuchadnezzar and to his Sons, evil Merodach and Bel≈øhazzar, as the Prophet Jeremy had foretold, Jer. 27. 6, 7. yet this was not to fulfill the Will of the Devil, but the Word of the Lord, 2 Chron. 36. 20, 21. Until onely the Land had Enjoyed her Sabbaths; which had likewi≈øe been foretold, Levit. 26. 34, 35. and 23. 32. Ier. 25. 9, 12. and 29. 10. Dan. 9. 2. The Land was Ea≈øed of that Wicked weight which brought upon it Gods heavy Cur≈øes, and it had been toyled and tyr'd out with continual Tillage, and ≈øo they had got out the very Heart of it to ≈øpend it upon their Lu≈øts, (both) in a Neglect and Contempt of Gods Holy Sabbaths: ‚òû The good Lord divert from us the like Judgements (as an utter extirpation) for the like Sins: Oh how ≈øhould our notorious Provocations make us Weep over, and Tremble at the Word of the Lord, Ezek. 24. 13, 14. lea≈øt Ruine come upon us without Remedy, as upon I≈ørael and Iudah, whom Ezekiel calls Aholah and Aholibah, Ch. 23. 4. the Lewdne≈øs of both which God cau≈øed to cea≈øe, as a Caution to all Kingdoms, that they may Hear, Fear, and do ≈øo no more, v. 49, 49. and Ezek. 16. 51, 58, 59. where the ≈øame matter is Expre≈ø≈øed more plainly, (as in Ch. 23. 'tis ≈øpoken parabolically) yet this Thundering
Law God was plea≈øed mo≈øt graciou≈øly to qualifie with ≈øome ≈øerene Sun-≈øhine of the Go≈øpel, v. 60. Neverthele≈øs I will remember my Covenant. This ≈øpoil'd the Devils plot, who thought the Cup now put into the Churches Hand (in her Captivity) was ≈øo Deep and Large, Ezek. 23.32. that it had Eternity to the Bottom; but Gods Covenant of Grace ≈øtop'd her bitter Draught be times, (not by thy Covenant, to wit, of Works, made on Mount Sinai) but by my Covenant, to wit, of Grace, made on Mount Sion, Ezek. 16. 60, to 63. This de≈øtroy'd the Devils De≈øign of Burying the Church in the Babyloni≈øh-Grave of Everla≈øting oblivion, which was as Impo≈ø≈øible as to keep Chri≈øt in his Grave from a Glorious Re≈øurrection, Act. 2. 21. Rom. 1. 4. as the literal Body of Chri≈øt (our Redeemer,) ≈øo the My≈øtical Body of Chri≈øt (the Church) Swallows up Death in Victory, 1 Cor. 15. 54. The Lords Witne≈ø≈øes cannot be kept Under without a Glorious Re≈øurrection, Rev. 11. 10, 11. Oh how gladly would the Devil have (by his Agents) kept Chri≈øt fa≈øt in the Grave, when he had got him there? Hereupon his In≈øtruments (tho≈øe Kill-Chri≈øts) procures a Commi≈ø≈øion to do that ≈øervile Work on the Sabbath-day, in Securing and Sealing up Chri≈øts Sepulchre by Authority: So they went and made the Sepulchre ≈øure, Matth. 27. 66. and now the Devil Dances upon the Grave of Chri≈øt, as
thinking him≈øelf Cock-≈øure of him, but he that ≈øat in Heaven Sees and Smiles, Videt, Ridet, looks and laughs, and Laughs all to Nothing: he ≈øets his King (in de≈øpight of the Devil) upon his Holy Hill of Sion, P≈øal. 2.4, 6. and, as Daniel was brought out of his Sealed Den of Lyons, was made greater than ever; So the Church (that Pri≈øoner of Hope) is rais'd out of the Pit (out of the Graves of Babylon) by the Blood of the Covenant, Zech. 9. 11, 12. Gods Promi≈øe to this People is, that though they lay in Babylon as in a Sepulchre, and, as it were, buryed alive there, yea, and now nothing but bare Bones, yea, dry Bones, ≈øuch as were ready to crumble into Du≈øt; Their Ca≈øe being ≈øo de≈øperate, that they de≈øparingly ≈øay, [We are cut off for our parts,] hanging up their Hopes and their Harps together upon the Willows, P≈øal. 137. 1, 2, 3. yet God owneth them, ≈øaying, [Behold Oh my People,] though they little de≈øerved it, Ezek. 37. 3, 11, 12. [The Graves ≈øhall be Opened,] together with my Dead Body they ≈øhall Ari≈øe, I≈øa. 26. 19. Come my People, your Captivity is but your Chamber, a place of Re≈øt, I will bring you out thence; God ≈øent his Angel to Roul back the Stone, as an Officer ≈øent to let Chri≈øt out of Pri≈øon without the Keepers con≈øent, and ≈øat upon it, in de≈øpight of all their Arms, which the Guard let fall out of their Hands at the A≈øtoni≈øhing pre≈øence of the Angel, Matth. 28. 2, 3, 4.
There was an Earthquake at Chri≈øts Death, that Opened the Graves, Matth. 27. 52, 53. for the Earth could not bear his Suffering, and there was an Earthquake at Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection, for the Earth could not hinder his Ri≈øing, and Chri≈øt graciou≈øly Comforts his Di≈øponding Church in the Graves of Babylon; Thy Dead Men ≈øhall Ri≈øe, together with my Dead Body they ≈øhall Ari≈øe; Awake and Sing thou that dwelle≈øt in the Du≈øt, I≈øa. 26. ‚Ä¢ 9. Ari≈øe, and come away, Cant. 2. 10, 13. and till thy 70 Y. be Accompli≈øh'd, he ≈øaith, Come my People, Hide your ≈øelves in your Chambers of Re≈øt, or Babyloni≈øh Retirement, as it were for a little Moment, &c. Thus God lovingly be≈øpoke his people when they were led Captive to Babylon; as if leading them by the Hand to an hiding place of his own providing there, ≈øaying, I will make Babylon to you (Oh my People) what the Ark was to Noah, and what Zoar was to Lot, your Captivity ≈øhall be your Sanctuary; [Build ye Hou≈øes in Babylon and dwell in them, take ye Wives and beget Sons, and ≈øeck the peace of the City, Jer. 29. 5, 6, 7. (in a Land like your own Land for Fruitfulne≈øs, 2 Kin. 18, 32. As it is with ≈øundry Plants which lo≈øes their Stalks (as well as their Flowers) in Winter, yet ≈øhelter them≈øelves by their Roots in the Earth, the Ground is not their Grave, but their Sanctuary; a New Spring makes them live again to Bud and Blo≈ø≈øom: So it was the Churches
Winter-time in the Graves of Babylon, wherein God ≈øecured Sion, when an out-ca≈øt (as it were) under Ground, and trampled under foot, (as Roots of the mo≈øt beautiful Plants in Winter) yet Behold how the Lord Cheri≈øhes the Churches Root there, and then with Thoughts of Peace and Love, to give her an Expected End of her Winter, and to bring a fre≈øh spring upon her, Jer. 29. 11, to 14. and 30. 17. 'Tis very remarkable, that tho≈øe Jews who were in Babylon (though as Buryed there) Fared far better than tho≈øe that were left and liv'd in Canaan; for God Spoke in the hearts of their Enemies for the Former, and made their Foes to Favour them; God Interceeded for them with the Chaldeans, Jer. 15. 11. Verily it ≈øhall be well with thy Remnant; Hebr. If it be not well, &c. and If I do not cau≈øe, &c. as if the Lord had ≈øaid, Then never Tru≈øt Me more, never look on Me as Lord or Ma≈øter of My Word more: But the latter that ≈øtill liv'd in their own Land, were within a little while Involv'd in Woful Mi≈øery by I≈øhmaels Murdering of Gedaliah, many of them were Ma≈ø≈øacr'd, and the re≈øt went down to Aegypt, (expre≈øly contrary to Gods Command, Deut. 17. 16. and the Prophets Coun≈øel, Jer. 42. 14.) where they found no ≈øuch Graves to Re≈øt in, (as their Brethren found in Babylon) but while they ≈øought to run from Death, they run to it, v. 22. and Jer. 43. 9, 11. and 46.
13, 15, 17, 24. Yet ≈øo compa≈ø≈øionate is God to his Church's-Relick there, that while he is denouncing the Doom, and foretelling the Conque≈øt of Aegypt, yea, and of Babylon too afterwards, (for Per≈øecuting the Church, Jer. 50. 1, 9. &c.) The Lord Intermingles his Comminations again≈øt Aegypt and Babylon with ≈øweet Con≈øolations to Sion, Jer. 46. 27. but Fear not thou, Oh my Servant Jacob, &c. I will make an End of all the Nations whither I have driven thee, but I will not make a full End of thee, but Correct thee in mea≈øure: ‚òû Oh the Bleeding of Divine Bowels over his Captivated Church, in this con≈øolatory Clau≈øe, God could not find in his Heart to make a full End of her, as Ho≈ø. 11.8. but keeps their Room empty all the 70 Y. till the return of the Natives, his Church. The Devil undoubtedly gave Judahs land, (as he had given the land of the Ten Tribes) primo occupaturo, to him that could catch and Conquer it fir≈øt: he was a Bla≈øphemous U≈øurper in his ≈øaying to Chri≈øt, [To whom≈øoever I will, I give it,] Luk. 4. 6. wherein he Robbs God of the chiefe≈øt Jewel in his Imperial Crown, Dan. 4. 32, 17, 25. Thus the Pope (like the Devils Heir) takes upon him to be Lord of all (that Incommunicable Attribute of Chri≈øt, Act. 10. 36) both Temporals and Spirituals in all Countries and Kingdoms: So Boniface the 8. (that Antichri≈øt) ≈øtiled him≈øelf to Phillip King of France; and ≈øo did his Succe≈ø≈øor
to our Henry the 8. whom he Excommunicated from the Church, Depo≈øed him from his Crown, and Di≈øpo≈øed of his Kingdom to him that could fir≈øt Win it, ≈øo far as his Roaring Bull (which yet proov'd but a brute Thunder-bolt) might Accompli≈øh; no le≈øs had the Devil (his Ma≈øter, Father, and God) done concerning the Kingdom of Judah. Neverthele≈øs the God of I≈ørael would not ≈øuffer any of tho≈øe Warlike Adver≈øaries (that ≈øurrounded Judea) ≈øo much as to De≈øire their Land, Exod. 34. 23, 24. when they left it unmann'd thrice in the Year, much le≈øs Invade it; and this Providence is yet more marvellous, that while their land was empty of its Inhabitants for 70 Y. together, yet none of tho≈øe Neighbour-Nations (which always Watched, yet never Catched an Opportunity) do make a Seizure of that tempting Glory of all Lands, Ezek. 20. 6. when the Prophet Jeremiah hath done Denouncing dreadful Woes again≈øt Aegypt, and all other Adver≈øaries of the Church, (nine in number) he comes to his 10th. even Babylon; and oh how amazing it is to Con≈øider how in his giving out Confounding Corra≈øives to Proud Babylon. He ≈øtill ≈øcatters mo≈øt Comfortable Cordials to drooping and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Sion, as Ch. 50. 4, 19, 20. The Iniquity of lacob ≈øhall be ≈øought for, and there ≈øhall be none, Ch. 51. 5. Judah hath not been for ≈øaken, &c. v. 44, 45. God will make Babel ≈øpue
up his Church as too Hot a Mouthful, and that cannot be di≈øge≈øted, and ≈øtill, My People, no rea≈øon can be rendred, why Iudah was not con≈øumed as well as the Ten Tribes, and the Ten Nations, but Gods never-failing Compa≈ø≈øions, Lam. 3. 22. his mindfulne≈øs of the Covenant of giving David a Lamp alway, 2 Kin. 8. 19. the Lord ≈øaid not, that he would blot out the Name of I≈ørael from under Heaven, 2 Kin. 14. 2, 7. Hereupon he ≈øent Prophets all along, 2 Chron. 24. 19. to comfort the good Figs, as to Confound the bad ones, Jer. 24. 25, 8. Finally, when the Devil had got the Church [the good Figs] in Babylon [as the bad Figs] in Aegypt, yea, and Fetter'd them there, until ≈øhe was become as very dry bones, and in a deep Grave too, with a great Stone upon it, in≈øomuch that ≈øhe looks upon her ≈øelf in a forlorn Condition, and that no Created power or Natural means could po≈ø≈øibly recover her, ≈øaying, Can the≈øe dry Bones live? &c. Ezek. 37.3, 11. they ≈øay (as it were) Let them Hope that Hope can, There is now no Hope, Ier. 2. 25. the le≈øs Hope that the Church had, the more Hope the Devil hath to win the Game: but the great and Gracious God comes with a [Liberate] ≈øerves a Writ of [Quare Impedit] upon the Devil for Detaining them, this ≈øpoils all his Sport, God Commands his Angels to Roul away the great Stone that lay upon the Mouth of his Churches Tomb, Sealed down with
the Devils Seal upon it, (as Daniels Den was with that of Darius, Dan. 6. 17.) then Opened he the Graves according to his Promi≈øe, Ezek. 37. 12. the ≈øame God who vouch≈øafed to be a Grave-maker for Mo≈øes Per≈øon, Deut. 34. 6. vouch≈øafes now to become a Grave-Opener for Mo≈øes People; when he had opened their Graves (with a Non-ob≈øtante-Writ,) the People were there pre≈øerved Alive (as they had been buryed Alive,) for God had ≈øent his Angel to ≈øhut the Mouth of that all-Devouring Lyon, Death, (as he did to the Lyons in Daniels Den, Dan. 6. 22.) Hebr. 11. 33. ≈øo that the Savage and Hunger-≈øtarv'd Death had not ≈øeiz'd upon them, P≈øal. 55. 15. with a Writ of Habeas Corpus, or taking their Bodies, like as an au≈øtere and over-Lordly Landlord attaques his poor Tenants, or as a cruel Creditor doth his failing Debtor; or as that mercile≈øs Man in the Go≈øpel, who took his Fellow by the Throat, and ≈øaid, [Pay that thou owe≈øt me,] Matth. 18. 28, 33. neither had the Devil (that Roaring Lyon, [≈øeeking whom he may Devour,] 1 Pet. 5. 8.) ≈øerv'd the other Writ of [Habeas Animam] or attaching their Souls, to carry them away into his Dungeon of Darkne≈øs: Oh what a miracle of Mercy was here manife≈øted, that neither the Cold Grave could contain their Bodies, nor Hot Hell catch their Souls: Death had not fed upon them, neither was their Beauty con≈øumed in the Grave, as P≈øal.
49. 14. but tho≈øe ∆≤pright ones had dominion over Death and Devil in the Morning, (after the long Night of their 70 Y. Captivity was ended) in a dawning Day: But ≈øuppo≈øe they had been of that Moyety of Mankind that lye dead in the Grave, as P≈øal. 88. 5. and that Death had not onely ≈øeiz'd, but al≈øo fed upon them, and had Gnawed them to the very bones, leaving nothing but bare bones; yea, ≈øuppo≈øe tho≈øe bones had been dryed, yea, ≈øo very much dryed, ex Vetu≈øtate, & Carie, both ≈øo old and ≈øo rotten, as ready to moulder into Du≈øt at the lea≈øt Touch: yet the great God, who comes to ≈øtand over the≈øe Opened Graves, (as Chri≈øt did over Lazarus's, Joh. 11. 38, 41.) and who by his Almighty Power can quicken the Dead, and call things that are not as if they were, Rom. 5. 17. Joh. 5. 28. I≈øa. 26. 19. Ho≈ø. 13. 14. he cryeth (with ≈øome Groanings over the Grave,) Lazarus, Judah, Oh my People, Oh my Church, come forth, Joh. 11. 43. Ezek. 37. 12. Yea, he Roareth mightily from on high, Ier. 25. 30. like the lu≈øty Lyon finding his Whelps dead in his Den at their birth, he falls a Roaring ≈øo fiercely, that (as Pliny Reports) they pre≈øently revive and ri≈øe up. So the Lyon of the Tribe of Iudah Roareth here to the like purpo≈øe, and much more at the la≈øt Day, 1 The≈ø≈ø. 4. 16. 1 Cor. 15. 52. together with Gods Word there goeth out a Power, Luk. 5. 17. (as when he ≈øaid, Lazarus come forth.)
So it is in the fir≈øt Re≈øurrection, and ≈øo it ≈øhall be in the la≈øt, Joh. 5. 25, 28, 29. If God do but Speak to the dry bones, ≈øaying, Ye ≈øhall Live, &c. accordingly it is done, as in the Creation of the World, Gen. 1. 3, 6, 9, 14, &c. The Admirable Work of this great World was all made by a bare Word out of the Mouth of the Almighty God, and He who could give a being out of nothing at the fir≈øt, can more ea≈øily re≈øtore a Being out of ≈øomething again, as out of dry Bones here. This great Truth, Ezekiel (Gods Interpreter) excellently Evidenceth in his Parabolical and Typical Vi≈øion of the dry Bones, mo≈øt aptly Applyed and Accomodated to the Jewi≈øh-Church in the Graves of Babylon, which yet was Reviv'd, Ezek. 37. v. 7. (1.) By a Noi≈øe, or Rattle, to wit, ≈øome Roaring Thunderclap. (2.) By a Shakeing, as that of the Earthquake at Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection, Matth. 28. 2. the Earth did ≈øhake then to let Chri≈øt out of his Grave, and now to let the Church out: and when God delivers his Church from my≈øtical Babylon, he will ≈øhake Heaven as well as Earth, Hebr. 12. 26, 27. he will ≈øhake the old Heaven and the old Earth, to ≈øettle the New Heaven, and the New Earth, 2 Pet. 3. 12, 13. Gods Shakeing concludes with Settling; 'tis not to Ruine, but to Refine his Church: Oh what a Noi≈øe and what a Shakeing was made here, by Ordinary Means (as well as by Extraordinary, in the
Thunderelap above, and in the Earthquake below;) to wit, (1.) by the Power of Prayer. (2.) by a prevalent Proclamation: (1.) Prayer hath a ≈øhakeing Power, Act. 4. 31. Yea, and a ratling Noi≈øe or Sound with it, Act. 2. 2. (as Ezekiels Vi≈øion of the dry bones had both tho≈øe Two extraordinary and ≈øen≈øible Signs of Gods powerful pre≈øence) ≈øo the Spirit of God came upon tho≈øe Praying Ones as a Spirit of Power, 2 'Tim. 1. 7. and ≈øhakes the place of Prayr (with a mighty ru≈øhing Wind) and ≈øhakes the Per≈øons too at that fir≈øt planting of the Go≈øpel, as Planters do to young Plants that they may ≈øettle the better. Now this Powerful Prayr (for the Jewi≈øh-Churches Re≈øtoration out of Babylon) was Threefold, 1. That of Solomon, 1 Kin. 8. from 46, to 54. this very Prayr (though made about 468 Y. before) ≈øhakes the Heart of the Per≈øian Prince (Cyrus) ≈øo, as to ≈øhew Compa≈ø≈øion to Gods poor people in Babylon, and at length gives them leave to Return: thus Jacobs Prayr, [God Almighty give you Mercy,] or Hebr. Bowels, Gen. 43. 14. was particularly An≈øwer'd, when Jo≈øephs Bowels yerned over Benjamin, v. 30. 2. That of Daniel, when he ∆≤nder≈øtood by Books how the 70 Y. were expired; then he puts Gods Promi≈øe in Suit, and ≈øpeaks nothing in his Prayers but what God had ≈øpoke in his Promi≈øes, and ≈øo was An≈øwer'd by God in his Providences, Dan. 9. 2, 4, 20. This Prayr ≈øhakes
Heaven, brings from thence Gabriel, who tells him, for the 70 Y. Captivity, they ≈øhall enjoy their own Countrey Seven Seventies, or 490 Y. v. 24. 3. That of the People, who Prayed, Fa≈øted, and Wept by the Waters of Babylon, P≈øal. 137. 1, 2, 3. 1 Kin. 8. 47, 48. Zech. 7. 5. Tho≈øe Three Actions in tho≈øe 70 Y. ≈øhows the Church was no more Dead in Babylon, than Daniel was in his Den, for they are all Actions of the Living, not of the Dead: They Sow in Tears the precious Seed of Prayr (Wing'd with Fa≈øting,) ≈øo Reaps at la≈øt in joy. Their De≈øolate Countrey made them Di≈øcon≈øolate Souls, yet their Sighs unutterable brought Joy ∆≤n≈øpeakable, P≈øal. 126. 1, 2, 5, 6. Then comes the (2d. Shake) Cyrus prevalent Proclamation, (the Lord ≈øtirring up his Spirit to it) Ezra 1. 1, &c. This turn'd the Churches Tears into Triumphs, her Sighing into Singing, her Sadne≈øs into Gladne≈øs. And the Devil (for all his Plots) hath the Contrary to all the≈øe, is Sad at his Defeat, and goes learing away. Now when God (in who≈øe Hand are the Hearts of all Kings, Prov. 21.1.) had mo≈øt Happily ≈øtirr'd up the Spirit of Cyrus to I≈ø≈øue out his mo≈øt Gracious Proclamation of a Jubilee to the Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Church, (wherein he was a Type of Chri≈øt, Proclaiming Liberty to the Captives, and the Opening of the Pri≈øon to them that are Bound, I≈øa. 61. 1.) and to give her ≈øo fair and full a Patent, this Mighty,
Marvellous, and Immediate Work of Divine Mercy (in her ≈øo deplorable mi≈øery) did ≈øo ≈øurprize her, that ≈øhe could hardly believe her own Eyes, but was for a while as tho≈øe that Dream, P≈øal. 126. 1. This was the Lords own Doing, and mo≈øt Marvellous in the Churches Eyes, P≈øal. 118. 23. e≈øpecially upon tho≈øe Re≈øpects. (1.) That their Graves ≈øhould be opened. (2.) That their dry Bones ≈øhould live again, ≈øtand upon their Feet, walk home into their own Countrey, build a Temple, &c. (3.) That Cyrus, an Heathen King, (who did not know the Lord, Sc. ≈øavingly, I≈øa. 45. 4, 5.) ≈øhould not onely be called by Name, (above 170 Y. before he was Born) to become the Lords Shepherd to Feed his di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Church, I≈øa. 44. 28. but al≈øo (4.) in the very Entrance into his Monarchy, before his Affairs were fully ≈øettled) to Di≈ømi≈øs ≈øo great and ≈øo United a People (in their Religion and Cu≈øtom) and ≈øo given to In≈øurrection (as their Character was, Ezra 4. 12, 19.) and to Return them into their own Land with all manner of Accomodations both for State and Strength. (5.) 'Twas mo≈øt marvellous, That this Decree or Proclamation ≈øhould be Signed, not onely, 1. Preci≈øely, at the End of Daniels Prayer, Dan. 9. 21, 23. and 10. 12, 14. No ≈øooner was Daniels Prayer out of his Mouth, but it was pre≈øently in Gods Ear, and no ≈øooner was it there, but Immediately Gabriel comes po≈øting
upon the Wing, with an An≈øwer, That (the 70 Y. being Expired) the Decree for their Liberty was now Signed, but al≈øo, 2. Exactly at the End of the 70 Y. Captivity, neither more nor le≈øs. God will come according to his Promi≈øe, Jer. 25. 12. and 29. 10. but Daniels Prayers mu≈øt lead him; thus he will have it to be: and God will be Punctual in keeping his Word: a Day (with Men) breaks no ≈øquares, it doth with God. Hence tho≈øe Two great Deliverances (out of Aegypt and Babylon, and this latter more Marvellous than the former, Jer. 16. 14, 15.) hath Two ≈øpecial Remarques upon them in their Accompli≈øhment at a Punctual and Preci≈øe point of Time promi≈øed, as 1. That very Night (wherein the Fir≈øt-born of Aegypt were ≈ølain) was the Ending of the foretold Four Hundred Y. Exod. 12. 40, 41. And 2. That very Night (wherein Bel≈øhazzar was Slain by Cyrus and Darius) was exactly the Expiration of the foretold 70 Y. Dan. 5. 30. ‚òû This is the Churches Cordial and Comfort, though God ≈øometimes fails to come at her time, yet he never fails to come at his own time.

argument.p: The Nineteenth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Judea: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.
div.p:
THe Church of God (through his Over-ruling Hand) having got this Royal Wind under her Wings, flyes Swiftly out of Babylon to Canaan, there to re-Build the Hou≈øe of the Lord, (one of the Seven Wonders of the World) and to Repair the City of Jeru≈øalem, that Holy City, Ezra 1. 5. then Ro≈øe up Zerubabel, the Chief Prince, and Jo≈øhuah, the Chief Prie≈øt, with all the Heads of the Families, the Prie≈øts and Levites, with all their Children, Men and Maid-Servants, in all 7337, Ezra 2. 65. who≈øe Spirits God had rai≈øed up, leading them into the Land of Uprightne≈øs, P≈øal. 143. 10. 1 Chro. 9. 3. Ezek. 37. 16, 17, 21, 22. many I≈øraelites joyned with the Jews: Tho≈øe (by the good Hand of God upon them) 1. ≈øetts up the Altar, Ezra 3. 3. in the place where the Temple ≈øtood, (for, as yet, they had none) v. 6. that by their Prayers and Offerings thereon,
they might get God on their ≈øide, and run to him Reconciled, what ever evil ≈øhould befall them from their Evil and Malignant Neighbours.

Then tho≈øe Godly and Active Souls (not being content with the Altar of God onely, but De≈øirous (as we ≈øhould all be) of all Gods Ordinances) lay the Foundation of the Temple, v. 10. Then did the Devil Rage, projects (his 19th.) a new Plot again≈øt the Church, which indeed is a Complication of Plots, as the Books of Ezra and Nehemiah doth Demon≈øtrate. The 1≈øt. part of the Devils 19th. Plot, was to ≈øtirr up (1) the Samaritans to ob≈øtruct the Super≈øtructure of the Temple upon the Now and New-laid Foundation, (2) the Governors of the Land, to wit, Tatnai and Shether-Boznai, when they began to Build again after the fir≈øt Ob≈øtruction: 1. The Samaritans Satan Awaken'd and Rouzed up at the loud Acclamations and Out-cries, (Partim Jubilando, partim Ejulando, ≈øome ≈øhouting aloud for Joy, and others howling aloud for Sorrow, Ezra 3. 9, 12, 13. Tho≈øe Adver≈øaries of Judah, Devi≈øes Two De≈øigns again≈øt the Children of the Captivity, to wit, the Church: Their (1.) Plot or De≈øign was mo≈øt Craftily to offer their own co≈øt and pains to promote the Building of the Temple, Ezra 4. 1, 8. Here the Devil pretends Devotion to promote his Diveli≈øh De≈øign: Tho≈øe Mongrels
in Religion (who put it on and off at plea≈øure) would have mingled with the Church, and would Compound with them here, when they ≈øaw they could not Conquer them, that would break through all Difficulties and Di≈øcouragements, and do their Duty, Ezra 3. 3. and this Accomodation they ≈øet on with a loud lye, ≈øaying, We ≈øeek your God, as ye do, which they did not, 2 Kin. 17. 28, 29, 32, 34. for they feared the Lord not Filially, but for his Lyons: Thus they Pretend Amity, but indeed, Intend Enmity, and breeding of New Broils by their Intermixed Influence, ≈øo as to Hinder the Building: This is the very practice of the Je≈øuits at this Day, who pretend Conver≈øion, and comming over to the Prote≈øtants, yet tho≈øe Ca≈ø≈øandrian Reconcilers intend Subver≈øion by the bitter Contentions they keep alive in the Church to hinder Reformation: but the Lord will Detect and Defeat them as he did tho≈øe Samaritans, whom his Servants repuls'd, telling them, Ye have nothing to do with us, but we our ≈øelves together (or alone) will Build the Temple, for which Doing they had Royal Authority, v. 3. So it was a Godly Combination, no Wicked Con≈øpiracy or Faction: In a Word, They ≈øtand off from them, 1 Tim. 6. 5. not accepting of their fal≈øe Service, for the Jews have no Dealing with the Samaritans, Joh. 4. 9. When this 1≈øt. De≈øign of the Devil (in tho≈øe Samaritans)
was Di≈øappointed, then the 2d. was, their Hiring of Coun≈øellours, that others might Hinder the Work; which they (them≈øelves) could not, v. 4, 5. Such Coun≈øellours as can Conde≈øcend to Bribing for bol≈øtering up a bad Cau≈øe, or for Brow-beating a good one, Ju≈øtifying the Wicked for a Reward, and condemning the Righteous, are the mo≈øt probable Promoters of the Devils Helli≈øh Plots and Projects: Tho≈øe Sordid Silver-Lovers, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] being Courtiers, had a fair opportunity to fru≈øtrate the Purpo≈øe of the Church; Ina≈ømuch as Cyrus Warring abroad again≈øt the Scythians, &c. made Camby≈øes, his Son, the Vice-Roy; and he, being a light, loo≈øe and lewd lo≈ø≈øel, was ea≈øily prevail'd with to ob≈øtruct the Building: If Cyrus did connive at the Cro≈ø≈øing of his own Decree (by his Son) all his Days, then his Fatal Fall by Tomyris (Queen of Scythia, who Conquer'd him, cut off his Head, ca≈øts it into a Ve≈ø≈øel full of Blood, ≈øaying, Satia te Sanguine quem Siti≈øti, Cuju≈øque In≈øatiabilis ≈øemper fui≈øti; Glut thy ≈øelf now with Blood, whereof thou could never get enough) was a Ju≈øt Reward from the God of Ju≈øtice: This Camby≈øes, (who is call'd Artaxerexes in the Per≈øian, and Aha≈øuerus in the Chaldee-Tongue, Names given in common to Kings of Per≈øia, (as Pharaoh to the Kings of Aegypt, &c.) ≈øignifying, Great Warriour, or Great-Head) tho≈øe Courtifi'd Coun≈øellors
Writes to, and turning Informers, Wrote a Diveli≈øh Accu≈øation, Hebr. [Satana] a Satanical Sugge≈øtion) Hatcht in Hell, and Dictated by the Devil, the Contents of it being Fal≈øe and Scandalous; for then they had not begun either with Building the City or the Walls of it, v. 6, 12, 14. Tho≈øe Mercenary Pick-Thanks obtains hereby a Commi≈ø≈øion to cau≈øe the Work of the Hou≈øe of God to cea≈øe, v. 24. The Hindring of the Temple-Building was the Principal thing Intended, though the Building of the City and of its Walls was fal≈øly Pretended. This Plot proves ≈øo powerful, that though the Propher Daniel, (and Gabriel, Dan. 10. 13.) Remain'd there with Camby≈øes and his Coun≈øellors, to repre≈øs their Rage, and to Bla≈øt their Projects again≈øt the Church; and though he was a great Man ≈øtill with the Kings of Per≈øia, (as he had been long with the Kings of Babylon, and ≈øo, marvellou≈øly U≈øeful to the Churches Pre≈øervation during her Captivity) though ≈øtill he was in great Account, (after her Return out of Babyloni≈øh-Bondage) yet was he not now Great enough at Court, ≈øo as to Defeat the Devili≈øh De≈øigns of Camby≈øes his Bribed Coun≈øellours, who had now put a Stop to the Temple-Building at Jeru≈øalem: This Di≈øa≈øter ca≈øts Holy Daniel into his Melancholly-Dumps, Dan. 10. 1, 2, 3. in the 3d. Y. of Cyrus (which was the fir≈øt of Irreligious Camby≈øes Reigning as a Vice-Roy in his Fathers
ab≈øence, as above, Ezra 4.6.) Daniel Under≈øtanding the Stop to Temple-Work, falls a Fa≈øting and Praying Three Weeks, becau≈øe the Prince of the Kingdom of Per≈øia with≈øtood him, v. 13. for ≈øo long a time, even Three Weeks, or One and Twenty Days: This [Him] thus with≈øtood, is the Angel Gabriel as well as the Prophet Daniel, and this Prince (that with≈øtood them both) is Wicked Camby≈øes, or that Evil Angel, the Devil, who had an Hand in the Stop, and ≈øet Camby≈øes on Work to Re≈øtrain the Re-edifying of the Hou≈øe of the Lord. Yet may we not Imagine that any Earthly Prince hath any power over an Holy and Heavenly Angel; No, not, though he hath the Devil to Help him, as here Camby≈øes had: but, ina≈ømuch as Camby≈øes (this New King of Per≈øia) had Hindred the Temple-Work (by Divine Permi≈ø≈øion,) he had thereby Hindred Gabriel from bringing Daniel the glad Tidings, which otherwi≈øe he had ≈øooner brought him, ≈øeeing his Prayers were (both) Heard and Granted from the fir≈øt of tho≈øe 21 Days, v. 12. Though this Grant was not made known by Gabriel to Daniel until Daniel had been Tugging hard with God for an An≈øwer all that Three Weeks; at the End whereof Gabriel comes flying ≈øwiftly, as Dan. 9. 21. Hebr. with wearine≈øs of Flight, as if glad of the Good News him≈øelf, thinking (as it were) his Wings could not carry him fa≈øt enough to
Comfort Di≈øcon≈øolate Daniel, as Ahimaaz (who over-ran Cu≈øhi) thought his Leggs could not carry him over-fa≈øt to Comfort Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed David, 2 Sam. 18. 23. 'Twas Gabriel that brought the good Tidings, but 'twas Daniel that brought him (who brought them) by his Prayers: the Angel ≈øaith, Now I am come for thy Word, v. 12, 14. Though I have ≈øtayed thus long, further telling him, Camby≈øes (and the Devil by him) had ≈øo ≈øtrongly with≈øtood his Mini≈øtring Office for the Churches Good in the Per≈øian Court, that he ≈øtood in need of the Help of Michael, that Angel of the Covenant, or Lord of Angels, One of the Chief Princes, v. 13. One of the Three Per≈øons of the Trinity, or Chief of the Angels, or, Sept.
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ the Chearful Ones, (who ≈øerve the Lord Chearfully in his Wars.) this Chief One was the Me≈ø≈øiah, who is Elegantly De≈øcrib'd, v. 6. an≈øwerable to that De≈øcription of Chri≈øt, Revel. 1. 10, 13, to 15. and 19. 12. Hence ob≈øerve that Gabriel ≈øtood in need of the Help of Michael or Me≈ø≈øiah (which is a better Help than that of Angels) again≈øt the Adver≈øaries of the Church, to Repre≈øs and Suppre≈øs their further Crafty Coun≈øels and Cruel Contrivances again≈øt her: This is a ≈øtanding Cordial to the Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Church, That She hath a Champion who will ≈øtand by her and for her, though all Wicked Men on Earth, and all the Wretched Devils in Hell ≈øtand again≈øt
her and with≈øtand her. Thus the Angel Gabriel Comforts Dejected Daniel, (who Sadly Sympathiz'd with the Sad Suffering-Church, v. 15.) that none Help'd the Angels again≈øt the Churches Enemies, but Michael her Prince, v. 21. and Dan. 9. 25, 26. He is the King and Head of his Church, and Saviour of his Body, Ephe≈ø. 5. 22, 23. ≈øee Jo≈øh. 5. 14. Ezek. 34. 24. Act. 5. 31. Revel. 1. 5. and 19. 16. This is Comfortable, that when the poor Church hath no Humane Helps, yet hath ≈øhe Angelical. The Angel Gabriel telleth Daniel, I will Return (now I have Delivered my Joyful Emba≈ø≈øage to thee) and Fight again≈øt the King of Per≈øia, v. 20. Ch. 10. to wit, Camby≈øes and all his Wicked Coun≈øellours, who are ≈øett on by the Devil, and who ≈øetts on their In≈øtruments, which went up in ha≈øte, to cau≈øe the Work of the Hou≈øe of God to cea≈øe, Ezr. 4. 23, 24. the Devil driving them, and their own Malignant Di≈øpo≈øition (like a ≈øtrong Bya≈ø≈øe) drawing them thereunto: but (≈øaith Gabriel) I will with≈øtand them (who hath hitherto with≈øtood me) and Confound all their Plots and Proceedings again≈øt the Church; I will Return and Fini≈øh that War which I have le≈øt (to come with Tydings to thee) Unfini≈øhed; and though not One (of the Princes or Potentates) joyn with me to An≈øwer thy Prayers and Favour the Church, yet know, the Arch-Angel, Michael or Chri≈øt, concerns him≈øelf, and
this is enough: Oh how many mu≈øt we Reckon the Me≈ø≈øiah for? as Antigonus ≈øaid of him≈øelf to his timerous Army, that Trembled at the multitude of their Adver≈øaries: This Michael (≈øignifying, who is like thee) is of him≈øelf a whole Army of Men, Van and Rear both, I≈øa. 52. 12. If he be for us, 'tis no matter who's again≈øt us, Rom. 8. 31. Hence the Devils Plot began to be Spoiled; this Mighty Michael ≈øtirs up Two Prophets (Haggai and Zechariah) to Stir up the People to Return to their Building, Ezr. 5. 1. Zerubabel and Je≈øhua (the Prophets of God Helping them) carry on the Temple-building which had been begun before; then the Devil Rages again≈øt them, being ever an Adver≈øary to the Hou≈øe of God and to the things thereof; He Stirs up Tatnai and Shether-Boznai (with their Complices) to Interrupt them in Building Gods Hou≈øe, (though they never oppo≈øed them in Building their own Hou≈øes) by Asking their Authority, and (ju≈øt like our Informers) requiring their names, Ezr. 5. 3, 4. but the Eye of their God was upon the Elders (that Eye not onely of general Providence, but al≈øo that of Special Grace) to Animate them in their Work) ≈øo that they could not make them to cea≈øe, v. 5. And hereupon tho≈øe Governours Write a Letter to Darius Hy≈øta≈øpes, (who Succeeded Camby≈øes) wherein they give a fair Relation, but with a foul Intention. The Devil and his In≈øtruments had
now the Ball upon their Foot, thinking to carry the Game before them (having now got the Governours on their ≈øides) and that none could come neer to overtake them; but behold! the Triumph of the Wicked is ≈øhort, Job 20. 5. The Pillar of Providence pur≈øues them (as with an Hue and Cry) comes up to them at Darius Court-Rolls, Ezr. 5. 17. and 6. 1. There that Commi≈ø≈øion of Cyrus for rebuilding the Temple was found, (which they had ≈øugge≈øted in their Malicious Letter would not be found, hoping the Jews would be found Lyars) the Contents whereof was, That none ≈øhould come at them to Hinder them, none ≈øhould meddle with them to make di≈øturbance, if any dur≈øt Di≈øturb, let his Hou≈øe be pull'd down for a Penalty, and let all Kings and People (that dare Di≈øturb them) be De≈øtroyed, [a Dreadful Cur≈øe, and ≈øuch as God ≈øaith Amen to,] Ezr. 6. 6, 7, 11, 12. The finding of thid Decree of Cyrus (with tho≈øe Contents, &c.) was a marvellous good Providence to the Di≈øturbed Church; the Malice of her Adver≈øaries in Writing that Malicious Letter, prooved a great Furtherance to the Fini≈øhing of the Temple, as Pauls Per≈øecution at Rome prooved not an Hinderance, but a Furtherance of the Go≈øpel, Phil. 1. 12.) For hereupon Camby≈øes's Wicked Decree (of Hindring Temple-Work) was far Removed, as Micah had foretold, Mic. 7. 11. and tho≈øe very Governours
(the Churches Adver≈øaries) do (upon the Receiving of Cyrus Decree by Darius) 1. Pay in the Kings Tribute to defray the Charges of Building the Temple; and 2. ≈øend in all manner of Sacrifices, when fini≈øhed, v. 12, 13, 8, 9. Thus God ≈øtill over-≈øhoots Satan in his own Bow, cau≈øes the very Dogs to lick the Sores of Lazarus, and makes all things to work for good to them that love God, Rom. 8. 28. Jo≈øephus and E≈ødras ≈øay, Darius granted all this upon Zerubabels excellent Di≈øcour≈øe, how Women was ≈øtronger than Wine, too ≈øtrong for Kings, yet Truth is ≈øtronge≈øt of all. Then the Lord Removed the Decree (of Hindring the Building) a≈øar off, Mic. 7. 11. by Darius's Commi≈ø≈øion, Ezra 5. 3. and 6. 1. So that notwith≈øtanding all the Oppo≈øitions from Wicked Men and a Wretched Devil, in the 6th. Y. of Darius, the Temple of God is Fini≈øhed, and the Dedication of it is Solemnly Ob≈øerved, Ezra 6. 15, 16. (about 15 Y. after the Foundation had been laid) Yea, and the Pa≈ø≈øeover al≈øo, v. 19, 20, 21, 22. Neither was this all the Lord did for his Churches Weal, Romovendo Prohibentia, in Removing Hinderances out of her way, but al≈øo [Applicando Adiutoria] in Contributing Furtherances, not onely in making their very Adver≈øaries to become their Auxiliaries, as before, v. 13. (who did lend her Sacrifices of all ≈øorts, and that Speedily, according to
Darius Decree, becau≈øe they dur≈øt do no otherwi≈øe) but al≈øo in Sending her Ezra in the 7th. of Darius, (call'd by that common Name of the Per≈øian Kings, Artaxerxes) to ≈øtrengthen their Hands in the Lords Work, and to make a wonderful Reformation, Ezra 7. 1. &c. and Ch. 8. and Ch. 9. Thus the Vi≈øion of Zachary, Zech. 1. 17, 22. (who Prophecy'd at that time) was Accompli≈øh'd in the greate≈øt part, for he ≈øaw four Horns who ≈øought to ≈øcatter Judah, to wit, Rehum and Shim≈øhai, Ezra 4. 17, 23. Tatnai and Shether-Boznai, Ch. 5. 6. and he ≈øaw four Carpenters to break tho≈øe Horns, to wit, Zerubabel, (call'd al≈øo She≈øh-bazzar, ≈øignifying, Joy in Tribulation) Jo≈øhua, (a Saviour) Ezna, (an Helper) and (to Compleat the Number of Four, God ≈øent his Church Nehemiah, (≈øignifying, the Comfort of the Lord) in the 20th. Y. of this Darius, Artaxerxes; with a full Commi≈ø≈øion from the King to repair the Walls of the Holy City, after that the Altar and Temple had been re-Built by other Hands. Hereupon began the 2d. part of the Devils 19th. Plot, who ≈øtirred up Pe≈øtilent oppo≈øition again≈øt the Church both from Without and from Within. (1.) From Without, by open and profe≈øs'd Enemies, to wit, Sanball at, Tobiah, and Ge≈øhum the Arabian, Neh, 2. 10, 19. Sanballat (which ≈øignifies a pure Enemy) and Tobiah, (that Advanced Va≈ø≈øal) were ≈øo Sly and Subtle, (being
the Old Serpents Di≈øciples) as to In≈øinuate by Allyances to the High-Prie≈øt, Neh. 13. 4, 28. yet were mortal Enemies to the Church, and 1. It grieved them exceedingly, that there was come a Man to ≈øeek the Welfare of I≈ørael, Neh. 2. 10. had they been Ingenious, their very Alliance to I≈ørael ≈øhould have made them Rejoyce in I≈øraels Pro≈øperity; but the Cur≈øed Malice of this Moabite and Ammonite, had ≈øwallowed up all the ≈øparks of common Ingenuity. This is the (1≈øt) Appearance of the Devil in them, they look'd upon Nehemiah with a lowring look, with an evil Eye, (as Cain did upon Abel) and ≈øuch was their Spleen and Spight, that they became Sad at it. (2ly.) The Devil (in them) turns their Sadne≈øs into Madne≈øs, v. 19. they had onely been made Sad before, but now are they made Mad with their own Malice, and falls a wagging their Wicked Tongues to Scoff and Deride tho≈øe Godly Wall-Builders, and to laugh them to Scorn. Herein Ge≈øhem (Darius's Lieutenant in Arabia) Confederates with them at the Devils In≈øtigation, v. 10. and Ch. 6. 2. and Ch. 4. 1, 2. Now when God had Laughed this Laughing-De≈øign of the Devil to Nothing (1) by Nehemiahs Courage, Neh. 2. ‚Ä¢ 0. and ( ‚Ä¢ ) by the Peoples Con≈øtancy, and their good mind to Work. Ch. 4. 6. when Scoffs and Sarca≈øms could not deterr them from Working; then (3ly) Satan Hurries them into a Secret Con≈øpiracy to Oppo≈øe
their Building-Work by an Open Ho≈øtility, Neh. 4. 8. that by turning their Works into Knocks, they might make them either Creep into Corners or Run away: (4ly) They Strengthen their Cruel Con≈øpiracy by the Devils Crafty Coun≈øel. (1) In Rai≈øing fal≈øe Rumours, Reporting that Nehemiah and the Jews did Intend to Rebell, Ch. 6. 6. Thus they lay no le≈øs than the Crime of High-Trea≈øon to their Charge, Intending to charge Home tho≈øe Children of the mo≈øt High God, as Dan. 6. 13. Ezr. 4. 13. E≈øth. 3. 8. And they have a mo≈øt Credible and Creditable Witne≈øs to prove it too, to wit, Ge≈øhmu (or Ge≈øhem, the Arabian, their Fellow-Con≈øpirator) ≈øaith it, ‚òû Who knows not, that Vulgar Rumour is a loud Lyar? Is it true becau≈øe it is Reported, and that by them that ≈øay Report, and we will Report it, Jer. 20. 10. P≈øal. 31. 13. as if there were no fal≈øe De≈øaming Detracting Reports feigned only out of the Addle-Brains of the Reporters them≈øelves, Ch. 6.8. Ge≈øhmu here Broaches the Slander, and Sanballat and Tobiah will Blazon it; the former ≈øetts it on Foot, and the latter keeps it a Float, Hoping (according to Machiavels Maxim, (Fortiter Galumniare, & aliquid Haerebit) If they ≈ølander'd ≈øtoutly, ≈øomething would ≈øtick: It doth not follow, becau≈øe 'tis Reported, therefore it mu≈øt be true, be≈øides Ge≈øhmu's Tongue was no ≈ølander, for he was known to teach his Tongue the Art
of Lying, as Jer. 9. 3, 5. and was this Man who was a loud and lewd Lyar, Yea, and a Party too in the Con≈øpiracy, fit to be a Witne≈øs, but any would ≈øerve Sanballats turn, who, for a need, could have Suck'd ≈øuch a Slander as this out of his own Fingers ends: And they belyed good Nehemiah, (as after they belyed Chri≈øt him≈øelf, Joh. 19. 12.) that he would have made him≈øelf King of the Jews, and that he had Hired Prophets to Preach him up King in Jeru≈øalem, v. 7. As if Haggai and Zachariah (the True Prophets of the Lord, and Preaching ∆≤p the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, Hagg. 2. 7. and Zach. 9. 9.) had been Hired by him to Preach up the Kingdom of Nehemiah: whereas (indeed) they Mu≈øed as they ∆≤≈øed; this was their own (2d) Artifice in Hireing fal≈øe Prophets to Affright the People from the Work of God, to wit, (1) Shemaiah the Prophet, Neh. 6. 10, 12, 13. and (2ly) Noadiah the Prophete≈øs, &c. v. 14. All the≈øe had Linguam Venalem, were meerly Mercenary: ‚òû Thus the Churches Adver≈øaries can be at Co≈øt and Charge to Corrupt Gods People, and ≈øuch Hypocritical per≈øons may ea≈øily by Hire be Corrupted: the Suffrages of a great many Bribed Prophets are not ≈øo much to be Numbred as Ponder'd, their concurring Con≈øent in an evil Matter, was not ≈øo much ∆≤nity as Con≈øpiracy; neither did the Devil Re≈øt here in giving Di≈øturbance from Without, but (2ly)
the Church mu≈øt have Di≈øturbance from within al≈øo, by their own People and Brethren, and that (1.) by Mutiny, Neh. 5. 1. and there was a great Cry of the People, as if it had been the outragious Uproar of a Seditious Faction, which is as Dangerous and as Threatning a Deluge, as the Head-≈øtrong Water when once it is out of its Banks: (2.) by Treachery; ≈øome of the Nobles Maintain a private Corre≈øpondency with their Enemies, (ju≈øt as it is at this Day) Neh. 6. 17. Tobiah (that Cur≈øed Adver≈øary of the Church) had his Pen≈øioners among the Jews, and ≈øuch as were his Sworn-Servants to be true to him, and to promote his De≈øigns, becau≈øe he was Son-in-Law to Shecaniah, Ezra 2. 5. who≈øe Son had Marryed the Daughter of Me≈øhullam, (a Zealous Builder, Neh. 3.4.) This Mi≈øchief mix'd Marriages brought upon them, Neh. 6. 18. and 3. 5. The Sooty Souls of tho≈øe Nobles, (or, Hebr. White Ones) under their White Garments, were too Stiff to Stoop to Gods Service, but not to the Devils. Notwith≈øtanding all this, The Lord Laughs all the Devils De≈øign to nothing: Nehemiah under all his Difficulties directs his Prayer to God, Neh. 4. 4, 5. This was his Sanctuary he ≈ølyes to, Ea≈øing his own Grieved Heart by Breathing Heaven-ward, and turning over all the Churches Adver≈øaries into the Hands of the Captain of his Salvation, (he looking upon him≈øelf but as a private
Souldier under him) to take them all to Task: ‚òû Woe to tho≈øe Enemies again≈øt whom Saints do Pray as he did, [Turn their Reproach upon their own Heads; Give them for a Prey, and Cover not their Iniquity.] If they onely be Ble≈ø≈øed who≈øe Sin is covered, P≈øal. 32. 1. Oh what a Cur≈øe do they lie under, who≈øe Condition is contrary: Nehemiah makes Prayr (all along) his City of Refuge, His Anchor in all Storms His Salve for all Sores, Neh. 4. 9. and this brought all the Coun≈øel of the Devil and his Imps to nought, v. 15. P≈øal. 33. 10, 11. God Strengthned his Hands in his Work, (as he Weakened the Hands of their Enemies) Neh. 6. 9. So that he Fini≈øhed the Wall of Jeru≈øalem, (maugre their Malice) v. 15. The Fea≈øts of Tabernacles was kept, Ch. 8. and a Solemn Fa≈øt, Ch. 8. and 9. a Solemn Covenant is Entred into, Ch. 10. Offices are Ordered, Ch. 12. The Temple Purged, and Religion Reformed, Ch. 13, &c. See more of this further on Nehemiah in the 20th. Plot next Following.

argument.p: The Twentieth Plot again≈øt the CHURCH, in Per≈øia: Defeated by GOD.

div.head: CHAP. XX.
div.p:
THe 3d. and la≈øt Plot of the Devils in the Old Te≈øtament, was again≈øt the Church that Return'd not with their Brethren out of Captivity, but continued (1) in Babylon, and (2) in Shu≈øhan, where they had Built Hou≈øes, and Planted Gardens, &c Jer. 29. 6. and ≈øo were unwilling to leave them, and their E≈øtates they had gathered (with Gods Ble≈ø≈øing, upon their Obedience to Gods Prophet) in them. There were (indeed) a Sordid ≈øort, (to wit, the Po≈øterity of Selab) who preferr'd the Service of the King of Babylon, above the Freedom of the Land of Promi≈øe, 1 Chron. 4. 23. They could be content to drudge in making Pots in Babylon, (as their fore-Fathers had made Brick in Aegypt) both tho≈øe Works were but Mortar-Works, Exod. 1. 11. There they ≈øtay'd with the King (of Babylon) for his Work, 1 Chron, 4. 23. which
Scripture ≈øhows, ‚òû that Ezra Wrote tho≈øe Two Books of the Chronicles after the Jews Return from their Captivity: but there were others, that might ≈øtay there upon more Noble Accounts, as (1) Daniel did and his Three Noble Companions, who≈øe continuance there conduced more 1. for Gods Glory; for though tho≈øe Four eminent Servants of God were not Delivered from their Captivity, yet God got greater Glory to him≈øelf in Delivering Daniel from the Den of Lyons, and the Three Nobles from the Fiery Furnace. 2. 'Twas al≈øo more for the Churches Comfort to have Four ≈øuch Friends and Favourites in the Court of Babylon, (where her Adver≈øaries were Unweariedly Circumventing her) than any Service they could do her in their own Land. 3. And 'twas likewi≈øe more for the Worlds Advantage, ≈øeeing by this very means, tho≈øe ≈øame Heatheni≈øh and Idolatrous Kings and their People came to ≈øome Knowledge of the True God, as appears by Nebuchadnezzar's, Cyrus's, and Darius's Proclamations: 2ly Ezra (him≈øelf) and his Company came not (all of them) out of Babylon at the fir≈øt Return upon Cyrus Proclamation, Ezra 1. 3. and 2. 2, to 60. and 7. 1. and 8. 35. with Zerubabel: nor 3ly. did Nehemiah come up with Ezra, it being 13 Y. after his Return, Ezra 7. 1. and Neh. 2. 1. and 'tis much he ≈øhould Return at all, being the Kings Cup-Bearer, a place of great Tru≈øt
and Credit, yet a Man of Religion is marvellou≈øly tru≈øted with it, even by an Heathen King: 'twas a ≈øtrange Work of God, that Artaxerxes ≈øhould ≈øhew Favour to a ≈øtranger, a Pri≈øoner, and one of a ≈øtrange Religion, which he him≈øelf knew not, and which his Subjects Hated: And 'tis as ≈øtrange a Work of God, that Nehemiah a Courtier, ≈øhould leave his Wealth, Ea≈øe, Honour, and Authority (that he was in,) and go ≈øo far from Court as many Hundred Miles, to Dwell in a Tatter'd and Decay'd City, among a poor People there to Drudge like a Day-Labourer, and that in dayly danger of his Life: Therefore is he mo≈øt de≈øervedly called and counted the 3d. Founder of that Church and Common-Wealth after Jo≈øhua and David: though Zerubabel began the Temple, and Ezra Re≈øtor'd the Law, yet Nehemiah comes after and Compleats All; ≈øo became [The Comfort of the Lord] to his Church, according to the ≈øignication of his Name. (4ly) God had his Mordecai, (which ≈øignifies Pure Myrrhe, or Bitter Contrition,) 1≈øt. in Babylon, and then (2) in Shu≈øhan; he was carried Captive to Babylon about Ten Y. Old, in Jeconiahs Captivity, 2 Chron. 36. 10. Jer. 24. 1. Ezra 22. 2. E≈øth. 2. 6. (according to Junius, Dr. Willet, and Dr. Lightfoot's Opinion) living about 110 Y. This Mordecai Returns to Jeru≈øalem, when the Captivity was ≈øent back again to
their own Countrey by Cyrus, Ezra 2. 2. and there had Helped forward their Settlement, ≈øo long as the Temple-Work was allow'd to go forward, but when that was Hindred by Camby≈øes, (all his Life time) He (with many others) Return back again to their Old Re≈øidence into Babylonia, or Per≈øia: As ≈øoon as Darius had Conquer'd Babylon, Dan. 5. 34. he Models his Monarchy into 120 Provinces, under 120 Princes, Dan. 6. 1. over the≈øe he ≈øetts a Triumvirate, or Three Prae≈øidents, being Principal Princes, whereof Daniel (≈øo well known in Babylon) was the Chief, v. 2. ≈øo was Removed from Babylon to Shu≈øhan the Metropolis of Per≈øia: compare Dan. 7. 1. (then Daniel was in Babylon) with Dan. 8. 1, 2. there he was in Shu≈øhan, (which ≈øignifies a Lilly, ≈øo called, for its Beauty and Delectable Scituation.) There was Nehemiah (as well as Daniel) Neh. 1. 1. waiting upon his Honourable Office of the Kings Cup-bearer, and upon promoting the Churches Weal: There got he his Commi≈ø≈øion to go Governour to Jeru≈øalem for 12 Y. Neh. 2. 6, 7. and 5. 14. In no le≈øs ≈øpace of time could he hope to Rectifie the Churches Deformation by a Glorious Reformation, which when (through the Good Hand of his God upon him) he had Accompli≈øh'd, he then Returns to his Office in Shu≈øhan again, Neh. 13. 6, 7. who≈øe Back was no ≈øooner turn'd but all Return'd into Di≈øorder again,
(as Exod. 32. 8. Gal. 1. 6.) notwith≈øtanding their better purpo≈øes and promi≈øes, Neh. 10. 30, 39. he ≈øtays in Shu≈øhan about 12 Months, and yet the Devil (that „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or great Church-Troubler) had in le≈øs than a Y. time notoriou≈øly Disjoynted, what Nehemiah had ≈øo Happily Settled, Neh. 13. 7, 8, &c. as he was Inqui≈øitive how it fared with the Church, Neh. 1. 2. The Church was his greate≈øt Care, [Omnis in A≈øcanio cari ≈øtat Cura Parentis,] His Honour in Shu≈øhan could not Satisfie him, ≈øo long as it went Ill with Sion: he ≈øtill Enquires how his Reformation Remain'd, and he ∆≤nder≈øtood, Neh. 13. 7. it was Deformed again, this puts him on getting another Congedelere, or Commi≈ø≈øion at Court, and Ha≈øtening to Jeru≈øalem (where his Heart was before him) Reforms all Di≈øorders, v. 8, 9, to 31. ≈øo leaves the Church in a mo≈øt Ble≈ø≈øed E≈øtate, (in despight of the Devil and his In≈øtruments) which continued ≈øo for a long time after. ‚òû And (5) Gods care of his Church (whom he be ≈øpeaks in the Phra≈øe of [My People,] Jer. 50. 4, 6.) even in Babylon, ≈øendeth Ezekiel thither among the Captives, to Nouri≈øh the Seed of God among them, Ezek. 1. 1, 2, 3. who had his Comfortable Vi≈øion by a Branch of the River Euphrates, (tho≈øe Waters of Babylon, where many Godly Souls ≈øat down and Wept at the Remembrance of Sion, P≈øa. 137. 1, 2, 3.) Now that the Church was planted in a Forreign
Countrey for a long time, (even for 70 Y.) The Lord mo≈øt Graciou≈øly ≈øhewed her ≈øuch a Glory, as he had ≈øhow'd her at her fir≈øt Con≈øtitution into a Church-≈øtate in the Wilderne≈øs by that Pillar of Glory; God ≈øheweth him≈øelf Here, as he had done There, out of a Cloud and Fire, v. 4, 5. and from between Living Creatures Here, as there from between the Cherubims; God gives his Oracles to this Prophet Ezekiel, who calls this Captivity [Our Captivity,] Ch. 40. 1. and be≈øides him ‚Ä¢ 6) many other Good Men, (as Heldai, Tobijah, Jedaiah, and Jo≈øiah, Zech. 6. 10, 14. who were Emba≈ø≈øadours from the Godly Jews in Babylon) together with tho≈øe Trade≈ømen and Carpenters, (Religion being mo≈øt really found among≈øt the Laborious) carried away in Jeconiah's Captivity, whom Jeremy calls his Ba≈øket of Good Figs, Ch. 24. 2. and to whom God gives many Gracious Promi≈øes, v. 5. I have ≈øent them out of Canaan for their Good, and v. 6. I will ≈øet mine Eyes upon them for Good, and v. 7; I will give them an Heart to know me, and they ≈øhall be my People, for they ≈øhall Return unto me. Thus the falling out of Lovers is the renewing of Love; their Afflictions were Sanctify'd to them, God Enforces them from Evil, and Entices them to Good; He ≈øaw to their Safety in Babylon, and provided for their Nece≈ø≈øity there. Jehoiakim (call'd al≈øo Jeconiah) was Spoke Kindly to, and done
Kindly for by Evil Merodach at length, 2 Kin. 25. 27, 28. having his Pri≈øon-Rags changed into Princely Robes, v. 29, 30. and (as the Rabbins tell us) was truly Converted, having his Heart changed as well as his Habit and Allowance, as Mana≈ø≈øeh had been before him, 2 Chro. 33. 12, 13. And tho≈øe Good Figs (no doubt) did ≈øhare in his Comforts, getting good E≈øtates and Re≈øpect in the Land of their Captivity, Jer. 29. 4, to 16. but the other Basket of Bad Figs, v. 17. was not Happyer becau≈øe at Home, were ca≈øt away as naughty Figs, or rotten Apples, and became mo≈øt mi≈øerable by Zedekiahs and I≈øhmaels Treachery; the 1≈øt. again≈øt Great N ‚Ä¢ buchadnezzar, Ezek. 17. The 2d. again≈øt Good Gedaliah, Jer. 41. 2. God gather'd the Good Figs as his ≈øcatter'd Jewels, and ≈øtrung them, Mal. 3. 17. but the Bad Figs he quite ca≈øt away; though good and bad Figs were carry'd out, yet in Differing Baskets, and for Differing Purpo≈øes.

The Two Baskets of Figs re≈øembled Two Brea≈øts, as the Hebr. Word Dodaim, or Dudaim, Baskets comes from Dodim or Dudim, Brea≈øts. Thus the Church at that time was like the Nur≈øe-Woman who hath one Brea≈øt ≈øound, good, and ≈øtrutting out with much Milk for Nouri≈øhing her Tender Babe; but the other is naughty, rotten, ≈øhrunck up and dryed away; And yet, even in this Basket of bad Figs, God had his [Methe-Mi≈øpar] a ≈ømall
Number, a poor Few of good Figs even among the bad ones, Jer. 44. 28. a ≈ømall Re≈øerve God had yet among them, to whom he was a little Sanctuary, Ezek. 11. 16. where≈øoever they were ≈øcattered: Still God Re≈øerveth a Remnant for Royal U≈øe, even in the bad Basket, and in Aegypt, where no good Figs ≈øhould have come, it being Expre≈øly contrary to Gods Command, Deut. 17. 16. and his Commination, as the la≈øt and greate≈øt Plague, Deut. 28. 68. and as expre≈øly contrary to his Prophets Coun≈øel, Jer. 42. 19. ≈øaying to them, Be Ruled, or you will Rue it. 'Tis better for you to be in cold Irons, Pri≈øoners at Babylon, where ye may ≈øerve the Lord among the good Figs, than to be ≈øerving the Idols of Aegypt at never ≈øo much Liberty; your Fathers brought one Golden Calf thence, Jeroboam Two, what may you bring thence if you ≈øhould e≈øcape? but know, All that learn their evil Manners, ≈øhall Peri≈øh in their Puni≈øhments, v. 22.
