of God which he giveth to Man and taketh from him according to his good Plea≈øure, P≈øa. 127.2. This great King, that commanded an 127 Provinces, cannot command ≈øo much as an Hours Sleep for him≈øelf when he plea≈øeth: It was God that kept him awake for excellent Ends. Gods 4th. Step was, The Kings Commanding to bring the Book of Records to be Read before him, the better to deceive that Tedious time of his lying Awake: Had not God over-rul'd him, he might have call'd for his Wives, Concubines, Mu≈øitians, &c. whereof he had abundance: Nothing but Hi≈øtory mu≈øt be call'd for to Comfort him, and thereby God put ≈ømall Thoughts into his mind for great Purpo≈øes, as the Scruple God ca≈øt into the Head of our Henry the 8th. about his Marriage, became the occa≈øion of Unhor≈øing the Pope in England, &c. The 5th. Step God takes here, E≈øth. 6. 1, 2. that the Reader of that Per≈øian Hi≈øtory or Chronicle ≈øhould be (by Gods Secret Providence) directed to Read that very Story of Mordecai's Saving the Kings Life by Di≈øcovering the Trea≈øon again≈øt him, (like as the Eunuch was, Act. 8. 30, 32. to that place in I≈øaiah, Ch. 53. 7, 8. and Au≈øtin to Rom. 13. 14. the main means of their Conver≈øion) not turning to that place purpo≈øely, neither the one, nor the other of all the Three, (no doubt but Gods Hand in the Margin pointed him to it.) The 6th. Step God takes in his Providence
is, That Noble and right Royal Mind God ≈øtirr'd up in the King, to enquire, What Honour hath been done to Mordecai for this, v. 3. Turpe e≈øt Regi, Beneficijs Vinci; 'tis too ≈øordid for mighty Kings to be Ungrateful to their mo≈øt Loyal Subjects, and not to Reward tho≈øe that have been In≈øtruments of Saving their Lives: God makes Aha≈øuerus Reflect upon the great Crime of his own Ungratefulne≈øs to Mordecai for ≈øo great a Service. Gods 7th. Step, is, his Ordering it ≈øo, that tho≈øe Gentlemen of the Kings Bed-Chamber ≈øhould be by, who were Ingenious, and had a Kindne≈øs for Mordecai, whom yet they knew a great Eye-≈øore to Prince Haman; and had tho≈øe young Courtiers been as envious as Haman, and di≈øaffected to Mordecai, they might have extenuated his good Service, and minded the King of his Decree again≈øt the Jews, or have told Aha≈øuerus, as the Apocryphal Additions, E≈øth. 12. 5, 6. telleth, that he had been Rewarded; but they candidly An≈øwer, There is nothing done for him, not Grudging (as 'tis common with Courtiers) to have others come over their Heads. Gods 8th. Step is, That Mordecai ≈øhould not have any pre≈øent Recompence for that eminent Service, but that he ≈øhould wait Six Y. (≈øaith Lyra) and yet have no Reward, e≈øpecially from a King of Per≈øia, who≈øe Kings had u≈øed to be very Bountiful to tho≈øe that De≈øerved well of them, as Herodotus,
Xenophon, and Plutarch, largely Relates. 'Tis probable, a Reward was at fir≈øt Decreed for him, but he being a Jew, its Execution was for ≈øome time (through Hamans In≈øluence) ob≈øtructed, and at la≈øt it was altogether forgotten till now. However Haman (and the Devil his Ma≈øter) had a Wicked, the great God had an Holy Hand in it, that it ≈øhould be deferr'd to a fitter opportunity, wherein he might be more Glorifi'd in the Pre≈øervation of his People, and in the De≈øtruction of his Enemies, at the Due Sea≈øon, Gal. 6. 9. Let us not therefore be weary of Well-doing, God Times all his Mercies well, and well ≈øees when they will be mo≈øt Sweet and Sea≈øonable, I≈øa. 30. 18. Gods 9th. Step, is, The Marvellous Providence, that Haman (him≈øelf) ≈øhould be pre≈øent at that Juncture, when God had corrected the Kings Forgetfulne≈øs, and now had put it into his Heart to Reward Mordecai, E≈øth. 6.4. 'Tis true, his carnal Friends had put this Revengeful Wretch onward in his pride and revenge, (adding fuel to his flameing ≈øire.) They ≈øaid to him, [To Morrow ≈øpeak thou to the King, &c.] Ch. 5. 14. Hereupon he gets early up, (≈øleeping that Night as badly as Aha≈øuerus) comes by Morning-light to procure a Warrant for Mordecai's Execution: yet all this was of God, (for it is not in Man to order his own way, Jer. 10. 23.) that Haman (him≈øelf) ≈øhould, to his greater Vexation, pre≈øcribe the
Honour that mu≈øt be done to Mordecai, and that at a time when he was come to get him Hang'd, yea, and with full confidence to compa≈øs his De≈øign, though for no other Crime but not cringing to him; neither Haman nor the Devil (him≈øelf) had any thing el≈øe to accu≈øe Mordecai of, for he is One of tho≈øe few in Scripture-Record, that both lived and dyed in Glory, being no where taxed for any Gro≈øs ≈øin, that we read off. Gods 10th. Step, is, The Wonderful Di≈øappointment he brought upon this Wicked Ambitioni≈øt. Haman comes merrily into the Kings Pre≈øence as ≈øoon as called, ('tis ≈øtrange Aha≈øuerus Con≈øulted not with his Courtiers who then attended upon his per≈øon; no, God will have Haman to be the Coun≈øellour) comming in for another purpo≈øe, a mi≈øchievous one again≈øt Mordecai, and is a≈ø≈øured it would be but Dictum, Factum, the King would not ≈øay him Nay; but God Over-rul'd all: Aha≈øuerus asks Hamans Advice [What ≈øhall be done, v. 6.] by an over-powering Providence he names not the Man whom he would Honour; Haman mi≈øtaking him≈øelf to be the Man meant, doth mo≈øt liberally Advi≈øe to all Punctilio's of Honour, and as A≈øpiring to the Kingdom, he affects the Crown-Royal it ≈øelf, v. 8. (which becau≈øe it was not practicable, the King leaves it out of his Commi≈ø≈øion.) All this Honour (he expected to him≈øelf) he is commanded to conferr upon Mordecai, whom
he hated, and would have Hanged. Thus had he made a Bridge of his own Shaddow, and down he falls into the Ditch, which was but a Praelude to his final fall at la≈øt. Thus Quos Deus De≈øtruit, Dementat, when God hath a mind to ∆≤ndoe a Man, he fir≈øt Infatuate him: Oh what a Fool God made of Haman here, he comes in to the King with his Head full of Hopes, but goes out with his Heart full of Blanks, (as in a Cheating Lottery) his big Expectations ends in gro≈øs Di≈øappointments, the Kings own Hor≈øe mu≈øt be the Gallows on which Mordecai mu≈øt ≈øafely and ≈øtately Ride in Triumph, and the lofty Gallows which Haman had erected for Mordecai, now groaneth for him≈øelf: Hamans malice (which would bear no delays, for he could neither Sleep in Quiet, nor Eat with Content) again≈øt Mordecai, is miraculou≈øly Converted to a conferring ≈øuch an Honour upon him, as the King or his Courtiers would never have thought on to have done him, had not Haman (him≈øelf) Coun≈øel'd it to be done; it is ea≈øie to be Imagined how the Kings peremptory Precept, v. 10. did Stabb Haman to the Heart, who mu≈øt now (perforce) Honour him whom he Hop'd to Hang, Cloth him with Royal Robes, whom he Hop'd to Strip of his own ordinary Raiment, Help him ∆≤p upon the Royal Hor≈øe, whom he Hop'd to Help ∆≤p upon the lofty Gallows, and then (when put down into his Grave) to Hop and
Dance over him; Prepare a Triumph for him, for whom he had prepared Ruine, Proclaim his Loyalty (the cau≈øe of that Honour) as a Cryer, for whom he had procured a De≈øtroying Decree of a Traytor; and la≈øtly, he mu≈øt run at Mordecai's Stirrup as a Lacquey, and as his Slave and Underling, being then a Great Prince, and the Kings greate≈øt Favourite. Oh what a Cutting and Killing Cordolium mu≈øt all this needs be unto Hamans Haughty Heart; 'tis a Wonder his Heart bur≈øt not, but that God would not have him to ≈øave the Hangman his labour, and therefore his ≈øordid Spirit truckles and crouches to do all tho≈øe Offices of Honour which he would have Monopoliz'd to him≈øelf: * Oh turn a≈øide (with Mo≈øes) to gaze a while upon this Work of Wonder: The King had no Intention (in all this) to cro≈øs Hamans Humour, or to thwart him in his malicious Ambition, not knowing any thing (as is ≈øuppo≈øed) of the Difference between him and Mordecai, but Gods all-powerful Providence brought all this about for effecting his own ends, which cannot but ever be exceeding good, ≈øeeing his Will is not onely Recta, but, Regula, the Rule Ruleing, never ≈øever'd from his Wi≈ødom: (1) Behold here how Men (by a ≈øecret Working of the Divine Hand) accompli≈øheth the Will of God, which they think not of, but are fulfilling their own wills. (2) Behold here (as in a Mirrour) how
the Holy God over-rules the Wicked Wills and Wiles of Men in all their Affairs, Coun≈øels, Times and Turns for the fulfilling of his own Will and Decree, even then, when they think lea≈øt of Serving his Providence. (3) Behold here the Excellency of True Piety, 'tis a con≈øtant and unchangeable Ble≈ø≈øing whether Advanced or Aba≈øed; Godly Mordecai's Motto was, [Semper Idem] always the ≈øame Man, neither Puff'd up with Honour, nor Pre≈ø≈ø'd down with Di≈øhonour, as too many be; a ≈ømall wind blows up a Bubble, all this Honour no whit over-joys Mordecai, he comes again to his old place, v. 12. and in his old habit ≈øits quietly down there, neither envying his Superiours, nor In≈øulting over his Inferiours, nor mole≈øting his Equals, &c. but committing his Concerns to Gods good Plea≈øure and Providence; this is the Godly Mans Gui≈øe, P≈øal. 131. 1, 2. and his Goodne≈øs to do ≈øo, 1 Pet. 4. 19. (4) Behold here the Ba≈øene≈øs of ba≈øe Impiety, every Di≈øappointment Unhinges their Di≈øpo≈øitions as this did Hamans, he ha≈øted to his Hou≈øe mourning, he fretted at him≈øelf, that he ≈øhould be ≈øuch a Fool as to pre≈øcribe ≈øuch Honour to a Man before he knew who the Man was that ≈øhould be ≈øo Honoured: he made account to have gone merrily to the Queens Banquet when he had Tru≈øs'd up Mordecai, but now (this Fortunae Ludibrium, Fortunes Play-fool) not onely mi≈ø≈øing of Mordecai's murder, but made to do
him publique Honour in ample manner, and all by his own Direction; this went like a Dagger to his Heart and Gall'd him above mea≈øure, he pulls his Cap over his Eye, as a≈øhamed to look any in the face, ≈øo Bladder-like is the mind of a proud Carnal man, that filled with Earthly Vanities (which are but Wind) it grows great and ≈øwelleth to a None ≈øuch; but if prick'd with the lea≈øt Pin of a piercing Di≈øappointment, it pre≈øently ≈øhriveleth into nothing. Thus Haman retires Home for his Privacy, there his own Wife and his Wizzards, (whom he Con≈øulted for his Lucky Day) when he expected Coun≈øel and Comfort from them, Read him his Doleful De≈øtiny, v. 13. they all prove as cold Comforters now, as they had been bad Coun≈øellors before: while Haman is grieving at this Di≈øappointment at Home, as well as at that abroad, he is Hurried away (the King and Queen ≈øtaying for him) to that fatal Fea≈øt, (where Haman pays the Reckoning of all with his own Life) v. 14. Harbonah Ha≈øtens him, who≈øe Stomach was now full enough already, and would rather have been excu≈øed: Now the Churches Deliverance draws near, being thus notably Provided for by 1. tho≈øe Preparing Means, and no le≈øs notably Promoted by (2) tho≈øe Performing Means, U≈øed 1. to God. 2. to the King. 1. to God, ≈øo the Jews and Mordecai falls upon 1. Weeping, 2. Fa≈øting, 3. Lying in Sack-cloth and A≈øhes, Ch. 4. 1, 2, 3.
This was the way to get in with God, though they might not come to the Court: this ≈øhows, God had his Remnant of Godly Jews, even in Per≈øia, ≈øuch as now were mourning before the Lord, but dare not be murmuring or mutinying again≈øt the King and Haman: ≈øuch as begin at the right end of Duty, to wit, Humiliation before God; then 2. to the King an Addre≈øs is made by E≈øther, not without ≈øome Reluctancy; that God might make it ≈øucce≈øsful, E≈øther Injoyns a Three Days Fa≈øt, 1. by her Self, 2. by her Maids, 3. by Mordecai, 4. by all the Jews in Shu≈øhan, Ch. 4. 12, 16. God Accepts of all their Prayers, and the King of E≈øthers Addre≈øs at her Fea≈øt. Haman is hang'd (before his Lucky Day came) upon his own Gallows, and Mordecai is Honour'd, all turns to the contrary, God Laughs the Plot to Nothing, and the Church is Advanced. See Prov. 4. 16. and 11. 8. P≈øal. 83. 3. Deut. 21. 34. E≈øth. 7. 9. and 9. 1, 3, 4. the Church (in City and Countrey) keep Yearly Two Days of Joy to God for this Great Deliverance, v. 17, to 29. Now when God (by his Wonder-Working Providence) had brought Godly E≈øther to be Queen, She came to the Kingdom (de≈øigned by a Divine Decree) for the Churches Deliverance, E≈øth. 4. 14. and had made Mordecai the Second Man in the Kingdom, being next unto the King, E≈øth. 10. 3. and Advanced Higher than ever Haman was, for he wore a
great Crown of Gold, E≈øth. 8. 15. which (we Read not) Haman had any like: Then the Church had Light and Gladne≈øs, v. 16. Light is ≈øweet, ≈øaith Solomon. Eccle≈ø. 11. 7. e≈øpecially to tho≈øe that had been ≈øome Months ≈øhut up (by Haman) in the Dark Dungeon of Deep perplexity, E≈øth. 3. 15. from that time walking in the very Vale of the ≈øhaddow (the Darke≈øt ≈øide) of Death, P≈øal. 23. 4. yet there God takes his Church by the Hand and leads her through that Dark Entry into Light and Gladne≈øs. The Churches Light had been Sown for her upon a ≈øafe Soil, P≈øal. 97. 11. All the time of Haman's Heart-grieving Grandeur, it lay under the Clods, as Seed under-ground, for a while Un≈øeen, but now 'tis Ri≈øen up for the Righteous, and their Seed-time brought in a Ble≈ø≈øed Harve≈øt, P≈øal. 126. 2, 5, 6. when Haman was faln from the Pallace to the Gallows, and from the highe≈øt Stage of Honour, to the lowe≈øt Stair and Step of Ignominy: thus Sings the Poet,
div.q: Ludit in Humanis Divina potentia Rebus.
div.p:
Gods Providence often to≈ø≈øeth Great Favourites like a Tennis-Ball, now up, and now down, from the highe≈øt Honour to extream Infamy, when Hamans Greatne≈øs was Hang'd up, and him≈øelf wrap'd up in a Sheet of perpetual Shame: then Shu≈øhan (the Lilly, Hebr.) and the Church (the Lilly, Cant. 2. 3.) now look'd mo≈øt Light≈øome and Lovely; and that Lucky
Day (as Haman had Deem'd it, but was Deluded by the Devil) had Deceived the Hamani≈øts, and by a ≈øw ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Gracious Providence was turn'd to „Äà‚óä„Äâ contrary, to wit, an unlucky and Bloody Day to them≈øelves who had de≈øign'd it a De≈øtructive-Day to the Church, E≈øth. 9. 1, 4, 6, 10, 16. Now the jollity of the Iews began, being deliver'd from their perplexity, by Standing for their Lives: upon the Thirteenth day (Hamans Lucky Unluckyday) on the very next (the 14th.) day, they made a Day of Fea≈øting and Gladne≈øs, v. 17. not deferring one day longer, while the mercy was fre≈øh and yet of Recent Remembrance, they Proclaim the Prai≈øes of their Delivering-God, and ≈øpeak good of his Name, covering Gods Altar with the Calves of their Lips, and paying their Vows to the Lord; Yea, and on the 15th. too, they do the ≈øame, (as if one day, the 14th.) had been too little, wherein to Magnifie Gods Mercy (in P≈øalms and Sacrifices of Prai≈øe) and to Te≈øtifie their own Thankfulne≈øs to him for their Lives, Liberties, and E≈øtates, ≈øo lately and ≈øo Liberally Re≈øtored to them, v. 18. and the Ob≈øervation of tho≈øe Three Days (the former as a Fa≈øting, the latter as Fea≈øting Days as ≈øay ≈øome,) became a Standing Law for both City and Countrey, v. 20, 21. not as any Addition to the Word of God, but onely as a Sacred Memorial of this ≈øo Remarkable and Memorable Mercy, in
turning them from Mourning to Mirth, &c. v. 22. from the Jaws of mo≈øt dreadful Death, into the Joys of a mo≈øt Glorious Deliverance: Thus God can turn (and hath often turned) the Churches Sadne≈øs into Gladne≈øs, her Sighing into Singing, and her Tears into Triumph: all Hamans and Hamani≈øts (notwith≈øtanding all their Fraud and Force, Craft and Cruelty) ≈øhall find to their Co≈øt that there is no Inchantment again≈øt Jacob, nor any Divination again≈øt I≈ørael: Yea, it ≈øhall be ≈øaid of the Church, Oh what hath God wrought? Numb. 23. 23. Such Savoury Di≈øcour≈øe the Godly Iews were Appointed to have upon tho≈øe Days of Purim, (≈øo called, for a Brand on Hamans ca≈øting Pur or Lots for a Lucky Day) as we ≈øhould have for our Deliverance from the Devils Water-Works in Eighty-Eight, and from his Fire-Works on that famous Fifth of November. This Annual Fe≈øtivity, E≈øth. 9. 23, 26, 28. was ≈øo Solemnly enjoyned, that Yearly the Jews kept it until the Comming of Chri≈øt, and do indeed (though Abu≈øively) Keep it to this Day, counting and calling all that Cro≈øs them, ≈øo many Humans, and Fondly plea≈øe them≈øelves with Hopes of being Revenged of them, as their Fathers were of this Haman. The Memorial of the Matter of their Fa≈øting, v. 31. (mo≈øt probably on the 13th. Day) and of their Fea≈øting (on the Two following Days) was not to Peri≈øh from their
Seed, but to be perpetuated from one Generation to another, and therefore was Regi≈øtred for Po≈øterity, that the People which ≈øhould be Created, might Prai≈øe the Lord, P≈øal. 102. 18. (Popi≈øh Per≈øons keep not the 14th. of February ≈øo well in their Vain Valentines,) and lea≈øt they ≈øhould ≈øleight and ≈ølack this Sacred Service, Queen E≈øther and Prince Mordecai did Confirm the Letter (Writ in the Y. foregoing) in the Y. following, v. 20, 29. And Mordecai (all his Life) kept his Dignity, Seeking the Weal of his People, and Speaking Peace to all His Seed, v. 30, 31. and Ch. 10. 3. God Rais'd him up for the Comfort of his Church, not onely in Speaking Good of and for His Countrey-Men, (then Living in the 127 Provinces) to the King, Promoting their Pro≈øperity to the Utmo≈øt all his Days, but al≈øo in Speaking Pro≈øperity to all their Po≈øterity, providing for Future, that after his Death, the Weal of the Church might be Continued: How long this la≈øted, the Scripture-Hi≈øtory (which extendeth no further) doth not Expre≈øs: To know therefore how it Fared with the Church after, we mu≈øt have Recour≈øe to Scripture-Prophe≈øie, for Scripture-Hi≈øtory gives onely ≈øome ≈øhort Intimations thereof, as Gen. 49. 10. tells us, How the Scepter ≈øhould not Depart from Judah, until Shiloh (or Chri≈øt)
come; and Luk. 3. (in the Genealogy of Chri≈øt) Sheweth how Gods Providence made Good that Precious Promi≈øe, in giving David a Lamp or Light in Jeru≈øalem, until Chri≈øt the Son of David was Born into the World: Even all the Prophets (the Greater and the Le≈ø≈øer) do Prophecy of the future E≈øtate of the Church from their own pre≈øent Time, and of the Comming of Chri≈øt, which ≈øhould make the Glory of the latter Hou≈øe to Exceed the Glory of the former; But more e≈øpecially the Prophet Daniel Writes a Prophetical Hi≈øtory of the Church during that Inter≈øpace of Time, in Chap. the 7th. he Declareth his Vi≈øion of the Four Monarchies which troubled the World, e≈øpecially the Church, from the Fir≈øt Ri≈øing of Nebuchadnezzar, till the Comming of the Everla≈øting Kingdome of Chri≈øt in the Go≈øpel. In Chap. 8, 9, 10, 11, and 12. Chri≈øt (Him≈øelf) comes to him, and gives him a Revelation (as he did to John in Patmos) how it ≈øhould Fare with the Jewi≈øh-Church under their Powerful Enemies, until the Fury of Antiochus Epiphanes, (Polybius calls him Epimanes, the Mad-Man, their wor≈øt Adver≈øary) was over: Daniel Declares, How this Mad Antiochus would Violate the Sanctuary, and Ca≈øt down Religion into the Dirt for Three Y. and an Half, or 1290
Days, yet Comforteth the Church with this Cordial, That He who Waiteth and Liveth Forty Five Days more, ≈øhould ≈øee an End of Antiochus, and of all his Crafty and Cruel Plots again≈øt the Church; and that in Fullne≈øs of Time the Me≈ø≈øiah would come to Fini≈øh Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øion, and to bring in Everla≈øting Righteou≈øne≈øs, &c. Dan. 9. 24. and Change the National Church of the Jews, (therefore much Wa≈øted then) becau≈øe Shortly to be Changed into Congregational-Churches by the Go≈øpel, Gal. 1. 22. 1 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 14. To know more particularly how God dealt with the Jewi≈øh-Church in all that Inter≈øpace of Time betwixt the Hi≈øtory of the Old and New-Te≈øtament, Con≈øult the Following Chapter, where that State of Defection (wherein Chri≈øt found them at His Comming) is largely Related.

argument.p: The Twenty-Fir≈øt Plot in the New-Te≈øtament; again≈øt the Church, in Chri≈øt, Defeated by God.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.
div.p:
VVHEN the Ble≈ø≈øed Me≈ø≈øiah ( „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , God-Man,) was Born into the World, he found his Brethren (the Church) as Jo≈øeph did his, Gen. 37. 17. Indeed in Dothan, Hebr. in Defection, as the Word Signifies: The Devil had Debauched the Jews mo≈øt De≈øperately, ≈øo that ≈øcarce were there Four or fewer that Waited for the Con≈øolation of I≈ørael, to wit, the Birth of Chri≈øt, which was ever the be≈øt Cordial that the Lords Prophets propos'd to the Church in her mo≈øt Di≈øcon≈øolate Condition in
foregoing Ages, as I≈øa. 9. 6. and Zech. 9. 9. and Mal. 4. 2. &c. That Chri≈øt is given to the World, is the Summ of all the good News in the World, and affordeth ≈øuch Joy as ≈øurpa≈ø≈øeth the Three Grand Worldly Joys, the Joy of Marriage, the joy of Harve≈øt, and the Joy of Victory, I≈øa. 9‚ñ™ 3, 5, 6. yet the Jewi≈øh-Church was at that time in ≈øuch a State of Defection, that they Generally minded it not, though then a very plentiful Harve≈øt, a great Number of Elect among the poor Gentiles were Ready Ripe, Matth. 9. 37. Luk. 10. 2. Joh. 4. 35. This Defection of the Jews was foretold by Daniel, (that I≈øh-Chamudoth or greatly Beloved Prophet) Speaking of mo≈øt Sad Calamities that ≈øhould befall them (both before and after the comming of Chri≈øt) for the over-spreading of Abomination, Chap. 9. 24, 27. with Ch. 8. 23. When the Tran≈øgre≈ø≈øions are come to the full, that is, when the Iews were notoriou≈øly Degenerated, then did God ≈øett that Breathing-Devil (Antiochus) over them, as a puni≈øhment of their publique Impiety, and prophane Apo≈øtacy: This was that which procured a Commi≈ø≈øion to this Fierce-Countenanc'd, or Hebr. Brazen-Fac'd) King for De≈øtroying Wonderfully the Holy and the Mighty People (who while they were Holy, were ≈øo Mighty as to be Inconquerable, but now being Revolted from God, as Weak as Water) both by Power and Policy, Chap. 8.
24, 25. Then was the Glorious Land, Judea, (as Daniel calls it, Ch. 11. 16. for its having the Service of God ≈øett up in it above all Lands) cru≈øhed a≈øunder, as Corn lying betwixt Two heavy Mil≈øtones, that is, betwixt the King of the South, Ptolomy, and this King of the North, Antiochus, called a vile Per≈øon, v. 21. though he affected the Name of Epiphanes, or Famous, yet this was his true Title with God, P≈øal. 15. 4. and though he be an Abominable vile Per≈øon, when Gods Ju≈øtice Required ≈øuch a Scourage to his People, His Heart mu≈øt be ≈øett again≈øt the Holy Covenant, v. 28. to wit, again≈øt the Jews, Gods Covenanters; and again≈øt the True Religion, which made that Land more Beautiful and Glorious than all other Lands, Ezek. 20. 6. He ≈øhall enter into the Glorious Land, Dan. 11. 41. and ≈øhall make Havock of Gods people, (Revelling in their Ruines) and ≈øhall ≈øet up the Abomination of De≈øolation (to wit, the Abominable Idol of Jupiter Olympius) in the Holy Temple: Yea, and the Renegado Jews (which fir≈øt for≈øake the Covenant, then do Wickedly again≈øt it,) Comply privily with him in all this Wickedne≈øs, v. 30, 32. & 2 Macca. 4. He (by their A≈ø≈øi≈øtance) practices and pro≈øpers, till the Indignation be Accompli≈øhed, v. 36. in Gods revengeing the Quarrel of his Covenant: notwith≈øtanding this vile Villain, this Turbulent and Truculent Tyger, God had turn'd loo≈øe upon his People to puni≈øh their
≈øins, and though he practic'd and prosper'd ≈øo far in his prodigious Prophanity, as to ca≈øt the Truth down to the Ground, both the Profe≈ø≈øion of Truth, and its profe≈ø≈øours, Dan. 8. 12. yet the Devil lo≈øes this Game al≈øo with all the other his Games afore≈øaid in the Old Te≈øt. Hi≈øtory: For the mo≈øt great and gracious God comes in with mo≈øt Comfortable Allays. (≈øo Spoils the Devils De≈øign.) The 1≈øt. Allay is, the Palmoni Hamadabbar, Hebr. or mo≈øt Excellent Speaker or Numberer Chri≈øt, Numbers the Time how long this Scourge ≈øhould continue upon Gods People, concerning their lo≈øs of the dayly Sacrifice, &c. to wit, onely Five or Six Years or thereabout, Dan. 8. 13, 14. this was a ≈øweet Cordial to them, that it ≈øhould be for no longer time, much le≈øs, not for Ever: * Now if the proper and genuine Sen≈øe of that Text and Type be Applyed to Antichri≈øt, typified by Antiochus, (as mo≈øt Learned Men Concurr) then it may be as comfortable for us to con≈øider how Chri≈øt, the Me≈ø≈øias, moderates the Matters of the Romi≈øh-Antichri≈øt, (though his Wicked practi≈øes do pro≈øper for a time, as Act. 12. 1, 2, 3.) yet due Bounds He ≈øets to his proud Waves, Job 38. 10, 11. as to the Sea or Ocean, ≈øo to the See of Rome, as he did in the Marian Days, (of Abhorred memory) which la≈øted no longer than tho≈øe of Antiochus, to wit, about Five or Six Y. and as he promi≈øed to do, Revel. 2. 10. The 2d. Allay,
was, Chri≈øt comforts the Church with telling her, not onely, that her Trouble under Antiochus ≈øhould not la≈øt Seven Y. much le≈øs Seventy Y. (as it la≈øted in Babyloni≈øh Bondage) but al≈øo that from the end of tho≈øe Seventy Y. they ≈øhould have Seven Seventies of Years in the enjoyment of their own Country, out of which they had been carry'd Captive, Dan. 9. 24. maugre the malice of Men and Devils: wherein behold how mo≈øt marvellou≈øly the Mercy of God doth bear the ≈øame proportion to his Puni≈øhments, which Seven (a compleat Number) carries to an Unit, or One: Thus his Mercy to his Church Triumphs over his Ju≈øtice, Jam. 2. 13. and over all his Works are his Tender Mercies, P≈øal. 145. 9. The 3d. Allay of this trouble≈øome Inter≈øpace of 490 Y. was Chri≈øts ca≈øting in that Signal Cordial, in the Days of Jaddus or Jadduah, (whom Neh. 12. 10, 11. mentions the High-Prie≈øt De≈øcended from Jeho≈øhuab) who met Daniels Capering Goat (Alexander the Great) in all his Pontificalibus or High-Prie≈øts Formalities, which ≈øtruck ≈øuch a Veneration upon him, that he whom all the World adored, falls down to Adore Jaddus, or rather (as he told Parmenio) Jaddus's God, who in ≈øuch a like Apparition had encourag'd him to Undertake his Wars again≈øt Asia: Hereupon he was ea≈øily prevailed with (the People of the Jews praying all the while for their High-Prie≈øts good Succe≈øs) to ≈øpare Jeru≈øalem,
(which he came to Plunder) e≈øpecially when Walking in Jaddus's Hand to the Temple, and ≈øeeing what Daniel had foretold of him, Writing rather an Hi≈øtory than a Prophecy, even an Abridgement of all his Victories; hereby he was not onely pacified, but al≈øo offer'd Sacrifices to the True God according to the High-Prie≈øts Direction, and be≈øtowing upon the Iews many Favours and Freedoms, he went away much encourag'd in his Enterprize, not doubting but (according to Dan. 8. 3, to 8. the Graecian Goat would overcome the Per≈øian Ram: 'Twas a marvellous Providence, that God ≈øhould pre≈øerve the High-Prie≈øt-hood all the Captivity to this time, (as Neh. 12. 11.) but more to have this Pledge of Gods Grace in Jaddus time. The 4th. Allay was, though Antiochus (who ≈øprung out of Alexanders Succe≈ø≈øors) became a fierce Fiend to the Iews, yet God told them by Daniel, that his ≈øtanding up again≈øt the Prince of Princes, (to wit, God Almighty, in De≈øtroying the Dayly Sacrifice, and in ≈øetting up Idolatry in the Temple) would quickly bring Gods Vengeance upon him, He ≈øhall be broken without Hand, Dan. 8. 25. and though for a few Y. (as above) he ≈øhall do according to his wicked Will in the Holy Land, Dan. 11. 36. not Regarding any God, v. 37. yet ≈øhall he come to his end, v. 45. a loath≈øome and lamentable end, a Vi≈øible Hand of God laid upon him a
loath≈øome Di≈øea≈øe, and wrapt him up in the Sheet of Shame, 1 Macc. 6. 8. and 2 Macc. 9. 5. not ≈øo much becau≈øe he would have ≈øpoiled the Temple of Diana, but becau≈øe he did Spoil the Temple at Jeru≈øalem. The 5th. Allay was that Spirit of God and of Glory which Re≈øted upon the Godly Jews, both for Doing Gods Work, and for Suffering Gods Will, 1. In Doing, Oh what a Ble≈ø≈øed Zeal did blow up Matthias, the Father, and Judas Maccabeus, his Son, who with the Help of his Brethren and other Iews, drove the Enemy out of the Countrey, and clean≈øed the Land of all the Uncleanne≈øs which had been brought into it; Yea, and with a very ≈ømall Handful of Men, did mighty Exploits again≈øt this Vile Antiochus's great Armies, ≈øo that the Church was (in tho≈øe Wor≈øt of Times) mo≈øt Graciou≈øly Holpen with a little Help, Dan. 11. 34. in which Weaker Means God Manife≈øted to them his Greater Strength, In who≈øe name, and by who≈øe Conduct, the People that knew their God, were ≈øtrong to do Exploits, and to out-doe tho≈øe Exploits of Antiochus, Dan. 11. 28, 32. The Apo≈øtle ≈øeemeth to ≈øpeak of the≈øe Maccabees, who wrought Righteou≈øne≈øs, (both Civil and Military) Obtained Promi≈øes, (of Glorious Victories) and E≈øcaped the edge of the Sword, (of their Cur≈øed Enemies) which ≈øometimes Conquerours do not, but purcha≈øe their Conque≈øts with the lo≈øs of their own Lives, as it happened
to tho≈øe brave Brethren at la≈øt, Hebr. 11. 32, 33. and 2ly. in Suffering, and no le≈øs Glorious Spirit did Act the Godly Jews in their Undergoing Cruel Mockings, and mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments, they were Tempted, and they were Tortured too, yet being got above both the Allurements and Affrightments of the World, they would not Accept of Deliverance, upon Sordid and ≈øinful terms, but as willing to Dye as to Dine, they commit them≈øelves to their God in their Martyrdom, That they might obtain a better Re≈øurrection, Hebr. 11. 35, 37. Where that time ≈øeems to be Related to; God had (even then) an Holy Remnant, whereof the World was not Worthy: They were fitter to ≈øhine as Stars in Heaven, than to be torn in pieces by tho≈øe Dogs and Hogs on Earth, as Jo≈øephus, the Book of Maccabees, and of Martyrs tell us. The 6th. Sweet Allay the Church had in this Doleful Day, was that miracle of the Pool of Bethe≈øda, graciou≈øly granted by God to corroborate Her in the True Wor≈øhip of God, under the ≈øad per≈øecutions of Antiochus and other Tyrants, until the days of John Bapti≈øt, and of the Lord Chri≈øt, Joh. 5. 2, 3, 4. This held up the fainting Spirits of the good people in tho≈øe bad Times, when Prophecy failed, and Pro≈øperity too, Yea, and in the general all true Piety, Prophanene≈øs comming in its ≈øtead, as Malachi (their la≈øt Prophet) declares at large: The Rabbins indeed
tell us of a Bath-Kol, (or Eccho) that was heard in the Temple, which ≈øerv'd them for an Oracle, &c. but waving Jewi≈øh Fancies and Fables, the Scripture of Truth tells us how an Angel went at certain times to give Healing Vertue to that Water (wherein their Sacrifices were wa≈øhed) Here many Impotent Folk lay Langui≈øhing at Hopes Ho≈øpital, and looking (after all other means had been ineffectual) for God to ≈øay to them, In the Hou≈øe of Mercy (as the Word Bethe≈øda ≈øignifies) I am thy God that Healeth thee, Exod. 15. 26. Jehova Ropheka, a Gyant-like Healer, Omnipotenti Medico nullus In≈øanabilis Occurit Morbus: No Di≈øea≈øe is, but God can Cure it. This Beneficial Pool was ≈øupplyed with Water from the Fountain of Siloam, which Repre≈øented the Kingdom of Chri≈øt, I≈øa. 8. 6. The 7th. and la≈øt Allay, was the Promi≈øe of the Me≈ø≈øiah, (that Mercy of Mercies) who was to be a more Soveraign Bath than this of Bethe≈øda, or Hou≈øe of Bounty: Chri≈øt is the Royal Fountain, or Kings Bath, Zech. 13. 1. ever-flowing and over-flowing, ≈øuch as Wa≈øh herein Believingly ≈øhall be both Clean and Whole, not Healing at the times of the Iewi≈øh Fea≈øts onely, as that Pool did, but all times of the Year, and not one at once, (as if one only had Suck'd up all the Healing Vertue from all others there) but here 3000 per≈øons were Healed together at one Sermon, Act. 2. 41. when the Angel of the
Covenant De≈øcended to move the Waters that were drawn out of the Wells of Salvation, I≈øa. 12. 3. for no other moving but that of an Angel (who are Mini≈øtring Spirits to heirs of Salvation, Hebr. 1. 14.) could Di≈øpence to the Di≈øea≈øed any ≈øuch powerful and immediate Cure, the Waters were at all times of a clean≈øing Property, (as to their Sacrifices) but onely at that time had they a Cureing Power, as to them≈øelves. When this Beneficial Vertue began in this Pool, is uncertain: 'tis ≈øuppo≈øed to begin when Elia≈øhib (Jo≈øhua's Grand-Child) with the godly Prie≈øts, Built the Sheep-gate, and Beautify'd it, then Con≈øecrated it with their godly Prayr, Neh. 3. 1. Hereupon (as Tremellius ≈øaith) probably followed that Miracle of an Angels De≈øcending into the Pool there, (at their ≈øeveral Solemn Fea≈øts) and Healing all Di≈øea≈øes, how old, great or De≈øperate ≈øoever, and that immediately and in a moment: 'tis as Uncertain likewi≈øe when this Miracle of Healing Cea≈øed, 'tis ≈øuppo≈øed, not till the De≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem, which did fall out about Forty Y. after Chri≈øts Healing this Cripple at Bethe≈øda, it being ≈øo many Y. 'twixt this Pa≈ø≈øeover, Ioh. 5. and that Pa≈ø≈øeover when Titus Ve≈øpa≈øian laid Siege to the City: yet this is more than probable, that this Miraculous Gift of Healing was given to this Pool before the Comming of Chri≈øt, as a „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or famous fore-Runner of him who
was to be the Opened Fountain, Zech. 13. 1. for Healing all Di≈øea≈øes, and Cureing all Sins, Matth. 1. 21. even Je≈øus, the Greek Word comes of „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Sano, to Heal, as the Hebr. Word, of Ja≈øhang, to Save; and this is mo≈øt certain that the time when this Famous Fountain was opened, is well known (though concerning the Pool (afore≈øaid) the Beginning of its Miracle be unknown) to wit, to be about the four Thou≈øand Y. of the World, according to the Latitude of Time, and late≈øt (therefore exacte≈øt) Computations: The Temple of Solomon was Erected about the 3000 Y. of the World, (as above) and the Temple of Chri≈øts Body, Joh. 2. 19. 21. (whereof Solomons Temple was a Type) was Reared up a 1000 Y. after, about the 4000d. Y. of the World, after 2000 more (≈øay the Rabbins) comes the Sabbatical 1000, See before of Solomons Temple; Chri≈øt calls his mo≈øt Exqui≈øitely Framed ( „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ . Hebr. 10. 5. Ephe≈ø. 4. 9. P≈øa. 139. 14, 15.) Body a Temple, wherein the God-head dwelt Bodily, Col. 2. 9. that is Per≈øonally, (as God dwelt in the material Temple, Sacramentally, and in our Hearts Spiritually, Eph. 3. 17.) to mind the Iews there, that their Second Temple wanted the Ark, ∆≤rim, and Thummim, which the fir≈øt Temple had; therefore they mu≈øt look for another Temple, that would corre≈øpond in all things to that Compleat Temple of Solomon, and that was the
Temple of his Body. No ≈øooner was this Fountain opened, this Temple Erected, but the Devil begins to play his pranks in plotting how to Stop up this Well of Salvation, as the Phili≈øtims (at his In≈øtigation) had done the Wells of the Patriarch I≈øaac. Gen. 26. 15. one of tho≈øe Wells is call'd Sitnah, of Satan, v. 21. for Satan Hindred it, (as he did the Word, (that Well of Salvation) 1 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 18. and this Prince of the Power of the Ayr, Ephe≈ø. 2.2. and 6. 12. (and ≈øo hath a power to move the Ayr, and to rai≈øe Storms, as he did to Blow the Fea≈øting-Hou≈øe of Jobs Children down, and to Sink the Ship wherein Chri≈øt was Embarqued, Matth. 8. 24.) Doth now Rai≈øe „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ a mighty Storm wherewith to Blow down this Temple as ≈øoon as ever it was Reared, and Herod the Askalonite or cur≈øed Edomite, was a fit Tool for the Devil to Work this Wicked Will and Wile with. This Herod was Troubled at the Birth of Chri≈øt, Matth. 2. 3. whereat the Sages and the Shepheards (with ≈øundry Saints) ≈øo much Rejoyced; hereupon he pretends to go and Wor≈øhip him, when as he Intends to go and Worry him; but God did marvelou≈øly Ba≈ø≈øle and Befool this Fox, ≈øo that with all his Craft and Cruelty he could not Worry the Holy Child Je≈øus, for he was Over-Witted by the All-Wi≈øe, and over-powr'd by the All-powerful God in tho≈øe following Re≈øpects. (1.) Though Herod wrought Wilily
with the Wi≈øe-men, Tran≈øacting all privately with them, that his purpo≈øe of Killing Chri≈øt might not be prevented, Matth. 2. 7, 8. yet all his Wicked Wi≈ødom prevails not again≈øt God, Prov. 21. 30. becau≈øe his Wi≈ødom was but Folly, otherwi≈øe 'tis a Wonder he went not him≈øelf with the Wi≈øe-men, or ≈øent ≈øome cruel Cut-Throat along with them privily. (2.) Though Herod had charg'd the Wi≈øe-men to bring him Word again, v. 8. yet after the Payment of their Homage to this Holy Babe and little King, v. 9, 10, 11. They being Warned of God, (an Higher power than that of Herods) Returned not to Herod. Thus God Kept them from Betraying Chri≈øt, and them≈øelves (as well as Chri≈øt) were pull'd out of the Mouth of this Lyon by this ≈øweet and marvellous providence. (3.) Though he ≈øent forth Souldiers which Slew all the Male-Children in all the Coa≈øts about, (as well as in Bethlehem) from Two Y. Old and ∆≤nder, &c. Matth. 2. 16. yet he deferr'd his Murdering Work ≈øo long, until the Bird (he ≈øought to Kill) was flown into Aegypt by Gods Direction, v. 13, to 15. Thus though it was the Devil in Herod that ≈øought to De≈øtroy the Young Child, Matth. 2. 13. Revel. 12. 4. yet God was aware of it, prevents it by providing a Sanctuary for his Son in Aegypt, which had been cruel to Gods fir≈øt Born, even I≈ørael, Exod. 4. 22, 23. There Chri≈øt was pre≈øerv'd in Safety, (though the Crafty
Fox (Herod) and the ≈øubtle Serpent (the Devil) Clubb'd their Wits together to contrive his Death) until God brought Word of Herods Death, v. 20. according to his promi≈øe, v. 13. ‚òû And, ≈øome ≈øay, at Chri≈øts comming into Aegypt, all the Idols of the Land (which abounded with them) did fall flat to the ground: 'Twas not onely this that enraged the Devil again≈øt Chri≈øt, but al≈øo, becau≈øe he had Silenc'd all his Oracles, as that at Delphos e≈øpecially, where Augu≈øtus Coe≈øar, urging the Devil for an An≈øwer, was told, That an Hebrew Child had ≈øtop'd his Mouth, and ≈øent him with a Mittimus to Hell, and therefore he might ≈øpare both his Labour and Co≈øt to Con≈øult his Oracle any more. The like Lamentation was made for the Death of the great God Pan (as Plutarch relates) in Arcadia, which Ru≈øtick God and Hairy Satyr, (with his Horns) was no other but an Apparition of the Devil. And as the Cau≈øe of the Devils Rage was his feeling the lo≈øs of his Kingdom, ≈øo the Cau≈øe of Herods Rage was his fearing the lo≈øs of his Kingdom; for as ≈øoon as he had heard from the Wi≈øe-men of Chri≈øt, (Born King of the Jews,) he was Troubled, Matth. 2. 2, 3. fearing that he him≈øelf being a Stranger (of Idumea, not of I≈ørael) might be Depo≈øed by the Iews, whom (he thought) would be glad enough to have a King of their own, to whom they would contribute their be≈øt A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, therefore he goes
about to Murder the Me≈ø≈øiah, before his time was come: 'Twas a marvellous providence that pre≈øerv'd the Line of David in the Tribe of Judah all that Trouble≈øome time from the 2d. Temple to Chri≈øt, (as both Matth. 1. and Luk. 3. doth in their Genealogies Demon≈øtrate) the former by the Pedigree of Jo≈øeph, the latter by that of Mary, (Maries Genealogy is put upon Jo≈øeph, becau≈øe the Hebrews do reckon them not by Women, but by Men onely.) Shewing that Chri≈øt was of the Line-Royal of David, (as well as that Seed of the Woman which ≈øhould break the Devils Head,) and though tho≈øe mentioned there, that lived in tho≈øe Calamitous Days, (after the Captivity) were not formal Kings, (being Subject to other Nations) yet were they Principal Men among their People and Law-givers, (as Iacob had Prophecyed, Gen. 49. 10) ∆≤ntil Shilo came; not a tittle of Gods Word can fail or fall to the Ground. In this Herod the Askalonite, (or Raskalonite) the Scepter departed from Iudah, and lea≈øt it ≈øhould depart from him, becau≈øe Shiloh was come, he Racks his Wit in Diveli≈øh Devices to ≈øecure him≈øelf, but at la≈øt he wracks his own Weal, for though he had e≈øcaped many Con≈øpiracies, yet ≈øoon after his Bloody Butchery in and about Bethlehem, the Hand of God ≈øeizes on him, ≈øo that he Dyes of an execrable and mo≈øt loath≈øome Di≈øea≈øe; And God (him≈øelf) takes care to ≈øend his Holy
Angel to Chri≈øt and his Parents with tho≈øe glad Tydings of cruel Herods Death, and of all his cur≈øed Complices and Con≈øpiratours too, for the merry Me≈ø≈øage is Deliver'd in the plural Number, [They are Dead that ≈øought the Young Childs Life,] Mat. 2. 19, 20. * And the like good News God hath in ≈øtore to ≈øend his Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Church in due time, that all they which ≈øought to make the Church Dye, are them≈øelves Dead, and all their Diabolical De≈øigns with them. The Devil being thus Defeated in the 1≈øt. part of his Plot again≈øt Chri≈øt in the Infancy of his Manhood, (Chri≈øt ≈øtill Lives, grows up in Wi≈ødom and Stature, and in Favour with God and Man, Luk. 2. 52. and at twelve Y. Old able to Dispute with the Doctors, Yea, to non-plus them, v. 47.)

HEreupon he projects a Second Plot again≈øt Chri≈øt in the Infancy (or Minority) of his Mini≈øtry: as the fir≈øt was Manag'd with an In≈øtrument, to

Now he A≈ø≈øaults Chri≈øt by him≈øelf, Matth. 4. 1. he had A≈ø≈øaulted the 1≈øt. Adam in his Proxy (the Serpent) but he will Venture upon the
‚Ä¢ d. Adam in his own Per≈øon, and that Immediately upon his very Entrance into the Mini≈øtery. Behold here the Dreadfulle≈øt Duel, the mo≈øt Memorable Battel betwixt Two the Stronge≈øt and Stoute≈øt Champions was ≈øought that ever appear'd upon the Stage of the World; that of David and Goliah was of a far Inferiour Alloy, (though a type of it) to this,
‚Ä¢ Sam. 17. 41, to 51. There was onely Man again≈øt Man: and that of Michael and the Devil, Jude 9. is below this, for 1. there it was onely an Arch-Angel again≈øt the Arch-Devil. 2ly. 'Twas onely a Di≈øpute about the Body of Mo≈øes, but here, 'tis not Man again≈øt Man as in the fir≈øt In≈øtance, nor an Angel again≈øt a Devil, as in the ≈øecond: No, 'tis the Lord of Angels, Hebr. 2. 4. Wre≈øtling a Fall with the Prince of Devils, Matth. 12. 24. Oh how do people Run to ≈øee ≈øome Remarkable Fencers ≈øight their Prizes? &c. * Behold here a Prize ≈øought betwixt God-Man and Beelzebub, 'twixt the Prince of Life, and the Prince of Darkne≈øs, and that, not about the Natural Body of Mo≈øes,
(as above) but about the Spiritual Body of the Me≈ø≈øias, to wit, his Church, the My≈øtical Body of Chri≈øt, 1 Cor. 12. 12. neither is it, that I≈ørael may Overcome the Phili≈øtims onely, (for which David fought Goliah) but that all Believing Jews and Gentiles (that ever have been, are now, and ≈øhall be to the end of the World,) may Overcome Fle≈øh, World, and Devil, in this Captain of their Salvation, Je≈øus Chri≈øt, Hebr. 2. 10. Rom. 8. 37. Col. 1. 16. and 2. 15. Oh what will ye go out into the Wilderne≈øs to ≈øee? Matth. 11. 7. turn a≈øide (with Mo≈øes, Exod. 3. 3.) and with Me, to ≈øee this Great Sight. The Strong Man, and the Stronger Man Entring the Li≈øts together, not Two Reeds (≈øhaken with the Wind) ≈øhakeing one another, but a mighty Devil (a compleat compound of Goliahs Strength, of Achitophels Craft, and of Doegs Malice) Combating and Conflicting with Almighty God; and for a fuller and more di≈øtinct View of this mo≈øt Famous Conte≈øt, behold it in Two Pregnant Particulars. 1. A mo≈øt ≈øtrange Act. 2. As ≈øtrange an End. 1. The Strange Act (like the River of Paradi≈øe, Gen. 2. 10.) Divides it ≈øelf into Four Streams, Branching it ≈øelf out in Four Circum≈øtances. 1. Time, 2. Place. 3. the Agent. 4. the Patient. 1≈øt. of the Time when, then Matth. 4. 1. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Immediately, Mark. 1. 12. 1. Pre≈øently after he was Baptized. 3. Pre≈øently after he was Proclaimed the Son of God, or Pre≈øently after

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.

NOw come we to the Devils 3d. Plot again≈øt Chri≈øt, when he carry'd on his Office, as the la≈øt was at the beginning of it: Though the Devil was now both Defeated and Departed, yet 'tis ≈øaid expre≈øly, He Departed from Chri≈øt but onely for a Sea≈øon, Luk. 4. 13. Here Expired the Devils Commi≈ø≈øion, he can now (nor at any time) do no more Evil than God permits; Here the Devil (Qua≈øi, Do Evil) endeavour'd to break Chri≈øts Head by drawing him to Sin, that thereby he might Overthrow both him and his Work of Redemption, which he had Undertaken: However Satan (being Defeated in this De≈øign) waits now for a Sea≈øon wherein to Brui≈øe his Heel, well knowing, That was in his Commi≈ø≈øion, from Gen. 3. 15. 'Tis pitty we ≈øhould be ≈øo Ignorant of the Holy Scriptures, when the Devil hath them ≈øo at his Fingers ends, (as we
≈øay) as readily to rehear≈øe them (as he did) in ≈øharpening his 2d. Tempting Tool again≈øt Chri≈øt. He well enough under≈øtood that though he could not now Corrupt Chri≈øt with tho≈øe his three temptations, ≈øo Spoil him as the Church's Redeemer; yet he might have leave (from that Gen. 3. 15.) to do him much mi≈øchief, yea, and to Murder him at la≈øt, which yet (as God over-rul'd it) was but the Brui≈øing of his Heel in his Redemption-Work, as will appear after. Hereupon the Prince of this World commeth again to Chri≈øt, (after his 2d. Defeat) Joh. 14. 30. Non tant√πm clam Tentaturus, quant√πm palam pugnaturus, Not ≈øo much privily to Tempt him, as openly to Fight him; the Tempter will have his Returning Times, as he had to Chri≈øt, ≈øo he will have to ∆≤s, and therefore after we have foiled him in one Con≈ølict, we mu≈øt expect another; he will have the t'other Bout with us, in a calm prepare for a Storm: Satan is Re≈øtle≈øs, Impudent and Importunate, and will not ea≈øily be ≈øaid Nay: If we live out all our Days, he may put us hard to it in every Article of the Creed in Re≈øpect of our Belief, and Urge us to the Breach of every Branch of the Dealogue in Re≈øpect of our Obedience, ≈øo may he tempt us to all kind of Sins. Matth. 7. 28, 29. Joh. 7. 15. and 1. 14. P≈øa. 45. 2. Cant. 4. 3. I≈øa. 50. 4. (that Palmoni Hammadabbar, mo≈øt Excellent Speaker, or Prince of Preachers, Dan. 8. 13.) and al≈øo had Confirmed His Doctrine (Preached) with Matchle≈øs Miracles, as was that fir≈øt of turning Water into Wine, (a better Miracle of the Me≈ø≈øias, than that of Mo≈øes's turning Water into Blood, Exod. 7. 20. for he was a better Mediator, and of better things, Hebr. 3. 3, 5, 6. and 8. 6. and 9. 11, 12, 13, 14, 23, 24.) The Devil ≈øtirr'd up tho≈øe Ungrateful Countrey-men of his at Nazareth, where Envy it ≈øelf had ≈øeem'd to be Silenc'd by his Gracious Words; yet (1) they (by the Devils In≈øtigation) cavil at his Per≈øon, ≈øaying, Is not this Jo≈øephs Son? v. 22. and (2) they would have

Mark 6. 1, 5.) v. 24, to 27. Hereupon (3) they were filled with Wrath, v. 28. picks a Quarrel with Chri≈øt whom they had ≈øo lately and ≈øo much Admired; Their Anger was Chri≈øts Danger: they thru≈øt Chri≈øt out of the City, as Unworthy to Walk upon their Pavement, and the Devil made them ≈øo mad with Malice, that though it were on their Sabbathday, v. 16. and though Chri≈øt was not Condemn'd by any Legal Tryal, yet will they Immediately (of them≈øelves, and on that Day) become Chri≈øts Executioners; in order hereunto, tho≈øe Diveli≈øhly Supercilious Jews carries him [ad Supercilium Montis] to the Brow of the Hill, to ca≈øt Chri≈øt down Headlong, and ≈øo to break his Neck: This the Devil would have had done by Chri≈øt (him≈øelf) Voluntarily, (which God permitted him not to do by his own Hands, when he ≈øet him upon the Pinacle of the Temple, and now Endeavours to do by the Hands of Chri≈øts own Carnal and Cur≈øed Countreymen, v. 29. but God Baffles the Devil here again; for Chri≈øt, like a ≈øecond

The 2d. A≈ø≈øault Satan makes again≈øt Chri≈øt, was, when he ≈øaw this Je≈øus of Nazareth (whom God Annointed with the Holy Spirit) going about and doing good, and Healing all that were Oppre≈ø≈øed of the Devil, for God was with him, Act. 10 38. therefore the Devil will be again≈øt him, for pulling down his Kingdom of Darkne≈øs, and ≈øetting up his own by the Light of the Go≈øpel, and by him≈øelf, the Light of the World, I≈øai. 42. 6. and Luk. 2. 32. and Joh. 8. 12. Hereupon the Devil catching Chri≈øt in a Ship, Matth. 8. 23. as Prince of the Ayr, Ephe≈ø. 2. 2. ≈øtirred up a mighty Tempe≈øt, v. 24. to drown Chri≈øt (that Male-Child of the Church, Revel. 12. 5.) and his Di≈øciples (the Church it ≈øelf) all together, and ≈øee how near he came to Accompli≈øh his Devili≈øh de≈øign, The Ship was covered with Waves, ≈øhe Shipped much Water in tho≈øe overgrown
Seas, in≈øomuch as ≈øhe was ready to Founder and to Sink down to the bottom: this „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ is U≈øually Under≈øtood of an Earth-Quake, but here 'tis a Sea-Quake, Luke calls it „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ; which Pliny calls Navigantium Pe≈øtem, the Seamans Mi≈øery, the mo≈øt Hideous of Storms, that will ≈øtrike all the points of the Compa≈øs, (like that call'd Euroclydon, Act. 27. 14.) Luk. 8. 23. and ≈øo Mark 4. 37. which is a Whirl-wind, not properly one Wind, but a Conflict of many Winds that turns all up≈øide down; no doubt but the Devil was in this ≈øtormy Wind, though God was not in that of Elijahs, 1 Kin. 19. 11. And the ≈øadde≈øt Circum≈øtance of that Story, was, that Chri≈øt was of a Deep Sleep upon a Pillow, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] Sopitus e≈øt, of a Dead Sleep as it were; ≈øo that neither the Noi≈øe of the Sea, now Roaring out its Rage; nor the Clamour of the Seamen, labouring for Life; nor the Single loud Call of his Di≈øciples, can Awake Chri≈øt, till they Double their Cry, Ma≈øte, Ma≈øter, Luk. 8. 24. Here the Devils Hope was as High as the Sea, yet Chri≈øt Awakes and Rebukes both the Rage of the Sea, and the Hope of the Devil: We mu≈øt cry Three times, Awake, Awake, Awake thou Arm of the Lord. (that is A≈øleep) I≈øa. 51. 9. then will Chri≈øt cry, Peace, be ≈øtill thou Stormy Sea, then both the Winds and the Seas, yea, and the Devil (that Rai≈øed them) doth Obey: Chri≈øt lays
Laws upon all Created beings, yea, upon the Devil him≈øelf: Hereby both Chri≈øt and his Church were both Delivered, and then the Calm became as Great as the Storm had been. There was then a great Calm, Mat. 8. 26. when Chri≈øt had fir≈øt Rebuked the Church's (His Di≈øciples) Unbelief; and then the Storm the Devil had rais'd again≈øt them, and again≈øt him≈øelf with them. Oh how ≈øafe is that Ship (the Church) wherein Chri≈øt embarques him≈øelf in the ≈øame Bottom; If Julius Coe≈øar could ≈øay to his Barge-man in a ≈øtormy Sea, [Quid times? Coe≈øarem Vehis, & ejus Fortunam,] Be of good cheer, Barge-man, for 'tis the Fortune of Coe≈øar thou art wafting over, and that cannot Mi≈øcarry: How much more may tho≈øe that are embarqued in the ≈øame Bottom with Chri≈øt, be confident of a ≈øafe Arrival. It may be ≈øaid to the Devil, (the rai≈øer of tho≈øe ≈øtorms again≈øt the Church) what was once ≈øent to the Great Turk,

q.l: Fluctuat, at nunquam Mergitur illa Ratis.

div.p:
The Church may ≈øometimes be Drench'd, but ≈øhe ≈øhall never be Drown'd, no not by the wor≈øt Storm that the Devil can Rai≈øe again≈øt her; the Venom of a Toad may foul that Chri≈øtal, but can never ≈øtain it; Satans ≈øtormy Sea may Dip and dow≈øe that Bottle, but can never Drown it: the Church is like the Con≈øtellation
(call'd the little Bear) that always turns round about the Axis, or North-Pole, but never goes down under the Earth with other Stars and Con≈øtellations, as Father Hieronimus elegantly expre≈ø≈øeth it in the≈øe Words, [Polus Septentrionalis, Semper Ver≈øatur, nunquam Mergitur,] The North-Pole always wheels about, but never wheels down out of the Horizon, much le≈øs, is drowned in the Sea: and as excellent is that Sentence of Father Ambro≈øe, [Diabolus contra Eccle≈øiam Tempe≈øtatem movet, ≈øed ip≈øe Naufragium facit;] though the Devil ≈øtirrs up many ≈øtorms again≈øt the Church, yet he (him≈øelf is ≈øure to ≈øuffer Shipwrack, as he did here, for no ≈øooner was Chri≈øt got ≈øafe to Land, but the very next News we hear of him is, his Encountring with and Ca≈øting out a whole Legion of Devils, that he might be Reveng'd of the Devil, who had endeavour'd to drown both Him and all His, Matth. 8 28. Mark 5. 2. and Luk. 8. 27. The 3d. A≈ø≈øault, or rather, a Meeting, through the Devils being Out-dared, was when a certain Man which had Devils met, Chri≈øt, (one that was more noted, more bewailed, and more outragious than the other) having a whole legion of Devils in him, (which among the old Romans was Six Thou≈øand Armed Souldiers, or as Dr. Hammond ≈øaith, more than twice as many, even Twelve Thou≈øand Five Hundred) ≈øo many Devils were gotten into this one poor Man:
All Pharaohs Cruelties exercis'd upon the I≈øraelites, and all the mo≈øt exqui≈øite Torments the mo≈øt Savage Per≈øecutors put Gods people to, were all nothing to this; 'tis a wonder that this poor Man, having ≈øo many Devils cramm'd up all together in him, did not crack a≈øunder both in Soul and Body: This Man had his Dwelling among the Tombs, There the Devils kept him to Terrifie him the more with the fear of Death all his Life, Hebr. 2. 15. and indeed he was as Dead while he Lived, ≈øo that Burying place (which the Devil Haunts and plays his pranks there to enhaunch a Super≈øtition of Praying to and for the Dead) was the ≈øitte≈øt place for him, thither had tho≈øe Devils driven him, ( „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , driven, as the Hor≈øe is by the Spur of the Rider,) Luk. 8. 29. 'tis a Wonder they drove him not into the Tombs, as well as among them, and that they made him not Run Violently down a ≈øteep place into the Sea to Choak him, as they did the Herd of Swine, Matth. 8. 32. This the Devils would have done with him, and more than this, they would have Run him down to the Bottomle≈øs Deep of Hell, had not God Pre≈øerv'd him from all, that he might meet his Saviour, who dur≈øt meet him, (though no Man el≈øe dur≈øt do ≈øo, becau≈øe of his Fiercene≈øs, Matth. 8. 28.) notwith≈øtanding his Legion of Devils in him: Tho≈øe Devils had driven him to A≈ø≈øault and Batter many Pa≈ø≈øengers Travelling that way,
yet dare they not (though ≈øo many Devils) Venture upon one Chri≈øt, for upon his fir≈øt Approach, they feel a Beam of his Divine Power comming forth to Torment them, crying, Art thou come hither to Torment us? and what have we to do with thee? v. 29. but Chri≈øt had ≈øomewhat to do with them, that is, to Di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them, letting them know their Unclean Company was ≈øitter for Unclean Swine than for Man, Gods noble≈øt Creature. Thus Chri≈øts Pre≈øence was the Devils Torment, yet the poor Mans Happine≈øs, * 12500 Devils cannot match one Chri≈øt; and this poor Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed Man becoming by Grace Di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, and comming to his Right mind, was ≈øo ≈øadly Affrighted, (as he had good cau≈øe) ≈øits down at Je≈øus Feet, and Intreated him that he might continue with him, Luk. 8. 35. 38. Mark 5. 18. not onely to Te≈øtifie his Love to his Redeemer, but al≈øo his Fear, that upon Chri≈øts Departure from him, he might Fall under the Devils Power again, and ≈øo be Repo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Thus Chri≈øt Conquers a great Army of Devils, and makes this Man (whom the Devils had made the mo≈øt mi≈øerable of Mankind) more Holy (and ≈øo more Happy) than all his Countrey-men, who be≈øought Chri≈øt to Depart from them, Matth. 8. 34. (preferring a Swine-≈øtye before a Sanctuary, and Swines Company before a Saviors) whereas this onely Man be≈øought Chri≈øt not to Depart from him; and the Devils be≈øought
Chri≈øt that he would not command them to go out into the Deep, Luk. 8. 31. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or Bottomle≈øs-Pit, 2 Pet. 2. 4. Joh. 12. 31. * The matter is well amended now, not long ago the Devil A≈ø≈øaults Chri≈øt with all might and malice in the Wilderne≈øs, but here in the Gadarens Countrey (none of the be≈øt) a whole Legion of Devils dare not Threaten Chri≈øt, but joyns all in one Petition, and be≈øought him not to pack them away to Hell: They had no mind out of this Country, (that loved the Devils Company better than Chri≈øts) and le≈øs mind out of this World, where they are (as it were) Re≈øpited and Reprieved till their full Torment come; they are ≈øuffred as Free Pri≈øoners (in Liber√¢, non Arct√¢ Cu≈øtodi√¢) to Flutter in the Ayr, and to Cour≈øe about the Earth, Ephe≈ø. 2. 2. Job 1. 7. Matth. 12. 43. 1 Pet. 5. 8. yet all this they do in Chains, 2 Pet. 2. 4. Jude v. 6. until the la≈øt Day, which they Tremble to think on, I am. 2. 19. And which they that mock at, 2 Pet. 3. 3. or make light off, Matth. 22. 5. are herein wor≈øe than Devils. ‚òû Behold here this great Wonder, that our Lord Chri≈øt (≈øo lately To≈ø≈øed in the Sea, as well as Tempted in the Wilderne≈øs) hath here, even in his State of Humiliation, brought (above 12000) Devils down upon their Knees, when they Be≈øought him, finding them≈øelves over-powered, not onely the Hoggi≈øh and carnal Gadarens Be≈øought Chri≈øt, (whom they dur≈øt not Threaten
out of their Coa≈øts) Matth. 8. 34. but even tho≈øe Principalities, Powers, and Spiritual Wickedne≈ø≈øes in High places, Eph. 6. 12. do bow before this Ab-rech, Gen. 41. 43. (which ≈øignifies Tender Father,) This Jo≈øeph our Brother to whom Men and Devils mu≈øt bow the Knee: How much more may he make every Knee bow to him in his State of Exaltation? Phil. 2. 8, 9. The ≈øame power of Chri≈øt (when He Plea≈øeth) can now make the Tempter to change his Tone to us, and all Incarnate Devils their Cruel, into Kind and Candid Carriages, undoubtedly He will Tread Satan under our Feet ≈øhortly, Rom. 15. 20. If it were [Shortly] in Pauls Day, wherein the My≈øtery of Iniquity did but begin to Work, and the long Lea≈øe of the Bea≈øts-Kingdom was not yet begun: How much more is it [Shortly] in our Day, wherein the Bea≈øt hath been playing Rex in his Pranks for above a 1000 Y. ≈øurely 'tis not long e're this Word ≈øhall be Accompli≈øh'd. The 4th. A≈ø≈øault the Devil makes upon Chri≈øt, (after his Departure from Him for a Sea≈øon, Luk. 4. 13.) was in his taking New Mea≈øures, (being Hitherto at every turn over-match'd) and putting the People upon makeing Chri≈øt King, whom he could neither Kill nor Conquer, Joh. 6. 14, 15. 'Tis true, before this, Satan made Two dangerous By-blows at Chri≈øt, the 1≈øt was in Cutting off John Bapti≈øt, who had Witne≈ø≈øed him into the World, that ≈øo Chri≈øt
might ≈øtand upon his own Legs onely, and not be any longer ≈øhored up by the Bapti≈øt, whom all People believ'd to be a Prophet, Matth. 21. 26. The Occa≈øion was this, John Bapti≈øt had not onely Preach'd up Chri≈øt and his Kingdom, (which Enrag'd the Devil) but al≈øo had told Herod the Truth about his Darling-Sin, which none others (though they knew it) dur≈øt tell Herod ≈øo, but the Bapti≈øt onely: this Herod (the le≈øs) was as fit a Tool for the Devil now, as his Father (Herod the great) was at Chri≈øts Birth, Tange Montes & Fumigabunt; Touch the Mountains and they will ≈ømoak, P≈øal. 104. 32. Touch a great Man upon the Sore, (as the Bapti≈øt here did Herod) and he fumes, ca≈øts the Toucher into Pri≈øon without Bail or Mainprize, and there he lies for half a Year without ever coming to a fair Tryal or Hearing: John Bapti≈øt knew well Gods Truth mu≈øt be told, however it be taken, and not to be Betrayed (as too oft it is) by a Cowardly and Sinful Silence: Here John lies in Fetters, while the Fear of Man (more than of God) Re≈øtraineth Herod from Murdering him, Mark 6. 17, 20. Matth. 14. 4, 5. he feared Johns Innocency, which ≈øhone in his Face, and he feared the People, (who Hated him already for his many Crimes and Cruelty) lea≈øt they ≈øhould move a Mutiny at the Death of ≈øo Innocent and ≈øo much Honoured a Per≈øon: Hereupon the Plot was layd 'twixt Herod and his
Harlot (Herodias) to cut him off when their convenient Day (Herods Birth-day) did come, Mark 6. 21. that day had been appointed long before for craftily Acting this cruel Tragedy; a great Fea≈øt mu≈øt then be made, the Nobles Invited, the Damo≈øel-Daughter mu≈øt Dance, the King mu≈øt Swear, and mu≈øt gratifie the Queen with the Bapti≈øts Head: All this was done as if God had not been concern'd at all; but God did ≈øo far concern him≈øelf, that Herod was ≈øtruck with Horror upon it, with Terrour and Torment, Luk. 9. 7. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , he ≈øtuck fa≈øt in the Mud, and could find no way out, yet God made him find a way out of his Kingdom, (the half whereof he had promis'd to the Damo≈øel (for Tripping Wantonly upon the Toe) as Jo≈øephus Relateth, and (probably, out of Gods Kingdom too: So Father and Son be both alike in their Sin and Puni≈øhment: The 2d. By-Blow the Devil gave Chri≈øt was, to cut off his Followers (the Di≈øciples) as he had done his Forerunner John Bapti≈øt; And this he endeavoured to effect, when he had got the Di≈øciples to Sea apart from Chri≈øt, Matth. 14. 23, &c. Mark 6. 45, &c. Joh. 6. 16. Very loth were the Di≈øciples to Lanch out to Sea alone, and to leave his Sweet and Safe Company, but Chri≈øt con≈øtrains them to do ≈øo, (1) that he might the ≈øooner di≈ømi≈øs the Multitude, (2) he di≈ømi≈ø≈øeth his Di≈øciples to Sea, lea≈øt they (al≈øo) ≈øhould ≈øtrike in with that Ra≈øh-many-Headed
Multitude, who would have made him King. (3) Though they were loth to leave their be≈øt Friend behind them ≈øo neer Night, in a De≈øart, and all alone too, yet this was Chri≈øts Choice, that He might have an Opportunity of Solitary Prayer for their Safety, and of his Miraculous Walking upon the waves to their Relief: by the Want of Chri≈øt (for a few Hours of Danger onely) they learnt the Worth of Chri≈øt: no ≈øooner had the Devil caught the Di≈øciples at Di≈øtance from Chri≈øt, but to Work he falls, then down comes the Storm and up goes the Sea; another „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ or mighty Storm, (which is a Wind (≈øaith Ari≈øtotle) that Rouls in a Circle with ≈øuch Violence, in≈øomuch as it ≈øwallows up whole Towns in Italy, &c.) and „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , a great Tempe≈øt, a very Sea-Quake, of the ≈øame Nature with an Earth-Quake, (which hath the Formidable force of removing Mountains, and of ca≈øting down Strong Ca≈øtles that ≈øtand upon them) De≈øcends from the Stinking Breath of the Prince of the Ayr, (the Devil) upon now the poor and Chri≈øtle≈øs Apo≈øtles, with a malicious Intention to Drown them all, that they might never trouble his Kingdom any more; as with an Horrible Wind Satan had Brain'd all Jobs Children, ≈øo by the like means he would have Drown'd all Chri≈øts Di≈øciples, Chri≈øt being ab≈øent in this latter, as Job (him≈øelf) was in the former In≈øtance. Behold (with me) a little,
1. The Churches Calamity, 2. Her Comfort; in the 1≈øt. See the ≈øad Circum≈øtances of this Hi≈øtory of the Church: * as (1) in this little Ship was embarqued all the Hopes of a Church that now God had in the whole World, as in Noahs Ark, couped up in a little compa≈øs: (2) The Winds were contrary, Matth. 14. 24. as Act. 27. 4. So 'tis mo≈øtly with the Church, that is ≈øo often blown back from the Cape of Good Hope, and from the Haven of Heaven in her Militant-State, ≈øhe is ever and anon, as in the Straits of Magellan, wherein which way ≈øoever a Man Bends his Cour≈øe, he is ≈øure to have the Wind ≈øit cro≈øs to him. (3) Tho≈øe Contrary Winds were not ≈øo much Ordinary as Extraordinary, ≈øo that tho≈øe Apo≈øtles (who were Fi≈øhermen, and thereby experienced in ordinary Sea-Storms) cryed out, We Peri≈øh, for (4) they were [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ Mark 6. 48, 49.] which ≈øignifies not onely that they were To≈ø≈øed with the Tempe≈øt, but al≈øo Tormented with it ≈øo the Word is u≈øed, Luk. 16. 23. The Rich Glutton was [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] in Torments: Thus the Afflicted Church was here not onely to≈ø≈øed with Tempe≈øts, and not Comforted, as I≈øa. 54. 11. but al≈øo Tormented, as tho≈øe mi≈øerable Men are by the Tormentors (in the Spani≈øh Inqui≈øition) to≈ø≈øing them too and fro up and down till they be Ready to loo≈øe one Limb from another: So this Wind was far unlike the ≈øweet Gales of the Spirit of God, which always blows
Good to the Church out of every Quarter, North and South, Cant. 4. 16. but more like that [Ruach Gedolah] ≈øtrong and mighty Wind, 1 Kin. 19. 11. which had not the Lord in it, for his Voice is a Voice of Mercy and Clemency, and Natural to him, Micah 7. 18. and his Voice of Ju≈øtice again≈øt Jezebel (which was not to be yet) is called his ≈øtrange Act, I≈øai. 28. 21. yea, more then ≈øo, for this Tempe≈øtuous Wind had the Devil in it, and therefore it to≈ø≈øed the Church up and down, hither and thither, ≈øo it Toiled and Tormented them, as if it had been Extorting (as upon a Rack) a Denyal of Chri≈øt and of all Chri≈øtianity from them: (5) They were in the Deep, the Ship was now in the mid≈øt of the Sea, Matth. 14.24.
