div.p:
BUt that which made them mad mo≈øt of all, was His Rai≈øing up Lazarus from the Dead, Joh. 11. 47. Tho≈øe Reprobate Wretches would not Believe, no, though one Ro≈øe from the Dead to them, Luk. 16. 31. as Lazarus, and yet they li≈øten'd as little to Him, as they did to Chri≈øt: They Call a Council, not out of the unlearned Rabble, but mo≈øt learned Clerks, (which ≈øhould have known better things) the Chief Prie≈øts and Phari≈øees Convene and Con≈øult, yea, and Unanimou≈øly Conclude, that not onely Chri≈øt, but al≈øo Lazarus mu≈øt be put to Death, Joh. 12. 10. and why mu≈øt Lazarus Dye? 'twas onely becau≈øe God had made him Alive; but they ≈øeem to have better Rea≈øon (even that of Nece≈ø≈øity) for Killing Chri≈øt; If this be not done (≈øay they) the Romans will come, &c. Joh. 11. 48. and becau≈øe it was done, the Romans came indeed
and Plagu'd them in taking away their Place and Nation, principally for this Inexpiable Sin of Killing the Lord of Glory, as Chri≈øt had told them, Matth. 21. 38, 39, 40. and as they (them≈øelves) had unwittingly Read, (even) their own De≈øtiny, v. 41, 43. Luk. 20. 15. Thus they pretending and pleading a Nece≈ø≈øity to Sin, whereas they lay under no Nece≈ø≈øity, ≈øave onely one, to wit, Not to Sin, and becau≈øe they did ≈øo Sin, (which they thought their Duty) therefore the thing that they feared came upon them, King Je≈øus (for Killing him) ≈øent forth his Armies, (the Roman-Spoilers) who Di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed them of their Country, Burnt their Temple, (as the Caldeans had formerly done in the time of their Fore-fathers) Matth. 22. 7. and 24. 2, 16, 20, 21, 34. the De≈øtruction of Ieru≈øalem (for Murdering of Chri≈øt) was a Matchle≈øs De≈øtruction, as Jo≈øephus Relates, a Million of Iews peri≈øhed mi≈øerably by the Siege, (the whole Body of the Land being then gather'd together at the Pa≈ø≈øeover,) and 97000 carry'd Captive, Mark Ch. 13. 19. calls tho≈øe Days Affliction, as if that time were nothing el≈øe but Affliction it ≈øelf. Well, therefore might the Chief-Prie≈øts and Phari≈øees (when „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Self-Condemned, Tit. 3. 11.) ≈øay, God forbid, Luk. 20. 16. when Chri≈øt had extorted from them an Evident foretelling of their own final Fate, Mat. 21.41. while they thought others were concern'd in
the Parable, but perceiving that them≈øelves were the Wicked Men which the Parable did per≈øonate, they would have Retracted the Sentence they had Denounced again≈øt them≈øelves out of their own Mouths, and crys [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] God forbid, Mark 12. 9. and Luk. 20. 16. which the Syriack Reads, [This ≈øhall not be, we will not Kill the Son of God, the Lord of the Vineyard, &c. notwith≈øtanding this their [ab≈øit] be it far from us ≈øo to do, yet they did it; the Devil Helping them with a Je≈øuitical Aequivocation, That it was not their Right Me≈ø≈øiah, but onely a Mock-Me≈ø≈øiah whom they ≈øought to Murder: Hereupon they fall to Work by the Devils Direction, and with his be≈øt A≈ø≈øi≈øtance; the Grand Remora was. They Feared the People, Matth. 21. 46. ‚òû (They are Wor≈øe than Chri≈øt-Killers, that fear them not, and while the Body of a People bear Favour to Chri≈øt and his Cau≈øe, neither of the≈øe Two can be Killed by the wor≈øt of Per≈øecutors.) This Rubb and Remora is ≈øtill Unremoved, Matth. 26. 3, 4, 5. The General Council (not unlike to that of Trent) Convene again, hold the Conclu≈øion, (Chri≈øt ≈øhall be Kill'd) but cannot Hit upon a Convenient time, crying, Not at the Fea≈øt, for Fear of a Re≈øcue: * Behold here the contrary Motions of Heaven and Hell: The Devil (in this Council, ju≈øt contrary to that, Act. 15. 28. where the Holy Gho≈øt ≈øat Prae≈øident) crys here, Not
on the Fea≈øt Day, another time is more ≈øea≈øonable: No, ≈øaith God, It ≈øhall not be when you will, Chri≈øt whom you Kill is my Pa≈øchal-Lamb, (the Lamb that is to take away the Sins of the World, Joh. 1. 29.) you (and the Devil to Help you) do nothing but according to My Determinate Coun≈øel, Act. 4. 28. and 2. 22. Though you be a Company of Bloody Dogs that are mu≈ø≈øled up with the fear of an Uproar from the Friends and Favourers of Chri≈øt; ≈øo that you ≈øay, Not on the Fea≈øt; but I ≈øay, It ≈øhall be on the Pa≈øchal Fea≈øt-Day, and on no other. Here is a Marvellous Over-Ruling Providence of God; tho≈øe Wicked Prie≈øts had oft ≈øought a time (before this) wherein to Kill Chri≈øt, but never could find any, ∆≤ntil his Hour was now come, and not now mu≈øt they Determine the time, the Pa≈ø≈øeover-Lamb mu≈øt Dye on the Pa≈ø≈øeover-Day, to put an End to the Iewi≈øh-Pa≈ø≈øeover, (≈øignifying their Deliverance from Aegypt and her King) but this Praefigur'd our Redemption from the Spiritual-Pharaoh, and from his Two Heavy-Handed Task-Ma≈øters, to wit, Sin Mortal, and Death Eternal: Yea, and in all this, tho≈øe Mi≈øcreants (in fulfilling their own Wicked Will) do but fulfill the Holy Will of God and his Divine Decree, and no more Thanks to them, than was to Haman in Mordecai's Advancement, whereunto Haman held the Stirrop onely. However, this Cur≈øed Council Con≈øults
to take Je≈øus by Subtilty, Mat. 26. 4. by Fraud, and not by Force, for fear of an ∆≤proar: they feared the fury of Man more than the frowns of God, v. 5. The Devil (who ≈øet them on Work) ≈øteps in to Hand them over this Stumbling-Block, He Entred into Judas after the Sop was given him at Supper in the Hou≈øe of Simon the Leper) Two Days before the Pa≈ø≈øeover, Joh 13. 27, 30. from Bethany (though it were Night, and though Un≈øolicited by tho≈øe Con≈øpirators) Satan makes Iudas trudge to Ieru≈øalem, he freely offers his Service, (not doubting of its Kind Acceptance) makes his Market with them at their own Rate, Referring the Price of that Peerle≈øs Pearl (his Holy Ma≈øter) to tho≈øe Barbarous Buyers Plea≈øure; they Bargain to give him Thirty pieces of Silver, (the price of a Slave, Exod. 21. 3 ‚Ä¢ .) a goodly Price for this Pearl of great Price, Zech. 11. 12. Mat. 13. 45, 46. The Devil of Di≈øcontent was Entred into tho≈øe Prodigiou≈øly pro≈øligate Prie≈øts long before, becau≈øe Chri≈øts Gracious Words (he Spake,) and the Mighty Works (he Wrought,) Weaken'd both theirs and the Devils Kingdom, therefore they all along ≈øought to Kill Chri≈øt, as before, but Dur≈øt not do it for fear of the People. Now the Devil of Di≈øcontent Entred into Judas, (mi≈ø≈øing his Fat Mor≈øel, the price of the precious Oyntment, which he would have put into his Bagg, Joh. 12. 4, 6.) ≈øo here was the Devil
in the Prie≈øts Con≈øpiring with the Devil in Iudas, therefore the Contract about this Horrid Trea≈øon was like enough to Comply: Hereupon Iudas Undertakes to take the Thorn out of the Prie≈øts Heel, (the fear of a Tumult) and to Deliver his Ma≈øter up to them, (though at the Fea≈øt, yet Quietly enough) to wit, In the Ab≈øence of the People; from that time he ≈øought Opportunity to Betray him, Matth. 26. 16. both for time and place he promis'd to do it [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] without any Tumult from the People, Luk. 22. 6. This Iudas (by the Devil, his Liege-Lords Direction) ≈øoon effected, to wit, in the Night when Chri≈øt was (with the Di≈øciples onely) in the Garden at Geth≈øemane, without the City, Matth. 26. 36. Mark. 14. 32. Luk. 22. 39. ‚òû Mark here (1) the Confidence, (2) the Contumacy, (3) the Craftine≈øs of this Devil in Iudas: (1.) his Confidence, Oh what a dareing Devil was this Frontle≈øs Traytor, that, after he had Contriv'd and Contracted that prodigious Villany of Shedding his Lords Blood, he ≈øhould Dare thus Boldly and Impudently to Intrude him≈øelf into the pre≈øence of his Omni≈øcient (as well as Innocent) Ma≈øter, at His Lords Pa≈ø≈øeover, Matth. 26. 20, 21, &c. (2.) his Contumacy, the Innocent Life of his Lord Chri≈øt could not but Dart mo≈øt powerful Convictions upon the Con≈øcience of this Traiterous Villain, yet Con≈øpires he his Murder, not out of any ≈øudden pang of
pa≈ø≈øion, or by any ≈øurprizing Incogitancy; but all he did was done in Cold Blood, and upon Mature Deliberation, (therefore 'tis ≈øaid, from the time of his makeing this Damnable Bargain with the Prie≈øts, he ≈øought Opportunity, &c.) and all, without any (≈øave Satan in him) to Solicit him to it, for Two Days and Nights together. (3.) his Craftine≈øs, in Watching this Opportunity, not in the Day-time, lea≈øt his Deed of Darkne≈øs ≈øhould be Di≈øcern'd and Dete≈øted; nor in the City, lea≈øt ≈øome good Citizens ≈øhould make a Re≈øcue; but his mon≈øtrous and matchle≈øs Villany mu≈øt be done in the Night-time, lea≈øt it ≈øhould blu≈øh to behold the Light, and without the City in a Solitary place, (Iudas knew Chri≈øt's Haunts, as Saul did Davids, 1 Sam. 23. 22.) to vvit, in the Garden, (where he had his Agony, and where he began to Expiate that fir≈øt Sin Adam had committed in a Garden) of Geth≈øemane, which ≈øignifies, the Valley of Fatne≈øs, there this unparallel'd Impiety mu≈øt be perpetrated; this place was over the Brook Kidron, Joh. 18. 1, 2. and neer the Mount of Olives, Luk. 22. 39. Mark 14. 32. Here was Chri≈øt (1) Apprehended, hence was he Hurry'd to be (2) Arraigned in the Spiritual-Court before a full Council of Corrupt-Churchmen, Matth. 26. 57. with a great deal of Inju≈øtice and Subornation, ver. 59.60. being Re≈øolv'd to have his Blood right or wrong; then is he (3) Condemned in their
Court for a Bla≈øphemer, v. 65, 66. then was he (4) Spitted on in token of Contempt, Numb. 12. 14. Deut. 25. 9. (5) He was Buffeted, v. 67. as if he had been their Slave. (6) Blindfolded, Luk. 22. 94. In≈øulting over him with their mad Mockings, as if he had been but a Mock-Prophet. (7) they Binded his Hands behind him, (as is done to the Condemned,) and is ≈øent away by the Con≈øi≈øtory of Prie≈øts to be put to Death by the Secular or Civil Power, Matth. 27. 2. Joh. 18. 12. (8) the Roman-Magi≈øtrate dooms him to be Crucified after the Roman manner, at the Wicked Iews In≈øtigation: Matth. 27.22, 23, 26. then (9) was he Striped, v. 26. that by his Stripes we might be Healed, I≈øa. 53. 5. (10) he was Stripped, v. 28. that we might be Clothed, Ezek. 16. 10. ≈øo was led away to Dye the mo≈øt Ignominious Death, as a Traitour to Coe≈øar, and as the Vile≈øt of Men, to expiate Adams Sin, who would have been as Wi≈øe as God; (La≈øtly,) When Dead he was Buryed, and his Sepulchre made ≈øure and ≈øecure both with Seal and Watch, and a great Stone upon it, Matth. 27. 64, 65, 66. 'tis a common ≈øaying, Mortui non Mordent, Dead Men Bite not: but here Chri≈øt, though Dead and Buried, Bites and beats Hard upon tho≈øe evil Mens Con≈øciences, they could not Re≈øt all the Night before, ver. 62. for fear Chri≈øt ≈øhould get out of his Grave ≈øome way or other, and ≈øo Create them more and further
Trouble: And they that had forgot all Chri≈øts other ≈øweet, ≈øavoury, and ≈øaving Sayings, (Writing them all in the Sand) could remember (but for a Wicked Purpo≈øe) that which his own Di≈øciples could not ≈øo Readi ‚Ä¢ y call to mind for their own good & Comfort; no, nor Under≈øtand it, when plainly told them, Mark 9. 31, 32. Tho≈øe mad Men remember what he had ≈øaid about his Re≈øurrection, onely becau≈øe they would gladly have kept Chri≈øt in the Grave ≈øtill, where now they had him; that they might ≈øecurely Dance upon his Grave, and that they might think them≈øelves ≈øufficiently Cock-≈øure of him. ‚òû Oh that we could do all this to the Cur≈øed Body of Sin, what tho≈øe Cur≈øed Prie≈øts did to the Ble≈ø≈øed Body of Chri≈øt, would we be of the Royal Prie≈øthood, 1 Pet. 2. 5. made ≈øo by Chri≈øt unto God, Revel. 1. 6. Exod. 19. 6. Then mu≈øt we do to the Body of Sin all the≈øe things: (1) Apprehend it. (2) Arraign it. (3) Condemn it. (4) Spit in its Face. (5) Buffet it Black and Blew. (6) Blindfold it. (7) Bind it Hand and Foot. (8) Stripe it. (9) Stripp it. (10) Crucifie it. (La≈øtly) Bury it in a ≈øure Grave, that [Peccata non Redeant] never Ri≈øe or Return our Sin may any more, neither in this World to our Temporal or Spiritual Confu≈øion, or in the World to come, to our Utter and Eternal Condemnation: All the≈øe Actions are but manife≈øt Duties in Scripture, as 1 Cor. 9. 27. Gal. 5. 24. Rom. 8. 13.
and 6. 4, 11, &c. Now when Chri≈øt was Buryed thus ≈øurely, the Devil (no doubt) Danced (for Company) upon His Grave, having made all firm and fa≈øt (as he thought) for ever and a Day: But He that ≈øat in Heaven (≈øaying, Yet have I ≈øet my King upon my Holy Hill of Sion, P≈øal. 2. 4, 6, &c.) Laughed at this, and all this to Nothing, Jehovah had them in Deri≈øion: Behold how God over-≈øhoots Satan in his own Bow: Divine Providence makes u≈øe of tho≈øe very Means (the Devils Malice u≈øed to ob≈øcure Chri≈øts Glory) to Render Chri≈øts Re≈øurrection more Glorious and much le≈øs Obnoxious to any Ju≈øt Exception: That very Watch which was ≈øet to keep Chri≈øt Under-Ground and in his Grave, are made (Nolens Volens) the Trembling Witne≈ø≈øes of his (to them frightful) Re≈øurrection, they were ≈øtruck half Dead for bearing and wearing Arms again≈øt God, and ≈øo Expo≈øing them≈øelves to his Wrath, Matth. 28. 4. and 'twas the Trembling of the Earth, (that now had Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, who proved too Hot a Mouthful for it to ≈øwallow, Act. 2. 24.) together with the Apparition of a Glorious Angel, (Rouling away the great Stone from the Mouth of the Sepulchre, and ≈øitting down upon it in Despight of the Guard, as a Conquerour) which made the Watch Tremble, the ≈øtoute≈øt of the Devils Champions ≈øhrink and ≈øhrivel away, when Chri≈øt begins to Di≈øplay his Glory: Neither
the Weight of the great Stone, nor the Watch of the Stout Souldiers, nor yet the Bands of Death, (≈øtronger than all, ≈øo ≈øtrong as to hold fa≈øt many Millions of Men, from Adam to this Day, under the power of Death) could Hold the Dead Body of Chri≈øt from Ri≈øing beyond his own time. To all tho≈øe Three Impeding Maladies, God found out and Applyed as many (even Three) mo≈øt Effectual Remedies: for (1.) The great Stone that was laid upon the Tomb by Man, was Roul'd away by an Angel: (2.) The Earth-quake makes an Heart-quake in the Watch, in≈øomuch that they (though Sixty of them, according to Theophylact) are all Affrighted away. And (3) the Deity of Chri≈øt Lo≈øed (or Broke) the Bands of Death, Act 2. 24. for Chi≈øt being Life E≈ø≈øential, it was not po≈ø≈øible he ≈øhould be Holden of them, therefore he Swallowed up Death in Victory, 1 Cor. 15. 54. His Re≈øurrection was to be the Demon≈øtration of His Divine Nature, Rom. 1. 4. and the Foundation of our Faith and Per≈øeverance, 1 Cor. 15. 14. notwith≈øtanding their malicious Wre≈øting of Chri≈øts words, [De≈øtroy this Temple of my Body,] yet I will Rai≈øe it again the Third Day, Joh 2. 19. (the meaning of which they Invert) and made it a matter of Accu≈øation again≈øt him, at his Arraignment, Matth. 26. 61. but after his Interrment, they take up his Right meaning, and made Advantage of it, for Secureing him fa≈øt
in his Sepulchre, calling the Faithful and True Witne≈øs, Revel. 1. 5. and 3. 7. this Cheat, or Deceiver, Matth. 27. 63. yet the Lord turns all their Wicked Coun≈øel into Folly, 2 Sam. 15. 31. 1 Cor. 1. 19, 25. &c. and in the ≈øight and De≈øpight of Sixty Weaponed Witne≈ø≈øes, (After the Sun of Righteou≈øne≈øs had been ≈øett in the Grave Six and Thirty Hours, ju≈øt ≈øo long as the Sun in the Firmament had his Cour≈øe, ≈øtop'd on Jo≈øhuahs long Day, Jo≈øh. 10. 13.) Then did Chri≈øt Break the Bonds of Death as ea≈øily as Sam≈øon did his Green Withs, Judg. 16.7. and Ro≈øe up on the fir≈øt Day to bring Life and Immortality to light by the Go≈øpel, 2 Tim. 1. 10. upon the ≈øame Day that God had drawn out of that Abhorred E≈øtate of Nothing, and brought the fir≈øt Light out of Original Darkne≈øs, by his Almighty Word, Gen. 1. 2, 5.

argument.p: The Twenty-Fifth Plot in the New-Te≈øtament, again≈øt the Church, in Apo≈øtles, Defeated by God.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.
div.p:
AFter a few Days that Chri≈øt was Ri≈øen out of his Grave, he Rode up to Heaven as a Conquerour (in his Triumphant Chariot) over Sin, Death, Hell, and Devil,
leading Captivity Captive, that is, Captivating all tho≈øe Four who had held us in Captivity, 2 Tim. 2. 26. Ju≈øt as in the Roman-Triumphs, the Great Conquerour Rode up to the Capitol in a Chariot of State, and all their Pri≈øoners following behind with their Hands bound behind them; He Throwing certain pieces of Coin abroad (all along as he A≈øcended) to be pick'd up by the People. Even ≈øo our Lord Chri≈øt (that Mighty Conquerour) in the Day of his Solemn Coronation, or Inauguration into his Heavenly Kingdom, Triumphed over all tho≈øe Spiritual Adver≈øaries of his Church, making a ≈øhew of them openly, Col. 2. 15. as Tamberlain did (the Great Turk) Bajazet, whom he carried about all A≈øia, ≈øhut up in an Iron-Cage, to be ≈øeen of all Spectators on every ≈øide for Scorn and Deri≈øion: And Chri≈øt likewi≈øe (that the Grandeur of his Glorious Conque≈øt might be more magnificently Celebrated) gave great Gifts to Men: 'Tis ≈øaid he Received tho≈øe Gifts before in the Old Te≈øtament, P≈øal. 68. 18. and he Gave them now in the New, Ephe≈ø. 4. 8. He Received them, that he might Give them, he therefore Receives them with one Hand, and Gives them with the other, Accounting it more Honourable to give than to receive, Act. 20. 35. Now the Gifts Chri≈øt gave to his Church were both Ordinary and Extraordinary, to wit, Apo≈øtles, Prophets, Evangeli≈øts, Pa≈øtours, Teachers, All Gifted
by God, for the Perfecting of the Saints, for the Work of the Mini≈øtry and for the Edifying of the Body of Chri≈øt, Ephe≈ø. 4. 8, 11, 12. „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , that is, for the right Joynting of what ever the Devil may Disjoynt, even to the End of the World, v. 13. before which, a compleat comming up into an ∆≤nity of the Faith, and unto that full Mea≈øure of the Stature of Chri≈øt (even a Perfection of Grace) cannot be expected: Hence Chri≈øt In≈øi≈øts upon this point, that his going from his Di≈øciples was as Expedient as his comming to them, Joh. 16. 7. He came to them, that he might Conver≈øe with them in the Fle≈øh, but he mu≈øt Depart from them, that he might Conferr upon them his Spirit. Chri≈øt had often promis'd (to ≈øend the Spirit (or Comforter) to them) in his Life time, John 14. 16, 26. and 15. 26. and 16. 7. that they might once ob≈øerve it as an unparallel Priviledge to have the Spirit (which is the be≈øt of all things) powred down upon all Fle≈øh, (the wor≈øt of all things, Ho≈ø. 8. 13.) Joel 2. 28. Chri≈øt tells them that this Spirit (whom he calls, Another Comforter, whereof they would ≈øtand in need, (during his Departure) in an Evil World) ≈øhould be as his Vicar-General, with whom he would leave them in a dark forlorn World, and by whom he would be with them, (and with their Succe≈ø≈øors) even to the End of the World, Mat. 28. 20. Now after his Re≈øurrection, He Breath'd on
them, ≈øaying, Receive ye the Holy Gho≈øt, Joh. 20. 22. as Adam received Life by Gods Breathing upon him, ≈øo the Di≈øciples received a power of Life and Death, of Remi≈ø≈øion of Sin and Execution of Judgment, (as Act. 5. 5. 10.) by Chri≈øts Breathing upon them, or, at lea≈øt, this Breathing was a prefiguring-preparation for their further and fuller Reception of the Spirit upon the Day of Penteco≈øt, which Chri≈øt had Promi≈øed, Luk. 24. 49. and did perform over and over again, Act. 2. 2, 3, 4. and 4. 31, 33. whereby they were Enabled (as Chri≈øt had told them) to do greater Works than he did, Joh. 14. 12. not for the Manner, they doing all in Chri≈øts Name, not in their own, nor as Equal with God, but for matter greater, as (1) Converting Three Thou≈øand Souls at one Sermon, (alas! now not one Soul ≈øcarce is Converted by Three Thou≈øand Sermons) Act. 2. 41. (2) Curcing the Di≈øea≈øed, not onely by a Word ≈øpeaking, or an Hand touching, but al≈øo by the ≈øhaddow of Peter pa≈ø≈øing by, Act. 5. 15, 16. or by an Handkerchief, (onely touching Paul, though at a Di≈øtance,) Act. 19. 12. both the≈øe had a Soveraign Miraculous (yet neither of them any Inhaerent) power to Cure Di≈øea≈øes, and to Ca≈øt out Devils. (3) Conver≈øing with all Nations in all their ≈øeveral Languages, Act. 2. 4, 8, to 11. which they never Studied to learn them at Home, nor ever Travel'd Abroad to gain them. (4) Conferring
Corporal Plagues, Act. 13. 11. and Spiritual, 1 Cor. 5. 5. Yea, Death it ≈øelf, Act. 5. 5, 9, 10. upon Oppo≈øers and Di≈øgracers of the Go≈øpel.

Chri≈øt never Hurt any by his Miracles, but Healed all. (5) Conquering a great part of the World, Reduceing it to the Obedience of Chri≈øt, they being the White Hor≈øes on which the Go≈øpel Rode abroad and about the World, Conquering and to Conquer, Revel. 6. 2. (6) Contracting no Harm by Drinking Deadly Poy≈øon, Mark 16. 17, 18. as John the Apo≈øtle, Bar≈øabas, and others did, according to Eu≈øebius and other Eccle≈øia≈øtick-Hi≈øtories: Yea, and Sacred Scripture doth better Confirm, that the Viper about Pauls Hand did not Hurt him, Act. 28. 3, 4, 5. no Doubt but the Devils de≈øign here was to have De≈øtroyed him by that Viper, but he was (as in all his other Plots) deceived and Defeated by Vertue of that Promi≈øe of Chri≈øt, Mark 16. 18. I≈øa. 11. 8. The ≈øame God that ≈øhut the Mouths of the Lyons for Daniels ≈øafety, Dan. 6. 22. did al≈øo ≈øhut the mouth of th ‚Ä¢ s Venomous Bea≈øt for Pauls Pre≈øervation, and ≈øo ≈øhut it, as the Devil could not remove the Muzzle for his De≈øtruction, ≈øee P≈øa. 91. 13. and Luk. 10. 19. Now the Devil beholding the Go≈øpel carry'd throughout the World upon tho≈øe Stupendious Miracles, as upon ≈øo many Eagles (or rather Angels) Wings; the Apo≈øtles Working greater Works by the power of Chri≈øts Spirit (Poured out upon them, Joh.

Imaginations and Helli≈øh Machinations, Chri≈øt meets him, and ∆≤nhor≈øt him or Knock'd him down with a Thunder-Bolt, or Fla≈øh of Lightning, when almo≈øt at his Journeys end, there he ≈øtumbl'd upon that ≈øtumbling-Stone, (the Rock of Ages, as well as of Offence) and falls to the Earth, Act. 9. 3, 4. and 'tis a Wonder he brake not all his Bones, and that his Breath was not beaten out of his Body, yea, that his Carca≈øs was not hung up in Gibbets, (as a publick Warning to all Bloody Per≈øecutors) that the Churches of Chri≈øt might have the more Re≈øt and Respite thereby: No, Chri≈øts thoughts are not as ours; 'tis True, Chri≈øts Throws and Blows with his Heavy Hand are Deadly to effect the afore≈øaid, and his Anger is De≈øtructive to ≈øuch as will not Ki≈øs him with a Ki≈øs of Subjection, he ≈øaith, a little of his Wrath will make them Peri≈øh in the mid≈øt of their way, of their Plots, and of their Lives, P≈øa. 2. 12. yet lo, together with the Beams of his Glory, Chri≈øt here ≈øhews the Bowels of his pitty: though now he be in Heaven in a Glorified E≈øtate, yet hath he ≈øtill his Heart as kindly affected to Sinners as when he was upon Earth; though he hath chang'd his Honour, yet not his Nature, he is as kind and loving as ever, yea more, for it is Glorifi'd Love that is now in Chri≈øt, though he now be free from Pa≈ø≈øion, (as „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , or uncapable of Suffering) yet not at all from Compa≈ø≈øion: ≈øtill hath He a kind of
Feeling, as well as Fellow-Feeling, in tho≈øe Words, Saul, Saul, why Per≈øecute≈øt thou me? Act. 9. 4. the Head of the Church (Chri≈øt) feels him≈øelf Wounded in his Members (the Saints) Chri≈øt liveth in them, Gal. 2. 20. their Reproaches are his, Hebr. 13. 13. and their ≈øufferings are his, Col. 1. 24. Saul Hearing from this Compa≈ø≈øionate Chri≈øt, that he was but kicking again≈øt the Pricks, v. 5. that is, In his mad marching to Dama≈øcus, he was but Hurting him≈øelf, in Hurting the Saints, he Truckles and becomes (of a mad Bull of Ba≈øhan) Tractable to Chri≈øts Yoke: * Oh matchle≈øs Mercy in Chri≈øt, thus to make of a Worrying Wolf, ≈øuch a Ble≈ø≈øed Shepheard of his Flock of Sheep, Then had the Churches Re≈øt, &c. v. 31. when the Wolf was chang'd into a Lamb, yea, into a Pa≈øtor or Feeder and Defender of the Lambs of Chri≈øt. ‚òû God hath ≈øtill this way open whereby to give Re≈øt to his Afflicted Chruches, He can Convert as well as Confound the wor≈øt of their Per≈øecutors: 'Tis plain here, Satan lo≈øt and Chri≈øt gain'd the Game. Satans (6th) A≈ø≈øault was upon Saul (him≈øelf) when converted into Paul, [≈øo call'd „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ
a Ce≈ø≈øando] becau≈øe Chri≈øt cau≈øed the Flame of Hell-Fire to Cea≈øe in him; no ≈øooner was the Fire of Hell cau≈øed to cea≈øe in Saul, and he become Paul, but pre≈øently the Fire of Hell from Satan began to flame out again≈øt him, Tempora Mutantur, etiam & per≈øona, &c.
Now Satans principal A≈ø≈øaulter of the Church, is become the principal A≈ø≈øaulted by Satan in the Church: now Satans prime Apo≈øtle, or (as the Word ≈øignifies) Me≈ø≈øenger, (with his Credentials and Plenipotentiary Letters-Pattents from the Soveraign Sanhredrim) for per≈øecuting the Church, becomes a prime Apo≈øtle of Chri≈øt (with all Apo≈øtolical Qualifications thereunto) for the pre≈øerving and protecting of the Church; this makes the Devil mad again≈øt him, and not onely to hinder him at every turn in his Work, (as him≈øelf ≈øayeth) 1 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 18. but al≈øo doth his Utmo≈øt not onely to Hurt him, yea, and to Hand him out of the way by ≈øome of tho≈øe often Perils he brought him into, 2 Cor. 11. 14, 24, to 30. Paul De≈øcribes his Perils and Pa≈ø≈øions both by Sea and Land, by Forraigners and Dome≈øticks (all Satans In≈øtruments) in a Golden Flood of Eloquence; to which Demo≈øthenes is but Dull: yet here again the Devil was Defeated in this De≈øign al≈øo by a marvelous Hand of God: for (1.) Paul (after he had been ≈øtruck Blind with the Lightning, and was led Blind into Dama≈øcus, (which he would ≈øo gladly have ≈øeen and been at for per≈øecuting the Chri≈øtians) to ≈øhew him he was but Blind in that Rage again≈øt them, and after he had Afflicted his Soul in Fa≈øting Three Days, and receiving his Sight both of Soul and Body by his Rapture into Heaven, as ≈øome ≈øay, 2 Cor. 12. 2.) becometh
In≈øatiabilis Chri≈øti Concionator, an Unwearyed Preacher of Chri≈øt, Act. 9. 20, 22. both there and in Arabia, Gal. 1. 17, 18. God Chain'd up Satan for Three Y. ≈øo that he could not Act any Violence again≈øt Paul all that time, God gave him [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] ≈øufficient (or ≈øo many) Days, Act. 9. 23. or Three Y. ≈øo long a time to Settle, e're he call'd him to Suffer; the good Husbandman turns not the cru≈øhing Wheel upon his (tender) Cummin, nor his (hard) Flail upon his (≈øoft) Fitches, I≈øa. 28. 26. when Paul was well confirmed in the Faith, then the Devil hath leave to ≈øtirr up Layers in Wait again≈øt him, but God both Di≈øcover'd it, and (by an Hone≈øt ≈øhift) Di≈øappointed it, Act. 9. 23, 24, and 2 Cor. 11. 32. (2) God delivers him his Danger from the Graecians or Heleni≈øts, (Stephens great Adver≈øaries, Act. 6. 1, 9. with whom then Saul was a Collegiate and Companion) who, now looking upon Paul as an Apo≈øtate, by turning Chri≈øtian, ≈øought his Death, as he (with them) had ≈øought Stevens, and the more Zealous he was now again≈øt them, the more Enraged they are again≈øt him, (more than again≈øt Peter, James, &c. in Jeru≈øalem) and is forced by them to flye to Tar≈øus for his Life, Act. 9. 29, 30. (3) From tho≈øe of Iconium, where the Malignant Jews Incen≈øed the Ignorant Gentiles to Stone him for cutting the City into Contrary Factions, Act. 14. 1, 6. (4) From tho≈øe at Ly≈øtra, whether he ≈øled, and
where he Heal'd the born Cripple, for which they fir≈øt Deifi'd him, (a wile of the Devil, tempting him to accept of Divine Honour) which Device being di≈øowned, then Satan ≈øtirrs them up to Stone him, ≈øo that he was Stoned unto Death, as to appearance; yet by a Divine Miracle he Revived for further Work, Act. 14. 8, 10, 12, 14, 20. (5) God Delivers him al≈øo from the Danger he was in by tho≈øe at Philippi, (for ca≈øting out a Divining Spirit out of a Gainful Damo≈øel, for which he was both Whipp'd and Impri≈øon'd) both by an Earthquake, and by the Conver≈øion of his Goaler, Act. 16. 12, 18, 20, 23, 26, 30. 34. (6) So likewi≈øe he was ≈øaved from the Uproar at The≈ø≈øalonica, Act. 17. 1, 5. made by the Ra≈øcality of the City, which pur≈øued him to Berea, (where he found Nobler Auditors, v. 11.) and Drove him thence. (7) He was al≈øo Deliver'd from Demetrius and his Silver-Smiths (that made Shrines for Diana) at Ephe≈øus, by the Wi≈ødom of the Town-Clark, Act. 19. 23, 28, 35, 39. (8) From tho≈øe Bea≈øts he found and Fought with, (as at Ephe≈øus, 1 Cor. 15. 32. ≈øo) at Jeru≈øalem, where Bea≈øtly Men laid hold of him, and would have Kill'd him, but the Chief Captain Re≈øcued him from them, Act. 21‚ñ™ 27, 31. Tho≈øe A≈øian-Jews were Satans Blood-Hounds, Cha≈øing Paul from A≈øia Hither. (9) From tho≈øe Forty Bloody Butchers that would have pull'd Paul in pieces, binding them≈øelves
under a Cur≈øe, that they would neither Eat nor Drink till they had Kill'd him. God Defeats the Plot (1. by ca≈øting a Bone of Di≈ø≈øention 'twixt the Phari≈øees and Sadducees, Act. 23. 7, 8. (2. by the Captains Re≈øcuing him again, v. 9, 10. (3. by ≈øending a Guard with him to Ce≈øarea; as the fir≈øt was a Godly Policy in Paul to Divide his Enemies, ≈øo the Two la≈øt were Effects of Gods great Power and Providence in making Heathen-Captains to become Pauls Patrons, v. 13, 15, 23, 33. (10) God ≈øaves him (1) from their Wiles, Act. 25. 3, 4. (2) from Shipwrack, Act. 27. 44. (3) from the Viper, Act. 28. 5. (4) from Nero the Lyon, 2 Tim. 4. 17. at Rome he Preached Two Y. and Converted ≈øome of Nero's Hou≈øe, and from thence Wrote Epi≈øtles to Confirm the Churches to the End of the World.

Satans (7th.) A≈ø≈øault was again≈øt Peter, the fir≈øt of the Apo≈øtles, again≈øt one of the Prime Pillars of the Church, which the Devil had oft been ≈øhaking to throw it down, ≈øeeing the Go≈øpel of the Circumci≈øion was committed to him, as that of the Uncircumci≈øion was to Paul, Gal. 2. 7, 9. both being Equal in Office and Dignity; God giving them alike Succe≈øs both to Jews and Gentiles, v. 8. 1 Cor. 9. 1, 23. and 2 Cor. 13. 4, 5. This the Romani≈øts do Deny, though more Failings be Recorded in Scripture of Peter, than of any other Apo≈øtle what≈øoever, Matth. 16. 23. Gal. 2. 14. Matth. 26. 70, 72, 74.
and Joh. 21. 17, &c. Yet this Peter, or Cephas, was a great Eye-≈øore to Satan, being always a ≈øtout Stickler, and a Couragious Champion for Chri≈øt, therefore doth he De≈øire leave to put Peter into his Sieve of Temptation, and therein by to≈ø≈øing him too and fro to make Chaffe of him, Luk. 22. 31. but the Devil was Deceived and Di≈øappointed in all his To≈ø≈øings and Temptings of Peter, by the Prayer of Chri≈øt, v. 32 and by the Power of God: as (1) no ≈øooner had Chri≈øt given Peter the Keys of the Church, (as he did al≈øo to all the other Apo≈øtles, Matth. 10. 2. and 20. 24. and 18. 18. and Joh. 20. 23. making them All the Stewards of His Hou≈øe, 1 Cor. 4. 1. I≈øa. 22. 22.) Matth. 16. 19. but immediately Satan tempts Peter to become as Satan him≈øelf, to wit, an Hinderer of Redemption-Work, v. 22, 23. no doubt but Peter had a good meaning in his taking Chri≈øt by the Hand and leading him a≈øide, (as we do an Intimate Friend for imparting ≈øome Secret to him) and in his ≈øaying to him, [Ma≈øter, ≈øpare thy ≈øelf, &c.] Rebuking him for his carele≈øne≈øs of him≈øelf, (being ≈øtill ≈øtrongly prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with a fond Conceit of an Earthly Kingdom) yet (to Humble him under that Honour put upon Peter, v. 17, 18, 19.) he is call'd a Devil for his Ra≈øh Incogitancy and Arrogancy, as well as Judas is for his Malicious Ob≈øtinacy, Joh. 6. 70. He was the Devils In≈øtrument in Di≈øwading Chri≈øt from Dying
for his Church, and ≈øo became an Offence to him: Notwith≈øtanding all this, Chri≈øt graciou≈øly brings Peter off out of Satans Sieve, Teaching him his proper place of following his Lord as a Di≈øciple, and not to Run before him as a Teacher, all along, v. 23, to 26. and al≈øo taking him to his Tran≈øfiguration, Mat. 17. 1. as one of his be≈øt Beloved, and 26. 37. (2) When this brave Champion (who out of a prepo≈øterous Zeal could cut off Malchus's Ear with his Sword, that he might ≈øtand to his Ma≈øter according to his Word) and ≈øtout Stickler, ≈øtood at the Door and by the Fire, yet was Daunted by a ≈øilly Damo≈øel, Joh. 18. 16, 18, 25. Matth. 26. 69, 70. to Deny his Lord Three times, and that with Swearing and Cur≈øing him≈øelf, v. 72. 74. notwith≈øtanding all, Chri≈øt had a Look of Love to melt Peters Hardened-Heart, Luk. 22. 61. he had a Plai≈øter Prepared before the Wound was Received, v. 32. and he had an Hand to ≈øave ≈øinking Peter, Mat. 14. 30. Now when he was like to Shipwrack Faith and a good Con≈øcience, and when Satan had like to have made Chaffe of him (indeed) in his Sieve of Temptation; through Gods Helping-Hand he comes out good Corn; and when Converted, he Strengthens his Brethren by his Two notable Epi≈øtles. (3.) When Satan ≈øought to Kill him (after he had been a Marvelous In≈øtrument in long promoting the Go≈øpel) by his Va≈ø≈øal Herod, (as Bloody as the 1≈øt, Herod,
that would have been a Chri≈øt-Killer, and as the 2d. that was John Bapti≈øts-Killer) this Herod-Agrippa was a James-Killer, Act. 12. 2. and according to the Old Trick of all Tyrants, willing to Curry Favour with the Wicked, by Shedding the Blood of the Godly, he Attempts to be a Peter-Killer al≈øo, v. 3. but Deferrs his Execution (God over-ruling his Bloody Intention by his own fond Super≈øtition) out of Reverence to the Pa≈ø≈øeover, while he had none at all to Gods Sixth Command, [Thou ≈øhalt do no Murder,] In the mean time, the Church was hard at Work in Earne≈øt and ∆≤nce≈ø≈øant Prayer, v. 5. This ≈øet the Prayer-Hearing God at Work, (yet not till Peter was at the Pits-brink, v. 6.) He ≈øends his Angel, Awakes Peter, (who had ca≈øt him≈øelf into Gods Arms in his Sleep) ≈øtrikes off his Chains, opens the Iron-Gates, conveys him out in De≈øpight of his Guards, Peter lives to do the Church much Service, and ≈øoon after the Tyrant Dyes of a Lowzy Di≈øea≈øe by the Churches-Prayer, ver. 7, 8, 10, 21, 23. to which Peters Relea≈øe, (who was Return'd to them in their very Work) and Herods Dreadful De≈øtruction, (in the mid≈øt of his Glittering Glory) was a Signal An≈øwer.

argument.p: The Twenty-Sixth Plot in the New-Te≈øtament, again≈øt the Church, in the Apo≈øtles, Defeated by God.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI,
div.p:
THe la≈øt and longe≈øt Liver of all the Apo≈øtles, was, John the Divine, who is well called the Daniel of the New Te≈øt‚ñ™ as Daniel is call'd the John of the Old; for as Daniel Wrote not onely an Hi≈øtory of the Church, what it was in his Day, but al≈øo a Prophecy what it would be after to Chri≈øts fir≈øt Comming: ≈øo John Wrote 1≈øt. an Hi≈øtory of the Church, what it was in his Day, (in the Three fir≈øt Chapters of his Revelation,) then 2ly. a Prophecy what it would be, from his time to the Second Comming of Chri≈øt, in all the following Chapters of that Book from the 6th. to the la≈øt, the 4th. (alluding to the Old Te≈øt.) and the 5th. (alluding to the New.) being but a Preludium or Preface to his Seal, Trumpet, and Vial-Prophecy concerning Things that mu≈øt after come to pa≈øs. This Apo≈øtle the Envious One (Satan) Envy'd above all; 1. becau≈øe
he was Beloved above all, he was as Daniel, [I≈øhchamudoth] a Man of De≈øires and Delights, greatly Beloved, Dan. 9. 23. Hence is he called the Di≈øciple whom Je≈øus loved, Joh. 19. 26. and 20. 2. and 21. 7, 20. Chri≈øt loved all his Di≈øciples, Joh. 13. 1. but Iohn more ≈øingularly and ≈øignally, therefore did he lean on his Bo≈øom, v. 23. and Chri≈øt committed his dear Mother to his peculiar charge; for this he was the more Hated by the Devil: and (2) for his being a Boanerges, a Son of Thunder, Mark 3. 17. a mo≈øt powerful Preacher, whereby he did Thunder down the Devils Kingdom. (3.) for his joyning in Commi≈ø≈øion with Peter in Cureing the Cripple, Act 3. and in Confirming the Samaritans, and Conferring upon them the Gifts of the Spirit, yea, and Confounding Satans Grand Sorcerer there, Act. 8. (4.) for his out-Living all the Apo≈øtles, (as Chri≈øt Intimates, Ioh. 21. 22, 23, 24. who Lived to 120 Y. old,) and ≈øo Succe≈ø ‚Ä¢ fully Watering tho≈øe Churches in A≈øia the le≈øs, which Paul had Planted; he after Pauls Death comes from Ieru≈øalem thither, and takes them for his Province and Dioce≈øs: Hereupon the Devil makes his 8th. A≈ø≈øault upon him, ≈øo begins his 26th. Plot again≈øt the Church. (1.) Satan ≈øtirrs up Domitian to ca≈øt Iohn into a Ve≈ø≈øel of Boyling Oyl, out of which he came out ∆≤nhurt, as the Antients tell us; however, the Scripture of Truth truly lays, (2) that he was Bani≈øh'd
(by Domitian, at the Devils In≈øtigation) into the I≈øle Pathmos, Revel. 1. 9. that he might Preach no more, he having none to Preach unto in that De≈øart-place. (3) The Devil ≈øets upon tho≈øe Golden-Candle ≈øticks, and Corrupts them mo≈øt Horribly in this Apo≈øtles Ab≈øence, in≈øomuch as (1.) the Church of Smyrna was Pe≈øter'd with a Synagogue of Satan, to wit, the Unbelieving Iews, Rev. 2. 9. but (2) more e≈øpecially Pergamus, where their Diveli≈øh Maliciou≈øne≈øs is ≈øtiled the very Throne or Seat of Satan, v. 13. and where Attalus (the Devils Agent) had Martyr'd Antipas. (3) Fal≈øe Apo≈øtles had Worm'd them≈øelves in among them, pretending Apo≈øtolick Power, and perhaps practiceing Magick, to make them≈øelves look more Apo≈øtolical like, Revel. 2. 2. Tho≈øe troubled the Church at Ephe≈øus, but they were Tryed and found Lyars there. (4) other Seducers crept in by the Devils Craft, (though not by the Magick Miracles of Devils, as the others did, yet) by the Doctrines of Devils, as that of the Nico Laitans, Rev. 2. 14. and 6. teaching Community of Wives, and that things Sacrificed to Idols might be Eaten. (5) a Jezabel, (either of her Name, or Nature, or both, was foi≈øted into Thyatira by Satan, both a Whore and a Witch, therefore ≈øhe and her Children (to wit, Di≈øciples) are Threatned to be De≈øtroyed, Revel. 2. 20, 23. (6) Formality and Hypocri≈øie had Leavened Sardis, Revel. 3. 1.
and (7) Lukewarmne≈øs was on Laodicea, ver. 15, 16. ≈øo to be Spu'd out. But mark how God Ba≈ø≈øles the Devil in ali this, by laying limits upon him: Rather than fail, Satan (him≈øelf) will execute the Office of a Ju≈øtice Rev. 2. 10. Behold the Devil will ca≈øt ≈øome of you into Pri≈øon, &c. either he acts thus in Per≈øon, or (at lea≈øt) by a Proxy, to wit, by his Imps and In≈øtruments, yet all Satans Actings (in the Children of Di≈øobedience, by whom he Works, Eph. 2. 2.) are under a Divine Limitation, as 1. 'tis but ≈øome of them, and not all of them, 2. into Pri≈øon, not into Hell, 3. 'tis onely to Try them, not to De≈øtroy them, 4. 'tis for Ten Days onely, not for Ever: and though the Devil got John the A po≈øtle ca≈øt into a Ve≈ø≈øel of Boyling Oyl, yet he came out thence without harm, as before; And though Domition (the Emperor of Rome) Bani≈øh'd him to Pathmos, yet there he Wrote tho≈øe Seven Epi≈øtles to the Seven Churches which were not un-Churched with all tho≈øe Corruptions, but are Written to as Churches ≈øtill, and as Golden-Candle≈øticks in tho≈øe Epi≈øtles, wherein ≈øweet Cordials and Comforts are Intermingled with ≈øundry ≈øad Corra≈øives and Cordoliums as (1) God threatens the Removal of the Candle≈øticks, id e≈øt, to another place, not the quite Extingui≈øhing of the Light ≈øet up thereon, Rev. 2. 5. (2) Chri≈øt ≈øtemms him≈øelf from that Removal, becau≈øe he ≈øaw ≈øome Goodne≈øs in the Church, v. 6. becau≈øe
thou Hate≈øt, &c. ‚òû God may do ≈øo to England, &c. (3) Deus minatur, ut non puniat, Ambro≈øe, God Threatens, that he may not Strike, he hath ≈øet his Bow in the Clouds, but there is never an Arrow in it, and the Bent of that Bow is towards Heaven, not towards Earth, or us. (4) Chri≈øt ≈øaith, Fear none of tho≈øe things, ver. 10. promi≈øing withal a Crown of Life. (5) He promi≈øeth al≈øo, the Hidden Manna, and the White Stone with the New Name, to wit, Ab≈øolution, as well as A≈ø≈øurance, v. 17. (6) not to lay any other Burden, than what they already ≈øuffer'd, v. 2. ‚òû Oh! that God may ≈øay ≈øo to his Churches in this great City and Nation. (7) that They ≈øhall walk with him in White, Revel. 3. 4. to wit, in pure Ordinances in a better Day and Di≈øpen≈øation, (8) and have an open Door, v. 8. yea, and (9) Good Coun≈øel, v. 18. to ≈øhew they were not Incorrigible, and (la≈øtly) Chri≈øt was not gone from them, much le≈øs had deliver'd them up unto Satan, but ≈øtill Walked in the mid≈øt of His Golden Candle≈øticks, Revel, 1. 13. and ≈øtanding at the Door Knocking both by Outward Means, and Inward Motions, by the Hammer of his Word, and by the Hand of his Spirit, Revel. 3. 20. with tho≈øe Seven Epi≈øtles (together with His own Return and Per≈øonal Preaching to them after the Death of Domition) he marvelou≈øly Repaired, Refre≈øhed, and E≈øtabli≈øhed tho≈øe Seven Churches well-nigh
laid wa≈øte by the Cruelty and Tyranny of that Per≈øecuting Emperour. In that I≈øle al≈øo (whither he was Bani≈øh'd from all Humane Society) Chri≈øt came to him and gave him to Write (not onely that Excellent Go≈øpel, ≈øo u≈øeful for Defence of Chri≈øts Divinity again≈øt the Bla≈øphemies of Cerinthus, &c. And tho≈øe Ble≈ø≈øed Epi≈øtles of His, the 1≈øt. 2d. and 3d. but al≈øo) the Revelation of things to come, Rev. 1. 19. and 4. 1. Even all the Wretched Maladies that ≈øhould befall the Church, and all the Ble≈ø≈øed Remedies for Her Deliverance to the End of the World. Thus in all this al≈øo, God over-Shoots Satan in his own Bow, and left not him≈øelf without Witne≈øs, Act. 14. 17. This Bloody Wretch (Domitian) was Murder'd by his own Men and the ≈øtiff-necked Jews (which had all along oppos'd Chri≈øt and his Go≈øpel with the utmo≈øt Outrage) were pay'd Home (at la≈øt with Matchle≈øs Mi≈øeries, as before, both under Vespa≈øian (the Father) and Titus (his Son) that were Predece≈ø≈øors to Domitian; and this John onely (of all the Apo≈øtles) lived to ≈øee (in De≈øpight of the Devil and all his Cruel Cut-Throats) the Wrath of God come down upon tho≈øe Chri≈øt-Killers to the utmo≈øt, as Chri≈øt had foretold.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.
div.p:
SAtans 27th. Plot again≈øt the Primitive-Church was manag'd by Rome-Heathen, when now Grown Great under her Coe≈øars, and became the Lady of Kingdoms, and the Imperious Domineering Mi≈øtris of the World: The Provocation was this, 1. Century, for Mahomet (that grand Arch-Impo≈øtor, and Boniface, that proud purcha≈øer of Supremacy (by Symony) of the Parracide Phocas the Emperour) brake forth (almo≈øt) both together, being (both of them) appointed by God to be a Scourge, the former, to the Ea≈øtern-Church, and the latter to the We≈øtern: Now becau≈øe Arriani≈øm had prevailed in the Ea≈øtern part, and the Ce≈ø≈øation thereof brought Pride, Luxury, Super≈øtition, and Idolatry into that Church, in≈øomuch that then John of Con≈øtantinople claimed the Title of ∆≤niver≈øal Bi≈øhop, which Gregory of Rome (Boniface's Immediate Predece≈ø≈øor) earne≈øtly with≈øtood: Then it was that the Spou≈øes Beloved had withdrawn him≈øelf, as a≈øhamed to own her, who was a≈øhamed to own him in the Naked Simplicity of the Go≈øpel, and not to be Cloathed with the goodly Coat of Humane Ceremonies, Cant. 5. 3. 6. and then it was that Chri≈øt (thus Offended) loo≈øeth the four Angels, (to wit, the Mahometan Tetrarchy) the four Sultans of A≈øia, Aleppo, Antioch, and Dama≈øcus; or tho≈øe four fierce and potent people, the Arabians, the Saracens, the Tartars, and the Turks, called (all) Angels, as they are Me≈ø≈øengers of Gods Wrath, and In≈øtruments of Chri≈øts Ju≈øtice, who hath power to bind and loo≈øe them at his plea≈øure, even from the four Horns of the Altar, or from any of the four Quarters of the World, Revel. 9. 13, 14, 15.
tho≈øe were all at an Hours Warning, at any time [for an Hour and a Day] when≈øoever Chri≈øt would Command tho≈øe fierce and fell Creatures out of their Caves, (wherein he had hitherto ≈øhut them clo≈øe up like Tygers or Band-Dogs) out they go to their Spoil and Rapine, and do Drive Chri≈øtianity out of the Ea≈øt, and De≈øtroy the 3d. part of Men, (to wit, of ≈øuch as were not Sealed, Rev. 7. 3.) with his Va≈øt Armies, and great Guns, ≈øuch as were tho≈øe Two mon≈øtrous Spet-fires, call'd, the Earth-quake, and Grand-Diabolo, or Great-Devil, ≈øuch were planted again≈øt Rhodes and Con≈øtantinople, &c. This is the 2d. Woe of the 6th. Trumpet, following the 1≈øt. Woe of Arriani≈øm, yet Differing from the 3d. Woe of Antichri≈øtiani≈øme, which wages War again≈øt the Sealed Ones, again≈øt the Saints is the Bea≈øts War, Rev. 13. 7. This Woe is the great Land-Leviathan (as the Whale is at Sea) that Devours all before it, Con≈øiderable (1) in its Author Mahomet, whom ≈øome Hi≈øtorians call the Sworn fore-runner of Antichri≈øt; Sure I am, he is his Fellow-runner, running in parallel Lines, the one ruining all the Ea≈øt and South, and the other all the We≈øt and North: and 'tis as ≈øure that this Dirty Dog or Hell-Hound lick'd up the very Excrements of Arrius (which carry'd out his Soul in the Jakes) from Sergius the Monk, who becau≈øe he was an Arrian had been Bani≈øh'd from Con≈øtantinople into Arabia,
where he taught Mahomet to Deride Chri≈øts Deity, and to make a Laughing-≈øtock of the My≈øtery of the Trinity; and where al≈øo they Club'd both their Wits with the Devil in Compo≈øing the Alcoran, (which ≈øignifies in the Arabick, The Glory) that Shameful Cento and Non-≈øen≈øical Poi≈øonful Gallimafry out of Chri≈øtian, Jewi≈øh, and Heatheni≈øh Writers, that ≈øomething might be in it to Tempt the Gu≈øt of all tho≈øe Three, e≈øpecially it being wholly accomodated to gratifie all Carnal Affections: And this Mock-Me≈ø≈øiah, that he might make many Pro≈øelytes, crys him≈øelf up as a greater Prophet than either Mo≈øes or the Me≈ø≈øias, and the better to Impo≈øe this Belief upon the Credulous People, he plays Three Legerdemain Tricks, the (1.) was, when his Debauchery had brought him into an Epilop≈øy, His Fits of the Falling-Sickne≈øs (he ≈øaid) were his Divine Raptures wherein he Convers'd with the Angel Gabriel: the (2) was, his Training up a Dove to pick Wheat out of his Eare: This he Bla≈øphemou≈øly profe≈øs'd to be the Holy-Gho≈øt, which Dictated his Alcoran to him: and the (3.) was, his breeding up a tame Bull to that Familiarity with him, that no ≈øooner heard he his Ma≈øters Voice, but he would Run to him and lay his Head upon his Ma≈øters Lap after a mo≈øt familiar manner: At a ≈øett time upon a Fryday He promi≈øeth a Miracle from Heaven to a great A≈ø≈øembly; His Bull
hath the Alcoran fa≈øten'd between his Horns, and ≈øet in a convenient by-place, when the Scene was Ripe, Mahomet lifts up his Voice, his Bull Immediately runs, makes his Way through the Throng, lays both his Head and the Book upon his Ma≈øters Lap, whereby 'twas cry'd up as comming from Heaven. (2ly.) The Extent of it is con≈øiderable both as to Place and Time; 1. as to Place, Mahometani≈øm is exten≈øive, having ≈øpread its ≈øelf over the Sea-Coa≈øts of Africa, almo≈øt all, ≈øaving ≈øome ≈ømall places, but much more in A≈øia, Running down the Golden-Candle≈øticks, and removing them as Chri≈øt had threatned, Rev. 2. 5. Yea, and in Europe al≈øo, from ≈øome part of Hungary to Con≈øtantinople in Greece, &c. In all tho≈øe places thru≈øting out Chri≈øtianity, and changing the Cro≈øs into the Half-Moon. 2. as to Time 'tis Exten≈øive; This Plot of the Devil hath la≈øted longer (to the Churches Di≈øquiet) than ever any of his other De≈øigns afore≈øaid, for this hath la≈øted above a 1000 Y. not only to the Grievous Vexation of the Church, but al≈øo to the great Di≈øhonour of Chri≈øtian-Princes, who, had they ≈øpent the 10th. part of that Blood and Trea≈øure, (which they have ≈øhamefully and ≈øinfully ≈øpent upon one another in their private Animo≈øities) might have by their ∆≤nanimity and United Armies given a Stop long ago to the Growing Grandeur of this ≈øevere Scourge of Chri≈øtendom: 'Tis True, ≈øome Expeditions
were made herein, but all were ≈øoon Bla≈øted, and no better could be Hoped, upon a Twofold Accompt, (1) from the Original, 2. from the In≈øtrument of the Holy War. 1. The chief Original was the Pope's Succe≈ø≈øively (though not Succe≈øsfully) Hopeful Promoters all, to wit, ≈øuch as (1≈øt.) Pope Adrian, (who was Choak'd with a Fly at la≈øt, perhaps it was Beelzebub the King of Flyes, that flew into his Mouth, and could not be got out with Medicines) gave both his Commi≈ø≈øion and his Benediction to Frederick, the 1≈øt. Emperor for Undertaking this Holy War, (≈øo called) yet could be ≈øo Incen≈øed again≈øt him, onely becau≈øe the Emperour (being not (as he ≈øaid for him≈øelf) Us'd to that Kind of Drudgery) Held not the Popes Stirrop (Ho≈øtler-like) upon the Right ≈øide; be≈øides many other Injuries. (2) Pope Alexander's Indignities he put on this Emperour, were Wor≈øe, (to ≈øay nothing of his Betraying Frederick into the Sultans Hand, by ≈øending him his Picture, &c.) who ≈øet his foul Foot upon the Emperors fair Neck, and ≈øaid the P≈øalmi≈øts Words, [Thou ≈øhalt Tread upon the Serpent and Adder, &c.] and the Emperor Replying, [Non tibi, ≈øed Petro.] The Bea≈øt goes on, crying, It belongs to me, as well as to Peter: But above all, (3) Pope ∆≤rbanus in Animating the Chri≈øtians again≈øt the Turks, at his Placen
‚Ä¢ ia-Synod, where Alexius (Emperor of the Ea≈øt) made his Complaint by his Emba≈ø≈øadors, that
the Mahometans had got his All in A≈øia from him, yet Dealt he mo≈øt Treacherou≈øly with the We≈øtern Emperors Forces, by mixing Lime with their Meal to Poy≈øon them; and this Pope was ≈øo Trouble≈øome to the over-Ob≈øequious Emperor, becau≈øe he Honour'd not his Holine≈øs in all his other Projects al≈øo, that he would needs Excommunicate him, hence got he his Name ∆≤rbanus chang'd into Turbanus, for being ≈øo Trouble≈øome; yea, Frederick the 2d. fared no better than Frederick the 1≈øt. afore≈øaid, who though he frighted the Turks into a Peace very Advantagious to the Chri≈øtians, yet all this could not Content (4) Pope Honorius, (5) Pope Gregory the 9th. (6) Pope Innocent the 3d. (7) Pope Coele≈øtin; but the poor Emperour, for all his good Service in the Holy War, was Excommunicated about Five times,and Seque≈øtred from all his Royalties, and this mu≈øt be Ratified by a Bull, (commanded (in ≈øtead of a Sermon) to be Read in every Church) beginning thus, A≈øcendit ‚Ä¢ Mari Bellica Be≈øtia, &c. the Words of Revel. 13. 1. ≈øo well his Holine≈øs could point out the Accompli≈øhment of that very Prophecy: The Benediction of ≈øuch Popes (as tho≈øe) was more like to bring a Cur≈øe than a Ble≈ø≈øing upon the Undertakers in this Holy War, e≈øpecially con≈øidering Four things. (1.) The De≈øign of tho≈øe Popes in ≈øending tho≈øe their Humble Servants (the Emperors) abroad into the Holy Land;
was, that they, being not onely ab≈øent, but al≈øo Weakened by War, might give unto them a better Opportunity of U≈øurping their De≈øired Dominion and Tyranny at Home. (2) Be≈øides, that Expedition into the Holy Land hath been notoriou≈øly Hindred by the Damnable Di≈ø≈øentions and Contentions of the Popes one with another for Peters Chair, in≈øomuch, that the Emperors have been ≈øundry times ≈øent for into Italy, and there found it a very Difficult Work to keep the Peace among the Popes, without who≈øe Mediation, the very Popes them≈øelves (by their many Schi≈øms and Animo≈øities) would Infallibly have pull'd the Infallible Chair all to pieces. (3) There was likewi≈øe another Avocation from that Expedition, to wit, The Deadly Fewd (that then was in its Height and Predominancy) betwixt the Guelphs (the Popes party) and the Gibellines, (the Emperors) the former Mortally hateing the latter, and had a more willing mind to Imbrue their Hands in the Blood of the French, (as they did in the Sicilian Ve≈øpers) and of the Imperiali≈øts, than of the Mahometan-Turks; Now while the Black and the White (as tho≈øe Two Factions were called) made all Red about them with Blood at home, the Holy War abroad was not likely to Pro≈øper. (4) Such was the Notorious Extravagancy of the Popes in all manner of Villany, that it is a ju≈øt Matter of Inquiry, whether the Grand Seignior with all his Mahometan-Saracens, did
not le≈øs Hurt to the Church and Chri≈øtianity in the Ea≈øt, than the Popes ∆≤nholy Holine≈øs with his Cruel Croy≈øado's did in the We≈øt: thus for the Original. The 2d. Accompt is from the In≈øtrument, which was Peter the Hermite, the grand Trumpet to this Holy War, who was better Acquainted with Sounding Alarums to War, than with lifting up his Voice like a Trumpet in Preaching the Go≈øpel of Peace; In a word, If he were not the ≈øame Man, yet was he very like that ≈øame Peter the Hermite, whom (the Centuri≈øts ≈øay) was a Magician, who told King John of England, That upon A≈øcen≈øion-Day he ≈øhould be ca≈øt out of his Kingdom, and he Pawn'd his own Life to a≈ø≈øert the Truth of his Prophecy: for an Experiment hereof the Hermite is Impri≈øoned from January to June the 24th. and then nothing Happening to K. John according to his Prediction, he was taken at his Word, and Hang'd up for a Fool, &c. Much more concerning this may be ≈øeen in Fuller's Holy War, which I have not by me to Con≈øult with. No Wonder then, If this Expedition, again≈øt the Turks, (both the fir≈øt Five and all others after) had no better Succe≈øs: When the Roman-Bi≈øhop (who was the Grand Promoter of it) did Pollute both the Ea≈øtern (yea, Jeru≈øalem it ≈øelf) and the We≈øtern Church with all kinds of Idolatry, which the very Turks Abhorr; yea, and chang'd the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Office of Epi≈øcopacy every where, into a
meer Political or Civil Admini≈øtration, and the people generally (in that Day) Loved to have it ≈øo. Jer. 5. 31. This drew on the Cur≈øe of God upon them, and not a Ble≈ø≈øing, e≈øpecially when that Bloody Bea≈øt or Bi≈øhop Delighted more in Drinking the Blood of the poor Walden≈øes and Albingen≈øes, (for Differing from him in ≈øome Popi≈øh points) than the Blood of the Saracens (who were profe≈øs'd Enemies to the Chri≈øtian Religion) in the 11th. Century, and the Blood of the Pauperes De Lugduno, the poor Men of Lions in the 13th. Century, when there had been no le≈øs than Twenty-Eight ≈øeveral Schi≈øms in the Romi≈øh Church, all which could not but exceedingly Hinder the Succe≈øs of the Popes Holy War.

'Tis True, Mahometani≈øm hath already Afflicted the Church longer than (1) the Aegyptians did, which was at mo≈øt but 430 Y. or (2) the A≈ø≈øyrians, which (from fir≈øt to la≈øt) was not above 300 Y. or (3) the Pagan-Roman from Nero to Con≈øtantine, which was about 260 Y. or (4) by the Arrians, which la≈øted about 300 Y. (to ≈øay nothing of other ≈ømaller terms of time) for it hath la≈øted above a 1000 Y. (as before) already, and how long it may ≈øtill la≈øt, the Lord alone knoweth, yet (for the Comfort of the Church) he maketh her to know, not onely in the general, that it ≈øhall not la≈øt for Ever, but more particularly, that (1) it is Limited as to Time; the ≈øame Divine Power that
(fir≈øt) Bound up tho≈øe Band-Dogs, and (2ly.) Loo≈øed them out of their Chains and Muzzels, both can and will (3ly.) Call them off from their Worrying Work, and Bind them fa≈øt up again in his Chain and Muzzel at his own due time, the Rod of the Wicked ≈øhall not always Re≈øt upon the lot of the Righteous, P≈øal. 125. 3. Though this 29th. Plot of the Devil again≈øt the Church hath been a long-la≈øting Plot, as Hi≈øtory ≈øheweth, yet Prophecy plainly Progno≈øticates its End, and ≈øo it ≈øhall not be Ever-la≈øting; the Devil will lo≈øe this Game al≈øo at la≈øt, for God hath Limited the time of it, how long tho≈øe Four Evil Angels, or Me≈ø≈øengers of his Ju≈øtice (being indeed Incarnate Devils) ≈øhall be lo≈øed, to wit, for an Hour and a Day, a Month and a Year, Revel. 9. 15. from which Words Mr. Brightman gathereth, that the Turki≈øh Empire ≈øhall la≈øt no longer than about 1696. (See my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, Pag. 115. line 12. for that Y. and Pag. 21.) However it holds out, that there is a Divine Determination in particular, even to a Year, a Month, a Day, and an Hour, when this Plot and Plague ≈øhall be Determined: And if Gog and Magog (mentioned Ezek. 38. and 39. and Rev. 20. 8.) have Relation to the Great Turk, as is ≈øuppo≈øed, then we have an Account of his End: Ezekiel is bid to ≈øet his Face again≈øt Gog, and ≈øay to him again and again, (for the better Support and Comfort of the Church) All thy Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion in
the Lords Land ≈øhall be a Grave onely, Ezek. 38. 2, 14. and 39. 11. One of the la≈øt Enemies of the Church before Chri≈øts fir≈øt Comming, was, that Heathen Antiochus, and God brought him down to his Grave: So one of the la≈øt Enemies of the Church before the 2d. Comming of Chri≈øt is this Mahometan Adver≈øary, and as ≈øure as God Dispatch'd the former, he will the latter al≈øo. (2) God would have his Church to know al≈øo, that the Great Turk is not Ab≈øolute, to do all what he will, but onely what God will; he cannot Conquer beyond his Commi≈ø≈øion, nor Kill beyond it; his Commi≈ø≈øion was Limited, not onely 1. as to Time, as before, but 2. as to Per≈øons, he mu≈øt not Kill all before him as he would do, no, 'tis onely a 3d. part of Men, to wit, onely ≈øuch as were not Scaled, Revel. 7. 3. God would Hide his Sighing ones from him, Ezek. 9.4. and 6. Come not near any upon whom is the Mark, what ever is Sealed is excellent in its kind, as Hordeum Signatum is Excellent Barley, I≈øa. 28. 25. The≈øe Sealed and Sighing Ones (that Sighed both out of Pitty and out of Piety for the Abomination of the Times) were the Precious Sons of Sion, and the Excellent Ones of the Earth, Lam. 4. 2. and P≈øal. 16. 3. they are Gods Darlings, and Heavens Favourites, therefore the Turk mu≈øt not Touch tho≈øe Anointed Ones, P≈øal. 105. 15. they are Sacred Per≈øons, to Touch the≈øe is to Touch the Apple of Gods Eye,
Zech. 2. 8. and that is a tender part, God will not ≈øuffer it. ‚òû 'Tis very Ob≈øervable, that as yet, the Turk hath not done much Harm to the Reformed Churches, (tho≈øe Sealed Ones,) all the Hurt he hath done is mo≈øtly upon the Supercilious Greeks, and the Super≈øtitious Romi≈øts, They both Providentially lying betwixt the Prote≈øtants and the Turk: and 'tis Italy, Italy (from whence Principally the Popes Holy War was Promoted again≈øt him) is the main Mark he Shoots at.

(3) This Ea≈øtern Antichri≈øt is Limited as to Place al≈øo, for though he be that Land-Leviathan, who hath Swallow'd up many Countries, (as the Whale doth Fi≈øhes) to wit, (1) the Name and Empire of the Saracens, (2) the mo≈øt Glorious Empire of Greece, (3) the Renowned Kingdoms of Macedonia, Pelopone≈øus, Epirus, Bulgaria, Servia, Boznia, Armenia, Cyprus, Syria, Aegypt, Judea, Tunis, Argiers, Media, Me≈øopotamia, with a great part of Hungary, as al≈øo ≈øome part of Per≈øia, all Chaldea, &c. in a Word, a great part of A≈øia, Africa, and Europe, as before; Yea, Keckerman ≈øaith, Mahometani≈øm is more and larger ≈øpread than Chri≈øtianity, yet never could he yet ≈øet his Foot upon any part of America, God puts an Hook into this Leviathan's No≈øe, Job 41. 1, 2. ≈øo that he cannot Conquer the Gold Mines of the Indies, nor the Golden Gospel of Chri≈øtendom:
The Great Power of God hath ≈øet Barrs and Bounds to him, ≈øaying, Thus far ≈øhalt thou go, and no further, and here ≈øhall thy proud Waves be ≈øtayed, Job 38. 10, 11. and in Due time God will break the Head of this proud Leviathan in pieces, and give him to be Meat to his People Inhabiting the Wilderne≈øs, P≈øal. 74. 14.

(4) God would have his Church to know, that the Grand Seignior is Limited al≈øo as to things, he cannot do every wicked thing he would do, he would Undoubtedly Blow out the Light of the Gospel, and le≈ø≈øen the Limits of the Church of God, but this God will not permit him, ≈øaying to tho≈øe Churches of A≈øia, Repent, or I will Remove thy Candle≈øtick, Revel. 2. 5. 'Tis Chri≈øts Work, not the Turks to do, and though this be done now by the Turk, not onely to them Seaven, but to all the other mentioned in Scripture, (except the Roman, which He Dayly Threatneth) yet all this is done by Commi≈ø≈øion from Chri≈øt, as a Puni≈øhment for their Apo≈øtacy, (which Paul both told and foretold, 2 Tim. 1. 15. Act. 20. 29, 30.) yet was it onely a Blowing away the Go≈øpel, and not a Blowing it out, The Candle was not put out, onely the Candle≈øtick was Removed, The Kingdom of Heaven was taken from them, Matth. 21. 43. It was not Lo≈øt or De≈øtroyed, but Given to another
place: Thus the Church is ≈øtill like the Sea, what it lo≈øes on one ≈øide, it gains upon the other; what ever it lo≈øt in A≈øia then, it hath Gained in America ≈øince, It goes with the Sun from Ea≈øt to We≈øt.

(5.) And to know, that though the We≈øtern Church were not wa≈øted by the Turk, (as the Ea≈øtern was for Idolatry) yet would ≈øhe not be Warn'd thereby, nor Repent of her Idolatry, Revel. 9. 20. (that mu≈øt be meant of Romani≈øts, for neither Jews nor Turks (much le≈øs Prote≈øtants) make Images for Wor≈øhip) and therefore Re≈øerved for the Seventh Trumpet, Revel. 11. 15. that brings in the Seven Vials upon it, and while the Pope Stands, the Turk cannot Fall, as more Tolerable of the Two in the≈øe Re≈øpects: 1. He Hates Images: 2. He Forces none in Matters of Religion; Hence our Martyrologies mentions no Per≈øecutions by him. 3. He is a Bridle to the Pope, (as to Prote≈øtants in general) but when he falls upon the True Church, then Fire from Heaven falls upon him, Rev. 20. 8, &c.

argument.p: The Thirtieth and la≈øt Plot again≈øt the Church, by Popery; Defeated by God.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.
div.p:
THE Devils Thirtieth and la≈øt Plot, (con≈øi≈øting of many parts,) (call'd ∆≤ltimus Diaboli Crepitus) is Antichri≈øtiani≈øm or Popery in the We≈øtern Antichri≈øt, which is the wor≈øt of all, ina≈ømuch as, [Corruptio optimi e≈øt Pe≈ø≈øima; The Golden Church of Rome-Chri≈øtian is Degenerated not onely into Bra≈øs and Iron, but into Clay; yea, into the Dung and Dirt of Rome-Antichri≈øtian, as I have largely Demon≈øtrated (1) in my Chri≈øtian-Walk, p. 9. (2) in my Hearts Treachery, pag. 85. (3) in my Antidote again≈øt Popery all along: and (4) in my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, quite thorough; to all which Four Books I ≈øhall Referr the Reader, and therefore I ≈øhall ≈øay the le≈øs of this Subject (which indeed would make, up a Di≈øtinct Volum of it ≈øelf) in this place. As the Turk is that great Sea-Mon≈øter Leviathan, ≈øo the Pope is that great Land-Mon≈øter,
Behemoth, Hebr. Faemin, plural, that is, Bea≈øts, for his prodigious Hugene≈øs, as if he were made up of many Bea≈øts, and ≈øo he is cal'd the Great Bea≈øt in the Revelation, that hath many Bea≈øts in the Belly of it; And indeed this My≈øtery of Iniquity (≈øo called, 2 The≈ø≈ø. 2. 7. 11.) hath many My≈øterious Plots in it, and is the Plot of Plots: As the Turki≈øh Empire, (Quantum, quantum e≈øt, as Luther Phra≈øeth it) however Va≈øt, yet is it but a poor Cru≈øt which God (the Ma≈øter of the Family) ca≈øteth to his Dog, whom he loo≈øeth off and binds up at his plea≈øure, as before: So, the whole Popedome is but a ≈øorry Commi≈ø≈øion which the ≈øame God gives unto a Company or Legion of ∆≤nclean Devils to Enter into an Herd of Hogs, or Swini≈øh Men: As the Elephant (or Behemoth) is the chief of the ways of God, Job 40. 15, 19. the Ma≈øter-piece among all the Bea≈øts: ≈øo this my≈øtical Behemoth (the Pope) is the chief of the ways of the Devil; the very Ma≈øter-piece of all Satans Works and Wiles: Now though he hath the Strength, Cunning, and the long-Life of the literal Elephant, yet he cannot carry it again≈øt Chri≈øt in his Antichri≈øtiani≈øm, for He that made him, can make his Sword to approach unto him, Job 40. 19. though no Man dare Undertake him, or can Match him, yet the Great God (who made him as the Devil hath marr'd him) both dare and can: As God hath given an Horn to the Rhinocero's, and Poy≈øon to the Dragon,

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.
div.p:

This was Occa≈øion enough to Rowze the Roaring Lyon or Dragon, the Devil, who≈øe Kingdome of Darkne≈øs was not able to bear any ≈øuch Shining Light, becau≈øe his Deeds are Evil, Joh. 3. 19. Hereupon he Stirs up his Elde≈øt Son the Pope, who Hires Thomas Walden≈øis to write again≈øt Wickliff, and the Popi≈øh-Prelates in England to per≈øecute Him, and to Bani≈øh him into Bohemia, where John Hus and Jerom of Prague had the Happine≈øs (as well as Hap) to Read His Writings again≈øt Popery, and ≈øo became (both) great Zelots for Reformation: Upon this, the Romi≈øh Fry of Fryars, &c. (like a Ne≈øt of Hornets with their Venemous ≈øtings, ≈ølye at them, and Burn them, and Wickliff's Books (becau≈øe his Body was out of their reach) with them: Yet that Fiery Pope Martin the 5th. had not the Flames of his out-ragious Folly quenched by all this, but Wickliffs Bones mu≈øt be Digg'd out of his Grave, (after he had layn in it One and Forty Y.) and mu≈øt be Burned (as if they had all been Hereticks) by this Popes Decree. ‚òû Oh the Sublime Folly of this Romi≈øh Rage, thus to Di≈øquiet the Body of him who≈øe Soul was at Re≈øt with God, and to nick-Name his many Learned Di≈øciples (he left behind him) Lollards, as if they had been (no
better than) Tares, Cockle or Darnel, (as the Word ≈øignifies) and them≈øelves (then mo≈øt lewdly Wicked) as pure and clean Wheat, Cujus Contrarium Verum. Notwith≈øtanding all this, God ≈øtill gets this Game from the Devil likewi≈øe; 'tis marvelous how the Lord was putting a Spoke into the Popes Wheel when it was in its faire≈øt and fa≈øte≈øt pa≈ø≈øage and progre≈øs, as appeareth in divers Divine Te≈øtimonies: The (1) was, Though Wickliff had mo≈øt Potent Foes, as Prelats, Pope, and Devil; yet had he more Potent Friends, as the Duke of Lanca≈øter, K. Edward the 3d. (who always protected him) yea, and God him≈øelf, by who≈øe good Providence he was not onely pre≈øerved from bloody per≈øecutors, but al≈øo Recalled from his Exile, and Re≈øtored to his Place, where (after his doing much Good) he Dyed full of Days, and in his Ne≈øt, (as Job ≈øaith) and not by the Hands of the Sons of Violence. The (2d.) was, when Pope Gregory the 11th. ≈øent his Roaring Bull to Oxford, wherein he Commanded them to Root out Wickliffs Tares, (as he call'd them) but the Ma≈øters and Proctors having a long Debate whether this Bull ≈øhould be Received or Rejected, at la≈øt ('tis ≈øaid) that the whole Univer≈øity gave a Te≈øtimony (in Favour of him) under their Seal in the Congregation-Hou≈øe, they not onely Rejecting this, but many other Bulls from Rome. in ≈øuch a Day wherein Rome was in her Regency. The (3) was, when the Popi≈øh Prelat of Canterbury, held a Convocation at London, for Condemning Wickliff's Doctrine as Heretical; and being all come together for that purpo≈øe, ju≈øt as they were falling upon the Debate, God ≈øent ≈øuch a Dreadful Earth-quake, as they (Affrighted with it) De≈øi≈øted from that Wicked Enterprize and Departed. The (4) was, As God had kept Alive the Coele≈øtial Live Coal of the True Religion from being quenched in England ever ≈øince the fir≈øt Plantation of the Go≈øpel Here, by his Rai≈øing up Worthy In≈øtruments in the wor≈øt of Times all along until Wickliff, (as I ≈øhow in my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, Ch. 16.) for the Vindication of the Truth; ≈øo this Live-Coal was blown up into a bright Flame (which did but Smoak before) by this bold Preacher of the Everla≈øting Gospel, (≈øee my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, pag. 82. 83. more of this,) and that Gospel (this 2d. Angel Preached) hath indeed been Everla≈øting hitherto, for though Pope and Devil (with all their Princes, Prelats, and People) have Conjoyned their furious Bla≈øts, yet could they never be able to Blow out the Light, for the Lord hath ever held his own Hand betwixt it and them: that Ble≈ø≈øed Doctrine did take ≈øuch Deep Root in the Hearts of the Elect then, and doth ≈øo now, that as Men and Devils never could, ≈øo they never ≈øhall ≈øuppre≈øs it in England.
The (5) was, by Wickliff's means the Pope lo≈øt his long U≈øurped Power of Impo≈øing what Bi≈øhops he pleas'd upon England, his great Gain of Peter-Pence, and of Tenths out of every Spiritual Promotion, our K. The (6) was, As Wickliff's Mini≈øtry was ≈øo exceeding Succe≈øsful in this Land, bringing ≈øo many to the Obedience of the Truth, that ≈øome thought that Day to be the fir≈øt Re≈øurrection; ≈øo it was a means of Reformation in other Lands, for our Rich. the 2d. then Marrying Ann of Bohemia; as this Queen Taught our Women Mode≈øty, in Riding on Side-Saddles, ≈øo in Exchange, they Taught Bohemia Religion out of Wickliff's Works, for there John Hus and Jerom of Prague Lighted their Candles at our Torch. The (7th.) was, Though the Devil and all his Black Bands did their Utmo≈øt to blow out this Candle, (thus Lighted) and to Run down the followers of it, yet God ≈øent them Valiant John Zi≈øca to comfort them, by Working mighty Deliverances for them: and when after Zi≈øca's Death, Pope Martin the 5th. ≈øent a great Army to ≈øuppre≈øs them, then did God ≈øtrike this Popi≈øh-Army with ≈øuch a panick Fear at the Approach of tho≈øe poor Orphans, (as they ≈øtiled them≈øelves at Zi≈øca's Death) that they all fled from the Siege of Mi≈øna, (before they ≈øaw the Faces of ‚Ä¢ ho≈øe Godly Orphans) leaving all their Engines
of War, and a great Booty behind them: and when the Emperor Sigi≈ømund, (the Popes Creature) to Retrieve the Popes Credit (lo≈øt by the ≈øhameful flight of his Army) Rai≈øes a va≈øt Army of 40000 Hor≈øe (be≈øides Foot) again≈øt them: Then was that Word made good, [In thee the Fatherle≈øs findeth Mercy, Ho≈ø. 14. 3. and that Word, [I will not leave you
„Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ , Orphans, Fatherle≈øs, or Comfortle≈øs, Joh. 14. 18. for God fought from Heaven for tho≈øe poor Orphans, ≈øtriking the prodigious Ho≈øt of their Enemies with a mo≈øt prodigious Fright that they all run away (at the very Report of the Prote≈øtants approach) without ≈øtaying to ≈øtrike one ≈øtroak, and being ≈øpeedily pur≈øued, became a very great prey to the pur≈øuers. The≈øe Two Signal Te≈øtimonies from Heaven, did ≈øo A≈øtoni≈øh the Pope and Emperor, that they afterwards fall upon ways of Fraud (when the way of Force failed) to ≈øuppre≈øs them; and though by that Method and Means they were much run down, yet God Rai≈øed them up again, by Rai≈øing up Undaunted Luther, (the 3d. Angel, Rev. 14.9.) that Thunderbolt again≈øt the Pope, who lighted his Candle at John Hus's Book, (≈øent to him by ≈øome Bohemians, when he was in ≈øome ≈øtrait,) This Candle gave light to all Germany. ‚òû Mark here what an Honour hath God put upon this our Land in this Ble≈ø≈øed Pedigree of Reformation, wherein Germany may be Reckon'd for the Son, Bohemia for the Father,
but England for the Grand-Father; ina≈ømuch as Luther received light from John Hus, and he from our Wickliff: * May not this Encourage us? that 'tis a Land our God careth for, Deut. 11. 11. and that He will yet have ≈øome Honourable Respect for us, having more Honour from his People here, than in any other Land; and notwith≈øtanding our Unworthine≈øs, may we not Hope, God will look more at his own Cau≈øe and Glory, than at our Folly and Iniquity, otherwi≈øe the ≈øame ≈øad Calamities may overtake us the Grand-Father, (that have over-taken both the Son and the Grand-Son) and that by the Fag-end of this 3d. div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.
div.p:
THe Devils 3d. particular De≈øign, (being the 3d. part of the la≈øt Plot) was again≈øt the Prote≈øtants, in, and after Luther. This Book having already ≈øwell'd into a greater Bulk then at fir≈øt Intended, (almo≈øt above a portable Pocket-Book) I mu≈øt Referr my Reader to the Morient (or Dying) Period of Antichri≈øt, in my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, pag. 81. to pag. 110. and Confine my ≈øelf by Con≈øtraint) to point out onely the mo≈øt Eminent Remarks of Divine Providence which hath Pre≈øerv'd the Church in tho≈øe Two la≈øt Centuries, to wit, the Fifteen and the Sixteen
Hundred Y. of Chri≈øt, becau≈øe it would require a Di≈øtinct Volum to Speak Di≈øtinctly of every Pa≈ø≈øage and Providence therein.

The (1≈øt.) Remark, was, The Harve≈øt of the Earth, yea, and of Heaven too, was fully Ripe, when God Rais'd up Luther to put in his ≈øharp Sicle (1.) that of Earth, the Kingdom of the Bea≈øt was ≈øo Debauch'd in that Day; as if Earth had been turned into Hell, in≈øomuch as Geffery Chaucer (that learned Poet in the 14th. Century) doth notably Scourge the Romi≈øh-Church for Degenerating ≈øo notoriou≈øly both in Doctrine and Di≈øcipline, both in Faith and Manners: (2.) that of Heaven; the Kingdome of Chri≈øt had then a whole Harve≈øt of Souls (Cho≈øen of God) to be effectually called, otherwi≈øe ≈øuch a poor Fryar (as Luther was) could never have gone through ≈øo great a Work again≈øt ≈øo Great and General Oppo≈øition with ≈øuch Great Succe≈øs.

The (2d.) Famous Remark, was, that Luther ≈øhould be ≈øent to Rome, as Me≈ø≈øenger of his Covent, for Deciding ≈øome Controver≈øies therein, (about the Monks Priviledges) before the Pope, in the Y. 1510. where beholding the Ba≈øe and Abominable Manners of the Roman Clergy, of the Pope, and of his Pallace, he Returned from Rome with Utmo≈øt Dete≈øtation both of it, and of its Religion, crying out often, Away with it, Away with it, and ≈øaying to his Friends, He would not have been without that

The (3) Remark, was, Pope Leo the 10th. through his Luxury wanted Money to be≈øtow a Dowry on his Si≈øter (Magdalen,) and ≈øo did his Cardinal, to pay for his New-Pall, both tho≈øe Summs mu≈øt be rai≈øed by Indulgences ≈øent into Germany: Tecelius (a Dominican Fryar) brings them to be ≈øold, ≈øaying, His Commi≈ø≈øion was ≈øo large from the Pope, that if a Man had Defloured the Ble≈ø≈øed Virgin, he could Pardon the Sin for Money; yea, he could Pardon all Sins to come, as well as any that were pa≈øt; Indeed much what alike. Luther's Godly Zeal takes Fire at tho≈øe Popi≈øh-Cheats, Inveighs again≈øt the Popes Pardons that his Huck≈øter had brought, He crys down (after) the Popes Supremacy, and all his Popi≈øh Tra≈øh, ≈øo Works (in God) a Wonderful Reformation.

The (4th.) Eminent Remark, was, that God ≈øhould provide ≈øuch a Protector (as Frederick, the Duke of Saxony) to pre≈øerve poor per≈øecuted Luther out of the Hands of Pope Leo the 10th. and of the Emperor Charles the 5th. (whom the Pope provok'd again≈øt him) ≈øometimes in his Patmos, (as he call'd Wartenburg-Ca≈øtle) and ≈øometimes Di≈øputing with Cardinal Caietan, and with tho≈øe Devils in the Court at Worms, yet was he kept ≈øecure by Gods good
Providence, till he had Fulfill'd his Mini≈øtry, and Fini≈øh'd the Work his Father gave him to do, Living to the Age of Sixty-Three, then Dyed in his Climacterical Year, Bequeathing his Dete≈øtation of Popery to his Friends and Followers, with this Ver≈øe,

The (5th.) Marvelous Remark, was, That not One of tho≈øe Three Angels, (forementioned) to wit, Waldus, Wickliff, and Luther, ≈øhould Dye a Violent Death; Con≈øidering the Rage of Rome and Hell again≈øt them all, That They ≈øhould all Three Dye quietly in their Beds in the mid≈øt of their mortal Enemies, to whom they all Three were ≈øo mi≈øchievous, was little below a Miracle: Well, therefore are they Named More than Men, even Angels, Rev. 14. 6, 8, 9. Angel) to thru≈øt in his ≈øharp Sickle into the Harve≈øt of Reformation, Revel. 14. 14, 15. and began to Reap Rome, which was now ready Ripe to have the Seaven Vials of Gods Indignation powred down upon her for the Wine of her Fornication, wherewith ≈øhe had made ≈øo many Nations Drunk; then Rome Raged with her Red Letter, being prompted thereto by the Red Dragon; in≈øomuch that the Pope

Luther's Ca≈øe (having all the World, the many as well as the Mighty, again≈øt him) ≈øeem'd now De≈øperate, ≈øo that Cranzius ≈øaid to him [Go into thy Cell, and cry,] Mi≈øerere Mei, for thou art an ∆≤ndone Man: Yet Behold! His Work being of God, he Weathers out the Point, Spreads the Go≈øpel into many Lands, and comes ≈øafe to Shore, and Dyes in peace, (as before) after he had exceeded the 12 Labours of Hercules, (as Beza ≈øaith of him.)
div.l: Rome tam'd the World, the Pope tam'd Rome ≈øo great,

div.p:
Ob≈øerve again the Foot-≈øteps of Providence following Luther. The 1≈øt. Remark, is, the Miraculous Increa≈øe of the Go≈øpel, after this 3d: Angel, Revel. 14. 9. we Read of another Angel, v. 17. and of another Angel, v. 18. and of Seven Angels too, Revel. 15. 1. ≈øuch as Melancton, Zuinglius, Zanchy, Beza, Marlorat, &c:
and above all, Calvin, who at Twenty-Five Y. Old, Writ his In≈øtitutions, (to Mall Rome withall) of which Book this High Encomium is given.

q.l: Praeter Apo≈øtolic as po≈øt Chri≈øti tempora Chartas,

div.p:
Since Chri≈øt and the Apo≈øtles time, no ≈øuch Book was ever Writ, as Paulus Meli≈ø≈øus long ≈øince Sang: In a Word, at that time the Lord Rais'd a whole Army of braye Heroick and Angelical Men, or Angels, (as Melchior Adamus, and Illyricus, largely Demon≈øtrate) at lea≈øt preparing to powr out the Seven Vials (being the ≈øeveral parts of the Seventh Trumpet,) for the Fall of Babylon, Revel. 14. 8. and 15. 1. for in the 2d. Memorable Remark, is, the prodigious Progre≈øs of the Gospel, which came fir≈øt from Jeru≈øalem by the Apo≈øtles, and ≈øo may well be called the Jeru≈øalem-Artichoke, a Plant that Over-runs the Ground where≈øoever it is planted. So was the Go≈øpel carryed as on Angels Wings wonderfully over all the World at fir≈øt by the Apo≈øtles, and now again by the late Reformers, as by tho≈øe Three Angels afore≈øaid, Waldus, Wickliff, and Luther: our Wickliff Wrote more than Two Hundred Volums again≈øt the Pope before Luther was Born; and Q. Ann, Wife to our Richard the 2d. and Si≈øter to Wence≈ølaus K. of Bohemia, by living here became acquainted with the Gospel, yea, many Bohemian Courtiers comming to the Engli≈øh Court, convey'd Wickliff's Books into Bohemia, whereby a Good Foundation was layd for a future Reformation. After this John Hus and Jerom of Prague did ≈øo notably Propagate the Truth in that Kingdom, that in the Y. 1451. the Church of Chri≈øt at Con≈øtantinople Congratulates the Happy Beginnings in the ∆≤niver≈øity of Prague, and Exhorts them to per≈øeverance in per≈øecution, which the raging Romani≈øts ≈øoon rais'd again≈øt them; though Q. Sophia (who favour'd them) had by her Mediation with the King procur'd a free Exerci≈øe of their Religion throughout the Realm; and though the Popi≈øh Per≈øecutors could ≈øay no more of them than this, [In their Lives they are Mode≈øt, in their

Reinerius (another of their per≈øecutors) ≈øhall tell you, [1. Becau≈øe of ≈øo long Standing. 2. becau≈øe ≈øo far Spread. and 3. for their appearance of Purity, &c.] Al≈øted. Chronol. pag. 375. and Jacob. Revius de Vit. Pont. pag. 151. This Paved the way for the Great Work of Luther in Germany, begun Y. 1517. which was Wonderfully carry'd on (even in a little time) through all Germany, and ≈øome Forreign Countries, as it were upon Angels Wings, though by weak means, yea, by ca≈øual and cro≈øs means, (as here by Henry the 8ths Scruple about his Marriage) and afterwards further promoted 1. by Publick and powerful Preaching. 2. by Printing good Books. 3. by Tran≈ølating the Bible into Vulgar Tongues. 4. by Catechi≈øing of Youth. 5. by Offering open Di≈øputations. 6. by Martyrologies, and all this was done again≈øt the Powers of a mo≈øt potent and politick Adver≈øary. ‚òû This was ≈øuch a Miracle of Mercy, as the former Age De≈øpaired of, the pre≈øent Age Admireth, and the future Following Age ≈øhall be ≈øtruck with A≈øtoni≈øhment at. The 3d.
