In the Reign of King Charles the 1≈øt. the Conclave of Rampant Je≈øuits (tho≈øe Cup-bearers of Romes Wine of Fornication, and Froggs going out to the Kings of the Earth, Revel. 16. 12.) had their Con≈øult to bring Brittany to Babylon, or tho≈øe Three Kingdoms into Confu≈øion, as they had done the Palatinate, Bohemia, and Germany, &c. The like Miracle of Mercy that made Remor≈øe to Di≈øcover the former, hath done no le≈øs in this latter, and to Di≈øappoint hitherto the Popes De≈øign; though He hath Depos'd the King as an Heretick, ≈øent Card. Heavens Hand will Help at a Dead Lift; Where Man ends, there God begins, P≈øal. 21. 13. Much more might be Added, were there not a [Noli m ‚Ä¢ Tangere] in the Ca≈øe: Controver≈øal Truth
≈øeldom goes without a Scratch'd Face: I ≈øhall Conclude the Hi≈øtorical part with ≈øome Memorable Remarks. (1) The Pope (who is the Devils By-blow) was Worthily Thru≈øt out of England, (as he was al≈øo out of France and Arragon,) it being ≈øaid of him, That He was like a Mou≈øe in the Sachel, or like a Snake in the Bo≈øom. A 2d. Remark is, Tho≈øe Princes, who have Tru≈øted God with their Lives and Lands, and kept Rome, &c. at Di≈øtance and Defiance, hath Speeded the Be≈øt, and Flouri≈øh'd the mo≈øt, and the longe≈øt, in their large Dominions. Q. Elizabeth is a pregnant In≈øtance hereof, who could never be per≈øwaded to Favour the Papi≈øts, (though ≈øhe was to Disfavour the Puritans) but ≈øhe ever kept a Vigilant Eye over the former, as being rightly Informed, that they (and not the latter) were the wor≈øt Enemies to Royal Power; and God Wonderfully Pre≈øerv'd this Heroick Lady from all the Romi≈øh Bulls, Interdicts, Poy≈øonings, A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øinations, &c. as before. A 3d. Remark, is,
Such Princes, as Relyed upon their own politick Projects, (in Conniving at, if not Complying with the Romi≈øh Intere≈øt) for their per≈øonal pre≈øervation, have ever fared the Wor≈øt; to omit K. Abbot's Advice, and not long after he was taken out of the way, by who≈øe Hands God onely knows: But Henry the 4th. of France is a clear In≈øtance, who, being bred up a Prote≈øtant, Turn'd Papi≈øt upon politick Grounds, and being Di≈øuaded by a great Duke from re-Admitting the Je≈øuits, (which ju≈øtly had been Bani≈øh'd the Realm) he Angrily An≈øwered, [Give me then Security for my Life.] Hereupon he not onely Re≈øtoreth them, but Demoli≈øheth the Pillar Erected in Paris as a Standing Monument of their Trea≈øons again≈øt their Soveraigns, yea, received them into his Bo≈øome, giving them his Pallace for their Colledge, and (in a publick Speech) ≈øaying, That they were Timothys in the Hou≈øe, Chry≈øo≈øtoms in the Chair, and Augu≈øtins in the Schools, &c. Tho≈øe Timothys proved Judas's, tho≈øe Chry≈øo≈øtoms, Cataline's, and tho≈øe Augu≈øtins, A≈ø≈øa≈ø≈øins: one of tho≈øe Slaughter-Slaves Stabb'd him in the Mouth, another in the Heart: Thus things, Men Fear, come upon
them by tru≈øting their own Politicks more than Gods Providence. La≈øtly, Other Nations, that have ≈øeen ≈øo little of their Wiles and Wickedne≈øs, have ≈øeen enough as not to tru≈øt them, as China it ≈øelf. God forbid that We who have Felt ≈øo much, ≈øhould See ≈øo little as now to be Cheated with them, e≈øpecially, after ≈øuch a Chain of Providence link'd together (on which we may Hang our Hope) for prevention thereof: In a Word, Gods Word is his Will, and his Will is his Work, and neither Man nor Devil can Di≈øappoint it: The good Lord give ≈øtill more Evinceing Proofs of his Providence.

div.head: XXXIV.
div.p:
HAving ≈øhown How it hath been with the Church from the Beginning of the World to this pre≈øent time, let me now make a ≈øhort-In≈øpection How it ≈øhall be with Her Until Time ≈øhall be no more, but turned
into Eternity. A Narrative hereof cannot be Deduced out of any Chronicle or Hi≈øtory, (either Civil, or Sacred) but out of the Apocalyp≈øe or Revelation, which Book is a Manife≈øtation of many My≈øteries by the Mediatour to John, who had the Mind of Chri≈øt ≈øhew'd to him, that he might ≈øhew it to the Church what things ≈øhould ≈øhortly come to pa≈øs, Revel. 1. 1, 19, 20. and 4. 1. and 1 Cor. 2. 16. The Divine Project of John therein, is a Contiguous and Continued Prophecy of the Churches Progre≈øs through all Times after Chri≈øt to his 2d. Comming, as that of Daniel was before Christ to his 1≈øt. Comming; both of them Divinely Declaring how God would pre≈øerve his Church in the Wor≈øt Times of Apo≈øtacy, both under Antiochus before Chri≈øt, and under Antichri≈øt after Him, (as is afore≈øaid) and that in no Age, ≈øhall ever the Gates of Hell prevail again≈øt the Church, Matth. 16. 18. on which both their Books be a Con≈øpicuous Comment.

I have already ≈øhewn how John's Seal-Prophecy, and his Trumpet-Prophecy, hath had their Exact Accompli≈øhment in our fore-going Ages, and how Time (the be≈øt Expounder of Dark Prophecies) hath turned tho≈øe ab≈øtru≈øe Mi≈øteries into plain and legible Hi≈øtories. Now I come unto the Book-Prophecy that U≈øhers in the 7th. Trumpet, Revel. 10. 2, 7. and 11. 15. and the Seven Vials (having the Seven la≈øt Plagues) which are the ≈øeveral parts of that 7th. Trumpet,
Chap. 15. 1, 7. Here (for brevity's ≈øake) take tho≈øe following Famous Remarks. The (1≈øt.) is, The Church of God is always under ≈øome ≈øpecial Prophecy, Promi≈øe, and Providence, and therefore is her State ≈øo ≈øtedfa≈øt and Unmoveable, as the Mountains of Bra≈øs, Zech. 6.1. neither Men nor Devils can remove her, P≈øal. 125. 1, 2. The 2d. Remark, is, The Book (which made John Weep) is call'd, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] a Book of ≈øome Bulk and bigne≈øs, while it had all the Seven Seals upon it, and the great Concerns of the Six Trumpets within it, Rev. 5. 2. But now, when the Seal-Prophecy was Accompli≈øh'd in its Events, as likewi≈øe Six parts of the Trumpet-Prophecy, 'tis call'd, [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ,] the Word is a double Diminutive, ≈øignifying a little, little Book, or a very little Book, containing onely the Seven la≈øt Plagues, whereby Gods la≈øt Wrath ≈øhould be filled up on the Antichri≈øtian-State, and Time ≈øhould be no longer for him, Rev. 10. 2, 6, 7. and 11. 15. and 15. 1. The 3d. Famous Remark, is, ≈øuch is Chri≈øts Compa≈ø≈øion to his Church and Cho≈øen, that in the wor≈øt of times he leaves her not comfortle≈øs, Joh. 14. 18. but Secures her (from Swounding) with Soveraign Cordials, as (1≈øt.) He gave the Comforts of the Fifth Seal, and the Interce≈ø≈øion of Chri≈øt, (giving Acceptance to that Prayer, Rev. 6. 10.) Ch. 8. 3. under the Evils of the former and following Seals. (2ly.) While
the Church lay under the Wo-Trumpets, Chri≈øt gave the comforting Vi≈øion of Revel. the 10th, where the Churches Redeemer is Repre≈øented as ≈øupream Lord of Sea and Land, and that he ≈øets his Feet (as a Conquerour) upon the Neck of that Double-Bea≈øt, the Political (Ri≈øing out of the Earth) and the Eccle≈øia≈øtical (Ri≈øing out of the Sea) Limiting the Time, and Fini≈øhing the Lea≈øe of that My≈øtery of Iniquity, and in the mean time Chri≈øt keeps his Right foot upon Antichri≈øts Clergy, and his Left foot upon his Layity, ≈øo that all their Exploits are what Chri≈øt (not what Antichri≈øt) Willeth, 3ly. Under the 3d. Wo-Trumpet, (where there is a Recounting of the Churches Evils both by the Bea≈øt and by the Dragon, Chap. 11. and 12. and 13. yet ≈øome Allays of Comfort are Annexed. Chap. 11. 14. &c and Ch. 14 2, 3, 12, 13. and Ch. 15. 3. The 4th. Remark, is, The little, little Book in the Hand of Chri≈øt, ≈øheweth, tkat he hath but a little more Work to do in the World after the Seal and Trumpet-Prophecies be fulfilled: Chri≈øt hath then but a few Things more to Accompli≈øh, to wit, 1. The Calling and Conver≈øion of the Jews. 2. A bringing in (at lea≈øt a few more, or) the Fulne≈øs of the Gentiles. 3. The Pulling down of the Kingdom of Antichri≈øt. 4. The Setting up his own Kingdom above all the Kingdoms of the World. Now the 3d. of the≈øe Works of Chri≈øt (the De≈øtruction of the Bea≈øts-Kingdom) mu≈øt be done by the 7 la≈øt Plagues,
≈øo called, onely becau≈øe they are the la≈øt in this pre≈øent Life (or peri≈øhing World) to be Inflicted, though there be far Wor≈øe Plagues re≈øerved for the Branded Bond-Slaves of the Bea≈øt in Hell, and in the World to come: The Seven Golden Vials lets fall (as it were) onely the Leaves of the Wrath of God, yet ≈øo, as gradually to De≈øtroy them as with ≈øo many Hail-≈øtones ≈øhot at them; but the whole Trees thereof ≈øhall fall foul upon tho≈øe Reprobates afterward, yet are tho≈øe Vials call'd the la≈øt Plagues, becau≈øe to be poured out in the la≈øt Age of the World, being the Third Period of Events, as the Seal-Prophecy was the fir≈øt, and the Trumpet-Prophecy was the 2d. Period, and had Plagues therein, Chap. 9. 20. And as the former Plagues De≈øtroy'd the Dragon and Rome-Heathen, Rev. 12. ≈øo tho≈øe latter Plagues ≈øhall De≈øtroy the Double Bea≈øt that ri≈øes out of the Ruines of the Dragon, to wit, Rome Antichri≈øtian, Rev. 16. yet his fall ≈øhall be gradual, as his ri≈øing, See for this at large, my Di≈øcovery of Antichri≈øt, Chap. 8 and 9. The 5th. Memorable Remark, is, The pulling down of the Bea≈øts Kingdom, which is the 3d. of tho≈øe four few Works, &c. Herein the Series and Order of the Vials, is very Ob≈øervable, The first is powr'd out upon the Earth, that is, upon the Popes Foot-≈øtool, his Stigmatiz'd Slaves, or Branded Va≈ø≈øals; This made them Sick of the Devils Di≈øea≈øe, to wit, Malice and Rage at

The 3d. upon the Rivers, their Bracki≈øh Clergy, (which Corrupt the Sea of Rome) e≈øpecially the Je≈øuits, who have Blood given them to Drink (by the Law of Nations) for they are Worthy, Rev. 16. 2, 3, 4, 6. The 4th. upon the Sun, the Hou≈øe of Au≈øtria, the Great Luminary of the Romi≈øh-Firmament, which being Incorporated with Spain, hath given Light and Su≈øtentation to the Tottering Kingdom of the Bea≈øt; and not onely ≈øo, but hath by the Indies Trea≈øure a≈øpir'd after the 5th. or Ab≈øolute Monarchy, (as France doth now,) but that Word of God, [There mu≈øt be Ten Horns] Way-lays them, ≈øo that One Horn cannot lick up the Nine. This makes them Gnaw their Tongues, Blaspheming, (as Faux did, when taken, ≈øaying, It was not God‚ñ™ but the Devil, that brought to light and to naught their Powder-Trea≈øon.) When the 5th. Vial is powred out [ „Äà in non-Latin alphabet „Äâ ] upon the Throne of the Bea≈øt, (which the Dragon had given him, Rev. 13. 2.) this can be no other than Rome, for here Chri≈øt Speaks without a Parable, that then it may be Con≈øpicuous to every common Eye, which of the Vials are pa≈øt, and which to come, and what Vial we now Live under, is Doubtful; yet this is beyond Doubt, that as the 5th.
